webTitle: Celtic's blank look has Rangers smiling

fields.headline: Celtic's blank look has Rangers smiling
fields.trailText:
Hibernian 0 - 0 Celtic
The only victors from this top-of-the-table tosh were Rangers as a gale ripped apart any notion of quality play.
fields.body:
This will surely rank as one of the most wretched matches to be witnessed anywhere in Britain all season. The notion that these two teams, currently first and second in the Scottish Premier League, were serving up top-of-the-table stuff last night became ludicrous in a match torn apart by a gale.

This ground has always specialised in minor tornadoes blowing down off Arthur's Seat and it provided classic slapstick. Passes went ballooning into the clouds and shots supposed to have swerve and pace often ended up trundling away for throw-ins.

The only victors from this dire occasion were Rangers. Celtic may have preserved their seven-point lead at the top, but Rangers, with two matches in hand, will feel their title hopes revitalised.

Martin O'Neill has provided plenty of eccentricity since arriving in Scotland and the highlight of a gruesome first half was his 30-yard sprint down a touchline to leap up and down beside a linesman in order to bring the official's offside flag to the attention of the referee, Stuart Dougal. This the Celtic manager succeeded in doing and the penalty Hibs had been awarded, following Didier Agathe's lunge at John O'Neil, was revoked.

Before the interval Franck Sauzee's shocking hack on Celtic's Bobby Petta required the Celtic winger to leave the field with a dreadful gash; a worthy footnote to a a grim affair at a disorientating Easter Road which deserves to be quietly forgotten.

 Celtic are to offer Alan Stubbs a one-year extension to his contract to remove doubts about the 29-year-old central defender's future at the club as as he continues his battle against cancer.

fields.headline: Morrison mauls West Ham
fields.trailText:
West Ham 1 - 2 Sheff Wed
Frank Lampard pulled one back as the Hammers mounted a late onslaught but Wednesday clung on to earn a quarter-final place.
fields.body:
Short of points and money Sheffield Wednesday may be, but they showed no lack of spirit in managing this notable upset last night, grittily hanging on after Frank Lampard had pulled back a goal for West Ham.

Poor defending enabled Owen Morrison and Ashley Westwood to put Wednesday 2-0 up and, although Lampard scored after Frederic Kanoute flicked on, Wednesday survived a serious late onslaught to earn a quarter-final against Birmingham City.

Wednesday had beaten West Ham 7-0 41 years ago this week, but only their most optimistic fans can have expected a repeat. Their team, 20th in the First Division, were without their cup-tied full-backs and started with six players aged 21 or under.

Within 45 seconds Lampard almost gave West Ham the lead, shooting narrowly wide from Paolo di Canio's neat pass. With Di Canio enjoying running through his tricks against his old club, it was virtually one-way traffic as Kanoute wasted a good chance and Lampard had another blocked inside 10 minutes. But for all their pressure West Ham were well below their best against feisty opponents, with their clearest openings coming from corners.

Wednesday had managed not a single shot before they took the lead on the half-hour. Efan Ekoku flicked on a goalkick by Kevin Pressman and, as West Ham's defence dithered, the 18-year-old Morrison shot through Shaka Hislop's legs.

A minute later Morrison saw a fine shot tipped onto the post by Hislop, but even that failed to rouse West Ham. This was presumably not what Rigobert Song, making his debut in defence, had expected when he joined from Liverpool. And things went from bad to worse when Westwood took advantage of pitiful marking to head in a Morrison corner.

West Ham responded purposefully but, despite Lampard's late effort, Harry Redknapp must have known his European dreams would - in the best Upton Park traditions - fade and die.

fields.headline: Magic Johnson finds late flourish
fields.trailText:
Birmingham 2 - 1 Newcastle
A late winner helped Birmingham knock Newcastle out of the competition for the second year running.
fields.body:
Michael Johnson more than lived up to his nickname here last night by scoring the goal that knocked Newcastle out of the competition for the second season in succession. The City defender, who is known as "Magic" more for his namesake than his footballing prowess, conjured up the late winner which his side's almost non-stop attacking deserved.

As extra-time loomed the Jamaica defender fired home a loose ball to book Trevor Francis's team a place in the next round, at home to his former club Sheffield Wednesday.

Little more than a year on from City's comfortable 2-0 home win against the same opposition and Bobby Robson has gone a long way towards repairing the damage inflicted by Ruud Gullit's regime at Newcastle, but the visitors' improved circumstances did not faze Birmingham last night.

Buoyed by becoming the only visiting team to win at Spurs this season, City wasted little time in serving notice that they were keen for another upset.

Only two minutes had passed when the Australian winger Stan Lazaridis, seemingly revitalised by his trip to play for his country at the Olympics, outpaced Andrew Griffin on the left and fired in a low cross which Geoff Horsfield hit first time straight at Steve Harper.

Newcastle's first realistic attempt came in the fifth minute following a crunching but illegal challenge by Danny Sonner on Christian Bassedas. Alan Shearer tried his luck from 30 yards but Ian Bennett saved comfortably in the home goal.

Bennett's next touch came in the 17th minute, when he had to retrieve the ball from his net after Kieron Dyer volleyed it past him from the edge of the area. There was an element of fortune about the goal, Warren Barton's hard-hit left-wing cross ricocheting off Darren Purse and into the path of the England midfielder.

Bennett was seldom troubled for the rest of the half, as Francis's team set about repairing the damage. And they should have done so before they did. Horsfield was culpable and then Nicky Eaden wasted a chance when he headed a cross from Lazaridis straight at Harper. That miss did not prove too expensive, however, as from the subsequent corner Dele Adebola headed home Martin Grainger's flag kick.

Francis's team maintained the pressure after the break and had three good chances in an astonishing five minutes. Lazaridis and Horsfield both had shots blocked before Alain Goma cleared a header from Grainger off the line.

City were fortunate not to lose their goalkeeper in the 55th minute, however, when he brought down Shearer outside the area after being put in danger by a weak back-pass.

Fortunately for the hosts the referee, maybe sensing that Newcastle's captain had made a meal of it, restricted the punishment to a booking. The subsequent free-kick proved to be a rare shot among the waves of home attacks.

webTitle: Swift Saha wins the space race

fields.headline: Swift Saha wins the space race
fields.trailText:
Fulham 3 - 2 Derby
An injury-time winner completed a Louis Saha double and sent Fulham through to the fourth round as they underlined their Premiership credentials.
fields.body:
Louis Saha is not quite the fans' favourite Frenchman but Craven Cottage rose in salute to his dazzling skills last night as he scored his 19th goal of the season to climax an outstanding, ferocious cup tie and give Fulham an injury-time passage to a quarter-final tie against Liverpool.

The same player had put Fulham on level terms after Derby took an early lead. The Premiership team spent the remainder of the game trying to hold back Jean Tigana's marvels but looked to have earned extra-time before Saha climbed to nod home a towering free-kick.

A nine-point advantage in the First Division is all well and good but it is no gauge to a team's prospects of competing with the big boys and Fulham fans were looking forward to this fixture to provide evidence of how they would figure in the Premiership, assuming their current ascendancy is maintained.

Tigana, though, chose to leave out more than one of his best players including his captain Chris Coleman. Derby were closer to a first choice with Taribo West taking his place in a three-man rearguard and warned, no doubt, about the danger that Saha could inflict given time and space.

The Nigerian international, at Pride Park for the remainder of the season, was a little too anxious as Saha sped away from him in the 20th minute but the referee Peter Jones charitably ruled that no foul had been committed.

Fulham's frustration was all the more because they were a goal down at that stage, Malcolm Christie having gathered Branko Strupar's through-ball to beat Maik Taylor.

Jones showed leniency again when he allowed Seth Johnson to crash into the back of Eddie Lewis without recourse to his cards. Justice was served by the strong header that Saha applied to Bjarne Goldbaek's in-swinging free-kick.

The goalscorer was operating just behind Barry Hayles and, while his speed and control had defenders struggling to retain their footing sometimes, Fulham lacked sufficient bodies upfield to make their growing command tell.

They scored their second on the counter after Rory Delap had just gone close at the other end, Fabrice Fernandes moving the ball across to Lewis who found the net with a crisp, low shot.

Fulham could have added to their tally when Lewis did wonderfully well to fashion an opening for Hayles. Somehow Mart Poom kept it out. The Derby goalkeeper would have had some sympathy for his opposite number who appeared to lose the flight of Darryl Powell's high centre from the right, allowing it to loop over his head for Derby's second.

The second period produced more of the same relentless action with Delap missing horribly in front of goal and the Loughborough official continuing to lose London friends. Once again he denied what looked a clear penalty when West blocked Goldbaek.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: New 'Bosman' raises fears of influx
fields.trailText: Fears that the Premiership would be swamped by low-cost foreign imports were increased last night after a landmark ruling in Spain.
fields.body:
Fears that the Premiership would be swamped by low-cost foreign imports were increased last night after a landmark ruling in Spain.

A court in Madrid has decided that the Russian midfielder Valery Karpin, who plays for Celta Vigo, should enjoy the same rights as players who are European Union citizens.

In particular it means that the rule barring teams from signing more than five non-EU players and fielding more than three in any one match no longer applies to Karpin, allowing him to line up as a domestic player in this Saturday's match against Barcelona.

Karpin's success was based on the fact that Russia has an association agreement with the EU which bars employers from discriminating against employees on the grounds of nationality. Some 20 countries, mainly in eastern Europe but also including Morocco and Mexico, have similar agreements with the EU.

The case, which is being compared to the Bosman ruling, could lead to a rash of similar court challenges by other foreigners playing in European Union leagues.

"I believed that the Spanish league, federation and the club were all discriminating against me," said Karpin, who has more than 30 caps for Russia. "In the end I've achieved my aim.

"I'm not a second Bosman, I'm the first Karpin. I'm not thinking about the consequences the decision might have for other players. I'm just thinking about myself."

"It will be good for the league but bad for Spanish players," he added.

It may also be bad for English players. Southampton's squad, for example, contains two Latvians and two Moroccans, all of whom come from countries with association agreements. Any of these could potentially bring a court action if he felt the "three foreigners" rule was restricting his first-team chances.

Players from eastern Europe, such as Tottenham's Sergei Rebrov would also be eligible to challenge their designation as non-EU players. That would remove one of the barriers that prevents Premiership managers from investing more in cheaper players, particularly from the former Soviet bloc.

Football administrators and the players' union were last night studying the possible implications of the judgment.

The agent Phil Smith saw the ruling as part of a trend to more freedom of movement for players. "The frontiers are only going to open up more in the future," he said.

Yesterday the Romanian international Cosmin Contra of the Spanish club Alaves said he was following Karpin's lead. "I've brought an action against the club and the Spanish federation," he said.

And a similar case involving a Hungarian former player of the Belgian club Charleroi, is currently being heard by the EU.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Venables keeps Boro sweating
fields.trailText: After meeting again yesterday in London to discuss a £1m-a-year offer to become Boro's first-team manager, chairman Steve Gibson is still awaiting Terry Venables' response.
fields.body:
The Middlesbrough chairman Steve Gibson, almost a week since he offered Terry Venables a route back into Premiership management, was still waiting for a response from the former England coach last night.

Gibson met Venables again yesterday in London to discuss a £1m-a-year offer to become Boro's first-team manager. Venables later said he was close to deciding whether to accept, although he was still attempting to juggle on-going business and media commitments which would be affected should he take up Boro's full-time post.

"I'm trying to sort out problems which I have had from day one owing to the fact that I'm not in the game," he said. "I have other contracts to sort out and that is what I am endeavouring to do. It should come to a close very quickly. It's a pity it's come out in the media because it makes a difficult decision that much harder."

Most pressing of those commitments may be his role as an on-screen summariser for ITV's football coverage, which is set to expand next season after the network secured the rights to broadcast Premiership highlights alongside the Champions League.

Venables also presents a London-based Saturday afternoon show on Virgin Radio, as well as writing a column in a Sunday newspaper. Away from the media the 57-year-old is developing a hotel complex for touring football teams, similar to that at La Manga, in Andalucia.

The initial offer made to Venables last Thursday stipulated that he should relinquish business commitments in London and Spain and move to the North-east. But, with Boro struggling in 18th place in the Premiership, the Teesside club may be prepared to bend their own self-imposed rules.

webTitle: Sideswipe for Vialli as Blues back Ranieri

fields.headline: Sideswipe for Vialli as Blues back Ranieri
fields.trailText: There were further signs that a new Chelsea is in the making yesterday when the club sacked Graham Rix and Ray Wilkins and put the boot into the recruitment policies of Ruud Gullit and Gianluca Vialli.
fields.body:
Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson criticised Gianluca Vialli's knowledge of players as "very limited" as he revealed that the club is ending its policy of signing established stars, many in the twilight of their careers, because they cannot afford to do it any more.

The new market strategy was made clear a day after Chelsea's new broom wielded by Claudio Ranieri swept away two of the old-guard coaches, Graham Rix and Ray Wilkins, both strongly associated with the Vialli regime.

The new way forward was pointed out by Hutchinson in response to growing fears that Ranieri is floundering as Chelsea's manager after a poor run of results. Chelsea are 14th in the Premiership and have already been knocked out of the Worthington and Uefa cups.

Hutchinson said one of the main reasons for appointing Ranieri was his deep knowledge of the emerging talent around the world, a subject Vialli - and indeed, added Hutchinson, his predecessor Ruud Gullit - was short on.

"We've always said that at some stage we must have a change of direction,'' Hutchinson declared. "Chelsea has been founded over the last five years on bringing in star names, many world renowned. But without unlimited funds you can't going on doing that. We've got to be looking worldwide at the next generation of stars.

"One reason for bringing Claudio Ranieri in was his knowledge of players ... With all respect, anyone can spot a [Marcel] Desailly. To get the next Desailly takes a lot of work.''

The departure of Rix and Wilkins, Vialli's right-hand men, was inevitable. Although Ranieri brought with him his own coaching team, the pair were intitally kept on out of loyalty, though in peripheral roles.

But amid accusations that their presence has hindered Ranieri's attempts to build a new team spirit they have now been sacked at the new manager's insistence.

The goalkeeping coach Eddie Niedzwiecki and fitness trainer Antonio Pintus have also been given the choice of leaving or accepting lesser roles. The reserve-team manager Mick McGiven is staying.

Tottenham have watched the Sweden defender Olof Mellberg and are considering a bid for the 23-year-old Racing Santander player.

Mellberg, a member of Sweden's Euro 2000 squad who has 10 caps, can play as a full-back, centre-half or defensive midfielder. Spurs have confirmed they saw him against Espanyol last weekend; George Graham is understood to have been at the game.

Mellberg's contract at Santander runs until 2003 but he is thought to have a clause which allows him to leave for £7m.

Newcastle's England midfielder Kieron Dyer is to be questioned by police as a witness to an alleged punch-up between four women.

It is believed the brawl broke out when a 22-year-old woman and a friend were being driven away by Dyer and a friend from a Newcastle city-centre pub on Sunday night. The car stopped and two other women tried to get into the car and a scuffle broke out.

The Premier League has scrapped English football's historic experiment with walkie-talkie devices.

Philip Don, referees' officer, has conceded his innovation of putting match officials in radio contact has received a majority thumbs down from referees.

One senior referee said: "The walkie-talkie gear was too bulky and it was also hard to hear messages above the crowd noise. In addition there were problems getting the frequencies right."

Linesmen now have electronic flags, a buzzer alerting the referee to anything he might have missed.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

But without unlimited funds you can't going on doing that. We've got to be looking worldwide at the next generation of stars. "One reason for bringing Claudio Ranieri in was his knowledge of players ... With all respect, anyone can spot a [Marcel] Desailly. To get the next Desailly takes a lot of work.'' The departure of Rix and Wilkins, Vialli's right-hand men, was inevitable. Although Ranieri brought with him his own coaching team, the pair were intitally kept on out of loyalty, though in peripheral roles. But amid accusations that their presence has hindered Ranieri's attempts to build a new team spirit they have now been sacked at the new manager's insistence. The goalkeeping coach Eddie Niedzwiecki and fitness trainer Antonio Pintus have also been given the choice of leaving or accepting lesser roles. The reserve-team manager Mick McGiven is staying. Tottenham have watched the Sweden defender Olof Mellberg and are considering a bid for the 23-year-old Racing Santander player. Mellberg, a member of Sweden's Euro 2000 squad who has 10 caps, can play as a full-back, centre-half or defensive midfielder. Spurs have confirmed they saw him against Espanyol last weekend; George Graham is understood to have been at the game. Mellberg's contract at Santander runs until 2003 but he is thought to have a clause which allows him to leave for £7m. Newcastle's England midfielder Kieron Dyer is to be questioned by police as a witness to an alleged punch-up between four women. It is believed the brawl broke out when a 22-year-old woman and a friend were being driven away by Dyer and a friend from a Newcastle city-centre pub on Sunday night. The car stopped and two other women tried to get into the car and a scuffle broke out. The Premier League has scrapped English football's historic experiment with walkie-talkie devices. Philip Don, referees' officer, has conceded his innovation of putting match officials in radio contact has received a majority thumbs down from referees. One senior referee said: "The walkie-talkie gear was too bulky and it was also hard to hear messages above the crowd noise. In addition there were problems getting the frequencies right." Linesmen now have electronic flags, a buzzer alerting the referee to anything he might have missed.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: In brief: Film-going no laughing matter for Woody
fields.standfirst: Plus: Brad Pitt joins star line-up for charity album; Smashing Pumpkin provides score for film by controversial director; Angelina Jolie says that filming Tomb Raider has changed her life
fields.trailText: Plus: Brad Pitt joins star line-up for charity album; Smashing Pumpkin provides score for film by controversial director; Angelina Jolie says that filming Tomb Raider has changed her life
fields.body:
 Woody Allen has admitted that he prefers to watch dramatic films rather than comical ones. Ananova reports that the 65-year-old New Yorker said, "I enjoy serious stuff more than I enjoy comedy when I go to see a film or a play or read a book, I enjoy a serious one. That's my own tasteI rarely go to see comedies. I've never seen too many good American talking comedies. I like the films of the Marx Brothers, but in terms of talking comedies, there haven't been many good ones. So I rarely go to see comedies."

 No sooner has Gwyneth Paltrow sung her little heart out in Duets than her old flame, Brad Pitt, jumps on the bandwagon by recording a song for a new charity album, according to People News website. Insiders who have heard the track, called Mid Town, describe it as "dark and moody rock" and likened it to "something that would be in a David Lynch film." There are also rumours that he will follow it up with a duet with his wife, Jennifer Aniston. The CD is also expected to feature the vocal talents of Russell Crowe, Bruce Willis and Johnny Depp.

 Billy Corgan, from the soon to be defunct American rock band Smashing Pumpkins, is to provide a soundtrack for a new short film from controversial video director Jonas Ackerlund, who has attracted much criticism for his gratuitous use of nudity in his films for the Prodigy's Smack My Bitch Up and Metallica's Turn the Page. Ackerlund, who recently directed videos for U2's Beautiful Day and Madonna's Music, will use Corgan's score for his short film, Try, which revolves around the pitfalls of drug abuse in Stockholm's subway system.

 Reuters reports that Angelina Jolie found filming Tomb Raider in Cambodia's Angkor temple a life-changing experience. ''I feel very blessed and very lucky to be part of this film, part of this whole experience,'' she told a news conference in the northern town of Siem Reap where the production has just finished filming. "This has changed my life being here in this country... It makes me feel differently about everything... about my life, about work, about what we can all do."

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Duncan
fields.trailText: The ferry over to Vancouver Island is great. The last time I went over, it was early on a clear, calm Saturday morning and as I sat sipping my coffee a pod of killer whales burst out of the water in a graceful, synchronised arc a mere 100 yards away!
fields.body:
Stumbled across the Guardian's Netjetter page the other night and was happy to see that your first stop is in my native province. I'm writing you from Montreal, where it is likely a good deal chillier than Vancouver, but perhaps less humid. I gather you're not staying very long in beautiful B.C, but thought I would offer some ideas for your stay. I guess that's the point of this whole experiment, right?

I must echo the suggestions for the Capilano Suspension Bridge and Victoria (where I lived for three years). The ferry over to Vancouver Island is great. The last time I went over, it was early on a clear, calm Saturday morning and as I sat sipping my coffee a pod of killer whales burst out of the water in a graceful, synchronised arc a mere 100 yards away! If you want to head over to Washington State, there are ferries from Victoria, or if you're looking for a quick, unconventional way to get back to Vancouver from Victoria, there's a helijet. The view is amazing as you literally plummet down to the Vancouver waterfront.

If you're feeling nostalgic, the Empress Hotel in Victoria offers a real-deal tea time. If you're into indigenous art, they have amazing collections of Haida (West Coast tribe famous for their distinctive, colourful carvings) totem, masks, etc. at the University of British Columbia campus and the museum in Victoria opposite the Parliament Buildings.

You may be a little early for skiing, which is a shame, because world-class resort destination Whistler-Blackcomb is nearby. There's always hiking and mountain biking in and around Vancouver, though. Drop by Mountain Equipment Co-op for outdoors suggestions and equipment rentals. You could go climbing in Squamish, or rent a kayak on the Sunshine Coast. Not that you should expect any sunshine this time of year. Expect rain and fog - (now that'll be a change for ya!)

Do visit Granville Island, in the heart of Vancouver (just down the hill from the Co-op, in fact). There's a large market for eats and meandering,plus The Granville Island Brewery, so you could send us your tasting notes. It's also home to the Emily Carr Institute of Art and Design - check the notice board or website for happenings not advertised elsewhere.

If you're a glutton for punishment, you could do the Grouse Grind - a masochistic hike up the face of Grouse mountain, which is another great way to see the city, although it might be a bit slick this time of year. Reward yourself with the great view then stumble into the gondola for the ride back down if your legs are jelly. The Nam (Robson Street, I think) is a funky place to do breakfast the healthy way. Commercial Drive has good energy, unless it has been gentrified since I was there a year ago - it was called one of the hippest 'hoods in North America a while back by the Utne Reader. Due to the fact that Vancouver increasingly straddles Asia and North America, your choice of food will be pleasantly baffling. I hope you appreciate seafood, because there's some great stuff here, especially Cantonese style. You'll also find great Indian food. Last visit I even enjoyed authentic Malaysian 'hawker' food, courtesy of this little hole-in-the-wall place that a friendly guy from Singapore had set up.

Rent some blades or pull on the walking shoes and head along the Sea Wall around Stanley Park (Vancouver's answer to Central Park) - it's a great way to appreciate the city and work off jetlag or a hangover, or both. If you were staying longer, I would recommend getting off the beaten track in the Kootenay region, where my hometown of Nelson is located. Everyone from Vancouver seems to be moving there, so I'll leave you to enquire why. Well, I hope you're confused by all this. Have fun!

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Nick Walker
fields.trailText: When you're in Vancouver, walk down Robson Street in the evening - it's full of light and colour and a great view of North American glamour shopping.
fields.body:
Vancouver. I am British and moved here in February. I love this city! You're right, it will be cold. And it is very wet. A rain jacket or umbrella are very useful. Firstly, stuff you MUST know about the transit here - it's breathtakingly efficient. The bus drivers don't give change, so you'll need 1.75 in loose change for each journey, or buy a book of 10 tickets in advance at a 7-11 store. When you pay on the bus, get a "transfer" from the driver and this entitles you to unlimited travel on the buses, seabus, and skytrain for two hours. The zonal system can be confusing (applies during weekdays). To get from the airport to downtown, take a number 100 to 70th Ave, then a number 8, which says 'Granville' on the front. Since this is a two zone journey, you'll need 2.50. Every coin has a nickname; 1c - a penny, 5c - a nickel, 10c - a dime, 25c - a quarter, $1 - a looney, $2 - a tooney. Beware that the prices displayed in stores are not what you actually pay. 14% Sales Tax is always added.

The Jericho Beach Youth Hostel is great, and the view of the city from the beach is spectacular. You should see Lynn Canyon on the North Shore. Most people are desperate to get to the very hyped Capilano Suspension Bridge, but Lynn Canyon is better and free. The Harbour Centre Tower gives a good view and costs $9. Your ticket allows you unlimited access for the day, so you can go up after dark as well as daytime, or even watch the sunset there. Walk down Robson Street in the evening - it's full of light and colour and a great view of North American glamour shopping. If you feel culturally inclined, go to the impressive UBC museum of Anthropology. One of the best restaurants is Steppho's Greek Taverna on Davey Street (near the junction with Thurlow Street), where there's huge portions for $9. There are also queues around the block if you get there after 5.30, so be very early!

Right now is the ice hockey season, and I definitely think you should see a game! Finally, if you have time, I recommend a trip to Victoria and/or Tofino. At Tofino you can watch whales or walk in the rainforest.

webTitle: Schoolboy's last hours caught on CCTV

fields.headline: Schoolboy's last hours caught on CCTV
fields.standfirst:
More about the Damilola Taylor case

Police incident room: 020 8247 4567
fields.trailText: Police are looking for a boy and a girl caught on close circuit television leaving a library with murdered 10-year-old Damilola Taylor shortly before his death.
fields.body:
Police are looking for a boy and a girl caught on close circuit television leaving a library with murdered 10-year-old Damilola Taylor shortly before his death.

Detective Superintendent David Dillnut said the two may be able to give the police vital information about the last hours of Damilola's life.

They want to know what the group talked about in case Damilola said anything that may lead to the identification of his murderers. His mother, Gloria, has said that he was being bullied in the days before his murder.

Investigators have found a second knife in a carpark about 200m from the spot where the Nigerian boy bled to death in a stairwell on the North Peckham estate in south east London.

Forensic officers are examining the knives.

A witness has also described seeing three youths marching a younger boy off in a headlock on the day Damilola was killed.

However, police said the group was walking away from the area where Damilola was believed to have been injured at 5pm that evening

DS Dillnut said Damilola was wearing a distinctive three-quarter length silver puffa jacket and appealed for more witnesses to come forward.

Damilola was stabbed in the leg by a group of 11 to 14-year-olds on his way home from school on Monday. He died of his injuries.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From  Norm
fields.trailText: Reading your story and your enthusiasm for your impending adventures has inflicted much nostalgia! You're setting off at the best time of your life to experience what only travel can provide.
fields.body:
Hi Milly, When I was about your age (feels like a very long time ago, but it's only 15 years or so) I, too, was lucky enough to take a gap year between school and college and spend it travelling. In my case, I spent about nine months in Africa and the Middle East. Reading your story and your enthusiasm for your impending adventures has inflicted much nostalgia! You're setting off at the best time of your life to experience what only travel can provide. If you'll allow me a moment to be an old git, its unlikely you'll ever be quite so free and quite so uncluttered in your life again. Yes, I'm envious! You're doing exactly the best thing. Therefore, the only really useful advice is travel light! Not just in bag, but in preconceptions, too. When travelling, the best things happen when least expected - if you let them.

As for the bag part, I recommend three piles:
1. "Absolutely essential - cannot survive without."
2. "Very important - would rather not survive without."
3. "Luxuries"
Keep pile 1. Leave the rest.

Vancouver: Probably seems a long way off yet, but you've chosen a beautiful and charming city to visit. Rent a bike and explore! BC is just gorgeous. Take the train to Banff, take a bus along the Icefields parkway, camp at the Athabasca Glacier and watch the moonrise. Keep your eyes open, be well and have a wonderful time.

fields.headline: The final countdown
fields.standfirst: Armed with the knowledge of how to hotwire a car, cope with a faulty parachute, and the means of telling the time 50m underwater, Sam contemplates his last few days in England
fields.trailText: Armed with the knowledge of how to hotwire a car, cope with a faulty parachute, and the means of telling the time 50m underwater, Sam contemplates his last few days in England
fields.body:
Five days and counting. I still have a ridiculous amount to do. I haven't bought a sleeping bag yet. Or a rucksack. Or even some walking boots (yes I know I won't have time to wear them in, and will end up with swollen, blistered feet). I have however, got the apparently one essential item - a large plug so I can still have a bath wherever I am. And I've got a very stylish watch (birthday present from my girlfriend - she has impeccable taste!) which means I can swim 50m underwater, should the need arise.

The last few days have been an exhausting, emotional rollercoaster. An endless rush of leaving parties (I need more hellos not goodbyes) and packing. I've shipped all my stuff back to my parent's house and my room is empty now. I've bought presents for my family as, for the first time ever, I will be away from home on Christmas Day - in San Franciso with my mate Roy.

I finished work last week. They gave me a good send-off with a nice card and lots of presents (including a book with useful tips on how to hotwire a car or what to do if your parachute doesn't open). Travelling in on the tube on my last day was strange - I realised it might be the last time I ever have to do a straight 9-5 office job. The whole reason I'm doing this trip is to sort out in my head what I want to do with my life. Who knows what answers I'll come up with when I'm sitting on the beach in Fiji or hiking up a mountain in New Zealand?

I picked up my air tickets yesterday and got very excited. When you see them in your hand and realise that they are going to take you to all these fantastic places that you've only ever read about or seen on the TV, then it suddenly becomes real. This is all I've thought about these last few weeks.

I seem to have spent so long planning and thinking about what I need to take - I just want to get on with it now. Having said that, I don't think I'll feel the same way when I'm standing in the airport. I've told my friends and family that I don't want anyone to come and see me off - I'll turn into a sobbing mess.

Well, I'd better get back to the packing. Next time I write I'll be in New York.

fields.headline: Culture of violence must end
fields.standfirst: Every day many social care staff find themselves the victim of verbal or physical assault. Action must be taken now before any more damage is done, writes Geoff Martin
fields.trailText: Comment: Violence towards social care staff is growing and it's time to take action before it gets any worse, writes Geoff Martin
fields.body:
Recent media coverage has highlighted the risk of violence against nurses and other staff working in NHS hospitals. Such coverage is important, but I can tell you from personal experience that, while the media will always give time and space to a staff nurse beaten up in accident and emergency, you've got zero chance of getting much publicity for a community psychiatric nurse (CPN) being assaulted.

At a Unison health and safety conference last month, one of our CPN representatives pointed out that, from his team of nine staff, six had been assaulted in the past two years. Two of them had been so seriously injured that they had been forced to leave. From my conversations with workers across the social care spectrum, both statutory and voluntary, these figures are not exceptional.

The employers know that their staff are facing risks but they expect them to put up with it. And this is where we get to the core of the problem. Verbal and physical assault of staff has now become institutionalised in most areas of social care. It has become part of the job and that should never have been allowed to happen.

Under existing health and safety law, employers have a duty to provide a healthy and safe working environment. Health and safety representatives have a legal right to carry out risk assessments of the workplace and to enforce changes to both the environment and working practices if they are unsafe. This applies to the community and a residential care home as much as it does to a car factory. I am forever urging staff to make full use of these legal powers.

To give you an example, you will never see police officers on the beat, on foot and on their own, in most inner-city areas. So why should social care staff be expected to knock on the same doors, but without any backup? I'm not saying that they need an armed tactical support group crouching behind them but they certainly need a damned site more support than is currently offered by most employers.

It's no excuse, but repeated cutbacks running alongside massive vacancy rates help to fuel the conditions where abuse and assaults are more likely to occur. Frustration with overstretched services can be the spark which leads to a situation boiling over into violence.

And it's not just the risk of being on the receiving end that worries staff. I recently represented a support worker at a major learning difficulties organisation who ended up in a disciplinary hearing after restraining a client with severe challenging behaviour who she was escorting on a shopping trip. The client reacted badly to a situation, the support worker used an approved restraint technique to protect both the client and members of the public and found herself accused of assault. With union support she was exonerated on all charges.

But the point is that she was only out on the trip on her own because of staff shortages. She didn't want the client to be disappointed and she nearly paid a heavy price for caring too much - the end of her career.

The combination of poor pay, grinding stress and the constant threat of violence has had a corrosive impact which will take years of action to repair. fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From: Alistair
fields.trailText: When you reach "down under", you'll have a great time here as well as your other destinations.
fields.body: Hi Milly, When you reach "down under" you'll have a great time here as well as your other destinations. Sydney - take the ferry from Circular Key to Manly. Do the Bridge Climb - approximately $130, but worth it. Cairns - do a scuba course or day trip to the reef. Snorkelling over the reef for the first time is awesome. The mask magnifies everything so you feel that you are so close to the coral you'll scrape your legs - but it never happens. I personally prefer the interior of Oz to the populated east coast. It's got that classic red earth that gets everywhere when you're driving. Last year I drove round Oz. It's a BIG place. Ayers Rock, Olgas and Kings Canyon are places to see. Bon Voyage.

fields.headline: Introducing the university fees debate
fields.trailText: The government would prefer the debate over extra fees for students to be kicked into touch until well after the next General election. But how would you vote on fees?
fields.body:
The heads of universities today publish the latest installment in the long saga on university fees. The problem, as explained in the report, is that universities are short of funding - needing an extra £1bn a year by 2004. The government wants the academic sector to expand and prosper, and in particular, attract more students from poor backgrounds. But it does not intend to use taxpayers money to do this.

Where else then is there to turn to for money? Those, it is argued, who benefit from their degrees in increased lifetime earnings: students. The question though is how to do this. The vice-chancellors' report considers three proposals for fees in detail. But here we list most of the major options for fees now being considered. We do not include here the various options for deferred contributions to fees as part of graduate earnings.

Government insiders have told university leaders that the introduction of tuition fees represents one of the bravest ministerial decisions during this parliamentary term (the other being devolution, which itself led to upfront fees being scrapped in Scotland). And they would prefer the whole debate over extra fees to be kicked into touch until well after the next General election. But how would you vote on fees?

The current system: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland students pay a mean tested annual fee of £1050 (2000-01 figure). In 2001-02 the government estimates that 50% students will not pay any fees. But 14% from higher income families will pay partial fees and 36% from the richest households will pay full fees. The fees generate about £350m in income for the government, not universities. Unit funding for students is now simply rising with inflation.

Following the Cubie report, there are now no upfront fees in Scotland,. Instead graduates make contributions from their earnings. Legally all UK universities are free to charge any level of fees for postgraduate courses, but the government advises them to charge £2740 a year for home students.

The proposals

1. Doubling fees

What it means for students

Double fees for students from £1000 to £2000 a year. These would continue to be charged only for the richest students. The extra fees would generate about £330m of extra income for universities from students and parents.

What it means for government

The government would have to pay an extra £470m a year to pay for the fees not paid by poorer students.

What do universities get out of it?

An extra £800m for all English institutions each year. About £8.9m a year extra for a research institutions with medical schools (Oxbridge, UCL, Manchester etc); £4.7m for research institutions without medical schools (Bath, York, Essex etc); an extra £6.9m for research-teaching institutions; and an extra £8m a year for teaching only institutions (former polytechnics).

2. Different fees for different courses

What it means for students

Double fees for students from £1000 to £2000 a year for courses such as English or sociology, where graduates earn less than those on more vocational courses. Triple fees for students from £1000 to £3000 a year for courses such as medicine, law and computer science, with the highest graduate earners.

Again, these would continue to be charged only for the richest students.

The extra fees would generate about £460m of extra income for universities from students and parents.

What it means for government

The government would have to pay an extra £640m a year to pay for the fees not paid by poorer students.

What do universities get out of it?

An extra £1.1bn for all English institutions each year. About £11.8m a year extra for a research focused institutions with medical schools (Oxbridge, UCL, Manchester etc); £5.8m for research focused institutions without medical schools (Bath, York, Essex etc); an extra £9.7m for research and teaching institutions; and an extra £11.6m a year for teaching only institutions (former polytechnics).

3. Increasing fees for richest students

What it means for students

Charging the average full cost fees (£4000 a year) for students from the richest backgrounds. Poorer students would continue to be exempt from fees.

The extra fees would generate about £259m of extra income for universities from students and parents.

What it means for government

The government would not have to pay an extra than that already paid for the fees for poorer students.

What do universities get out of it?

An extra £259m for all English institutions each year. But almost all this would end up in the research institutions with medical schools.

Proposals not covered in the report

4. Charge the richest students full cost fees, (for medical schools these can be £15,000 a year)

5. Allow universities to set their own fees - limited to a number of student places and courses.

6. Defer payment for fees until after graduation.

7. Abolish fees

webTitle: Capital's homeless problem is getting worse

fields.headline: Capital's homeless problem is getting worse
fields.standfirst: London's councils are working on a city-wide housing strategy.  But the situation will worsen before it improves, warns Tony Newman
fields.trailText: London's councils are working on a city-wide housing strategy. But the situation will worsen before it improves, warns Tony Newman
fields.body:
London may be home to 7m people but it is also a city which is scarred by homelessness.

In the last financial year the bill for homelessness in our capital was more than £92m and since March this year, it has already risen by about 13%.

Homelessness is certainly not a problem that is unique to London, but it is true to say that the capital has disparities of wealth and poverty existing side by side and on a scale which is not seen in any other part of the UK.

The £1m home may be commonplace in some of London's more affluent areas, but even the most casual visitor to the city will be all too familiar with the scenes of homeless people wandering the streets and sleeping in shop doorways.

Recent estimates published by the Rough Sleepers Unit suggest there was a 36% reduction in the number of rough sleepers between 1998 and 2000, but the figures for London show only a marginal reduction of some 4% and in at least one borough, the unit reports an increase in the number of rough sleepers.

There has also been a significant increase in the number of families placed in temporary accommodation by the boroughs.

There are now 48,000 homeless families in London - the highest level for 20 years and certainly not the proudest start to a new millennium. The city has 6,411 families in temporary bed and breakfast accommodation.

In March last year there were 36,677 families in temporary accommodation and 4,812 in bed and breakfast hotels - so in just 18 months, the capital has seen a 31% increase in the number in temporary accommodation and a 33% increase in the number in bed and breakfasts.

The latest available figures from the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions in June this year showed 43,146 homeless in London compared with a total of 32,360 homeless for the rest of England. And these figures exclude the special needs of the 22,000 destitute asylum seekers who are in temporary accommodation.

As is often the case, the levels of homelessness vary quite considerably across London and within the London boroughs. The highest levels of people accepted as homeless are in Brent, Camden, Croydon, Hounslow, Islington, Lambeth, Lewisham, Newham, Tower Hamlets and Westminster but while Lewisham has had to cope with a dramatic 118% increase, Islington and Westminster have each been left to face hefty 37% increases.

The issue of affordable housing is a major one for London which also has far higher levels of overcrowding and home sharing than other parts of the country and there are signs that the capital's problems could well get worse before they get better.

After years of slow decline, London's population is on the increase, with the Greater London Authority now projecting that it will reach 8.148m by 2016 - an increase of more than 1m on the 1996 figure of 7.071m.

Even without tackling existing shortages, the increase in population will inevitable lead to a growing demand for housing in the capital where charity Shelter estimates there is already a backlog of around 240,000 homes.

All this, remember, is in a city where housing is at an expensive premium. In Kensington and Chelsea the average house price is almost £360,000, which would suggest a household income of around £120,000 to support a mortgage - far beyond the means of most Londoners.

No wonder London's councils are hard at work on a housing strategy and no wonder we have welcomed the promise of increased investment by the government. But we should be under no illusions, this is just the start of tackling the accumulated problems of years of underinvestment in our housing.

 Tony Newman is chairman of the Association of London Government's housing panel

fields.headline: Ofsted climbdown over 'failing' comprehensive
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government's education watchdog, Ofsted, yesterday agreed to drop its decision to label a London comprehensive "failing", admitting that there had been procedural errors in its inspection of the school which made the judgment "unsafe".
fields.body:
The government's education watchdog, Ofsted, yesterday agreed to drop its decision to label a London comprehensive "failing", admitting that there had been procedural errors in its inspection of the school which made the judgment "unsafe".

In what would have led to a landmark case being launched in the high court today, Crown Woods school in Eltham, south London, had sought a judicial review to try to overturn Ofsted's decision to put it into "special measures" - the official term for failing.

The school claimed that the decision was based on flimsy evidence from an unsatisfactory inspection in April.

But in a humiliating 11th-hour climbdown, the office for standards in education agreed to an out-of-court settlement with the school, which spared it the embarrassment of a public hearing.

Ofsted was ordered to pay the school's costs - estimated to run into five figures - as well as lifting its judgment that it should be placed in special measures, pending an imminent reinspection.

The terms of the settlement were hammered out over the past few days in the run-up to chief inspector Chris Woodhead's last day in the job today. One theory was that the deal was sought by Mr Woodhead's successor, Mike Tomlinson, in order to allow him to start his new job with a clean slate.

The school - one of the largest comprehensives in England and backed by its local education authority in Greenwich - was the first to threaten to test the results of an unfavourable inspection in the courts.

Its teachers and governors claimed the inspectors' ruling was harsh and unfair, and that they had not gathered enough evidence to substantiate their argument.

Local politicians and education officials welcomed the settlement, while teaching unions said it was a victory and underlined the need for an independent appeals procedure to eliminate the lengthy and expensive route to the courts.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said: "I welcome the settlement of the case, which undoubtedly represents a victory for the school and the LEA over the Ofsted dictatorship.

"It is a fitting farewell message to the departing chief inspector, Chris Woodhead. The settlement confirms there were serious procedural irregularities in the conduct of the inspection."

Mr Tomlinson will tomorrow hold his first press conference as Mr Woodhead's successor and he is expected to announce details of the next round of local education authority inspections.

Ofsted is planning to inspect all 150 authorities in England by September next year, and will have visited 107 by the end of this term. Mr Tomlinson will announce the next 16 to be inspected next year.

webTitle: Charities want radical approach to rural regeneration

fields.headline: Charities want radical approach to rural regeneration
fields.trailText: Charities have raised some searching questions about the government's rural white paper launched on Tuesday. Although the programme is broadly welcomed, the National Federation of Women's Institutes (NFWI), the UK's largest rural women's organisation, claimed the government is still not tackling the root causes of rural decay.
fields.body:
Charities have raised some searching questions about the government's rural white paper launched on Tuesday. Although the programme is broadly welcomed, the National Federation of Women's Institutes (NFWI), the UK's largest rural women's organisation, claimed the government is still not tackling the root causes of rural decay.

National chairman Helen Carey said: "We are disappointed that the government has not seized the opportunity for a more radical shift in direction."

She added: "Ministers have still not fully grasped the central importance of land and food production, not only to rural life but also to the nation's well-being and security."

Turning agricultural land over to development, Ms Carey claimed, was a high risk policy at a time of climate, ecological and world economic instability. "Our best farmers will be turned into tourist guides, and our nation will become increasingly dependent on imported food brokered by giant trans-national corporations," she said.

There was a cautious welcome for the white paper from Action with Communities in Rural England, the national association of rural community councils. Chief executive Les Roberts called it the first real attempt to tackle social needs but he questioned whether it was adequate or sustainable.

"There are some good ideas but they need to be linked together with investment and long-term commitment," he said. "The plans for affordable housing are good but this is not enough - you can't build houses without facilities and I'm not convinced that the proposals to revitalise services will be directly linked to increased housing."

Mr Roberts also called for imaginative ideas to increase bus use in rural areas. "In Turkey minibuses run around picking people up from anywhere and it seems to work well," he said.

However, he welcomed some of the detail, for example, controlling car use in rural areas. He explained: "There are often no pavements in villages making it very dangerous, especially for children. The control of speeding cars is essential."

The director of the Campaign for the Protection of Rural England (CPRE), Kate Parminter, said the white paper was "a cautious but well founded start to securing a better deal for rural communities and a more beautiful countryside for everyone".

CPRE particularly welcomed the curbs on billboards in the countryside and the provision of services and affordable homes. Yet, it claimed that the white paper still faces a major challenge in reversing continuing environmental and social decline. Ms Parminter added: "The success of the many welcome new initiatives in the rural white paper depends on the countryside becoming more mainstream to the government's vision and priorities."

Meanwhile, the Rural Housing Trust said that providing 3,000 new affordable homes by 2004 is barely significant when compared to a current estimated need of around 50,000 homes.

Chief executive Moira Constable also said that giving councils the discretionary power to levy full council tax on second homes as opposed to the statutory 50% discount at present was a "fudge". She argued: "There is no guarantee that funds raised through this mechanism will be spent by local authorities on providing capital grant for more affordable housing in villages."

The trust called for more work to translate the proposals into action, a speeding up of the spending programme and more education of housing developers to ensure the promises of the white paper are fulfilled.

She argued: "There is no guarantee that funds raised through this mechanism will be spent by local authorities on providing capital grant for more affordable housing in villages." The trust called for more work to translate the proposals into action, a speeding up of the spending programme and more education of housing developers to ensure the promises of the white paper are fulfilled.

fields.headline: Guardian websites hit 22m page impressions
fields.trailText: 2pm: The Guardian's network of websites has exceeded 22m page impressions.
fields.body:
Guardian Unlimited has had its 22m page impression figure validated by the official industry audit body.

According to ABC electronic, page impressions for October reached 22.1m, double the traffic 12 months ago.

The audit comes just a week after the GU network picked up its ninth major award of the year, the IPTOP Grand Prix European Content Award.

The surge in traffic is attributed to continued expansion of the network.

GU has launched a number of new websites and internet services in recent months, including MediaGuardian.co.uk, SocietyGuardian.co.uk, Money Unlimited, The Newslist, The Weblog and the Wrap.

Simon Waldman, head of Guardian Unlimited, said: "This surge in traffic is fantastic news - a just reward for the commitment we have made to the continuous improvement and development of our sites."

GU's last official ABCe audit was 10.2m a year ago.

fields.trailText: "The public have an insatiable curiosity to know everything. Except what is worth knowing. Journalism, conscious of this, and having tradesman-like habits, supplies their demands."

webTitle: Five minutes with Mark Z Danielewski

fields.headline: Five minutes with Mark Z Danielewski
fields.standfirst: Mark Danielewski spoke to us on the phone from Los Angeles, eager to talk about his shortlisted book The House of Leaves. Find out how his story of how a house that is larger on the inside than the outside came about, and listen to audio clips of the interview (you will need RealAudio, download it here for free)
fields.trailText: Mark Danielewski spoke to us on the phone from Los Angeles, eager to talk about his shortlisted book The House of Leaves. Find out how his story of how a house that is larger on the inside than the outside came about, and listen to audio clips of the interview
fields.body:
Can you tell us a bit about the book?

House of Leaves is about a family who move into a small house in Virginia. One day they go away for a wedding and when they come back discover that a space has appeared between the master bedroom and the children's bedroom. The walls that appear are black and perfectly smooth. Will Navidson (the protagonist) begins to measure the inside of the house and soon discovers that the inside is larger than the outside by a quarter of an inch and that's where it all begins to happen. What it comes down to is how this family deals with a house that is larger on the inside than the outside and how it begins to influence those who live there and those who hear about it and those who write about it and maybe even those who read about it.

 Audio clip: Mark Danielewski on the House

Where did the idea come from?

Way back in the beginning, I had a sense of a big project that I wanted to write and so I started writing about characters and writing these theoretical essays on film and sketching out philosophical ideas I was interested in pursuing. Then, in 1993, my father died and it was shortly after that that I had this idea about a house that was a quarter of an inch shorter on the inside than the outside. I really didn't know what it was, I thought it was a footnote or maybe a story, perhaps a poem and then I realised it was exactly what I'd been looking for all along. It was the space in which the characters I'd been working on lived. It was a space where these philosophical ideas and theoretical concepts I had could be applied. I wanted to be as true to the book as possible so I kept following it and then when I was done, I looked back and I had this 750 page book. It was seven or eight years of a lot of work.

 Audio clip: Mark Danielewski on the project

What was the idea behind your unusual use of typography?

I would say that most of the typographical setting is influenced by film. That had been the design from the very beginning: to use the image of text itself in a way that had been studied very carefully for a hundred years by exquisite film-makers and to increase the reader's experience as they progress through the book.

When I first began writing the book 10 years ago, I wrote a series of essays for myself on how cinematic grammar could be applied to text. One of the things that I've also noticed - thanks to my father who was a film-maker - was how film has a type of grammar that intensifies the viewers' experiences. A very simple example is in an action movie. Before an action sequence, a director tends to present the audience with long shots and static views so the eye is fixed on a certain focal point on the screen and doesn't move. When the action sequence actually comes in, a lot of short cuts are used and it intensifies the viewers' experience by shifting the focal point all over the screen. The eye is moving all around and there's an actual visceral response to that.

So I began to theorise how one could adopt the same techniques textually. So, for example, in chapter nine, The Labyrinth Chapter, the density of the text intentionally slows the reader down, reorients the reader, redresses that question of direction inside the book. However, the next chapter, The Rescue Chapter, only has a few sentences per page so the reader will move through a hundred pages a lot quicker.

 Audio clip: Mark Danielewski on typography

Much has been made of your references to academic criticism within the book. What was reason for that?

Well, I read my share at Yale and Berkeley. It's also something that we're all aware of and we're constantly doing in our day-to-day lives. At the breakfast table we are footnoting everything that we read. We don't recognise it as such but we encounter an article in the newspaper and then suddenly we recall that a friend had a certain comment on that particular story, a certain bit of news that we saw on the television applies to that and we immediately assemble an idea of a story. It isn't exactly what*s on a newspaper in front of us. So, what I decided to do was adopt that mode of thinking, looking closely at the way we really process stories and how we encounter narratives and footnote them with our own personal experiences, our own emotional registers, and put it on the page. It's something that looks terribly foreign when you first glance at it in the book but then, as you begin to read it, you realise that actually it's patterned very naturally on the way we all think.

 Audio clip: Mark Danielewski on academic criticism

Are there any first books that you've read this year that have stood out?

I'm excited by what I have read so far of Helen de Witt's The Last Samurai. I read White Teeth by Zadie Smith and was enchanted. After reading Zadie's book, I wanted to come to London, I wanted to see it. It got me all excited about it. I read Dave Eggers's book, A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius and thought the opening was absolutely devastating. Having lost a father to cancer it reminded me of lots of similar events that took place in my life.

 Audio clip: Mark Danielewski on first books

Any plans for another book?

After 10 years, isn't that enough! I'll probably start on something later in the year. I'm a big believer in big books and that doesn't necessarily mean long books. Books that have a great deal of content in them so I'm not going to be publishing a book in the next sixth months or so. It'll be another project.

 Audio clip: Mark Danielewski on future projects

fields.headline: Vinnie Jones answers your questions
fields.trailText: He came, he saw, and then - after a whistle-stop visit to London to launch his new video and, as it turned out, make a surprise appearance on This Is Your Life - Vinnie Jones buggered off back to LA. Without answering your questions. Obviously, we weren't happy - and judging by the volume of emails we received, you weren't either. But finally, after endless phone calls, thinly veiled threats and a galaxy of excuses from PR people, Vinnie has come through. And, by God, do we thank him for it.
fields.body:
He came, he saw, and then - after a whistle-stop visit to London to launch his new video and, as it turned out, make a surprise appearance on This Is Your Life - Vinnie Jones buggered off back to LA. Without answering your questions. Obviously, we weren't happy - and judging by the volume of emails we received, you weren't either. But finally, after endless phone calls, thinly veiled threats and a galaxy of excuses from PR people, Vinnie has come through. And, by God, do we thank him for it.

We would also like to thank the hundreds of you who emailed in questions for him. So give yourselves a hearty pat on the back - actually, make that two if you didn't ask what Gazza's testicles felt like - and enjoy the verbal sparring that takes place when soccer hardman and Hollywood star Vincent Jones goes head-to-head with the best Football Unlimited readers can muster. Let battle commence!

1. Do you think the reputation you had as a hardman of football perhaps masked your footballing talent? And if it did, do you care? - George Davidson

I had a great time when I was playing football and I think my tough reputation did go before me, but that is no bad thing as a lot of the game is down to a state of mind. Half the job of winning is down to making an opponent think he has already lost before he even steps onto the pitch. It's not for me to comment on my footballing talent but I can't complain about my achievements.

2. What pleased you more - winning the FA Cup final in 1988 or receiving rave reviews for Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels? - Alexandre Gontijo

Winning the final with Wimbledon was one of the most amazing things ever and nothing can take away from that. The previous question asked if I felt my hardman reputation masked by talent, well you don't win the Cup with just reputation.

It was great to get recognition for all the work that I put into Lock, Stock. Guy Ritchie was a great director and his strong belief that I had what it took really inspired me. When the reviews came in I was really touched to see that all the hard work I put into the part wasn't in vain - and it has spurred me on even more in Snatch, Gone in Sixty Seconds and the films I am working on now.

3. Have you ever committed a foul and thought, "Shit, I've gone too far here?" If so, when and where? - Jack Saunders

Not really. Every player knew what they were going up against when they stepped on to the pitch with me. I wasn't the only 'bad boy' out there anyway. There were tons of other players doing what I did and it still goes on now. The referees just kept watching me more than other players.

4. Exactly what possessed you to feel Paul Gascoigne's package? - Neil Butler

He was annoying me and wouldn't stop and I thought I'd stop him once and for all. Simple as that!

5. At a time when the football club with whom you were earning your wages, QPR, were in real dire straits, financially, mentally and generally, why did you publicly mock our club on the late night TV show McCoist and McCauley? And why did you never apologise to QPR fans for not wanting to play for our club? - Tracy Stent

There were things happening behind the scenes that I won't go into. This is all a long time ago and I've changed since then. I am sorry if the fans were offended but they have had their fair share of goes at me.

6. At the end of last season you offered to take the Wimbledon job for £200,000 a year. Do you still fancy becoming a football manager? If you do, which formation would you play and why? - Alex Clarke

I'm really committed to my film career and am putting all of my effort into it so I don't have much time for the game - at the moment. Who knows what the future holds, though?

7. Which opposition player did you look forward to meeting on a Saturday, and which player did you hate playing against? Why? - KB8MPO@bolton.ac.uk

Some things are better left unsaid. My fans will probably know the answer to this already.

8. Now you're spending six months of the year in Hollywood can you tell us: does anyone down to earth and normal (besides yourself) actually live in that God-forsaken hell hole? - Mark Bridges

You can get strange people wherever you are in the world. I have got a great place in LA and quite enjoy it out there. It is obviously very different to home, and I miss the UK a lot, but it is where I need to be for my film career right now.

9. What's your juiciest piece of Hollywood gossip? - Lawrence Booth

I'm not really in with the Hollywood party circuit. I prefer to spend time with my family and friends that come over from home, so I am not really the person to ask for hot gossip.

10. Why does America use an electoral college system in the Presidential election? Why don't they just tally up the votes of the nation as a whole? - julian@gluemedia.com

Better ask an American.

The competition winners were: Richard Snoxell, Gregory Manberg, Martin Delaney, Rory McKerrell and Lisa Noonan. They all win a copy of Vinnie's new video: Vinnie's Revenge, which is out in all good shops now.

webTitle: Fed rises put brake on US growth

fields.headline: Fed rises put brake on US growth
fields.trailText: The US economy has slipped to its slowest growth rate for four years as a series of interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve begins to bite.
fields.body:
The US economy has slipped to its slowest growth rate for four years as a series of interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve begins to bite.

Gross domestic product grew by 2.4% in the third quarter - revised down from earlier estimates of 2.7% - less than half the rate seen in the second quarter and the weakest since the third quarter in 1996.

Financial markets had a bumpy rise with both the dollar and US equity markets falling ahead of the figures. However the Dow Jones industrial average recovered to show a near three-figure gain on the day while the dollar also regained lost ground.

Analysts attributed the rally to the GDP data proving less weak than a pessimistic Wall Street had been expecting, raising hopes that the US economy could still achieve a "soft landing". The Federal Reserve, the US central bank, has raised interest rates six times since the summer of 1999 in an effort to prevent the economy from overheating and triggering higher inflation but without throwing the economy into reverse.

The technology rich Nasdaq index, however, remained in negative territory. "We have probably seen what the Fed would like to see, a slowdown, and that is a reaffirmation. We don't see the worst case scenario of anything below 2% or 1.5% [growth], which people were fearing," according to Oscar Gonzalez, an economist with Boston's John Hancock.

Mr Gonzalez argued that there could be more fallout from the series of interest rate rises but played down concerns about a hard landing. "We still expect [growth in the fourth quarter] to be around 3%.

The slowdown in the economy is beginning to show up in corporate profits. Tax profits for US companies rose by an annualised rate of 0.6% in the third quarter, compared to a 2.5% increase in the second quarter, the worst figure since the Russian debt crisis squeezed bank profits in 1998.

On the foreign exchanges the dollar had initially weakened against the euro, with the single currency reaching its highest level for almost two months. But it regained ground after the release of the figures, with the euro dipping back below 0.86.

webTitle: Urban white paper offers dynamic tool kit for change

fields.headline: Urban white paper offers dynamic tool kit for change
fields.standfirst: Muted responses to the urban white paper are misguided, says Esther Knight of the Centre for Local Economic Strategies, who believes it is a significant agenda for renewal
fields.trailText: The urban white paper received a muted response in the House of Commons, and members of parliament struggled to find much that was new in the long-awaited document. Their response was misplaced. This white paper, and the activity that lies behind it, adds up to unprecedented change for those involved in urban regeneration and renewal.
fields.body:
The urban white paper received a muted response in the House of Commons, and members of parliament struggled to find much that was new in the long-awaited document. Their response was misplaced. This white paper, and the activity that lies behind it, adds up to unprecedented change for those involved in urban regeneration and renewal.

The urban white paper is the first attempt in almost a quarter of a century to bring together the government's approach to urban areas at the strategic, regional and local levels. Significantly, it sets up a new committee at cabinet level to oversee this process.

The paper also paves the way for its rural counterpart by making explicit the link between urban population and pressure on the countryside.

The paper takes on board key recommendations from Lord Rogers's urban task force report Towards an Urban Renaissance, and uses as its starting point the links between the social, economic and environmental factors at play in urban areas. To put it simply, joined-up problems require joined-up solutions.

At the national level, the government committed itself in the chancellor's pre-budget statement to a series of measures designed to encourage physical development in run-down areas. This included additional expenditure in the transport strategy, and a review of the planning framework aimed at putting urban renewal at the heart of the country's planning system.

At the regional level, a greater role in joining up urban initiatives is given to the government's regional office, and extra resources, announced in the pre-budget statement, go to the regional development agencies.

At the local level, recently introduced legislation gives local authorities wide powers to act in the interests of economic, social and environmental wellbeing of their areas.

The quality of public services is being monitored through pilot local public service agreements in individual councils, while the introduction of local strategic partnerships, bringing together local agencies and community groups to co-ordinate regeneration work, places much greater emphasis on genuine local consultation.

The white paper aims to tackle poverty and social exclusion through economic growth, and links quality of life with quality of public services. All the new initiatives and structures are designed to recognise that the needs of individual areas are very varied. The "tool kit" approach - moving away from the previous "one size fits all" attitude - is to be welcomed. This white paper increases the scope for local action, though not necessarily local power.

 Esther Knight is the assistant director of the Centre for Local Economic Strategies

 Skills training for the new urban agenda will be examined at a CLES conference at Sheffield Hallam University on December 5. For further information, email: cynthiacarter@cles.org.uk
