At the regional level, a greater role in joining up urban initiatives is given to the government's regional office, and extra resources, announced in the pre-budget statement, go to the regional development agencies. At the local level, recently introduced legislation gives local authorities wide powers to act in the interests of economic, social and environmental wellbeing of their areas. The quality of public services is being monitored through pilot local public service agreements in individual councils, while the introduction of local strategic partnerships, bringing together local agencies and community groups to co-ordinate regeneration work, places much greater emphasis on genuine local consultation. The white paper aims to tackle poverty and social exclusion through economic growth, and links quality of life with quality of public services. All the new initiatives and structures are designed to recognise that the needs of individual areas are very varied. The "tool kit" approach - moving away from the previous "one size fits all" attitude - is to be welcomed. This white paper increases the scope for local action, though not necessarily local power.  Esther Knight is the assistant director of the Centre for Local Economic Strategies  Skills training for the new urban agenda will be examined at a CLES conference at Sheffield Hallam University on December 5. For further information, email: cynthiacarter@cles.org.uk

fields.headline: Decision, Appeal, and Judgement
fields.trailText: TEL US WHY!
fields.body:
TEL US WHY!

According to our sources (and not our sauces who, while smelling tasty and garnishing burgers superbly, have made no comment on the matter) Terry Venables will politely decline the opportunity to become manager of Middlesbrough. Yes, it seems that after days of late-night talks with Steve Gibson - at least we presume they were talking - Tel has decided to stay down south, where everybody knows his mug, and cheeky Chris Evans is only a jellied eel's throw away.

The ginger maestro is believed to have been an important factor in Venables' decision, as Tel is down to present his fabulous Rock 'n' Roll Football Show on Virgin Radio (105.8MHz, 10cc fans) until the end of the season. Combine that with the fact that ITV want him to be Des Lynam's bestest pal when their new Match of the Day effort hits the screens next season, and you have a fair few commitments for someone supposed to be free at weekends.

Of course, if Tel does turn Boro down, it leaves them putting a tight squeeze on a tricky spot of bother. Having admitted they no longer want Bryan Robbo as boss, they will be forced into looking for a new man, even if there aren't that many candidates about - are you listening, Roy Evans? Meanwhile, Tel can return to doing what he does best which, according to Fiver reader Gavin Hosford, is buying Spanish villas. "Mr Terry Venables has just bought a house down the road from me, in the exclusive Son Vida area of Mallorca," writes Gavin without a hint of bragging. "It's a long way to travel from Mallorca to Boro every Saturday!" he adds, rather unnecessarily.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

'APPY 'ARRY 'AS 'AD IT UP TO 'ERE

You just don't mess abaht with the likes of Appy Arry, the 'ard-as-nails guv'nor of Appy Arry's Ammers. Paolo Di Canio recently found that out after giving it a bit of "marf", and we don't even want to think about what could have happened to poor Rio Ferdinand had he queered that big deal. So why the Department for Education and Employment are risking the big man's ire by delaying 23-year-old Australian international Hayden Foxe's move to Upton Park, we don't know.

"It's a scandal and a disgrace!" screamed Arry after a second appeal against to grant Foxe a work permit was turned down. "The whole system is crooked and it's all about who you know and who can pull the strings. I'm not going to let this one die," he bellowed, slowly and systematically tooling himself up. Of course, like any East End psychopath worth his salt, Arry only goes on the rampage when right is on his side. "He's Australian, he's in the Commonwealth," Arry reasoned. "They fought the war with us. I know that might sound like bollocks to you but we let foreign people in who have no allegiance to the country."

Predictably, a DfEE spokesperson disagreed. "The work permit rules are clear and transparent," it droned. "There is no question that the system is other than fair and just". Equally predictably, the pen-pusher's rationale cut no ice with Arry. "Forest got a player in on loan and Wrexham have got tuppence-halfpenny players from abroad," the cockney boss snarled erratically, apropos of nothing. "And how did Brad Friedel get a work permit?" he went on, suddenly sounding much more lucid.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I would want to keep some reference to Stockport in the name. Man-Stock County for instance" - Stockport chairman Brendan Elwood reveals his plans for the club, which include moving to Maine Road when Manchester City leave. And a snazzy new name which just rolls off the tongue.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

JONES TRIAL BEGINS

Former Southampton manager Dave Jones began his trial today on charges that he sexually abused boys at a residential school in the 1980s.

The 44-year-old Jones denies a total of 14 charges, including indecent assault and assault causing actual bodily harm, against four boys when they were aged between 10 and 14. The prosecution allege Jones committed the offences over four years from January 1986, at a residential home in north-west England which catered for children with emotional and behavioural problems.

Prosecuting lawyer David Aubrey told Liverpool Crown Court: "It is the prosecution's case that the defendant carries with him a dark secret... it is a secret that will be revealed by those who assert that they were physically or sexually abused by this defendant while they were in his care and he was employed as a care worker at the school." The case continues.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale has laughed off the Mirror's suggestion that he is "hatching an incredible plan" to bring Ronaldo on loan until the end off the season. "It's nonsense," he said. "There's more chance of us signing Pele."

Tottenham are set to bid £8m for Francis Jeffers, according to reports. Everton need to sell to balance their books and have already made "discreet calls" to potential bidders. Manchester United are also said to be interested.

Real Madrid have laughed off a reported £44m bid from Barcelona for Ivan Helguera.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Tottenham striker Sergei Rebrov has admitted he would have preferred playing with his former team-mate Andriy Shevchenko at AC Milan. "I won't lie that I wanted to play with Shevchenko not only in the national team, but also at club level," he told Sport-Express newspaper. "But I don't regret at all that I chose London."

Chelsea have escaped with a warning after being charged with misconduct following their 1-0 defeat against Sheffield Wednesday in April. The FA admitted the club had not been told in advance about a crackdown on intimidation of referees.

Bradford hope to complete the signing of Leeds defender Robert Molenaar in time for Saturday's Premiership match against Coventry. Meanwhile David Batty will make his comeback for Leeds in a reserve match on December 14 after more than a year out with an Achilles injury.

Aston Villa have offered David James a new three-and-a-half year contract. The deal would keep him at Villa Park until the summer of 2004.

Grandstand and Match of the Day could be blacked out this weekend because of strike action. BBC technical staff plan to down tools on Saturday in a dispute over redundancies.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (3.10am) "A round-up of the best football action from around the world," says ITV, "including news, interviews, and features on some of the game's lesser-known characters." Probably worth watching, just to see if your Sunday League side makes it in.

Channel 5: Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (12.45am) Last week, JP smashed the 90-decibel level. So if you're looking for some shut-eye be warned: he's g-g-g-gunning for the hundred.

Dutch Football (1.15am) Sit back, relax, be mellow.

Argentine Football (2.50am) Great news! Argentine Football is now broadcast in stereo. Does it get any better than this?

International Football (4.25am) Let's be honest: It's at 4.25am in the morning, so it's not going to be any good, is it?

Sky Sports 1: Football (6.30pm, 11.30pm) Oh dear, looks like Eurosport's old scheduler has got himself a new job.

Spanish Football (8pm) Bet he's wondering how to shorten this snazzy little number even as we speak.

You're on Sky Sports (10pm) McCaff is back. Click here and wince.

Fifa TV (11pm) Who says bribery and corruption is any worse than scheduling a programme this good this late?

Sky Sports 2: Australian Football League (10.30pm) "Top flight football action from down under," say Sky. "Save it until the summer when we're doing our pools coupon," says the Fiver.

Sky Sports 3: Classic World Cup Football (10pm) Relive Italy's tedious 0-0 draw with Cameroon in 1982 in glorious technicolour.

Eurosport: Football (10.30pm) Oh bother he's at it again! Why can't Eurosport just explain that they're showing the best action from the second round of the German Cup? Then we'd all be watching. Wouldn't we?

webTitle: North takes holistic approach to homelessness

fields.headline: North takes holistic approach to homelessness
fields.standfirst: The problem of rough sleepers in London may dominate policy and debate on homelessness. But, writes Stuart Bowman, the north has its own issues to tackle, caused by years of poor quality housing, drug misuse and unemployment
fields.trailText: The problem of rough sleepers in London may dominate policy and debate on homelessness. But, writes Stuart Bowman, the north has its own issues to tackle, caused by years of poor quality housing, drug misuse and unemployment
fields.body:
Think of a homeless person and what do you see? Someone bedding down in a doorway? A beggar in the street? The old cardboard city at Waterloo?

Homelessness is now commonly equated with rough sleeping, a clear indication of how the situation in central London has come to dominate national debates about the subject.

By setting up something called the Rough Sleepers Unit and giving it the job of reducing rough sleeping by two-thirds, Tony Blair sent out a clear message - he wants to clean up our streets. The current anti-begging campaign is cut from the same cloth.

Working in the north, however, it sometimes feels that a small central London clique dominates the debate and that policy has been led by concerns in the capital.

Of course the streets are a bad place to be, but northern cities do not have London's problem with long-term rough sleeping. Three-quarters of our Big Issue vendors slept rough last year but only 12% of them spent more than six months living on the streets. More than half spent less than a week on the streets last time they slept rough.

Loft living and Harvey Nichols may have arrived, but behind the façade northern cities still have the same old problems of unemployment, drug misuse and poor quality housing which are creating new generations of homeless people.

Rough sleepers need our help but they represent only the most visible aspect of a much broader homelessness problem which has not received anything like the same level of attention.

To tackle it, health and drug services must improve, sustainable regeneration of our older industrial areas must create jobs and desirable places to live for everyone and integrated packages of support for homeless people need to be put into place. There is a revolving door of rough sleeping, hostels and insecure housing. Only this can jam it.

Rough Sleepers Unit staff have ventured out into the wilderness beyond the M25 and distributed £37m to a variety of projects outside London through the new Homelessness Action Programme.

Some less headline-grabbing initiatives offer more long-term, sustainable improvements. For example, the care system has been failing for too long and its ongoing reform could reduce the number of care leavers who end up on the streets.

The proposed National Treatment Agency must improve drug services, make them more accountable and focused on helping users to become drug free. They need to move away from just substituting heroin with methadone and meet the housing, health, educational and employment needs of drug users. Three-quarters of our vendors use illegal drugs but our research shows that 80% of them had a drug problem before they became homeless.

Since 1996, the Big Issue in the North Trust has been helping homeless people move away from the streets to good homes, good health, good jobs and good lives. Unlike other Big Issues around the UK, vendors in the north participate in the Big Futures programme.

Under the programme, they complete three accredited training courses, meet with staff every month and have access to a range of services including housing, fast access to drug detox, and a variety of projects, short courses and activities to help them develop self-esteem and realise that they have a right to the good things in life.

We think it works. Since May, 40 vendors have moved into permanent accommodation, 30 have found employment and 50 have undertaken a detox.

It is only this sort of holistic approach that can help homeless people to achieve their full potential and one which the Rough Sleepers Unit should embed in services all around the country. It may be a cliché but what is a cliché other than something that is true but which we are bored of hearing?

 Stuart Bowman is research manager for the Big Issue in the North Trust

webTitle: How to choose the perfect tree

fields.headline: How to choose the perfect tree
fields.standfirst: How to choose the perfect tree
fields.trailText: How to choose the perfect tree
fields.body:
* Check the height of the the room where you will display your tree and pick a tree that is at least a foot shorter. Also check the shape. Each tree will taper differently and you may not have enough space for a very "fat" tree in your front hall.

* Run your fingers over the branch along the needles. The needles should be pliable. They should bend, but they should not break or fall off.

* Check the colour and the smell. Christmas trees of whatever variety should give off quite a strong aroma. Make sure yours does. Colour is also important as trees fade as they get older. A strongly coloured tree is healthier and will last longer.

* Give the tree a good shake to make sure that the needles are still firmly attached. If the tree is fresh, few needles should fall off.

* Make sure the tree trunk is straight. Cheaper trees can have crooked trunks, which will make your Christmas tree look even sillier once the decorations are on. Make sure the base of the trunk is between six and eight inches long. It will make it easier to place in a tree stand.

webTitle: How much can you pay for

fields.headline: How much can you pay for
fields.standfirst: . . . a bubble blower
fields.trailText: . . . a bubble blower
fields.body:
Remember the simple joys of childhood? All that Julie Andrews stuff about "raindrops on roses"? The excitement of getting one of those 10p bubbleblowing sets from the newsagents? Well, with the new pre-teen spending power you can kiss goodbye to all that. You can bet your bottom-dollar that the "warm woollen mittens" are cashmere (preferably Jo Gordon) and the "white dresses with blue satin sashes" are fine as long as they're bought at Semmalina or The Cross. The ultimate toy for the grown-ups this season is Links of London's solid-silver bubble blower. It's the shape of a champagne bottle and comes packed in tissue paper in a wooden crate - just like the real thing. You can even buy a case of six. Fill with washing-up liquid (unfortunately, champagne won't work), dip in the bubble blower and, in the words of Lauren Bacall, "Put your lips together and blow."

Although a plastic version can be purchased for mere pennies, don't let the price tag - £28 for one or £168 for the six - put you off. Call 020 7730 3133 for stockists.

fields.headline: Take a bough
fields.standfirst: The days of plastic trees are over. Now millions of us are buying the real thing. So how do we choose among the forest on offer?
fields.trailText: The days of plastic trees are over. Now millions of us are buying the real thing. So how do we choose among the forest on offer? Susan Emmett investigates.
fields.body:
It used to be so simple. Every December, the most lasting of trees would be brought down from the attic in a large brown box. Its prickly boughs would be dusted, then assembled and finally decorated by delighted owners. These days, however, we are unlikely to gaze admiringly at a conical-shaped bit of plastic. More and more people are opting for the real thing, leaving behind the artificial imitations that decked our halls in years gone by. This year, we will be spending well over £150m on the genuine article, with growers expect to sell some 7m Christmas trees compared with only 1.5m in the early 80s.

Some authorities consider the Christmas tree to be a survivor of pagan worship and trace it to Egypt and ancient Rome. Others say that the first real Christian Christmas tree dates back to 8th century Germany where it was used as a replacement for pagan worship. However, it was not until the beginning of the 19th century that the Christmas tree as we know it really became part of celebrations in England. Although Christmas trees were not unknown in England in Georgian times, it was Prince Albert of Saxony, the prince consort of Queen Victoria, who set an example and encouraged people to have a decorated tree at Christmas.

Until relatively recently, trees would be cut in the woods, brought into town and sold mostly by greengrocers. Some are still grown in this way but environmental concerns and a reluctance to spoil the woodlands has prompted farmers to start growing trees as a crop in special plantations. More than 85% of the trees in our homes are grown in Britain and the remainder imported from Denmark, Ireland and Belgium.

Growers are keen to publicise the environmental benefits of their farms. The average six foot Christmas tree takes about eight years to grow in Britain. According to the British Christmas Tree Growers Association, an acre of 2.5m trees can take two tonnes of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and release sufficient oxygen for 12 to 15 people to live on for a year. Trees are also replanted within six weeks of being cut down.

Such a quick turnover means that finding an evergreen on which to hang your baubles is hardly difficult. Trees are sold by garden centres, supermarkets, DIY stores, garage forecourts and even on the internet. The more dedicated tree shoppers can also visit the growers who allow customers to choose and dig up their own tree. But for all the increasing availability, knowing which variety to pick and how much to pay for it is another matter.

In Britain, the Norway spruce has always been the most popular species. It was, after all, Prince Albert's favourite. But the tree's habit of dropping its needles when brought into a heated room has prompted growers to plant hardier, if more expensive, varieties such as the Scots and lodgepole pine and the noble and nordmann fir. More exotic species are also creeping into our homes. This year, Number 10 will be decorated by a blue spruce instead of its more mundane Norway cousin.

As a rule of thumb, the bigger and rarer the tree, the pricier it is. An ordinary six foot Norway spruce will set you back between £12 and £15 if you buy it directly from the grower. But you can expect to pay up to £40 for a similar noble fir which does not drop its needles.

Buying a potted tree is also more expensive and will set you back at least £5 more than an equivalent cut tree. While it may last longer than a cut tree, potted trees are not necessarily any more alive and you may be disappointed if you plan to plant it in the garden come January.

If you want your tree to live and can afford to part with an extra £10, choose a variety that has been grown in a container rather than dug up and potted. Living trees tend to be bushier and more attractive because they have been grown in controlled conditions and not exposed to the ravages of the weather. However, you are unlikely to find anything over five foot in a container.

Nobody would dream of putting fresh flowers in a vase without any water. But many of us simply forget to water our Christmas trees. They may be big but they are just like any other plant. In fact, an average six foot tree will happily drink its way through a pint of water a day, especially if it is not potted. So it is best to check the stand several times a day.

If your tree is cut, it is a good idea to trim about half an inch off the end once you get home. When trees are cut, they tend to seal up so moisture is not lost. By slicing off the end you will help the tree soak up fresh water once you have brought it indoors.

Tree specialists also advise buyers not to take trees indoors straight away, especially if you have bought the plant directly from the grower. Christmas trees which have been living out in the cold will suffer shock if brought straight into a heated house. It is best to leave it in the garage overnight or propped against the side of the house so it has time to get used to the severe change in temperature.

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst: Boys' toys
fields.trailText: Boys' toys
fields.body:
Websites targeting men are sadly lacking in imagination; hawking a similar range of products - music and gadgets - and using the most garish of colours to grab the customer.

Firebox.com is the slickest of the lot. Choosing from its bachelor pad section, you can pick up shot glasses made of ice (pictured right), or a remote-control flying saucer. There's also the "sarcastic" prediction ball for egos strong enough to take a bashing. Think the Snow White mirror in a bad mood.

Big-boys-toys.net is also big on flash graphics and offers a 5% reduction if undersold. Its TV fish - a video of swimming goldfish - is a must-have for he who wants a low-maintenance pet. BoysStuff.co.uk , which is endorsed by Loaded magazine, is the easiest of the sites to navigate. Each section features one main item with specific links to the rest so there's no scrolling through page after page to find what you want. Check out Slam man. A mechanical punch bag in the shape of a torso, it is designed to improve the reflexes of martial arts enthusiasts. This is great for letting off steam and won't hit you back.

For the serious shopper, the "wow gifts" section of www.sfcody.com is the place to be. MIR CORP has assigned it the rights to sell trips to the space station itself. Only problem is it costs £20m. Never mind, there's always that tank-driving course.

Generally on the sites, postage is either free or competitively priced and delivery ranges from 24 hours to 10 days.

webTitle: Elton John makes £100,000 in four hours

fields.headline: Elton John makes £100,000 in four hours
fields.trailText: Sir Elton John opened a shop yesterday in London to sell off his clothes for charity and raised £100,000 in the first four hours. The shop on New Bond Street will only stay open until the 1,500 donated items are sold.
fields.body:
Sir Elton John opened a shop yesterday in London to sell off his clothes for charity and raised £100,000 in the first four hours. The shop on New Bond Street will only stay open until the 1,500 donated items are sold.

Spokesperson for the charity, John Kenny, expects most of the items will be gone by Saturday. The sale is timed to coincide with World Aids day on Friday. Money raised will go to the Elton John Aids foundation, which mainly funds projects overseas to help people living with HIV/Aids.

Outfits up for grabs include a black and luminous green panther-style Gianni Versace suit and a full length striped Jean-Paul Gaultier coat.

The sale, called Out Of The Closet III, is the third time the singer has opened a shop in London to sell his clothes. Sir Elton's partner, David Furnish, has also donated some of his unwanted items and the couple hope to exceed the £330,000 raised at the 1997 sale.

The Elton John Aids foundation, formed in 1992, is based in both London and Los Angeles. To date it has distributed more than $20m in grants.

Last year, the UK arm of the charity gave more than £2m to organisations working with people living with HIV/Aids. Three-quarters of its money goes to fund work in developing countries.

It supports projects and services ranging from education outreach programmes to early testing and treatment advocacy, buddy programmes, food banks, hospice care and adoption services for children orphaned by HIV or living with the condition.

fields.headline: Aids: South Africa's new apartheid
fields.standfirst: HIV spells death for the poor, while the rich buy drugs and survive. A special report on the eve of World Aids Day
fields.trailText: HIV spells death for the poor, while the rich buy drugs and survive. A special report on the eve of World Aids Day.
fields.body:
There are two kinds of Aids in South Africa. Sophy Nkabule has one type and she will soon die. Edwin Cameron has the other and he will most likely live for many years to come. The difference is cash.

Mrs Nkabule has lived her 32 years on the front line of brutal racial and economic segregation. Her home in Johannesburg's impoverished Alexandra township - part slum, part shanty town - looks out on Sandton City, a sprawling, opulent shopping mall prowled by wealthy whites.

The HIV-positive mother of three young children is going to die painfully, knowing that if she lived half-a-mile away in Sandton she would probably have the money to buy life. With cash, Mrs Nkabule could obtain the full array of anti-retroviral drugs available to HIV carriers in Britain. The medicines are not banned in South Africa, they are merely not distributed by the public health service because President Thabo Mbeki's government says it cannot afford them and their effectiveness is unproven.

The result, in the country with the highest number of HIV cases in the world, has been called "Aids apartheid".

"If you go to the clinic here they tell you they can give you some pills to make you feel better, but they tell us that we must brace ourselves to die because there is nothing they can do," Mrs Nkabule says.

"I don't understand it. Why do these white men who have sex with men get to live and I have to die? What will happen to my children when I am dead? Who will look after them - these men?"

Mrs Nkabule is talking about men such as Edwin Cameron, a judge of the supreme court of appeal. He is gay, white and HIV-positive. He is also wealthy enough to buy survival. Triple therapy costs about £400 a month - three times what most people in Alexandra earn.

Doctors estimate that just 10,000 people among the 4.2m HIV-positive South Africans can afford such treatment. Most of those who can are either white or among the new black elite.

Mr Cameron is acutely aware of the divide. In a speech earlier this year he lambasted governments and pharmaceutical companies for failing to develop a strategy to get life-saving drugs to the poor. "International agencies, national governments and especially those who have primary power to remedy the iniquity - the international drug companies - have failed us in the quest for accessible treatment," he said.

But while getting anti-Aids drugs to the poor is a problem across the globe, South Africa is the only country to refuse outright to provide anti-retrovirals as a treatment within its public health system. Uganda and Kenya have negotiated deals with the drug companies to bring down prices of medicines that directly tackle HIV. South Africa will not even bid for anti-retrovirals because President Mbeki has challenged their effectiveness and has controversially questioned the link between HIV and Aids.

Ignoring HIV
Instead, South Africa restricts itself to seeking deals on drugs that confront the symptoms of Aids, such as fungal infections, but not HIV itself.

The result is 50,000 children a year infected with the disease. On Friday, doctors from East London plan to hand a petition to the health ministry demanding that anti-retroviral drugs be provided to pregnant women.

"We are the medical professionals who care for the increasing number of children with HIV/Aids each day. Half of these cases could be prevented with cheap and safe anti-retroviral regimens - [costing] at the most 30 rand (£2.80)," a spokesman for the Group of Concerned Doctors said. "We cannot stand by and watch children die."

The ruling African National Congress accuses those who distribute anti-retrovirals, including the opposition-led provincial government in the Western Cape, of using black people as guinea pigs by giving them "dangerous and toxic drugs".

The South African government has not only been criticised for its refusal to buy anti-retrovirals. It is also under attack for banning the import of cheaper generic drugs to deal with Aids symptoms.

The health ministry says it is forced to buy more expensive medicines from the big drug manufacturers because of international patent agreements. Its critics say this is not true of other African countries, and that the government has a legal and moral right to buy the cheaper drugs.

The Treatment Action Campaign (Tac) has led the charge to get anti-retrovirals and other Aids-related drugs to the less well-off by illegally importing 3,000 generic drugs from Thailand and dumping them on the health ministry.

Tac has also appealed to the Medicines Control Council, which approves drugs for distribution in South Africa, to allow generic imports under a special provision. If that fails, it intends to bring in more cheap drugs illegally.

Risking arrest
"We risk arrest. That's not the ideal situation, but if you have to contest government policy and patent abuse by mounting a defence for illegal importation, it's one way of getting it into court," said Mark Heywood, a Tac director and its leading legal strategist. "Our objective is to get the government to get over its reluctance to use the powers it has and import generics. The second problem is to overcome its refusal to use anti-retrovirals as part of the public health battle against Aids."

One leading British charity has pro posed flying a planeload of generic drugs to Johannesburg and challenging the government to ban their distribution, in a symbolic act of defiance modelled on the aid flights to Iraq.

Perhaps Mrs Nkabule's best hope is a new strategy by South African and foreign doctors aimed at getting anti-retroviral drugs to about 750,000 people by using the profits generated by private medical treatment to fund drug supplies to the poor. The Right-to-Care scheme, backed by international medical groups, is hoping to do what the South African government will not - persuade the drug companies to provide treatments at lower costs.

webTitle: Chamberlain to present sports quiz on 5 Live

fields.headline: Chamberlain to present sports quiz on 5 Live
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: BBC Radio 5 Live has signed Helen Chamberlain from Sky Sports to front a new sports quiz show next summer, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC Radio 5 Live has signed Helen Chamberlain, co-presenter of Sky Sports' Soccer AM, to front a new sports quiz show next summer.

Hel's Bells 'n' Buzzers will feature 16 teams of sports fans from all parts of the UK testing their sporting knowledge.

Ms Chamberlain said: "I'm excited and chuffed to be joining the radio station that I've been listening to for years.

"As a football fan, 5 Live is always on in the car, in the bath and very often in the bedroom."

It is 5 Live's second big new signing in the past week, following Simon Mayo's move from Radio 1 to host the station's afternoon show.

Ms Chamberlain will also continue to work for Sky Sports.

webTitle: Straw appeals to public after 'evil' schoolboy murder

fields.headline: Straw appeals to public after 'evil' schoolboy murder
fields.standfirst: More about the Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, today appealed to the public to help the police track down the killers of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, today appealed to the public to help the police track down the killers of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor.

On a visit to the dead boy's school in Peckham, south east London, Mr Straw said that anyone with information about the murder had a responsibility to the community to come forward.

Damilola was left to bleed to death after being attacked by a group of 11 to 14-year-olds on his way home from school on Monday.

"We know young people and some adults and friends know exactly who killed Damilola Taylor," Mr Straw said.

Althea Smith, chair of the local police consultative committee, backed the home secretary's appeal.

"Someone is shielding these children. There are bloodstains on someone's clothes," she said.

Forensic experts are running tests on a knife discovered yesterday near the murder scene.

The knife was wrapped in a piece of cloth but there were no visible signs of blood.

Tests are also being run on a broken bottle found near the scene and detectives are examining CCTV footage.

Mr Straw described the death as "an awful evil" and acknowledged fears among the local community that it would be stigmatised as a result of the crime.

But he said he knew the area well and that it is full of "law abiding people" who want to get on with their lives.

"Someone said to me in the meeting that it is not the buildings that killed Damilola Taylor but some people," he said.

Mr Straw also heard parents' concerns about bullying. Damilola's mother, Gloria, has claimed the school did not take seriously her complaints that he was being bullied in the days before his murder.

She says that he wrote the name of one of his tormenters on a scrap of paper left in his locker, a clue that could provide the police with crucial evidence.

Headteacher Mark Parsons is certain that none of his pupils were responsible for the murder and said he was "immensely proud" of the school's anti-bullying policy.

Damilola staggered 100 yards with blood pouring from a sliced artery in his leg after being stabbed by a fleeing gang.

Nearby workmen tried to save him but other passersby ignored Damilola as he lay dying on a stairwell near his council home.

Police are hunting for three boys seen near the scene of the attack.

webTitle: Jonathan King remanded on sexual abuse charges

fields.headline: Jonathan King remanded on sexual abuse charges
fields.trailText: Pop impresario Jonathan King was remanded on bail when he appeared in court today accused of sexually abusing three boys in the 1970s.
fields.body:
Pop impresario Jonathan King was remanded on bail when he appeared in court today accused of sexually abusing three boys in the 1970s.

Mr King faces charges of buggery of a boy under 16, indecently assaulting a male, and attempting to bugger a male under 21.

The offences are alleged to have taken place between December 27 1970 and December 26 1971.

The 55-year-old record producer spoke only to confirm his name and address at the magistrates' court in Staines, Surrey.

The charges, which Mr King has publicly rejected as absurd, relate to three men who were boys at the time of the alleged offences.

Mr King, a bachelor, who was represented by Mr Ronald Thwaites QC, was appearing under his real name of Kenneth George King.

The chairman of the bench, Dr Mary Trimble, gave Mr King bail on condition that he should surrender all passports and did not contact any victims or witnesses.

Mr King, who was dressed in a black suit, white shirt, blue tie and trainers, was remanded to appear before the court again on January 2.

After the hearing, he was whisked away in a chauffeur-driven blue Mercedes and refused to comment.

The Cambridge university graduate, who discovered Genesis, became famous at the age of 21 when his hit single Everyone's Gone To The Moon became an overnight success, making him a millionaire.

fields.headline: Mystery remains over Chinook crash
fields.standfirst: 1994's Chinook crash over Mull of Kintyre contained some of Northern Ireland's top security staff. Where were they going and who sanctioned the flight? asks Derek Brown
fields.trailText: 1994's Chinook crash over Mull of Kintyre contained some of Northern Ireland's top security staff. Where were they going and who sanctioned the flight? asks Derek Brown.
fields.body:
There are many mysteries cloaking the crash of Zulu Delta 576, the RAF Chinook helicopter which slammed into the Mull of Kintyre on June 2 1994. But the most obvious one is mentioned the least.

How could the authorities have sanctioned a single flight carrying the cream of Northern Ireland's intelligence community?

Of the 29 who died that day, four were RAF crew. The remaining 25 knew all there was to know about security operations in Ireland. There were 10 senior RUC men on board including the head of special branch, Assistant Chief Constable Brian Fitzsimons. There were nine army intelligence officers and six MI5 agents.

18 minutes into their flight from Aldergrove, outside Belfast, to a security conference in Inverness, all were wiped out, and their secrets with them.

While there has never been any suggestion that the Chinook was sabotaged, there are some freakish theories about covert US military activities in the Kintyre area.

Controversy remains focused on the reliability of the aircraft's complex computer-aided avionics. In spite of the mechanical doubts, a report by air marshals Sir William Wratten and Sir John Day blamed the two young pilots, Jonathan Tapper and Rick Cook, calling them guilty of "gross negligence".

But what was the Inverness conference about that it justified packing the key members the security establishment into a single helicopter?

The meeting may have been planned to consider the security forces' response to the provisonal IRA's imminent ceasefire, of which there had been rumours for months. It was declared in August 1994, two months after the crash.

Successive governments have kept silent in the face of commons criticism and complaints from relatives of the pilots and the other victims.

When one widow took legal action which threatened to haul leading players into the witness stand, the government swiftly settled her compensation claim, reportedly paying out more than £500,000.

fields.headline: Head defends bullying record
fields.standfirst:
Parents fear for children after incidents
More about the Damilola Taylor case
Ofsted report: the Oliver Goldsmith primary school
fields.trailText: At Oliver Goldsmith primary school, news of the murder of Damilola Taylor, and the suggestion that the attack may have had its roots in playground bullying, provoked an angry reaction from parents.
fields.body:
At Oliver Goldsmith primary school, news of the murder of Damilola Taylor, and the suggestion that the attack may have had its roots in playground bullying, provoked an angry reaction from parents.

All day yesterday they queued to sign a petition calling for the school to take tougher action against bullies, but head Mark Parsons insisted he was "immensely proud" of his anti-bullying policy. "The vast majority of parents think I have a very strong line on bullying," he said. "I exclude a lot of children. I don't know how many but a lot - a lot more than the borough average. He rejected claims made by Damilola's mother that staff had failed to take reports of name calling seriously and added he was 100% satisfied that the death of the 10-year-old had nothing to do with the school. "The mum thought that I could deal with the stuff that led to his death but that was all about other people outside the school," he said.

He added that the type of behaviour the boy's mother had complained about would not have warranted serious punishment because he had not regarded it as bullying. However Jojo Kumi, 30, signing the petition outside the school, criticised Mr Parson's stance, saying: "When my son started he complained of being bullied. I sat down with the headmaster and he said it was just a minor problem. "It seems all bullying is a minor problem to him but every child reacts differently and what seems minor may be major to that child. I think he is running away from his responsibilities."

Asked when he first became aware that Damilola was being bullied at his 600-pupil primary school, Mr Parsons said: "If you mean when we actually called it bullying, that was when his mum came in. But the incidents she was calling bullying I had already dealt with before. "These were very low-level person to person slightly threatening behaviour. We are not talking physical violence in any sense. And there was name-calling and I also dealt with that. "Damilola had been here three months. In that time he had one argument with a child of equal size in his class, one little slight disagreement with a good friend of his and name calling. We are not talking about serious bullying here."

Outside the window, life seemed to go on as normal at the school with children wearing their maroon sweatshirt uniform. But the presence of two uniformed policemen alongside the children's regular supervisors gave a hint of the tragedy that had enveloped the whole estate.

fields.headline: Estate 'one of toughest in Europe'
fields.standfirst: More about the Damilola Taylor caseSpecial report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Community leaders yesterday admitted that the estate where Damilola lived and died suffers severe deprivation -but they insisted that huge efforts are being made to improve the situation.  Residents claim that for years the area has suffered from an acute lack of investment. Housing and shopping areas have fallen into neglect.
fields.body:
Community leaders yesterday admitted that the estate where Damilola lived and died suffers severe deprivation -but they insisted that huge efforts are being made to improve the situation. Residents claim that for years the area has suffered from an acute lack of investment. Housing and shopping areas have fallen into neglect.

Violence is common, drugs a massive problem and inter-gang rivalry a worrying feature. Many locals believe they struggle to get work because employers are put off by their address. Though the latest statistics show that crime in general is down in the London borough of Southwark, violent crime is up. There were 854 instances of violent crime in October - 54 more than in the same month last year.

The Bishop of Southwark, the Right Reverend Tom Butler, described the North Peckham estate as one of the toughest in Europe. But he said there was also cause for optimism that there could be a brighter future. He said: "There is a lot of effort going into that estate. A lot of people are doing a lot of things. I wouldn't want the people to be scarred by being told that they are living on the worst estate in Britain. Hopefully, things are changing there."

Southwark council began a major scheme to demolish 3,000 homes on four estates in the area and rebuild 2,000 new homes as part of a £260m project. So far 454 new homes for council tenants have been built. Damilola's home would have been included in the next phase of redevelopment. One resident said: "We're glad this is happening now but it's too late for Damilola. The council and the government have a lot of explaining to do. They've let this area become ruined."

Former government minister Harriet Harman, who is the local MP, said more work was still needed. She said: "I think it is about working together with the local community, the local council and the police to try to improve the physical environment and improve the opportunities for people to work. "That has been going on, that has been inching forwards. The local community has been shattered by this savage murder."

Superintendent Rod Jarman, Southwark's borough commander, rejected the portrayal of Peckham as a place of violence. He said: "Young people don't realise how dangerous weapons can be, and what can be a very minor injury can easily turn into death. That's a danger we need to get across to people carrying any weapon." Yesterday residents were begging photographers not to take pictures of the smashed up abandoned vehicles that litter the estate. One said: "We don't want it to appear any worse than it actually is". The home secretary, Jack Straw, is due to visit the estate tomorrow. Community leaders are bound to give him plenty of food for thought.

webTitle: 'My son is dead and I am bitter'

fields.headline: 'My son is dead and I am bitter'
fields.standfirst:
Mother says she wished family had never returned to UK
More about the Damilola Taylor case
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The mother of the 10-year-old boy who bled to death in a council estate stairwell admitted yesterday she was bitter about his murder, and wished that she had never brought her family to the UK.
fields.body:
The mother of the 10-year-old boy who bled to death in a council estate stairwell admitted yesterday she was bitter about his murder, and wished that she had never brought her family to the UK.

Gloria Taylor said the decision to move to London four months ago was only taken because her daughter Olugbemisola, 23, needed treatment for severe epilepsy that could not be provided in Nigeria.

The lifestyle the family enjoyed in Africa was far removed from the grim surroundings of the north Peckham estate in south London where they were placed last summer, and where her son, Damilola, was stabbed as he walked home from school on Monday.

"Before my daughter had this treatment in London she was so ill she couldn't even walk. Now she is much better. But I wish we had never come. My son is dead and I am bitter," said Mrs Taylor, 49.

The family had saved £5,000 over two years for the treatment at London's King's College hospital. In Nigeria, Damilola attended a private primary school and the family had a comfortable lifestyle, she added. "I decided I would bring my daughter over here but I could not leave my children alone. How could I leave my little son Damilola? So I brought him, my daughter and my other son Baba Tunde with me."

Damilola was stabbed in Blakes Road, Peckham, as he walked home on Monday evening. His femoral artery, which runs along the inside of the leg, was severed, causing massive and uncontrollable bleeding. He staggered 100 yards before collapsing in a concrete stairwell - 20 yards from a shop where he would have found help.

Detectives hunting his killers found a kitchen knife with cloth wrapped around the handle during an extensive search of the surrounding area yesterday.

Detective Superintendent David Dillnutt, who is leading the investigation, refused to say where the knife was found, but confirmed it was concealed.

This and a broken bottle found in the road close to where Damilola was attacked have been sent to the forensic science service for examination.

During a press conference at Scotland Yard, Mr Dillnutt said films from closed-circuit television cameras in the neigbourhood had been recovered, but that it could be some time before officers knew whether they would reveal vital clues.

Taunted

Some children at Oliver Goldsmith primary school, where Damilola had been studying for three months, have already given preliminary interviews to detectives, under the supervision of specialist counsellors.

Damilola had complained he was being taunted and bullied by pupils.

The prime suspects remain three youths who were spotted at the bottom of the stairwell by a man who discovered Damilola's body.

The boys, who were wearing hoods, ran away as the passerby cradled Damilola and tried to stop the bleeding.

Mr Dillnutt urged the youths, aged 11 to 14, to come forward.

"There is no firm motive for why Damilola was attacked," said Mr Dillnutt. "He could have been picked on. He could have been the victim of a robbery. He may have been the victim of a stranger attack.

"It is possible that he may have been attacked by children messing around with, unfortunately, tragic consequences.

"We appeal to children and parents who know anything about this murder to come forward."

He added: "This investigation is attracting the highest level of attention that is available. There will be no stone unturned, no avenue which is not explored."

Prince Bola Ajibola, the Nigerian high commissioner in London, said the country's President Olusegun Obasanjo had sent his condolences to the Taylors.

"The Nigerian government has tremendous confidence in the British legal system and believes that in time the law will take its normal course to find and arrest those involved in this gruesome act.

"Damilola came to the United Kingdom in search of a greener pasture only to be kiilled a brutal manner."

Although Damilola was born in Nigeria, his parents lived in London for 10 years in the late 1970s and early 1980s before emigrating.

"I can't believe how much Britain has changed since we left," Mrs Taylor said.

webTitle: Making a successful trust fund application

fields.headline: Making a successful trust fund application
fields.standfirst: Heather Swailes works for a charitable trust that has nearly £500,000 to give away and she explains what charities must do to secure some of the money
fields.trailText: There are more than 8,000 trusts and foundations in the UK and they give approximately £1.25bn in grants each year to charities. Heather Swailes works for the Allen Lane Foundation, which was set up in 1966 by the founder of Penguin Books to support general charitable causes. Its endowment has been valued at approximately £17 million. Swailes is the first person to see the thousands of applications that land on the doormat of their office in Bracknell.
fields.body:
There are more than 8,000 trusts and foundations in the UK and they give approximately £1.25bn in grants each year to charities. Heather Swailes works for the Allen Lane Foundation, which was set up in 1966 by the founder of Penguin Books to support general charitable causes. Its endowment has been valued at approximately £17 million. Swailes is the first person to see the thousands of applications that land on the doormat of their office in Bracknell.

She says the two most important factors for applicants to consider are identifying the appropriate trust and writing a good application. To find the right trust, use directories produced by the Directory of Social Change and the Charities Aid Foundation, or search the computer programme FunderFinder. Most libraries or councils for voluntary services will hold copies of these resources.

It might sound obvious, but check that a trust will fund charities in your area, that they wish to fund the kind of work your charity does and that they make grants of an appropriate size. "Don't ignore their funding exclusions - believe what they say!" warns Swailes. Once these criteria are met, she says, allow lots of time to write the application. "Do a draft, put it aside for a week and ask someone outside of the organisation to read it."

These are her top tips for a successful application:

 Tailor it to the trust you are applying to - don't do generic applications
 Write between two and four pages of A4, and include your annual reports and accounts
 Glossiness is not important, but legibility and accessibility are
 Use headings, boxes, and shading - anything to make your application more readable
 Try to say what you actually do - avoid jargon and don't use sophisticated language
 Ensure the first paragraph grabs attention, encapsulates what you do and explains why you need the money
 If what you are doing is at risk of being excluded, address this early on - for example, "We are part of a national organisation, but don't receive central funding"
 Make sure you answer the questions "who?", "what?", "why?", "when?" and "how?" in your application
 Be realistic with the budget - not too small, but not padded out
 Show you have thought about costings, but don't go into too much detail - four to five lines would be sufficient
 Don't ask for £4,999 if the maximum is £5,000 - it looks suspicious
 Make sure you include the name, telephone number and address of your organisation - "sounds obvious, but you'd be surprised"
 Ask for a specific amount of money
 End the application with your vision - write it with "fire in your belly"
 Include a paragraph about a case study demonstrating who will benefit from the money - "it brings it to life"
 Give referees, but don't name drop
 If you have received money from a local trust before, indicate this - it is a good sign
 Use the name of the administrator or correspondent - don't say "Dear Sir/Madam"

Once you have written the application, Swailes advises imagining you are a funder. Ask yourself:
 What is good about the application?
 What is not so good?
 Is there enough to interest me?
 Are there any gaps?
 What would I ask if I went on a visit to the organisation?

A few final words of advice. Swailes says: "Most of us don't want to be taken out to lunch - life isn't long enough."

If, after taking on board all of this advice, you are not successful, ring up to find out why. If you have no luck elsewhere, go back and try again. But if you are successful, remember to say thank you and keep trusts informed of how their money is being spent.

webTitle: Milligan's doodles get Xmas airing on BBC

fields.headline: Milligan's doodles get Xmas airing on BBC
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: Spike Milligan's crazy doodles are to be animated for the first time as part of the BBC's Christmas schedule, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Spike Milligan's crazy doodles are to be animated for the first time as part of the BBC's Christmas schedule.

Badjelly the Witch is the first hand-drawn animation by Ragdoll Productions, the company behind the Teletubbies.

The story features the adventures of two cartoon children, Jim and Rose, whose idyllic life is disturbed by Badjelly the Witch.

The programme was a co-production between Ragdoll and Milligan's agent, Norma Farnes Management, and features Mr Milligan's voice on most of the characters.

Liz Ellis, the line producer for the programme, said the story was "absolutely enchanting" and guaranteed that it had a happy ending.

She said that although Badjelly the Witch was a one-off, Ragdoll was hoping to capitalise on the phenomenal success of the Teletubbies and would sell it abroad.

fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: Jet Set Radio | Dino Crisis 2 | Shenmue
fields.byline: Steven Poole,  Jack Schofield and Andy Bodle
fields.body:
Jet Set Radio
Sega Dreamcast £39.99 Sega *****
Never has a comedy gang-warfare graffiti-spraying street-skating game looked this good. While the detailed, Crazy Taxi-style Tokyo city environments are built in standard "realistic" polygonal fashion, the lovable teen-tearaway characters are given heavy black outlines to resemble hand-drawn cartoon figures.

This "cel-shading" technique provides a glorious fusion of traditional anime style with high-powered computer rendering.

And it all moves beautifully.

Skating around bus stations, marinas or crowded nightlife hotspots, you "grind" on handrails and do tricks - à la Tony Hawk's Skateboarding, although the mechanics of the skating owe more to Nintendo's classic 1080 Snowboarding: very simple controls allowing fluid, almost balletic movement. You can hang on to the rear bumpers of cars to ride uphill, and jump and skid on to any available surface.

The object of each area is to cover buses, walls and cars with your gang's graffiti tag (you "spray" shapes with the analogue controller). This entails avoiding a hilarious force of baton-wielding cops, whose evil sergeant runs after you firing a gun. Later on, the police call in helicopter gunships and tanks. And you also have to deal with rival graffiti gangs who aim to cover your artwork with their own logos.

A soundtrack of pleasingly banging Japanese hip-hop is pumped via the city's local pirate radio station (hence the game's name), and there is even an onboard paint application for designing your own graffiti tags, which can then be uploaded to the Dreamarena website.

Occasionally the camera gets confused when you are in a tight spot, and there could have been a multiplayer option. But few games can boast such a strong, coherent design personality as Jet Set Radio. It is one of the freshest videogame ideas in a long while, and it is really, um, rad and phat. (SP)

Dino Crisis 2
Sony PlayStation £29.99 Capcom/Virgin ****
"You are food," say the TV ads and website for this game (see www.youarefood.com). Not quite. It is no fun being carried around in a dinosaur's jaws, but it doesn't swallow.

Actually, this game, descended from Capcom's Resident Evil, is for people who like killing, especially dinosaurs. At first it is annoying to have two or three pesky raptors leaping on you every time you move. Then you hit the first save point and find that you can buy really powerful weapons only in exchange for thousands of "extinction points", and a raptor is only worth 100. After that, you'd prefer they formed an orderly queue to get shot or slashed.

Clouds of blood fly up. The slaughter quickly becomes mechanical and is entirely tasteless.

Oh, I forgot the plot. You play a muscle-bound meathead called Dylan and a sharp, sexy redhead called Regina (but not at the same time). You make your way through the jungle and a military complex, do a bit of underwater work, collect files and find the keys to various doors. Presumably it all leads somewhere in the end.

The graphics are fabulous, and the game starts with stunningly cinematic intro .

But there are limitations. The camera hops about, leaving you vulnerable to off-screen raptors. Your character is sometimes very slow to aim. While there are different types of dinosaur, their movement patterns are repetitive. As a result, the game is less a matter of skill than endurance.

If you are addicted to run-and-shoot mayhem, this is a great buy. Non-addicts should borrow it. If you are any good, you will finish it in a weekend, and there's not much to provide replay value. (JS)

Shenmue
Sega Dreamcast £34.99 Take 2 Games ****
It is no understatement to call Shenmue one of the most eagerly awaited games of all time. A whispering campaign ensured that: "Did you know you can collect toys in the game and swap them over the net?" "Have you heard you can actually get a job?"

And every word of it is true. Shenmue is mind-boggling any way you look at it: in its beauty, its size, and its minutely observed detail. Every character - and there are hundreds - is unique, with his/her own voice, dialogue options, facial expressions, clothes and mannerisms. And if you go to the shops on Christmas Eve, they'll be playing festive Muzak.

The game opens with a cut scene in which a young Japanese man looks on as his father is murdered. As Ryo, you vow to hunt down those responsible. With little to go on, you set out from the house and start looking for clues.

But it's a big world out there, with a bewildering array of options. On any one day, add to your rip-off plastic toy collection, spar with your dad's pupil, listen to some tunes, feed the injured kitten down the road, go shopping, chat to the locals, go for a drink in the bar, hang with your buddy; play darts, pool, fruit machines, or, in the ultimate irony, kill a few hours at the local arcade.

You never feel completely comfortable engaging in any of this - you're supposed to be hellbent on revenge, after all - but the daily routines of your various leads and witnesses often leave you no choice.

Advancing the plot is a painstaking process - and a teensy bit dull. Tramp to and fro across town, talk to everyone, finally find someone with useful info, go on to X's house, find he's out, realise it's past 8pm and hurry home to avoid a ticking-off from grandma...

Because beneath the fantastically ornate trimmings, Shenmue is, essentially, a point-and-click adventure. Sure, it's a huge, detailed, sumptuous, epic point-and-click adventure with a bucket- load of sub-games, but as with your average sumptuous, epic movie, sometimes lacking in the action department. The neat-looking fights are so few and fast they feel like a game within the game.

Make no mistake, Shenmue is a grand vision superbly realised. As for whether you'll still be playing it in two months... I'll whisper it: nah. (AB)

fields.headline: BBC strikers threaten programme blackout
fields.standfirst:
Nov 30: World Service strike gathers pace
Nov 27: World Service dispute escalates
fields.trailText:
12pm: BBC technical staff are threatening to pull the plug on the National Lottery and Match of the Day as part of growing strike action, reports Jessica Hodgson
Nov 30: World Service strike gathers pace
Nov 27: World Service dispute escalates
fields.body:
BBC Grandstand, National Lottery Live and Match of the Day could be blacked out this weekend because of strike action.

Technical staff working for BBC Resources plan to down tools on Saturday in a dispute over redundancies.

It is the first strike since Greg Dyke took over as director general and comes as managers try to implement his plans to cull up to 1,000 posts from the corporation.

The move also comes just one week after the BBC World Service faced a strike over pay and conditions.

Bectu members will not work from midnight on Friday until midnight on Saturday in the first strike at Television Centre in over two years.

The union is protesting at the announcement by the BBC that it plans to make over 50 resources staff redundant across BBC Resources including all 40 studio managers, and close an outside broadcast unit at BBC Manchester.

A Bectu spokesman said the strike was designed to cause maximum damage to weekend programmes. "We'd like to think they won't go out," he said.

A spokeswoman for BBC Resources said that the BBC had "extensive plans in place to prevent disruption", but failed to rule it out.

She said that the BBC was "disappointed" at Bectu's determination to strike.

Bectu is also objecting to the BBC's refusal to pay transport costs to Resources staff and the policy of making OB management staff "act up" if supervisors are not at work.

webTitle: BreakingViews to charge for full site access

fields.headline: BreakingViews to charge for full site access
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Financial news website BreakingViews.com is to begin charging its subscribers after just four months, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Financial news website BreakingViews.com is to begin charging its subscribers just four months after launch.

Its controversial decision to limit the free service comes two weeks after the closure of rival TheStreet.co.uk.

In the daily email sent out to registered users, the website set up by former Financial Times Lex columist Hugo Dixon, informed users of its decision to add a new revenue stream.

From December 11, users will have to pay an annual fee of £500 to access all areas of the site, although limited access will still be available free of charge.

Registered users have been offered the chance to take up a subscription at a discounted annual rate of £200.

Explaining the reasons behind the change, spokesman Pete Pender-Cudlip, said it was always part of the plan and that the founders were convinced there was demand for "premium high-grade content".

He said: "The feedback we've had from the target audience [affluent decision-makers] is that it's a valuable service.

"There's a wealth of difference between what TheStreet tried to do - pumping out commodity news - and the451.com's niche news, and the crunchy financial comment a day ahead of Lex that BreakingViews.com provides."

BreakingViews.Com has yet to reveal registered user figures or figures for the number of page impressions. However, it claims to reach more than 1m readers through its offline commissions, such as the columns it writes for Wall Street Journal Europe, La Repubblica, La Tribune and Handelsblatt.

fields.headline: World Service strike gathers pace
fields.trailText: 8.15am: The strike at the BBC World Service could spread to other areas of the corporation's news operation, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The strike at the BBC World Service over nightshift pay and conditions could spread to other areas of the BBC news operation.

Broadcasting unions are understood to be preparing to ballot their members, following the industrial action that hit the World Service's English language service last weekend.

One union source said: "It's beginning to gather momentum."

He added that the World Service strikers had received messages of support from several other areas at the corporation.

World Service staff members belonging to Bectu and the NUJ are taking industrial action in a bid to secure better pay and a shorter working week for night shift workers.

Other areas with significant night shift working include the World Service foreign language service, BBC News Online, the radio news operation and BBC News 24.

Some of the BBC's biggest regional centres, such as Glasgow, could also get involved in the dispute, according to a union insider.

fields.headline: From country lane to catwalk
fields.standfirst: Seen the scarves? Hate the handbags and the wallpaper but just need to know why Kate Moss finds it fashionable? Print out and keep this guide to Burberry, the ragtrade's biggest marketing success story for years. By Jade Garrett.
fields.trailText:
What is its heritage?
The company has been trading since 1856. The tartan print came later in 1924.
fields.body:
What is its heritage?
The company has been trading since 1856. The tartan print came later in 1924.

Who used to wear it?
The Burberry trenchcoat was worn by Humphrey Bogart in Casablanca and Audrey Hepburn in Breakfast at Tiffany's. Otherwise the preserve of middle class Home Counties ladies and middle-aged City gents.

Who is wearing it now?
Burberry has become de rigeur among rock stars and royalty. Kate Moss, Meg Matthews, Nicole Appleton and even Prince William are all big fans of the Burberry beige. David Beckham has the "postman's" over-the-shoulder look while Victoria has been on TV wearing the scarf as a boob tube.

How did it become so fashionable?
Simple. The company hired super-woman Rose-Marie Bravo, the former Saks Fifth Avenue president, to revive the brand in 1997 and she quickly set about diversifying the brand and licensing it to luxury goods manufacturers everywhere.

What is the company worth today?
Burberry is the top performing division at parent company, Great Universal Stores. In the six months to the end of September, it produced pre-tax profits of £26.6m, up from £4.3m last year. Analysts have predicted the float could value the brand at between £1bn and £2bn. There are currently 57 stores trading under the company name. In addition, 33 licensees have been authorised to produce and market a wide range of products under the Burberry trade marks.

Where does Burberry feature today?
You name it, and the famous tartan is adorning it. From the original trench-coats and cardigans the pattern is now splashed across umbrellas, cosmetic ranges, spike-heeled boots, bandanas and hot water bottles. There is even a Burberry garter and a Silver Cross pram with Burberry lining.

What do the experts say?
"The renaissance of Burberry has been one of the most important fashion stories of the past year or so," says Jess Cartner-Morley, the Guardian's fashion editor.

"Like Gucci before it, Burberry was a label with fantastic brand recognition but a fusty image, which was turned into a must-have name by a combination of good design and canny marketing. The Burberry check is like the Nike tick - an instantly readable visual logo."

"The new challenge Burberry face is to hang on to their fashionable clientele now that the check itself has become a bit of a cliche with copies of it all over the high street the beige, red and black check is in serious danger of losing its crucial luxury appeal. The fashion-forward people who were fighting over the check bikinis in March wouldn't be seen dead in them now."

"The renaissance of Burberry has been one of the most important fashion stories of the past year or so," says Jess Cartner-Morley, the Guardian's fashion editor. "Like Gucci before it, Burberry was a label with fantastic brand recognition but a fusty image, which was turned into a must-have name by a combination of good design and canny marketing. The Burberry check is like the Nike tick - an instantly readable visual logo." "The new challenge Burberry face is to hang on to their fashionable clientele now that the check itself has become a bit of a cliche with copies of it all over the high street the beige, red and black check is in serious danger of losing its crucial luxury appeal. The fashion-forward people who were fighting over the check bikinis in March wouldn't be seen dead in them now."

webTitle: Chinook verdict 'a gross miscarriage of justice'

fields.headline: Chinook verdict 'a gross miscarriage of justice'
fields.standfirst: MPs condemn MoD over ruling blaming pilots for helicopter crash on Mull of Kintyre that killed 25 Northern Ireland intelligence officers
fields.trailText: MPs condemn MoD over ruling blaming pilots for helicopter crash on Mull of Kintyre that killed 25 Northern Ireland intelligence officers.
fields.body:
A ruling by two air marshals blaming the pilots for the Chinook helicopter crash on the Mull of Kintyre - the RAF's worst peacetime accident - is "unsustainable", a cross-party committee of MPs says today in one of the most damning attacks made on the integrity of a Whitehall department.The report will intensify pressure on ministers to overturn the verdict.

The Commons public accounts committee accuses the Ministry of Defence of "unwarrantable arrogance", employing "flawed logic" and adopting "incredible" and "shocking" aircraft test procedures.

David Davis, the committee's Conservative chairman, said last night: "In truth, we shall never know what happened on that fateful day at the Mull of Kintyre. But the evidence provided to the committee points quite clearly to a major miscarriage of national justice."

The report will boost an all-party coalition of MPs and others - including Sir Malcolm Rifkind, defence secretary at the time of the crash - who have long campaigned to get the verdict set aside.

Chinook ZD576 crashed into the Mull of Kintyre on June 2 1994, killing all 29 on board - the four air crew and 25 MI5, army, and RUC intelligence officers from Northern Ireland.

The pilots, Jonathan Tapper and Rick Cook, were sufficiently experienced and highly regarded to be given the status of flyers for the SAS.

A Scottish fatal accident inquiry under sheriff Sir Stephen Young concluded the cause of the crash could not be determined. An RAF board of inquiry concluded the accident had "many potential causes".

However, two air marshals, Sir William Wratten and Sir John Day, reviewed the board's conclusion and found the pilots guilty of "gross negligence", a verdict which had to pass the strict test of "no doubt whatsoever".

The committee says: "There are clear grounds for doubts in a number of areas." They relate mainly to the Chinook's Fadec computer software equipment which at the time of the crash was experiencing what the committee describes as "repeated and unexplained technical difficulties".

Technical data recovered from the wreckage was incomplete, the MPs add. The Chinook had neither cockpit voice nor accident data recorders - black boxes - despite recommendations from three previous RAF inquiry boards.

It is "incredible", adds the committee, that 175 serious anomalies were found in the software nine years after it was developed.

The MoD criticised testing techniques on the Chinook used its by own aeroplane and armament research establishment at Boscombe Down, the MPs note. Yet, they add, the MoD was prepared later to use identical techniques on other aircraft including the navy's Merlin helicopter.

The MoD's criticism of Boscombe is connected to its test pilots' decision - highly embarrassing to the ministry - to ground all test flights on the Chinook in June 1994, the month of the Mull crash. The tests did not resume for five months.

The MoD admits that after the crash it received 23 reports of Fadec-related faults. It says none were "flight safety critical" though it adds "some had safety implications".

But the MoD declined to give the MPs a full explanation of faults reported before the crash - including problems with warning lights, described by the committee as a "source of distraction for the crew". The MoD declined to give the information on grounds of the time the task would take and the costs involved.

The MPs accuse the two air marshals of "flawed logic" by selecting negligence as the most likely cause of the crash because none of the alternative explanations were strong enough. "The proper approach," they say, "should have been to reach a finding of gross negligence only if it could be positively ruled in."

The MPs note that the two air marshals were also responsible for managing Chinook operations and minimising their disruption, giving rise to a "perceived conflict of interest".

Sir William Wratten has retired, while Sir John Day is now a deputy chief of the defence staff. The RAF has changed the rules so boards of inquiry will no longer apportion blame for accidents, a change the committee welcomes.

"We regard the department's preference for the results of their own procedures as constituting unwarrantable arrogance," the committee concludes. "We simply cannot understand why the department continues to defend the unsustainable finding of gross negligence and recommend it should be set aside."

John Cook, father of Rick Cook and a former Concorde pilot, said last night he was delighted with the report. But he added: "The question is what notice, if any, the government takes of it. The MoD seems to think it is above the law."

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, dismissed the report, saying it provided no new evidence that would cast doubt on the integrity of the verdict. "There is clearly a good deal of material in the report but none of it constitutes new evidence," he said.

Faults, fears and accusation:

 The day before the crash, MoD test pilots suspended Chinook flight trials. One of the pilots, Jonathan Tapper, asked to fly an earlier model. The request was refused.

 In the three weeks before the crash, the Chinook which crashed suffered three software problems, one leading to an engine replacement.

 In the six months before the crash, Chinooks suffered a "series of problems" - many traced to software design and systems integration problems, according to an internal MoD report.

 Soon after the Chinook Mark 2 - the model that crashed - entered service in 1993, pilots reported serious software problems. Engines would cut out or suddenly run out of control.

 The Chinook was not fitted with voice recorders or acci-dent data recorders despite three recommendations by RAF boards of inquiry.

 The Scottish fatal accident inquiry and the investigating officers, including the president, of the RAF board of inquiry, were unable to determine the cause.

 Two air marshals, Sir William Wratten and Sir John Day, found the two pilots guilty of "gross negligence".

 "There are clear grounds for doubt," says the Commons public accounts committee.

webTitle: Burberry to float on stock market

fields.headline: Burberry to float on stock market
fields.trailText:
11.15am: Burberry is to be floated on the stock market since its successful repositioning as a must-have label, writes Jade Garrett.
From country walk to catwalk
fields.body:
It has been the most extraordinary turnaround for a fuddy-duddy fashion label.

And now, after winning the affection of Posh Spice, the Appletons and Japanese tourists everywhere, Burberry has announced it is to float on the stock market.

Parent company Great Universal Stores announced the decision to float after an phenomenonly successful marketing campaign has made it a must-have for the fashion-conscious.

Its recent marketing drive has transformed Burberry from a tired, old English gents' outfitters into the hottest fashion label in the land - worn by celebrities and fashion-conscious teenagers.

Older generations will remember its hallmark tartan fabric simply as an upmarket lining for overcoats.

But now the tan, black and red fabric is just about everywhere with Burberry scarves, bags and even wallpaper available on the high street.

The marketing department at GUS scored a coup earlier this year when it persuaded Kate Moss and royal Frederick Windsor to star in its brand relaunch campaign leading to a remarkable revival for Burberry.

They appeared as bride and groom, dressed head to toe in the distinctive print.

In a profits statement issued today, GUS announced it will sell off part of its holding in the brand within the next 18 months.

Burberry has proved the top performing division at GUS in the six months to the end of September, producing pre-tax profits of £26.6m, up from £4.3m year on year.

Analysts have predicted the float could value the brand at between £1bn and £2bn.

Burberry was forced to issue a statement this year, warning of the dangers of using its trademark print after a spate of appearances on the catwalks from London to New York.

fields.headline: techMARK 100 tumbles to new low
fields.trailText: The FTSE techMARK 100 index fell to another low this morning, as the values of tech shares continued to tumble in Europe and the US.
fields.body:
The FTSE techMARK 100 index fell to another low this morning, as the values of tech shares continued to tumble in Europe and the US.

The index, which was launched by the Chancellor Gordon Brown on 3 November last year, consists of over 240 companies in the technology and telecoms sectors.

In the first three hours of trading this morning, the index fell steeply to a low of 2,405.00 - below the previous closing low of 2,421.13, achieved on only its second day - although it rallied later to reach 2432.11 after 2pm.

Yesterday in the US, the tech-based Nasdaq Composite Index had closed at its lowest value since October 1999.
