webTitle: View from Japan: Japan's state executions 'obscure and arbritrary'

fields.headline: Japan's state executions 'obscure and arbritrary'
fields.standfirst: While officials argue the merits of the death penalty, the number of executions surges, writes Jonathan Watts in Tokyo
fields.trailText: While officials argue the merits of the death penalty, the number of executions surges, writes Jonathan Watts in Tokyo.
fields.body:
The hanging season came early in Japan this year, though no one will ever know whether that was a surprise to the three men executed by the state yesterday.

As is the case around this time every year, the executions of Kiyotaka Fujiwara, 52, Takashi Miyawaki, 57, in Nagoya and Kunikatsu Oishi, 55, in Fukuoka were carried out under a veil of secrecy.

The only official statement by the justice ministry was a single-line confirmation that three men had been hanged. Their names, as always, were leaked to the press rather than being disclosed publicly.

According to human rights groups, condemned men are only told of their fate as they are being led from their cells 30 minutes to an hour before the executions. Their families are given no advance warning and no opportunity for a final farewell.

Often the first the families hear of the executions is when they are instructed to collect the bodies. Even for convicted multiple murderers - practically the only crime punishable by death in Japan - this seems inexplicably callous and secretive.

Defenders say that withholding information is necessary to spare the condemned men's families from anxiety and public shame but the government has never explained its rationale.

Capital punishment remains the biggest secret in Japan, where three to six people are hanged each year. The justice ministry has never explained how it decides who to execute or when.

Past cases suggest that is it not based on age, time on death row or the process of appeal. No one is even sure how many people have been hanged since the war or the numbers of those currently on death row.

Amnesty slams the system as obscure and arbitrary. It argues that men awaiting execution are left to rot for decades. Because they have fewer rights than other prisoners, their treatment is left to the whim of governors of detention centres.

The human rights group also complains that the process of appeal against the death penalty is vague. This is a worrying accusation in Japan, where the potential for a miscarriage of justice is amplified by the fact that suspects can be held without being charged for almost a month, most prosecutions are based on confessions, there are no juries and 99% of criminal cases brought to court end in a guilty verdict.

Such criticism prompted Japan to call a moratorium on executions between 1989 and 1993, when the post of justice minister, the official who must put his seal on hanging orders, was held by critics of the death penalty.

As crime has risen in the past seven years, however, the government has set about emptying the cells on death row with new vigour. Thirty-nine men have been hanged since 1993, nearly four times as many as in the seven previous years.

Usually the executions take place during the summer and winter holidays when they attract little public attention and parliament is in recess. But this winter the hangings have come several weeks earlier than usual, prompting suspicions that they have been rushed ahead of a forthcoming cabinet reshuffle.

"The timing is clearly politically motivated," said a statement by a coalition of groups against the death penalty. "The government is worried that the justice minister in the next cabinet may favour a new moratorium."

This is not just wild speculation. Due to the unpopularity of prime minister Yoshiro Mori and splits within his Liberal Democratic Party, the ruling coalition is increasingly reliant on the support of the New Komei party which is in favour of scrapping the death penalty.

Reducing the sentences of the men on death row would not go down well with the electorate. In opinion polls last year, 80% of respondents supported hanging, compared to 10% opposed. This number has grown since the Aum Supreme Truth cult carried out a poison gas attack on the Tokyo subway system in 1995, which killed 12 and seriously affected thousands of others.

Seven members of the cult have been given the death penalty and the guru, who is still on trial, is expected to receive the same sentence. Despite this mood MPs plan to use this year's early executions as a rare opportunity to speak out in parliament against capital punishment.

"Politicians in Britain and France abolished the death penalty in the face of hostile public opinion and we should do the same," said Nobuto Hosaka, a leading opponent of hanging. "It's about time Japan moved in line with international trends on human rights."

It is unlikely that his appeal will halt the executions, but it will at least turn the spotlight - albeit for a short time - on one of the darkest areas of Japanese justice.

fields.headline: Redknapp attacks 'crooked' work permit system
fields.trailText: West Ham manager Harry Redknapp has attacked the work permit system as "crooked" after a lengthy delay to Hayden Foxe's move to Upton Park.
fields.body:
West Ham manager Harry Redknapp has attacked the work permit system as "crooked" after a lengthy delay to Hayden Foxe's move to Upton Park.

Redknapp is struggling to get a work permit for Australian international Foxe, who hasn't played the recommended 75 per cent of games for his country during the last two years because of a foot injury.

But despite two appeals by West Ham against the rejection of his work permit, Redknapp is not giving up the fight.

He said: "It's a scandal and a disgrace that we haven't got it yet but I will take it to court - or anywhere I have got to take it. The whole system is crooked and it's all about who you know and who can pull the strings."

The Hammers are determined to get their man and have hired the services of an immigration consultant in a bid to get the outcome they want.

Redknapp continued: "I'm not going to let this one die. He's Australian; he's in the Commonwealth. They fought the war with us. I know that might sound like bollocks to you but we let foreign people in who have no allegiance to the country."

He continued: "I've got so much faith in Foxe - I've offered him a fabulous four-year contract on good money."

Redknapp is unhappy that American Olympic midfielder Ben Olsen - who scored for Nottingham Forest last night in their win over Sheffield United - was given permission to join the First Division club on loan on the day Foxe's bid to join the Hammers was turned down.

He added: "Forest got a player in on loan and Wrexham have got tuppence-halfpenny players from abroad. And how did Brad Friedel get a work permit when he wasn't even allowed in the country originally?"

However the Department for Education and Employment disputes Redknapp's claims. A DfEE spokesman said: "The work permit rules are clear and transparent.

"International teams must be in the top 70 of Fifa's rankings and the player must have played in 75% of the international side's matches in the previous two years.

"If these clear criteria are not met there is an independent review procedure to consider additional evidence. There is no question that the system is other than fair and just."

A DfEE spokesman said: "The work permit rules are clear and transparent. "International teams must be in the top 70 of Fifa's rankings and the player must have played in 75% of the international side's matches in the previous two years. "If these clear criteria are not met there is an independent review procedure to consider additional evidence. There is no question that the system is other than fair and just."

webTitle: Casting news: Brad Pitt to wear chef's hat

fields.headline: Casting news: Brad Pitt to wear chef's hat
fields.standfirst: Plus: Candice Bergen and Rob Lowe take flight in star-packed comedy; Forest Whitaker signs up for Joel Schumacher's latest
fields.trailText: Plus: Candice Bergen and Rob Lowe take flight in star-packed comedy; Forest Whitaker signs up for Joel Schumacher's latest
fields.body:
 Having excelled as an incomprehensible Irish gypsy in Guy Ritchie's Snatch, Brad Pitt (pictured) is to take on a similarly left-field role when he plays a temperamental New York chef in the black comedy, Seared. A tell-all satire about the restaurant industry, the film is based on the book, Kitchen Confidential, by American chef Anthony Bourdain.

 Just one day after Gwyneth Paltrow and Kelly Preston boarded the air-stewardess comedy, A View from the Top, other actors are clamouring to join them - and hitch a ride on the comeback trail. Candice Bergen is to play a retired flight attendant, while Rob Lowe will take a support slot as a boorish co-pilot. The seats are almost filled for the Miramax feature, which begins shooting next month. But one all-important slot has yet to be filled: the role of the airline pilot who Paltrow and Preston squabble over. The makers are reportedly attempting to snare John Cusack for the role.

 Ghost Dog star Forest Whitaker has signed on to play a tough New York cop in the experimental Fox thriller, Phone Booth, which Joel Schumacher begins shooting next month. Played out in real time, the film charts the experiences of an everyman hero trapped in a phone box by a sniper who is targeting him from a nearby building. The phone booth hostage will be played by Colin Farrell, the Irish actor who has won raves for his role in Shumacher's Tigerland,.

fields.headline: LineOne up for sale
fields.trailText: 12.30pm BT and United News & Media have finally admitted their LineOne internet service provider is up for sale, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
BT and United News & Media have finally admitted their LineOne internet service provider is up for sale.

Following months of speculation, the co-owners said in a statement that the company would be better off under a new proprietor.

"Both owners are refocusing their businesses, and LineOne no longer fits with either company's plans.

"They believe that LineOne's continued growth and ambitious development intentions would be better served under a new owner," said the statement.

BT and United are undergoing extensive restructuring, and it was an open secret that LineOne was to be hived off.

BT is committed to reducing its £30bn debt burden, while United is transforming itself from a multi-media player into a business information company.

However, turbulent market conditions for technology stocks will make a successful sale difficult. Shares are the normal currency for such deals, but negative market sentiment has reduced the share value of all the potential bidders.

Analysts say LineOne is worth around £400m.

Nick Bubb, internet analyst at SG Securities, said: "A sale could be complicated by the fact that other companies, such as Freeserve, are up for grabs.

"LineOne is not a bad company, but it does not have the size of Freeserve. However, there are a lot of companies interested in the UK market and not all of them can buy Freeserve."

LineOne has broken into the top five of UK ISPs since its launch in 1997, with more than 1.4m subscribers and over 1m unique visitors per month.

webTitle: Middle England or bust for Desmond

fields.headline: Middle England or bust for Desmond
fields.standfirst: Sagittarian Richard Desmond may have galloped away with the Express, but his success depends on not riding roughshod over the paper's traditions, writes Maggie Hyde.
fields.trailText: Sagittarian Richard Desmond may have galloped away with the Express, but his success depends on not riding roughshod over the paper's traditions, writes Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
At first sight, it's a puzzle why the world of the Express should be so dominated by the slow, earthy Taurean Bull.

The paper itself has the Sun in Taurus (April 24 1900), like its arch-rival the Mail (May 4 1896). Its editor Rosie Boycott is a Taurus (May 13 1951), and so is its last proprietor, Lord Hollick (May 20 1945).

Now it has been sold to Richard Desmond's company, Northern & Shell, another Sun in Taurus (May 7 1982).

Apart from the temptation to write all this off as a load of bull, the Taurus symbolism is a reminder that despite the speedy Geminian turnover of news and opinion, a newspaper's success depends on Taurean endurance and a firm base of Taurean capital and resources.

Northern & Shell has a striking horoscope on two counts. Neptune, the fantasy planet, was rising at its incorporation.

This is the symbol of celebrity, glamour and image, perfect for soft porn and OK! magazine but 180 degrees opposite the Express's Neptune, suggesting a foggy mismatch of divergent visions.

Despite the shared Taurus, Northern & Shell's bewitching Moon in sexy Scorpio is exactly opposite the Express' Sun.

This is a further indicator of the clash of spirit between the corporate vision of Big Ones International and the values of middle England.

So far, it is not obvious that Richard Desmond can handle these contradictions. He has none of the stability, endurance or wealth characteristic of Taurus.

Desmond is a lusty Sagittarian (December 8 1951), half-man and half-horse, and his horoscope bursts with extravagant, entrepreneurial fire. His reputation as coarse and boastful smacks of the worst side of the Sagittarian gambler and empire builder.

Astrologer Charles Carter says of the 'primitive' Sagittarian type: "There may be extravagance, carelessness over detail, waste, exaggeration, too great faith in luck, superficiality, a tendency to know a little of everything but all of nothing, with sudden crazes for people, intellectual interests and hobbies, which blaze up and die away, and also a certain degree of loudness and vulgarity."

Primitive Sagittarian clown he may appear to be, but Desmond is no fool. His Jupiter is conjunct the Express' Mercury, planet of communication, and this bears out the obvious possibility that he desires the paper for political status and a voice of power. So if he wants the Express to work, despite his fiery ego, he is unlikely to pepper it with Asian Babes.

The Express' horoscope looks better than might be expected with signs of a turnaround after summer 2002, but the big question raised by the astrology is how long its new owner will stay. His restless Sagittarian Sun enjoys the thrill of the hunt but transform-or-bust Pluto threatens to stop his game in the coming year.

If he has enough savvy to know that he has stepped into a different league, Desmond could produce an amazing rebirth, but only if he works WITH the paper's existing journalistic traditions, and not against them.

He could equally surprise everyone by galloping off with the Daily Star and selling on the Express. Watch for make-or-break moves next March.

fields.headline: In brief: taxman tracks down Travolta
fields.standfirst: Plus: Jack Lemmon honoured for half a century of classic films; rumours continue about a Madonna-Guy Ritchie wedding; Sean Connery banishes British reporters from film premiere; and Russell Crowe lets the music speak
fields.trailText: Plus: Jack Lemmon honoured for half a century of classic films; rumours continue about a Madonna-Guy Ritchie wedding; Sean Connery banishes British reporters from film premiere; and Russell Crowe lets the music speak
fields.body:
 Nabbed by the taxman, John Travolta (pictured) has agreed to pay $607,400 (£427,235) in back taxes dating back to 1993-1995, a period of comparative slump for the star of Saturday Night Fever and Pulp Fiction. Travolta admits that he may have short-changed Uncle Sam, but in the event he seems to have got off lightly as the IRS was originally demanding some £1.1m (£773.000) in back taxes and penalties.

 Jack Lemmon received the Spencer Tracy Award for Dramatic Achievement in a Tuesday night ceremony at the University of California in Los Angeles. The award was an acknowledgement of a fifty-year career that has included roles in such classic films as Some Like it Hot, The Apartment, Save the Tiger, The China Syndrome and Short Cuts. Lemmon, now 75, said he was honoured to be given an award named after his all-time favourite actor.

 Rumours continue to swirl like confetti over the possibility of a second marriage for Madonna. According to the gossip column in Wednesday's Sun, the singer-actress is planning to wed British director Guy Ritchie in a ceremony on December 22 at Domock Cathedral in Scotland. Expect the paparazzi to be already setting up camp outside.

 Home-grown reporters will certainly have more luck with born-again Brit, Madonna, than Scotland's favourite son, Sean Connery, who has reportedly asked Columbia Pictures to ensure that they are banned from attending next week's LA premiere of his new film, Finding Forester. "Sean has flat-out refused to have British journalists in the line-up," says a source at Columbia. "He just doesn't like the British press."

 Connery could perhaps take a leaf out of Russell Crowe's book and convert his anger into sweet music. The star of Gladiator has written a song for his rock band, 30 Odd Foot of Grunts, which takes aim at what Russ clearly regards as a corrosive and evil press. Entitled The Photograph Kills, the lyrics run like this: "Don't stand up, they'll try to push you down/Don't let them hold you in their hands/And they'll feed you while you lie bleeding on the ground/The photograph kills and your fame will destroy you" The ditty then builds to its devastating pay-off: "Don't let them mould you to their plans/Don't step into the glare of the flash-bulb lighting." To which one might add yet another "don't". Don't give up the day job, Russ.

fields.headline: The name's Putin, Vladimir Putin
fields.standfirst: As far as Russia's thirtysomething women are concerned, President Vladimir Putin is a wanted man. Ian Traynor on an unlikely sex object
fields.trailText: As far as Russia's thirtysomething women are concerned, President Vladimir Putin is a wanted man. Ian Traynor on an unlikely sex object.
fields.body:
Running at 70% in the opinion polls, with a supine parliament about to put him beyond the reach of the law, and spraying foreign policy initiatives into the vacuum left by America's political uncertainty, President Vladimir Putin could be forgiven for feeling that fortune is smiling on him.

As he approaches the one-year mark in the Kremlin, Mr Putin's good fortune was compounded this week when the president of Russia's judo federation, Vladimir Shestakov, piped-up to comment that the black-belt president was in such good shape at the age of 48 that he could still occupy a place in Russia's Olympic team.

What's more, for thirtysomething women, VVP, as he is commonly known, is the sexiest man in Russia.

According to a poll conducted by a Moscow newspaper this week, Mr Putin outstrips the film stars, TV personalities, pop singers, and other celebrities in his sex appeal. Sexy politicians are not exactly thick on the ground in Russia.

If power and money are aphrodisiacs everywhere, the cruel geriatrics who ran the Kremlin for much of the 20th century remained less than attractive to Russian women.

Mikhail Gorbachev had charisma and a charming wife, but his appeal was avuncular. Boris Yeltsin, too, acquired the appeal of the erratic, forgetful grandfather.

But Vladimir Putin, according to the newspaper, is virtually unique among Russian politicians in being seen as a sex object.

''He doesn't smoke, he doesn't drink, he's into sport, he loves his wife and kids. What more do you want?'' Anna, 30, told the newspaper.

Others detailed their erotic fantasies about the former KGB colonel and confessed that they dreamt of sleeping with the president.

Only last week, Mr Putin surprised the Russian and British press by quipping, a propos of his get-together with Tony Blair in a Moscow pub, that in male company Russian men talked about women.

According to Komsomolskaya Pravda, Russian women not only talk about, but dream about VVP. If the image of the steely, creepy secret policeman is cause for suspicion of Mr Putin in the west, it seems to be part of his appeal to Russian women who buy the spin-doctored version of a less flamboyant, Russian-style James Bond.

''I've been in love with intelligence agents since I was a child,'' confessed Vika, 32. ''The KGB is so romantic - men in black suits, listening devices, impassionate faces, epaulettes. The president has an iron hand inside a velvet glove.

''Even when Putin is shaking someone's hand on television with a little smile to show that he is human, I am frightened of him - in other words I want him.

"Danger and sex always go together... Putin is like a glass of 12-year-old whisky.''

The top ten sex symbols listed for Russian women predictably include sports stars, singers, actors, and TV personalities. Perhaps the bad news for Mr Putin is that the only other politician who makes it to the top ten is the lager lout of the Russian parliament, Vladimir Zhirinovsky.

He is the loudmouth, extremist clown of Russian politics, the opposite of Mr Putin's sober and severe public image.

Writing in Komsomolskaya Pravda, Darya Aslamova reveals: ''I dream of Putin at night. Black-and-white and handsome like the intelligence agent in the old Soviet cinema.''

The nostalgia for the old days of Soviet superpower is a common thread in the fantasies of Mr Putin. President Boris Yeltsin destroyed the Soviet Union and communism.

President Vladimir Putin plays with that nostalgia, deliberately and probably genuinely ambivalent about the so-called Soviet glory days, and constantly pledges to restore a semblance of that past power.

''To be honest,'' Ms Aslamova goes on, ''I thought it was only me who was licensed for the nocturnal rendezvous with Putin... So I was a bit jealous when I asked my friends - all over 30 - and found out that they all had had sex with the president in their dreams.''

The Kremlin spin doctors could not have done a better job in maintaining those 70% ratings.

webTitle: Photography gives HIV-positive women enthusiasm for life

fields.headline: Photography gives HIV-positive women enthusiasm for life
fields.standfirst: Previously abandoned HIV-positive women are being trained in photography techniques in the Congo, writes Susan Roberts of Christian Aid
fields.trailText: Previously abandoned HIV-positive women are being trained in photography techniques in the Congo, writes Susan Roberts of Christian Aid
fields.body:
Abandoned by the rest of her family, the woman slept on a dirt floor in her sister's house. Too weak to stand, she crawled on her hands and knees to the most basic of toilets. Food mouldered on plates around her. Even those close to her, feared infection through touching her or sharing utensils. She used to be a wealthy and attractive woman until she lost everything when she learned she was HIV-positive.

"It pained us to see it," says Bernadette Mulelebwe, director of Fondation Femme Plus (FFP), an organisation dedicated to helping HIV-positive women in the Congo. "We took her away to a centre."

Bernadette and others from FFP looked after the woman until she died. After her death, they asked her sister to come and bury the body, but she refused. No one from her family wanted to help. In the end, FFP bought a coffin and arranged a decent funeral. A young man at the cemetery was moved to tears to see the group of mourning women arrive and offered to carry the coffin. "That was our first time in the cemetery," says Bernadette. "That was the first experience which was followed by many others." FFP, which is supported by Christian Aid, did exactly what a family would normally do in such circumstances. Sadly, it is exactly what many families are not doing in the Congo. There is minimal funding for health services in the country, impoverished after years of war. People with HIV/Aids are ostracised, rejected and isolated. Many Aids widows sleep on the streets and in churches with their children. The number of Aids orphans is rising dramatically - and now stands an estimated 800,000. Organisations like FFP play a vital role in providing support services.

FFP's work will gain an international profile this week with the opening of Positive Negatives, a photographic exhibition in London. Pictures taken by FFP women, given training by Christian Aid to become photographers, went on display at the Africa Centre in Covent Garden.

Bernadette, who travelled to the UK for the exhibition with one of the photographers, reflects that FFP has come a long way from its beginnings six years ago. A social worker, she was in daily contact with women with HIV/Aids and saw an urgent need to do something to help. She and a few friends started to meet every Saturday, bringing food to share and talking as they ate.

"People brought something to eat, rice, fish, oil We were cooking, chatting. We said, well. 'Who has a story to share with us about Aids?' And then someone began to speak. And then we said 'Who can say something to our friend who has just told her story?' It helped people open up, simply to know that they were not alone."

Gradually, women became more open about speaking about HIV/Aids. Hearing others' stories, they began to realise that they were not alone and gained a measure of confidence and self-respect. "They realised that they should be strong, for themselves and for their children. The objective was to help them live positively and not to hide," Bernadette comments. "They had so many negative thoughts." Now, more than 1,200 women belong to FFP and the organisation has branches in other parts of the Congo. It provides basic medical care, runs a sewing workshop and owns rice fields where members can work and raise crops. Two years ago, it started a restaurant in Kinshasa, which has become a popular meeting place.

The Christian Aid photographic project has given its work a new dimension. Christian Aid wanted to help the women earn money through a new skill - but also a chance to express just how they felt about HIV/Aids. The UK-based training agency PhotoVoice provided two blocks of training for 15 women in Kinshasa, some of whom had never used a camera before. They started off with simple equipment, learning about theory and basic technique. The change in their appearance and morale was immediate, says Bernadette.

"I have never seen such a change from one day to the next," she comments. "At first they came dressed in their everyday clothes. Then the next day, they had changed; they took care with their hair. Women who had been coming to the centre for medical attention suddenly needed it less frequently."

Anna Blackman of PhotoVoice, who spent a total 12 weeks in Kinshasa, said that the women's attitude to the project inspired her.

"It was amazing. They all made such an effort even if they had to walk two hours, change buses three times and walk to the centre," she comments. "More than anything, they are some of the strongest women I have met anywhere. They're so proud to be learning photography. They just haven't given up in any way at all. "

Gabrielle, a former television presenter who travelled to London for Positive Negatives, found that she was HIV-positive two years ago. Her husband died of an Aids-related illness in August. She says that the training gave her a new reason for live.

"It was beneficial for all of us because it gave us a means of working honourably. I had fallen very low. No one would shake hands with me. No one would look at me."

Gabrielle's photographs show children, as young as four, sleeping in a huddle on a street in Kinshasa. A woman, gravely ill, lies on the most basic of hospital beds as her young son crouches beside her, because there is no one else to care for him. These were not easy images to take, she reflects. But it was necessary to face up to them, so that others could learn about the tragedy of HIV/Aids in Africa.

"We had to educate people," she comments. "We had to take those photos. We must help others who have need of us."

 Positive Negatives can be seen at the Africa Centre, 38 King St, Covent Garden, London until December 15. The centre is open from 9:30am to 5:30pm, Monday to Friday and from 11am to 6pm on Saturday, December 2 and 10.
fields.bodyText: Abandoned by the rest of her family, the woman slept on a dirt floor in her sister's house. Too weak to stand, she crawled on her hands and knees to the most basic of toilets. Food mouldered on plates around her. Even those close to her, feared infection through touching her or sharing utensils. She used to be a wealthy and attractive woman until she lost everything when she learned she was HIV-positive. "It pained us to see it," says Bernadette Mulelebwe, director of Fondation Femme Plus (FFP), an organisation dedicated to helping HIV-positive women in the Congo. "We took her away to a centre." Bernadette and others from FFP looked after the woman until she died. After her death, they asked her sister to come and bury the body, but she refused. No one from her family wanted to help. In the end, FFP bought a coffin and arranged a decent funeral. A young man at the cemetery was moved to tears to see the group of mourning women arrive and offered to carry the coffin. "That was our first time in the cemetery," says Bernadette. "That was the first experience which was followed by many others." FFP, which is supported by Christian Aid, did exactly what a family would normally do in such circumstances. Sadly, it is exactly what many families are not doing in the Congo. There is minimal funding for health services in the country, impoverished after years of war. People with HIV/Aids are ostracised, rejected and isolated. Many Aids widows sleep on the streets and in churches with their children. The number of Aids orphans is rising dramatically - and now stands an estimated 800,000. Organisations like FFP play a vital role in providing support services. FFP's work will gain an international profile this week with the opening of Positive Negatives, a photographic exhibition in London. Pictures taken by FFP women, given training by Christian Aid to become photographers, went on display at the Africa Centre in Covent Garden. Bernadette, who travelled to the UK for the exhibition with one of the photographers, reflects that FFP has come a long way from its beginnings six years ago. A social worker, she was in daily contact with women with HIV/Aids and saw an urgent need to do something to help. She and a few friends started to meet every Saturday, bringing food to share and talking as they ate. "People brought something to eat, rice, fish, oil We were cooking, chatting. We said, well. 'Who has a story to share with us about Aids?' And then someone began to speak. And then we said 'Who can say something to our friend who has just told her story?' It helped people open up, simply to know that they were not alone." Gradually, women became more open about speaking about HIV/Aids. Hearing others' stories, they began to realise that they were not alone and gained a measure of confidence and self-respect. "They realised that they should be strong, for themselves and for their children. The objective was to help them live positively and not to hide," Bernadette comments. "They had so many negative thoughts." Now, more than 1,200 women belong to FFP and the organisation has branches in other parts of the Congo. It provides basic medical care, runs a sewing workshop and owns rice fields where members can work and raise crops. Two years ago, it started a restaurant in Kinshasa, which has become a popular meeting place. The Christian Aid photographic project has given its work a new dimension. Christian Aid wanted to help the women earn money through a new skill - but also a chance to express just how they felt about HIV/Aids. The UK-based training agency PhotoVoice provided two blocks of training for 15 women in Kinshasa, some of whom had never used a camera before. They started off with simple equipment, learning about theory and basic technique. The change in their appearance and morale was immediate, says Bernadette. "I have never seen such a change from one day to the next," she comments. "At first they came dressed in their everyday clothes. Then the next day, they had changed; they took care with their hair. Women who had been coming to the centre for medical attention suddenly needed it less frequently." Anna Blackman of PhotoVoice, who spent a total 12 weeks in Kinshasa, said that the women's attitude to the project inspired her. "It was amazing. They all made such an effort even if they had to walk two hours, change buses three times and walk to the centre," she comments. "More than anything, they are some of the strongest women I have met anywhere. They're so proud to be learning photography. They just haven't given up in any way at all. " Gabrielle, a former television presenter who travelled to London for Positive Negatives, found that she was HIV-positive two years ago. Her husband died of an Aids-related illness in August. She says that the training gave her a new reason for live. "It was beneficial for all of us because it gave us a means of working honourably. I had fallen very low. No one would shake hands with me. No one would look at me." Gabrielle's photographs show children, as young as four, sleeping in a huddle on a street in Kinshasa. A woman, gravely ill, lies on the most basic of hospital beds as her young son crouches beside her, because there is no one else to care for him. These were not easy images to take, she reflects. But it was necessary to face up to them, so that others could learn about the tragedy of HIV/Aids in Africa. "We had to educate people," she comments. "We had to take those photos. We must help others who have need of us."  Positive Negatives can be seen at the Africa Centre, 38 King St, Covent Garden, London until December 15. fields.headline: ITV pulls with Beckham and strippers
fields.trailText: 12.15pm TV overnights:ITV scored a ratings double whammy last night with its David Beckman documentary and Full Monty premiere, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV delivered the anticipated ratings double whammy last night, with documentary The David Beckman Story and the terrestrial premiere of The Full Monty combining to pummel the opposition.

The David Beckham Story, the heavily-trailed look behind the celebrity facade of Britain's most famous footballer, pulled in 10m viewers and a 43% audience share, according to unofficial overnights.

And Blockbuster feel-good movie The Full Monty, starring Robert Carlyle as a hard-up stripper, took 10.4m viewers - half the available audience.

It was ITV's third-highest rating film this year, while the broadcaster's 48.9% share of peak-time viewing from 7-10.30pm was its fourth best night so far in 2000.

The line-up left the BBC with just one in five viewers between 8-9pm. A repeat of Only Fools and Horses did reasonably well with 4.9m, while just 4.3m tuned in to the National Lottery.

However, BBC1's decision to show movies after the Ten O'Clock News is proving more popular - shark-attack movie Jaws at 10.30pm got an average audience of 2.8m - one in four viewers.

BBC1 averaged just an 18.5% peak-time share. The Ten O'Clock News, which was up against The Full Monty, had its lowest audience yet, with 3.5m and a 16% share.

The final instalment of David Attenborough's landmark documentary, State of the Planet, also suffered, dropping nearly 2m viewers compared with last Wednesday to finish on 4.1m.

fields.headline: Can the USA learn?
fields.standfirst: Polly Ghazi reviews the US media response from Washington D.C.
fields.trailText: While European politicians laid the blame for the collapse of the Hague negotiations squarely at the door of United States, the US media last weekend warned that the world may have missed its best chance to forge an effective climate treaty.
fields.body:
While European politicians laid the blame for the collapse of the Hague negotiations squarely at the door of United States, the US media last weekend warned that the world may have missed its best chance to forge an effective climate treaty.

The Washington Post took a mildly anti-European line, arguing that the negotiations "fell apart after some EU countries, notably Germany, rejected an eleventh-hour compromise". This compromise, it disclosed, had been hammered out on Friday night "in a lengthy telephone discussion between President Clinton and British Prime Minister Tony Blair." The paper quoted Frank Loy, the US chief negotiator warning that "while the United States was ready to resume negotiations at any time, there would obviously be something of a hiatus until a new U.S. administration gets settled in office, regardless of whether Gore or Bush becomes president."

It added that American environmental groups, who had previously sided with the Europeans in demanding concessions from the Clinton administration, had expressed dismay on Saturday with what they described as the short-sighted attitude taken by those European delegates who decided to quash any compromise. "There is no excuse for having walked away," the paper quoted Philip E. Clapp, president of the National Environmental Trust in Washington. "This was Europe's best chance to achieve a strong climate treaty, and they decided to pass it up. This window of opportunity may not come again."

Sunday's Los Angeles Times took a similar line. Denouncing the meeting's collapse as "an embarrassing international fiasco," it laid much of the blame at Europe's uncompromising door. The US delegation, it reported, had made two "generous" last minute offers to the EU nations which responded by "a reopening of old disagreements and America-bashing".

The paper added that, while America's role in future climate change talks remained "pure conjecture" until the next president was inaugurated, US participation in global talks was by no means guaranteed.

"Already on Saturday," it reported, "there were indications that some Republicans believe that the process began in Kyoto has struck a dead end." The Republican-dominated US Senate has so far refused to ratify the Kyoto Treaty and George W. Bush denounced the treaty as "unfair" during the election campaign. Sunday's New York Times was more measured, reporting simply that "in the end the negotiators got lost in the trees." European nations, it said, suspected that America was playing a "get out of jail free card" in trying to use its existing forests as carbon sinks which could be counted towards meeting US Kyoto commitments. The US, on the other hand, was highly resistant to following the European path of higher fuel taxes to reduce carbon emissions.

"Despite a report issued during the conference from the Energy Department saying that the United States could reduce its fuel use though fairly simple, inexpensive changes with almost no harm to the economy, conservation measures have long been resisted in a country where big cars, low gasoline prices and economic growth have come to be considered nearly inalienable rights."

The Times stated that the final analysis came down to a 20 million ton difference between the two sides - "a minuscule amount of carbon dioxide in a world spewing 6 billion tons a year into the air." The crunch came, the paper said, "when domestic political pressures, exhaustion, an exceptionally tight relationship between the Europeans and environmental groups and simply too much data to sort through in too little time all collided to destroy any environmental detente, at least for now."

While the Hague negotiations made front page news across Europe for a fortnight, much of the mainstream US news media either downplayed or ignored them altogether. Preoccupied with the US election drama, their lack of coverage reflected widespread public indifference to the challenge of climate change.

There were a few honourable exceptions. The Washington Post ran an impassioned opinion piece co-written by Jennifer Morgan, climate campaigner at World Wildlife Fund US, accusing the US government of adopting Orwellian.tactics and "deceptive accounting" in its negotiating stance over counting forest cover as carbon sinks. "Internationally, Kyoto is the only game in town," she wrote. "The next president should wake up, smell the carbon and make the United States a responsible actor in the world."

The Detroit News, mouthpiece for America's "motor city" took the opposite view in a hard-hitting editorial. "It is imperative that Kyoto not become an excuse to shake down the United States for billions of dollars. If it is fully implemented, an average American family of four would have to absorb an estimated $2,700 in loss of income just for the cost of containing US emissions."

The paper also challenged the scientific consensus that man-made emissions are causing temperatures to rise: "Science is no closer to establishing the causes of global warming than it was four years ago when Kyoto was written. It makes sense to wait for more conclusive evidencebefore any expensive commitments are made."

The rightwing Washington Times ran a similarly hardline editorial last Wednesday (Nov 22) which warned that enforcing the Kyoto treaty "could cripple the US economy". Only massive new energy taxes or draconian rationing schemes would enable the US to meet its commitments it claimed, adding: "Perhaps the impoverishment of nearly 300 million Americans could be justified if, indeed, a man-made environmental apocalypse was imminent. It is not. The whole body of "global warming" evidence rests on skewed and politicised data fed into highly questionable computer models designed to spit out the most calamitous result, even when such a result is the least realistic scientifically."

Meanwhile, on a lighter note, the Christian Science Monitor reported from the Hague that the beleaguered US delegation had received support from an unlikely source for its much-criticised plan to conserve existing forest cover as a "carbon sink". Eco heroine Julia "Butterfly" Hill, who spent two years living in a Californian redwood to save it from loggers, told the paper: "We have to value natural systems. I know how these forests stabilise climate."

fields.headline: Aids is back in town
fields.standfirst: In the UK the rate of infection is soaring again. And in Russia, there is a massive rise.
fields.trailText: In the UK the rate of infection is soaring again. And in Russia, there is a massive rise. Sarah Boseley reports.
fields.body:
God bless Thabo Mbeki. It is not often that sheer bloodymindedness on the part of a politician becomes a force for good. Thanks to the South African president airing his irrational doubt that HIV causes Aids earlier this year, the world has sat up and once again taken some notice of the appalling progress of this disease.

Aids is orphaning children in unprecedented numbers, wrecking lives and unpicking the development gains of a continent. But in the mud clouds stirred up by the Mbeki controversy, it was hard to see clearly where we were with Aids, let alone the road ahead. Now, some months on, before Aids slips once more into the background as just another of those disasters which are impossible to think about and don't affect us in the UK anyway, it is time for some clear and strategic thinking.

Fallacy number one is that it doesn't affect us. Most of us don't notice it in our daily lives. There are no more iceberg advertisements on prime time TV. But what we should all know is that the number of HIV infections is soaring here in the UK. Last year 3,300 more people tested positive for the virus. That is more than double the average rate of diagnosis in the 1990s. Within five years, it is expected that 45,000 people in the UK will be HIV positive - half as many again as have the virus now. They won't die within 10 years, which is the fate of an impoverished African, but there is no cure. They will be condemned to a life-preserving cocktail of powerful drugs which at some unpredictable point the virus may mutate to overcome. Aids is held at bay in rich countries like ours - but that is all.

Although the UK scenario vanishes in significance when set beside the disaster in sub-Saharan Africa, it is important to remember that Aids has not gone away and that the virus lurks and spreads among us, just as it does in Zambia or Malawi. This sickness is a disaster for every human being on the planet. The global statistics are frightening. Some 3m people died of Aids this year, according to UNAids figures this week, of whom 500,000 were children.

The numbers incubating HIV who will probably die of Aids are far, far larger. There are 36.1m living with HIV, of whom 1.4m are children. In some parts of the world, new infections are rising almost off the scale. UNAids talks of "exponential growth" in the Russian federation, where 50,000 new infections have been reported in the first nine months of this year. There were only 29,000 registered in the previous 12 years. This massive rise is caused not by heterosexual sex, nor gay sex, but by intravenous drug use, and everybody recognises that the real figures are very much higher even than this, because only a minority of such cases will be reported.

Throughout eastern Europe and the former Soviet bloc the picture is the same. In the debris left by political and social upheaval, an epidemic of drug abuse and commercial sex has acted as a fast breeder for HIV. At the end of last year there were 420,000 cases in the region. Now the conservative estimate runs at 700,000.

In sub-Saharan Africa, where a devastating 25.3m men, women and children are effectively under sentence of death with HIV, there is for the first time a glimmer of light. The number of new infections dropped slightly in 2000 to 3.8m from the 4m of last year. Prevention programmes like Uganda's - a shining light on the continent - may be part of the answer, but it is also true that so many are now infected that there is a smaller and smaller pool of sexually active people to whom they can transmit the virus.

The new fear is for Asia. Huge populations are at risk. Unicef, the UN children's fund, fears Asia could eclipse Africa if more is not done to stop the virus spreading. In India, the numbers are thought to be under-reported in a political climate of denial that unsafe and promiscuous sex is rife. China is now seeing a steep rise in sexually transmitted infections, which usually bring HIV infection in their wake. Thailand - Asia's beacon, just as Uganda is Africa's - is showing a worrying increase in HIV infection. A powerful and effective campaign brought condoms to the red light districts, but now it appears the virus has passed out of the world of commercial sex to thrive among pregnant women who have had sex only with their husbands or boyfriends. And the Thai government, proud of its success in tackling HIV, has cut the budget.

So much fear and horror can paralyse the best of us. No effort to tackle Aids is going to be big enough. The World Health Organisation has launched an impossibly heroic, all-out drive to slash the numbers of people with HIV and those who die from malaria and TB. It is a call to arms and a call for the wallets of the donor nations, but they are setting targets so daunting that they are hardly credible.

Money is certainly needed in unprecedented sums. But the wrangling over what should be done with it does not encourage donors. While UN agencies have prevention at the top of their agenda, through educating people to use condoms and refuse unsafe sex, many of the aid agencies are increasingly calling for treatment. We in the rich countries have antiretroviral drugs. These drugs must be made available to the poor countries at prices they can afford.

War has been declared on the multi-national pharmaceutical companies - another heroic struggle. Organisations like Medecins sans Frontieres have got Aids drugs for the developing world onto the agenda. In May, five of the biggest drug companies told the Wall Street Journal that they would slash their prices for poor countries that wished to negotiate a discount. But only Senegal has done so.

Even at a discount, these drugs which cost $10,000 a year in the developed world are beyond the reach of countries in sub-Saharan Africa. Some countries like Brazil make generic versions (cheaper copies) but they are not cheap enough and countries that might buy them are afraid of falling foul of international patent law or incurring the wrath of the US which protects drug companies.

It is shameful that the oldest drug, AZT, which was patented by Glaxo Wellcome in 1987 (even though most of the research was done by the US National Institutes of Health), should not now be given for free or a pittance to the developing world. It must happen. One really positive step forward has been nevirapine, which is going to be made freely available to prevent mothers transmitting HIV infection to their babies. But drugs are never an answer on their own. There must be masses more money for doctors, nurses and clinics to hand out the drugs and advise and monitor people taking them. Wrong use means the virus will become immune to them.

Yes, we need the drugs and the clinics, but we have more hope of getting them if the renewed concern about HIV/Aids in the world can be sustained. We should all be thinking about it. Everyone on the planet needs to remember that sex can deliver HIV/Aids just as easily as it can make a woman pregnant. It is a fact of life, and countries where it is denied, hidden or where women are not given the moral authority to refuse unprotected sex are contributing to a massacre. The one hope on the horizon is a vaccine, but that may be a decade of deaths away. Until then, we all have a problem.

Sarah Boseley is the Guardian's health editor. sarah.boseley@theguardian.com

It must happen. One really positive step forward has been nevirapine, which is going to be made freely available to prevent mothers transmitting HIV infection to their babies. But drugs are never an answer on their own. There must be masses more money for doctors, nurses and clinics to hand out the drugs and advise and monitor people taking them. Wrong use means the virus will become immune to them. Yes, we need the drugs and the clinics, but we have more hope of getting them if the renewed concern about HIV/Aids in the world can be sustained. We should all be thinking about it. Everyone on the planet needs to remember that sex can deliver HIV/Aids just as easily as it can make a woman pregnant. It is a fact of life, and countries where it is denied, hidden or where women are not given the moral authority to refuse unprotected sex are contributing to a massacre. The one hope on the horizon is a vaccine, but that may be a decade of deaths away. Until then, we all have a problem. Sarah Boseley is the Guardian's health editor. sarah.boseley@theguardian.com

webTitle: Most men don't give to HIV charities

fields.headline: Most men don't give to HIV charities
fields.standfirst: HIV is an unpopular cause to give to, particularly for heterosexual men, but there is still no cure or vaccine to help sufferers, writes Nick Partridge, chief executive of the Terrence Higgins Lighthouse trust
fields.trailText: HIV is an unpopular cause to give to, particularly for heterosexual men, but there is still no cure or vaccine to help sufferers, writes Nick Partridge, chief executive of the Terrence Higgins Lighthouse trustrust
fields.body:
The first World Aids Day was held in 1991, at a time when I was still going to the funeral of someone who had died with Aids at least once every month. Things have changed now. Thanks to powerful new drug treatments, people with HIV are now living fuller lives and the death rate has dropped by two-thirds in the last five years. This is great news, but it does mean that HIV has gradually slipped out of the media spotlight, and the importance and value of a day about Aids is now more clearly appreciated by those of us working in the voluntary and public sectors. That's one reason why tomorrow, World Aids Day, when we remember the 34m people worldwide who are living with HIV, is so important.

This year, the theme of World Aids Day is Men Make a Difference. This serves to remind us that men play a vitally important part in preventing the spread of HIV, both in their sexual behaviour and also in their willingness to support HIV organisations and help raise the profile of the illness. Many heterosexual men believe HIV doesn't affect them and isn't relevant to them. This attitude is just as prevalent in developing countries where the bulk of the epidemic is among the heterosexual population.

When it comes to giving donations to HIV charities, men are less likely than women to give time and money - they are less willing to give to street collections, less likely to wear a red ribbon at any time of year, and also less likely to become volunteers. Sometimes they are downright hostile, an attitude fuelled in part by the misconception that HIV only affects gay men. By encouraging all men to take more of an interest in supporting HIV organisations, we can do a lot to break down the prejudice and stigma that people living with the disease have to face.

We have all witnessed tremendous shifts in the epidemic over the last five years. Combination therapy has dramatically improved the health of many people, but brings with it a different set of complications. While the number of people dying from HIV is falling, the rates of new infections are on the increase. In the UK, 30,000 people are believed to be living with HIV and the groups most affected include people from African communities and gay men.

People with HIV have complex needs and live every day with a life-threatening illness, which carries with it unprecedented stigma. The Terrence Higgins Trust Lighthouse, along with other organisations, aims to campaign to create greater awareness of what living with HIV really means, to tackle the prejudice which sees people sacked for no reason or ostracised from their family, and to provide flexible, needs-driven services.

But the stark reality is that HIV is one of the least popular causes to give to or get involved with, yet the help, support and information we all provide is needed more than ever. There is still no cure or vaccine for HIV and it affects some of the most disadvantaged and vulnerable people in the UK. Every day we help men, women and children deal with the consequences of this terminal illness.

As the full scale of the tragedy unfolding in Africa and Asia has become so terribly apparent - none of us remains untouched by it. Most importantly, though, it is the insularity that has gone. In our pain, grief and anger during the early part of the epidemic it was sometimes hard to appreciate the impact of Aids elsewhere. World Aids Day is no longer about what happens elsewhere. It happens here, every day and the future of how we respond to HIV is now intimately linked with how Aids moves worldwide, making World Aids Day this year more important than ever.

fields.headline: T-Online appoints new chief executive
fields.trailText: 11.30am: T-Online, Europe's largest internet service provider, has finally ended its prolonged management crisis, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
T-Online, Europe's largest internet service provider, has finally resolved its prolonged management crisis.

The German company has drifted since chief executive Wolfgang Keuntje resigned in August, but Thomas Holtrop has been poached from Deutsche Bank to replace him.

Mr Keuntje's departure, which was swiftly followed by the resignation of T-Online's finance and marketing chiefs, has stifled the company's ambitions to lead the consolidation of a crowded sector and wounded its share price.

Parent company Deutsche Telekom has been accused of reining in T-Online's management, who had wanted to expand abroad more aggressively.

Ron Sommer, the hands-on boss of Deutsche, had a prominent role in most of the management clashes.

Bob Kommers, analyst at ABN Amro, said: "Mr Holtrop's background is in retail banking and he will probably be a yes man to Mr Sommer. An internet company simply cannot be run by an incumbent company."

T-Online has struggled to convince investors that it is a company with an independent management and secure revenue streams.

The company makes most of its money by providing internet access to its 7m subscribers, but analysts doubt this is sustainable.

While T-Online has been scouring the files of head-hunting firms, its rivals have stolen a march by leading the way in sector consolidation.

Wanadoo of France is negotiating to buy the UK's Freeserve, whilst Tiscali of Italy is taking over World Online.

T-Online pulled out of a deal to buy Freeserve in the summer, when Mr Sommer refused to pay over the odds for the company.

webTitle: Goater and Wanchope are City's dream team

fields.headline: Goater and Wanchope are City's dream team
fields.trailText:
Man City 2 - 1 Wimbledon
Joe Royle's team shook off their Premiership blues to reach their first quarter-final in any competition for five years.
fields.body:
Manchester City may be riding on the crest of a slump in the Premiership but last night Joe Royle's team shook off their blues in this Worthington Cup fourth-round tie to reach their first quarter-final in any competition for five years.

Having trailed to an early goal from Andy Roberts, the Premiership team fought back well from a dismal start to set up a date with Ipswich thanks to goals in either half from Paulo Wanchope and Shaun Goater, who eventually gelled on their first start together.

Five successive league defeats have sent City into free-fall in the Premiership, and not surprisingly there were unusual expanses of empty seats inside Maine Road.

Sure enough, Wimbledon were ahead after only 10 minutes. Steve Howey lost the ball in his own defence and when Neil Ardley crossed from the right Roberts had the time and space to direct a precise volley beyond Nicky Weaver.

City's first attempt on goal brought an equaliser on 26 minutes. The Dons' goalkeeper Kelvin Davis failed to grasp Shaun Wright-Phillips's low shot, presenting the recalled Wanchope with a rebound for his sixth goal of the season.

With six First Division wins on their travels, Wimbledon came with one of the best away records in the country but the gulf in status began to tell after the interval. Wright-Phillips was an increasingly potent force on the right side of midfield, though Wanchope and Goater took time to team up.

Even so City's fragility in defence should have been exposed once again when Mark Williams missed with an unchallenged header from Ardley's corner. Then, as extra-time beckoned, Goater latched on to Wanchope's overhead kick to volley a fierce right-foot shot past Davis.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: First light for films at Sundance 2001

fields.headline: First light for films at Sundance 2001
fields.trailText: Although not officially announced until next Tuesday, early rumours suggest a typically strong mix of independent films from around the world
fields.body:
The line-up for the 2001 Sundance Film Festival is not officially announced until next Tuesday, but recent leaks have revealed the films that could be dominating America's premiere independent film showcase.

Cannily positioned at the start of the year, the festival has been known to effectively set the pattern of play on the indie-cinema calendar for the following twelve months and has frequently spotlighted low-budget movies which have gone on to become huge sleeper hits.

Variety reports that this year's festival will be opened by Caveman's Valentine, the new film from Afro-American writer-director Kasi Lemmons, creator of the American deep southern melodrama, Eve's Bayou.

The paper also tips Bill Bindley's Madison, starring Jim Caviezel, Jake Lloyd and Bruce Dern, as the early favourite to scoop a prize. Other films expected to be in competition include John Cameron Mitchell's Hedwig and the Angry Inch, Patrick Steffner's The Business of Strangers and Scotland, PA, a warped adaptation of Macbeth, starring Christopher Walken and James LeGros.

The festival will also feature not one, but two films from wayward director of Slacker, Richard Linklater: the live-action feature, Tape, and the animated curio, Waking Life.

But just to show that Sundance isn't completely ahead of the game, the unofficial line-up also includes some titles that may be more familiar to British audiences. Included in the World Cinema section are Jonathan Glazer's Sexy Beast (pictured) and Jose Lius Marques's Fuckland, which have already been showcased at the London Film Festival.

Also in the running are the Australian true-crime drama, Chopper, and the ingenious puzzle- thriller, Memento. Already released to rave reviews in the UK, both films are now hoping to crack the crucial US market.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
Honeymoon hitch

This weekend B Downing and his bride are due to fly to the island of Nevis in the Caribbean. Last April, they booked two British Airways tickets to neighbouring Antigua and a connecting flight to Nevis. Five months later, with only a few weeks to go before the wedding, BA informed them it had rescheduled its timetables and the couple would consequently arrive in Antigua too late for their connecting flight. They would have to pay for their own accommodation in Antigua and fly out the next day. "I pointed out that we had already paid $250 (£178) for our first night on Nevis and weren't going to spend any more on a hotel in Antigua, where we didn't want to stay," says Downing. "BA told me if I'd read the small print in its terms and conditions it says that BA doesn't have to do anything so long as its is not cancelling flights." The airline eventually offered to pay for the hotel on Antigua, but by then Downing had discovered he could charter a flight to Nevis for $160 (£114) per person and invited BA to contribute towards that instead. BA refused, nor would it refund him for the now useless connecting flight.

They are a soft-hearted lot really. As soon as Consumer points out the sad tale (and the potential publicity) to BA, it begs to be allowed to fund the charter flight for the newlyweds as a gesture of goodwill. But lest that give anyone else grand ideas: "We're not bound to do this by our terms and conditions," emphasises a spokeswoman.

Trapped in the net

Ranjan Bhattacharyya of London is one of 15,000 surfers who stumbled upon a website run by a company called Smartalk, which was offering £600-worth of computer equipment for £179. The catch was that he had to answer a monthly lifestyle questionnaire for two years. He duly sent off a cheque and expected to receive a delivery within two weeks, as promised on the website. Two months later he has heard nothing. His letters and emails have gone unanswered and no one picks up the telephone when he rings the advertised numbers.

Over to Trading Standards in Lancashire, where Smartalk is based, and a spokesman breaks the news that the company has been compulsorily wound up by the Department of Trade and Industry. A hearing is due this week. Officers became suspicious back in March and asked for details of the company's backers and the source of computers, but although Smartalk claimed to have distributed 250,000 machines in a year, it refused to comply. "We found that some people were getting computers, but they were very few and far between, so we got the police and the DTI involved," says the spokesman. "Just before the winding-up operation began all the staff had their contracts changed to make them employees of a company called Info4pc, which then started trading in the same way. They're still doing so in Australia and Canada."

People who, like Bhattacharyya, have been caught out, can try writing with details of their claim to the Insolvency Service, Public Interest Unit, PO Box 203, 21 Bloomsbury Street, London WC1B 3QW. If you bought your computer through an ad in a publication which subscribes to the Mail Order Protection Scheme, you can write to the publisher with your claim. For further details try www.ppa.co. uk.consumer/mops.htm.

Left high and dry

Craig Robertson has suffered a similar experience with Ryanair. He bought return tickets for his girlfriend's journey from Pisa to London Stansted then from Stansted to Prestwick. But Ryanair altered its schedules, which meant she would miss one leg of her journey. Robertson was promised a refund for the unusable ticket, but was only reimbursed for the airport taxes. Since then, numerous attempts to contact Ryanair for an explanation have failed.

A spokesman explains that Ryanair doesn't do connecting flights and advises passengers not to attempt to combine its services. "In this case the journey counts as two separate bookings, since we don't sell through tickets involving a change over," says a spokesman, "the rescheduling of the one flight does not make us liable for the other." However, the carrier is to refund Robertson as a goodwill gesture. Reforms proposed by International Air Transport Association will oblige them to offer refunds to passengers if rearranged flight times are unacceptable.

Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 020-7713 4731, send a fax on 020-7239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com

webTitle: Ex-Border TV chief Corley to join Media Holdings

fields.headline: Ex-Border TV chief Corley to join Media Holdings
fields.trailText: 11am:Former Border TV chief Paul Corley has been appointed to the board of Media Holdings, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Paul Corley, former chief executive of Border Television and former head of factual programming for ITV, has been appointed to the board of Media Holdings, the parent company of Channel TV.

Mr Corley left Border earlier this year following the station's takeover by Capital Radio.

He started his broadcasting career at the BBC's news and current affairs departments, moving on to work as a producer on the first two series of Channel 4's The Tube.

Mr Corley went on to be controller of factual programmes for ITV, where he commissioned a number of popular factual formats such as Police, Camera, Action, Neighbours from Hell and Blues and Twos.

He then became managing director of Carlton Broadcasting.

Commenting on his appointment, Mr Corley said: "As I learned at Border, small can be beautiful and successful, and I'm looking forward to making a contribution to the growth of the business."

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours in a £9,000 custom-made bath
fields.trailText: Peter Ridsdale has "hatched an incredible plan" to bring Ronaldo to Leeds on loan, claims the Daily Mirror. The paper says that Ridsdale hopes to persuade Leeds' sponsors Nike - who also promote Ronaldo - to use their influence and their money to bring the Brazilian to Elland Road until the end of the season. However, Ridsdale this morning rubbished the story, describing it as "nonsense".
fields.body:
Peter Ridsdale has "hatched an incredible plan" to bring Ronaldo to Leeds on loan, claims the Daily Mirror. The paper says that Ridsdale hopes to persuade Leeds' sponsors Nike - who also promote Ronaldo - to use their influence and their money to bring the Brazilian to Elland Road until the end of the season. However, Ridsdale this morning rubbished the story, describing it as "nonsense".

Equally incredible is the news - also from the Mirror - that Real Madrid are lining up a £3m bid for Frank Leboeuf when Spain's transfer window opens on December 15. A Real spokesman admitted: "Frank is a very good player and we have seen him make some good performances. But we must look at our financial situation."

Terry Venables will take over as manager of Middlesbrough today, claims the Star. Bryan Robson - who the paper says will become El Tel's assistant - has had a clause inserted into his contract saying that he will be the Boro manager at the start of the 2002/2003 season.

Tottenham are set to bid £8m for Francis Jeffers, according to the Mirror. The paper reports that Everton need to sell to balance their books and have already made "discreet calls" to potential bidders (not that discreet obviously). Manchester United are also said to be interested.

Norwich have agreed a £400,000 fee with Kilmarnock for midfielder Gary Holt and hope to conclude a deal next week.

Grimsby have signed China captain Zhang Enhua on loan from Shanghai side Dalian Shide.

webTitle: View from New York: Harlem developers accused of driving out locals

fields.headline: Harlem developers accused of driving out locals
fields.standfirst: Property values are skyrocketing in New York's historic neighbourhood, but fraudulent housing schemes are also on the rise,  writes Jane Martinson
fields.trailText: Property values are skyrocketing in New York's historic neighbourhood, but fraudulent housing schemes are also on the rise, writes Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
Economic regeneration has brought a multiplex cinema, expensive shops and record house prices to Harlem, the once benighted New York neighbourhood. It is also suspected of encouraging fraudulent developers to drive out local tenants with the use of government aid.

The average price of a turn-of-the-century townhouse in Harlem jumped 29 per cent to a record $391,000 in the first nine months of this year, according to a report by Corcoran, the upscale real estate agency. In the trendiest streets, houses sold for as much as $750,000.

Local politicians and real estate groups have hailed this inflation as a sign that America's booming economy - with unemployment at record lows and spending at record highs - had filtered down to an area dogged by crime and poverty for most of the post-war period.

For some, however, the rapid rise in the value of local properties appeared at odds with the number of dilapidated buildings left in some of the most expensive areas.

Questions were raised about many of the homes bought under government assistance programmes designed to allow local residents or charities to buy crumbling brownstones and renovate them. Many of these homes, about 200 in total, appeared to have been sold on immediately for a much higher price and/or left to rot. In both cases, existing tenants were forced to leave.

The Westside SRO Project, a law firm specialising in tenants' rights, was among the first to raise the alarm about the possible abuse of schemes run by the department of housing and urban development (HUD). It is understood that there are three investigations into several professed charities and developers suspected of doing sweetheart deals to drive up prices or of failing to meet the standards designed to help low income households.

Matthew Franklin, a senior HUD official, told the New York Times that some non-profit organisations were selling the right to develop homes. "We have very strong evidence that fraud was perpetrated by non-profits, as well as lenders," he said.

Terry Poe, an organiser at Westside SRO, suspects that the fraudulent behaviour has artificially inflated house prices in Harlem. "Real estate brokers saw that things were really hopping in Harlem in the last year or so and came up here," he says. "But in fact, most of the action is going to wind up making no profit for anyone because it was all crooked."

This week civil charges against a social services group were brought in Brooklyn, a nearby suburb. However, the impact of the alleged fraud has been even greater in Harlem, where more homes are understood to have been affected and which has only in the past two years started to enjoy the sort of renaissance that attracts coachloads of tourists on Sundays.

The controversy has underlined existing tensions in the area in a backlash against gentrification with echoes around the world. Although residents have welcomed the local Disney store, Starbucks coffee house and a $68m Harlem USA shopping mall, some are less than happy with the high prices they charge. Last month over 200 people demonstrated in front of the glitzy mall chanting, "Harlem is not for sale".

Mr Poe points out that brownstones have traditionally been divided into single room dwellings, which means that between eight and 12 rooms are carved out of the house and made into individual homes. Many of these apartments, with rents typically between $200 and $700 a month, do not have private bathrooms. Once such a property has been developed, rents can be as high as $3,000 per apartment.

Such sums are impossible for many local residents to afford. The average household income in central Harlem is significantly less than that enjoyed by the rest of Manhattan. Unemployment is up to 18% in some parts of the neighbourhood compared with a national average of less than 4%.

There are still many local residents and businesses optimistic about the area's prospects. Vie Wilson, a Harlem real estate agent for the past three years, says that the homes suspected of being bought fraudulently reflect only a small percentage of local house sales. "These people did the wrong thing with money meant to do right. They do not represent Harlem."

Signs of tension have not stopped the area being portrayed in glossy property supplements as a cheap alternative to the astronomical rents elsewhere in Manhattan. As Barbara Corcoran, the ebullient founder of the property group, gushed in releasing the price report earlier this month. "Harlem is the last great frontier of Manhattan real estate. There are many wonderful things happening in this historic and beautiful area."

fields.headline: Broadcast round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: December 1.
fields.trailText: December 1: ITC chief Patricia Hodgson has indicated that the ITC is not - in principle - opposed to a single ITV.
fields.body:
ITC chief Patricia Hodgson has given a strong indication to Broadcast that the ITC is not - in principle - opposed to a single ITV.

The BBC's director of television Mark Thompson has written to independent production companies apologising for the delay in finalising the BBC's commissioning structure, and is sending out an A-Z of commissioning, both internally and externally.

BBC Christmas epic Lorna Doone is £1m over budget after production was hampered by the petrol crisis and bad weather in the Brecon Beacons.

Bectu members have called a one-day strike this weekend at BBC Television Centre in a dispute over enforced redundancies and pay cuts.

Granada has created a dedicated in-house new media division for its new health channel, under the auspices of Yorkshire Television's head of news, current affairs and sport, Clare Morrow.

fields.headline: QXL's shares plunge
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Shares in online auctioneer QXL.com have fallen to a record low, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Online auctioneer QXL.com, home to Hugh Scully's antiques valuation service, has received a financial lifeline after plummeting further into the red.

But the stock market was not impressed and slashed the company's share price by an incredible 40% to a record low of 15p in three hours of trading early this morning.

This year's worst performer on the FTSE TechMark 100 index has been forced to seek more cash after admitting it does not have enough in the bank to survive.

The need for funding became apparent in the company's second-quarter results, which showed a loss of £66.5m, compared to £11m for the same period last year.

QXL said the loss largely stemmed from extra costs relating to the £347m acquisition of Scandinavian rival Bidlet in March. The company also paid £668m for German online auctioneer Ricardo in a drawn-out takeover saga.

The acquisition that was supposed to turn QXL into a rival to US giant eBay has almost proved to be its undoing.

QXL was founded by journalist Tim Jackson three years ago and floated last October. Mr Jackson cashed in and left the company but it was still riding on a crest of optimism and even attracted the services of Mr Scully, veteran presenter of the BBC's Antiques Roadshow.

Earlier this year the shares touched £15 but today's spectacular collapse underlines the scale of the dot.com stock market crash.

The company today said it will raise £30m thanks to a share and bonds deal with the Credit Suisse First Boston bank, after touring investors over the past month.

QXL has around £45m left in the bank, which it claims will not be enough to see it through to profitability.

Jim Rose, QXL's 39-year-old chief executive, said: "QXL's business continues to experience solid growth in the recent quarter.

"We have developed our customer offering, increased our focus on multi-device access to QXL through the PC, mobile telephony and television, and completed significant corporate acquisitions."

It has been a troublesome year for the company. Second-quarter turnover rose from £1.9m to £5.9m, but the market preferred to focus on the losses.

QXL has been hit harder than most by the negative sentiment which has been directed at business-to-consumer internet stocks.

QXL is expected to link up with a strategic partner, such as eBay or Lycos Europe, as the company's plan to grow through all-share takeovers is now impossible.
