webTitle: Judge sends disputed ballots on cross-state journey

fields.headline: Judge sends disputed ballots on cross-state journey
fields.trailText: Ballot papers in the still unsettled US election were being ferried across Florida today, after a judge ordered 1m of them to be packed up and taken 400 miles to Tallahassee.
fields.body:
Ballot papers in the still unsettled US election were being ferried across Florida today, after a judge ordered 1m of them to be packed up and taken 400 miles to Tallahassee.

One convoy of disputed forms was due to leave West Palm Beach today, with another scheduled for departure from Miami-Dade tomorrow.

The move came following an announcement by circuit judge N Saunders Sauls that the ballots should be taken to the state capital so that they are instantly available if he orders a recount after a hearing on Saturday morning.

But the drama doesn't stop there. Democrat presidential candidate Al Gore's legal team are set to take more legal action today, as they seek to bypass the decision by Judge Sauls and ensure that a recount starts straight away.

The decision to go to the supreme court to appeal against yesterday's ruling was prompted by a poll that was published on Wednesday night, which emphasised the need for Mr Gore not to be seen to extend the process too long.

The CBS poll revealed that 42% of people surveyed said that Mr Gore should concede the presidential race to his Republican opponent George W Bush now, but 48% said that it was still too early to take such an action.

On Sunday, Florida's Republican secretary of state Katherine Harris had certified Mr Bush the state winner by just 537 votes. That would give the Texas governor enough electoral college votes to gain the White House.

On Monday later, Mr Gore's legal team launched a challenge to that declaration, claiming that thousands of ballots in the Florida counties of Palm Beach and Miami-Dade had not yet been counted, and were not included in the manual recount totals that were submitted to Ms Harris last weekend.

The dispute continued as the Republican-controlled state legislature moved closer to calling a special session for the purpose of appointing a slate of electors who would be loyal to Mr Bush.

"I'm prepared to go ahead," said the new speaker of the Florida House, Republican, Tom Feeney. "I'm standing on the playing field ready to put my helmet on."

Mr Bush's brother Jeb, Florida's governor, removed himself from elections issues while the recounts were under way. But he said yesterday that it would be "an act of courage for lawmakers to meet," and said that he would sign any legislation "if it was the appropriate thing to do."

The courts and the legislature have been operating under an informal deadline of December 12, since that's when the electors for the electoral college are supposed to be chosen. However, December 18 is the date when the electoral college should meet.

Congress is scheduled to tally the results formally on Janunary 6, but the US Constitution also gives lawmakers the right to challenge any electors.

fields.headline: Supermodel to front anti-smoking campaign
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Supermodel Christy Turlington, whose own father died of lung cancer, is fronting a new government anti-smoking campaign, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Supermodel Christy Turlington, whose own father died of lung cancer, is fronting a new government anti-smoking campaign.

She will appear in a series of TV adverts, along with former EastEnders star Troy Titus Adams who played Nina, promoting an NHS smoking helpline.

The ads, created by Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO, use the testimonials of victims or relatives of victims suffering from smoking-related illnesses to try to drive home the message, "Don't give up giving up".

Since her father died three years ago, Christy has given up smoking and made it a personal quest to get others to kick the habit.

"My dad missed so many important things in my life and in my family's life as a result of an early death from lung cancer," she said.

"He would have loved to see me graduate from New York University or have witnessed the birth of another grandchild. He was at a point in his life where he really could have enjoyed so many things."

More than 120,000 people die each year from smoking-related illnesses in the UK, making it a bigger killer than breast cancer. Approximately 70% of smokers say they want to give up, according to government research.

Public health minister Yvette Cooper believes that the involvement of celebrities in the campaign will help raise awareness of the impact that smoking can have on health, and of services available to would-be non-smokers such as the helpline, smoking cessation clinics, and free nicotine replacement therapy.

fields.headline: Pensioners win extra £4bn in compensation
fields.trailText: Millions of widows who were misled about their pensions have won a multi-billion pound compensation package when the government bowed to pressure and abandoned an earlier scheme which had been branded as mean-spirited. Nicholas Watt reports.
fields.body:
Millions of widows who were misled about their pensions won a multi-billion pound compensation package yesterday when the government bowed to pressure and abandoned an earlier scheme which had been branded as mean-spirited.

In a spectacular u-turn, the social security secretary Alistair Darling pledged an extra £4bn to exempt millions from a plan to cut pension payments to widows and widowers.

His announcement was welcomed last night by pensioner groups which had campaigned against the initial compensation package for widows who were misled about plans to cut the state earnings related pension scheme.

Mr Darling introduced his first compensation package last March after it emerged that pensioners had been misinformed about a Tory scheme to halve the amount of Serps that widows or widowers inherited on the death of their spouse.

Up to 20 million people were not told about the Tory scheme which was announced in 1986 and was due to come into force this year. Widows without an occupational or personal pension, who relied on Serps to top up their state pension, could have lost up to £62.50 a week.

In his announcement yesterday, Mr Darling pledged an extra £4bn to make three fundamental changes to his initial compensation package. The new scheme will mean that:

 Pensioners will no longer have to prove that they were misled in order to receive compensation. The government's initial scheme, in which pensioners had to demonstrate in an interview that they had been misled, was condemned by a Commons committee last week as an unworkable fiasco which was open to fraud.

 Anyone of pensionable age on October 5 2002 - the day the new scheme comes into force - will be exempt from the changes. Under the governmment's first scheme, existing pensioners would have been affected by the changes from that date;

 A transitional scheme will soften the blow for people who become pensioners after the scheme is introduced. Anyone who becomes a pensioner between 2002-04 will be entitled to 90% of their spouse's Serps. This will decrease to 80% for people who become pensioners between 2004-06 and so on. The transitional scheme is designed to avoid a "cliff edge" in which pensioners suddenly find themselves hit by the new rules; Mr Darling declared yesterday that his announcement would remove any worries pensioners have about providing for their spouses. "This problem should have been sorted out 14 years ago," he told MPs. "What happened in the years after 1986 was a series of colossal blunders which was inexcusable and caused untold distress to millions of people."

Mr Darling admitted that his initial compensation package, known as the protected rights scheme, would have been unfair. "Over the past few months I have become convinced that [it] would not work in the way intended," he said. "It wouldn't be fair because we cannot be sure that it would reach all those affected and it would be difficult to safeguard against fraud and abuse."

The news was welcomed by Age Concern. Gordon Lishman, its director general in England, said: "Alistair Darling's announcement is a victory for Age Concern's two-year campaign. It will come as a huge relief to pensioners... who can now enjoy retirement knowing their spouse will be properly provided for if they die before them."

Tony Wright, the Labour chairman of the Commons public administration commitee which had condemned the initial package, welcomed "an act of justice that all the Serps pensioners will be thankful for".

Mr Darling's announcement represents a significant victory over the Treasury which had been resisting the extra costs of the new scheme. However, the government has decided that it must do more for pensioners after a successful campaign against last year's 75p rise in the basic state pension.

fields.headline: Press Gazette round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: December 1.
fields.trailText: A House of Commons Public Accounts Committee has publicly vindicated a campaign by Computer Weekly magazine that showed that a Chinook helicopter crash was caused by faulty software rather than pilot error.
fields.body:
A House of Commons Public Accounts Committee has publicly vindicated a campaign by Computer Weekly magazine that showed that a Chinook helicopter crash was caused by faulty software rather than pilot error.

David and Victoria Beckham were given the star treatment by new Express owner Richard Desmond at the paper's offices this week.

Marina Hyde , the sacked Sun columnist who is still in dispute with the paper, has been given a job as a columnist on the Mirror's sister paper, the Sunday People.

Associated Newspapers is believed to be launching a new version of Metro for commuters in Leeds and Sheffield, in partnership with Regional Independent Media.

The decision by Associated Newspapers to cut its distribution relationship with WH Smith's wholesale arm may be repeated by other newspaper groups who have been angered by WHS's insistence that publishers move to its new centralised distribution system.

And Tyler Brule, the founder of the interior design magazine Wallpaper, is working on the launch of a new upmarket fashion title.

fields.headline: Campaign round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: December 1.
fields.trailText: December 1: Unilever is reviewing its Van Den Bergh and Bestfoods roster with a view to cutting it back.
fields.body:
Unilever is reviewing its Van Den Bergh and Bestfoods agency roster, which includes Lowe Lintas, Ogilvy & Mather, J Walter Thompson, DDB and BBDO, with a view to cutting it back to fewer networks.

Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe has won the £10m launch account for the joint venture health and beauty channel from Boots and Granada Media.

Mindshare has triumphed in the $700m centralised media pitch for Unilever's US business.

IPC Southbank is looking for advertising agencies to work across its portfolio of titles which include Nova, Marie Claire, Woman's Journal and Ideal Home.

Starcom Motive has picked up the award for best media campaign for the second year running with its Stella Artois's "Movies that matter" ads.

The government has abandoned plans for more poster hoardings in the countryside following severe criticism from environmental groups.

webTitle: Smash Hits' text messaging 'an instant success'

fields.headline: Smash Hits' text messaging campaign 'an instant success'
fields.trailText: 8am: Smash Hits' text message marketing campaign offering pop gossip and promotions has grabbed teenagers' attention, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Smash Hits has jumped on the text messaging bandwagon and launched a wireless marketing campaign for its UK concerts tour and its poll winners' party.

Teenagers will receive the latest pop gossip from the magazine and information on competitions and promotions.

To sign up for the service, they have to send a text message to a given number and can opt out at any time.

The campaign kicked off on Tuesday at a concert in Cardiff and will run over the next few weeks, culminating with the Smash Hits poll winners' party on December 10.

Pamir Gelenbe, vice-president of business development at Flytxt, the mobile marketing company handling the campaign, said it had been an instant success.

He declined to reveal how many had signed up but said it was a "double digit percentage" of the 3,000 people at Tuesday's event.

Promotional flyers will be distributed at another four Smash Hits concerts over the next few weeks. There will also be 30,000 flyers inserted into Smash Hits magazine.

Stephen Palmer, marketing director at Emap Performance Network, said: " We have recognised that the meteoric rise of text messaging has opened up a new channel for us to communicate with our readers."

The campaign is the first in a series of planned response-based text messages from Flytxt, a new technology company founded at the start of this year that is working with advertising agencies to sign up new clients.

webTitle: BBC invites pitches for Scottish soap

fields.headline: BBC invites pitches for Scottish soap
fields.trailText: 8am: BBC Scotland is considering a number of options for a new Scottish soap opera, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
BBC Scotland has confirmed it is looking at a number of options for a Scottish soap, after Greg Dyke announced plans to pump £14m into BBC Scotland.

The bids are thought to include plans to set the soap in either a leafy suburb in Edinburgh's Leith district or in a Trainspotting-style tenement.

A spokesman for BBC Scotland said it had invited pitches from BBC Scotland's in-house production departments, as well as independents Wark Clements, Antonine Films and Skyline.

The spokesman said: "We are keen to have a long-running Scottish drama coming on air on BBC Scotland in the next 12 to 15 months of the highest quality.

"We are looking at a number of approaches to ensure we capitalise on the best writing, acting and production talent available."

Bidders were coy about plans for the soap, but it is believed that a decision could be made before Christmas.

The plans follow a speech made by BBC director general Greg Dyke to journalists in Scotland. Mr Dyke said he hoped the Scottish soap would air on network television.

The BBC chief also said that he planned to give BBC Scotland greater editorial and scheduling freedom.

webTitle: Writer leaves online fans in suspense

fields.headline: Writer leaves online fans in suspense
fields.standfirst:
King sows seeds of discontent among readers
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Net news
fields.trailText: Stephen King sows seeds of discontent among readers
fields.body:
It was written in the best traditions of a spine-tingling Stephen King novel: the chilling story of a mutant vampire plant that wreaks havoc and mayhem as it preys on unsuspecting citizens.

But now the author has included a nasty shock for fans of his chapter-by-chapter online book, The Plant. He has decided to can the project for the foreseeable future.

Attention and sales have steadily faded and this month the multi-millionaire decided to suspend the novel, explaining that he needs to work on more conventional books. "The Plant will be going back into hibernation" he wrote last week on the site, saying that he began the story years ago and would eventually finish it. He added: "Don't despair. The last time The Plant furled its leaves, the story remained dormant for 19 years. If it could survive that, I am sure it can survive a year or two."

Originally King had claimed he would write up to eight instalments of The Plant, in segments ranging from 5,000 to 7,000 words. The sixth instalment will go on sale in December, described by King as the "most logical stopping point".

Marsha DeFilippo, the author's assistant, said sales had fallen sharply to levels that threatened the future of the project. King also discovered the harsh economic reality of internet publishing - that some people are freeloaders. The writer issued instalments of The Plant under an honesty plan where readers were asked for $1 per chapter. He pledged to keep writing if at least 75% of readers complied, adding: "If you pay the story rolls. If you don't, the story folds".

The first three chapters cost $1 and those after $2. Downloading was free but readers were asked to "return to pay" at a page headlined "Thank you for your honesty".

But by chapter two, only 70% of readers paid; by part four, only 46% paid. "There is undoubtedly some thievery and bootlegging going on," King complained last month.

King's publisher has been bombarded with angry emails from people who have spent $7 (£5) on a book that may never be finished.

King's curtailment of the project also contrasted sharply with his optimistic prediction at the outset, describing The Plant as perhaps "going to be publishing's worst nightmare".

The horror writer is not the only author to embark on the e-book revolution. Frederick Forsyth recently published a series of five short stories on the internet which can be downloaded for £1.99 each, but was more sceptical.

"If it's a startlingly small number of hits then I shall desist from ever doing it again because it will be shown to be hype. Certainly the boasting is way ahead of the technology."

webTitle: Cost of motoring belies protest claims

fields.headline: Cost of motoring belies protest claims
fields.standfirst:
Family spending per car is no higher than in 1970, nationwide survey finds

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Despite the country having been almost brought to a standstill by protesters complaining   about the cost of motoring, a survey published today shows that families are spending   roughly the same amount per car per week as 30 years ago.
fields.body:
Despite the country having been almost brought to a standstill by protesters complaining about the cost of motoring, a survey published today shows that families are spending roughly the same amount per car per week as 30 years ago.

The Family Spending Survey, produced by the office of national statistics, found that while spending on motoring has risen by 85% since 1970 after allowing for inflation, the increase is exactly the same as the rise in the number of cars per household, with the average British home owning at least one car compared with 30 years ago, when there was just over one car for every two households.

The survey studied the weekly expenditure of more than 7,000 families in the UK. People from all walks of life were asked to keep fortnightly diaries on where and how much they spent.

They were then asked about their regular outgoings and one-off large purchases to build a fuller picture of the average household's spending power and habits.

The survey found that the average weekly expenditure was £360 per family, a £10 increase on last year. It ranged from an average of £120 a week for households in the lowest of the 10 income groups to £780 a week in the highest.

Last year leisure goods and services became the largest item of spending and the trend continued this year with the average family spending £62 a week. The category, which includes the cinema, football matches and holidays, was up £2.50 in real terms on last year.

Satellite and cable TV subscriptions showed the biggest rise, increasing almost three and a half times between 1995-96 and 1999-00.

The increased price of sports tickets was also reflected, up substantially over the past five years to 60p a week.

The Family Spending Survey found that food and non-alcoholic drinks accounted for £60 a week on average, while housing cost £228 a month.

People in the north-west were fondest of a tipple, spending £16.40 a week on alcohol compared with Northern Ireland which was the lowest at £12.40. But while Ulster may have resisted one vice it easily topped the list in another, spending £8.70 - 50% above average - on cigarettes.

Somewhat surprisingly, the total expenditure on gambling had fallen by a fifth since 1995-96 with the lottery, scratchcards and the football pools being the main losers.

The growth of the internet was reflected, with spending on computers, printers and calculators rising by a third to £1.40 a week. Thirty-eight per cent of families had a home computer compared with just 13% in 1985.

The rise of the mobile phone continued unabated with 44% of households owning at least one, compared with 16% in 1996-97.

One of the biggest changes over the past 30 years could be found in one of the basic welfare indicators: central heating. In 1970 it was fitted in only 34% of homes, but this has risen to over 90%. The lowest levels were for households in the lowest tenth income bracket and pensioners dependent on the state, but even these were still above 80%.

fields.headline: Websites for SMEs
fields.standfirst: There is a lot of information on small business but it has to be tracked down
fields.trailText: There is a lot of information on small business but it has to be tracked down.
fields.body:
The internet is supposed to be the ultimate repository of free information, and the government and others are making concerted efforts to persuade the small-to-medium enterprise that it really ought to be getting online. It's reasonable enough to expect that there will be quite a lot of information on small business out there if only it can be tracked down; in fact there is, loads. The trouble is sorting out what's genuinely useful from the company sales pitch.

Possibly the two best places to start looking for information, then, are the government's own small business site and the independent Federation of Small Business. Cynics expecting New Labour propaganda and not much else from the government's site will be disappointed.

UK Online for Business contains useful information for businesses which have recently started on the internet, and plans to offer a lot more in terms of how-to guides later this year. The government will help find leads for overseas sales at www.tradepartners.gov.uk and www.tradeuk.gov.uk.

The independent sector is rather more unfettered. Groupings of independent business people can be found at the Federation of Small Business and the Institute of Directors; the sole trader and teleworker is more likely to find items of interest at the Telecottage Association.

Sites devoted to SMEs among private companies have proliferated in recent months: the ManageIT pages on www.vnunet.com are as independently and rigorously written as any of VNU's paper magazines, frequently using exclusive content from the company's established roster of experienced writers. Others such as www.businesseurope.com have started as internet-only projects; this one is very new but contains much that should be of interest including a number of basic how-to guides.

Some people have a specific service in mind, whether it's an account with free web space or the ability to develop a full-blown electronic commerce site online. Virgin Biznet will develop such a site for a sliding scale of charges, as will Sage as long as you're a customer of its accounting systems.

Other people prefer to ask specific questions, in which case there are discussion areas devoted to SMEs. Virgin Biznet has been established for a while in this area and Themutual also offers a discussion area. BT has a small business area although its initial branding as Btclickforbusiness has recently been abandoned.

The advantage these sites have over ordinary newsgroups is that they tend to be moderated, so the quality of the content is more reliable than it would be on an internet free-for-all. The disadvantage is that a number of similar sites launched at the same time, so competition for participants can be fierce. It's worth knowing about the even more closed areas that have established communities, such as the UKProfessional forum on CompuServe, though you need a CompuServe account: go to www.compuserve.co.uk and either download the software or ask for a disk.

Likewise the own.business conference on Cix (order a disk and make sure you opt for an account with conferencing) is text only, no pretty pictures, but the signal to noise ratio is very high. AOL has also launched its small business area to complement its personal finance area.

Clearly the internet is massive and smaller businesses don't have the luxury of time to trawl through it for the right information or service every time they need something. Sites are launched and shut down every week, but hopefully some of the above will offer a reasonable starting point. The author's own website at www.clapperton.co.uk contains links to a number of services for small business.

fields.headline: A  new gateway to prosperity
fields.standfirst: Small business may feel it has had little support from government, but with new initiatives in place, this is set to change. Alan Burkitt-Gray reports
fields.trailText: Small business may feel it has had little support from government, but with new initiatives in place, this is set to change. Alan Burkitt-Gray reports
fields.body:
Small-business people are not happy with the support they get from government - but some of them are optimistic about the potential of new initiatives. In a survey that firmly lines them up with the farmers and hauliers in their opinion of how much Whitehall understands of their concerns, only 10% expressed satisfaction with government.

It wasn't a small survey, either: 22,000 members of the Federation of Small Businesses responded, about 15% of the total membership.

But the Department of Trade and Industry's new Small Business Service, set up in April, is "on the right lines", says Stephen Alambritis, the head of parliamentary affairs for the federation. It's headed by a north-eastern entrepreneur, David Irwin, and what he is doing is "encouraging", said Alambritis.

But unlike, say, the Labour government of the 1960s which was keen on getting companies to merge into larger units, New Labour ministers are keen on saying how important small firms are: it's one of the clichés of modern business and politics.

In October innovation minister Lord Sainsbury of Turville - a member of the supermarket family - delivered a eulogy to internet incubators. The Small Business Service "is very keen to encourage the development of incubation as part of its start-up policy," he said in a speech to the UK Business Incubation Conference.

There are regional innovation funds, internet mentoring - also launched in October by e-commerce minister Patricia Hewitt - and even an Innovative Clusters Fund, designed to encourage localised groups of related businesses to start up and help one another. But don't bother with this last scheme if you're planning to start a business in one of the established high-tech growth areas of Cambridge, Reading or Basingstoke. "They will focus on areas outside the London, south-east and east England regions," warned Lord Sainsbury. Small businesses have very specific needs, says Alambritis. "People don't set up in business to do paperwork. They don't have legal departments or personnel departments. What they want is help at the end of the telephone line."

The Federation of Small Businesses has obviously been captivated by the idea of NHS Direct, the network of call centres designed to provide first-stop medical advice and, in theory at least, reduce the load on GPs who are inundated with people with sore throats and sprained wrists. The federation's model is the US Small Business Administration, a vast organisation which provides help and advice to entrepreneurs, and even rents or sells low-cost property. "We want a true one-stop shop for advice and help," says Alambritis. "A glorified call centre." And just as NHS Direct is staffed with nurses and other qualified staff who know what they're talking about, small business people want to be able to trust the advice they get.

Who they don't trust, he says, is local authorities. "They see them as enforcers," as places that impose rates and uphold regulation. Though many councils have "useful development units", they are "the last place" many small businesses would go for help.

But that means that start-ups would not get to hear of schemes for rate and rent holidays, and offers of low-cost property, he admits. That's why he thinks business people would be happy to go to a neutral call centre, offering advice about a variety of services.

Is that what's on the way? The Small Business Service already has the beginnings of a useful website on www.businessadviceonline.org, and there are indications that it will be developed in the way that, if the federation is right, entrepreneurs want.

"We want the Small Business Service to be as close to a one-stop shop as possible," says SBS chief executive Irwin. It is planning to set up what it calls "Gateway" - an internet-enabled network of knowledge and information for use by small businesses and others. "Essentially it will be composed of a website and a call handling service; and underpinning these will be a knowledge base and a client base."

The projected launch date for Gateway is April 1 2001, says an SBS spokesman. It will be interactive, and will recognise callers who have been for advice before. The model, he adds, is the personal portal which the Cabinet Office is developing with BT - eventually to be on www.ukonline.gov.uk - to allow individuals to interact with government electronically. A trial change-of-address system is already in operation: tell the government once that you're moving and the information will be communicated automatically to every agency.

It's all part of the government's aim of getting all services to the public available electronically by 2005, and services to business are covered by the same target, which was set by the prime minister in March 1999.

Gateway, the electronic version of Small Business Service, will be delivered via the web as well as through call centres and face-to-face, using the new Business Link network. It's all at a very early stage, though. A chief knowledge officer, John Gibbons, was appointed in October: he has spent more than 30 years in the IT industry, including 19 years as a principal consultant with Price Waterhouse.

Potential contractors are already talking to the SBS about starting up the Gateway service, and SBS staff were coy in late November about going into too much detail. "It's going to be much more sophisticated than the current site," said an official. "It will address you as an individual." But the level of complexity that the SBS is aiming for means that "we have to be sure that bidders can deliver".

The background to this is the government's long, sad history of unsuccessful IT projects, and its wariness following a series of criticisms from the industry, from inside Whitehall and from the source civil servants fear most, the House of Commons Public Accounts Committee.

As recently as October the Cabinet Office called off negotiations with computer supplier Compaq on a projected contract to build a similarly named project, the Government Gateway, intended to be the interface between portals offering citizens' services and the vast array of government computer systems which hold incompatible personal information.

Instead the government, worried about the vulnerability of the Government Gateway to cost overruns, delays and security glitches, decided to run the contract itself, with much of the work going to Microsoft. Now the Department of Trade and Industry, which supervised the SBS, will be concerned to avoid similar risks with the SBS Gateway.

Will this be what entrepreneurs are looking for? At the Federation of Small Businesses, Alambritis is enthusiastic about the progress made by Irwin. "He has direct access to Number 10 when he's not getting his way," he says. "But he seems to be getting his way."

Global perspective

The new United States portal www.firstgov.gov leads straight to a range of business services, including the Small Business Administration, www.sba.gov. This is an instant demonstration of the American zest for success: the "starting up" section has a page on "some ideas on how to be successful", with success stories and a magazine called Small Business Success, produced by the phone company Pacific Bell.

The site has clearly laid out step-by-step hints: do your research, training, business plans and so on. There's advice about finding the money, and whether or not to lease premises. There's even a link to a 13,000-strong team of retired executives who are prepared to offer help and advice. And the SBA advertises property and land it has acquired in the course of its operations: there's a 4,000 sq ft warehouse/retail unit in Los Angeles going for $220,000, for example.

The Irish Republic's Enterprise Ireland on www.enterprise-ireland.com, is an altogether more cautious operation. "We have a service targeted to meet the needs of high-calibre, experienced managers, academics and entrepreneurs creating and building new companies with significant growth and export potential," says the site, adding a series of questions about "credible projected sales" and export potential, before offering links to a development adviser.

There are relatively few other resources on the web for entrepreneurs, or other sources of government help. The UK Federation of Small Businesses' ideal is the Confederation for Artisans and Craftspeople, which even fills in health and safety forms and tax forms for members, according to the federation's head of parliamentary affairs, Stephen Alambritis. "It means they don't have to hire an accountant." But governments in the EU have a delicate line to walk to ensure they are not breaking anti-competition laws in the way they support industry.

Alan Burkitt-Gray is editor of Government Computing magazine and KableNET

webTitle: Arafat: does he alone hold key to peace?

fields.headline: Arafat: does he alone hold key to peace?
fields.standfirst:
Barak's call for early elections has put his fate, and possibly that of the Middle East, in one man's hands

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Barak's call for early elections has put his fate, and possibly that of the Middle East, in one man's hands.
fields.body:
After ordering helicopters to strafe Palestinian cities, and laying economic siege to the West Bank and Gaza, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday brought a bizarre twist to two months of undeclared war by entrusting his political survival to Yasser Arafat. As Israel's politicians digested the import of Mr Barak's shock announcement of early elections on Tuesday night, it became increasingly evident yesterday that the Israeli prime minister had embarked on a monumental gamble.

Despite the killing of the last two months, Mr Barak continues to believe he can reach a final agreement with the Palestinians before elections - which could be in May - and thus sweep back to power as a triumphant peacemaker.

"Barak's fate is now in the hands of the man whom he supposedly despises more than anyone else: Yasser Arafat," the veteran Israeli commentator Nahum Barnea wrote in the Yediot Ahronoth newspaper.

"If he wants, Arafat can give Barak a half year of quiet and an agreement that he will be able to sell to his voters. And if he should want otherwise, Arafat can give Barak a half a year of warfare, and wipe him and his party off the political map of Israel."

Opinion polls show that 70% of Israelis support a peace agreement with the Palestinians, despite the recent carnage. Mr Barak repeatedly has accused Mr Arafat of stoking the violence, and in October called "time-out" in talks, arguing the Palestinian leader was no fit partner for peace.

Yesterday, however, the tables turned, and it is Mr Arafat who must consider whether Mr Barak or a rival from the rightwing Likud party would be a better partner for peace. The last week has brought a flurry of contacts between diplomatic and security officials aimed at enforcing a truce.

Mr Barak told his Labour party caucus overnight that he was optimistic about reaching an agreement with the Palestinians based on a new set of proposals his advisers were drafting. Meanwhile, politicians began meeting yesterday to decide the timing of the elections for prime minister and for parliament, the knesset. Most leaders favour dates in May.

Yesterday brought no respite to the violence that has killed more than 280 people, mainly Palestinians. In the Gaza Strip, Israeli forces shot dead four men, whom they accused of trying to sneak into Israel. In the West Bank, an Israeli motorist was shot and seriously wounded south of Nablus.

Yesterday, Mr Barak's main opponent, the Likud party hawk Ariel Sharon, accused Mr Barak of being prepared to sign away Israel's security to guarantee his political career. "He will try and reach a deal at any price," Mr Sharon said.

Mr Sharon is desperate to shore up his own support, in the Likud party, to forestall a possible leadership challenge from the former prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, as well as other aspirants. Yesterday, he called on Mr Barak to reopen talks on forming a national emergency government.

Mr Netanyahu, who received a new lease of political life after the Israeli authorities dropped corruption charges against him, is expected to return to Israel next week from California where he is on a lecture tour.

Mr Barak could also face a leadership challenge, with a mounting sense of mutiny within his Labour party faction over his imperial and remote style of decision-making. The speaker of Israel's parliament, Avraham Burg, yesterday was touted as a potential challenger. There is also support for the acting foreign minister, Shlomo Ben Ami.

Despite Mr Sharon's protests, it is far from certain whether Mr Barak can reach a deal with the Palestinians after so much blood has been spilled. Even before the start of the Palestinian uprising, Mr Barak and Mr Arafat viewed each other with loathing.

Mr Arafat may not be inclined to ride to Mr Barak's rescue just to stop a rightwing opponent from coming to power.

"We signed agreements with Israeli governments, not Israeli parties," said Nabil Abu Rudeinah,a senior Arafat adviser. "We hope we will see an Israeli government committed to the peace process, and to implement signed agreements."

"If he wants, Arafat can give Barak a half year of quiet and an agreement that he will be able to sell to his voters. And if he should want otherwise, Arafat can give Barak a half a year of warfare, and wipe him and his party off the political map of Israel." Opinion polls show that 70% of Israelis support a peace agreement with the Palestinians, despite the recent carnage. Mr Barak repeatedly has accused Mr Arafat of stoking the violence, and in October called "time-out" in talks, arguing the Palestinian leader was no fit partner for peace. Yesterday, however, the tables turned, and it is Mr Arafat who must consider whether Mr Barak or a rival from the rightwing Likud party would be a better partner for peace. The last week has brought a flurry of contacts between diplomatic and security officials aimed at enforcing a truce. Mr Barak told his Labour party caucus overnight that he was optimistic about reaching an agreement with the Palestinians based on a new set of proposals his advisers were drafting. Meanwhile, politicians began meeting yesterday to decide the timing of the elections for prime minister and for parliament, the knesset. Most leaders favour dates in May. Yesterday brought no respite to the violence that has killed more than 280 people, mainly Palestinians. In the Gaza Strip, Israeli forces shot dead four men, whom they accused of trying to sneak into Israel. In the West Bank, an Israeli motorist was shot and seriously wounded south of Nablus. Yesterday, Mr Barak's main opponent, the Likud party hawk Ariel Sharon, accused Mr Barak of being prepared to sign away Israel's security to guarantee his political career. "He will try and reach a deal at any price," Mr Sharon said. Mr Sharon is desperate to shore up his own support, in the Likud party, to forestall a possible leadership challenge from the former prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, as well as other aspirants. Yesterday, he called on Mr Barak to reopen talks on forming a national emergency government. Mr Netanyahu, who received a new lease of political life after the Israeli authorities dropped corruption charges against him, is expected to return to Israel next week from California where he is on a lecture tour. Mr Barak could also face a leadership challenge, with a mounting sense of mutiny within his Labour party faction over his imperial and remote style of decision-making. The speaker of Israel's parliament, Avraham Burg, yesterday was touted as a potential challenger. There is also support for the acting foreign minister, Shlomo Ben Ami. Despite Mr Sharon's protests, it is far from certain whether Mr Barak can reach a deal with the Palestinians after so much blood has been spilled. Even before the start of the Palestinian uprising, Mr Barak and Mr Arafat viewed each other with loathing. Mr Arafat may not be inclined to ride to Mr Barak's rescue just to stop a rightwing opponent from coming to power. "We signed agreements with Israeli governments, not Israeli parties," said Nabil Abu Rudeinah,a senior Arafat adviser. "We hope we will see an Israeli government committed to the peace process, and to implement signed agreements." Useful links Yasser Arafat's office Ehud Barak's office

webTitle: Freeze tease Magician wins $1m for 58 hours in ice block

fields.headline: Freeze tease Magician wins $1m for 58 hours in ice block
fields.trailText: A 27-year-old self-styled mystifier returned to the world last night without ever breaking the ice of scepticism encasing his latest stunt.
fields.body:
A 27-year-old self-styled mystifier returned to the world last night without ever breaking the ice of scepticism encasing his latest stunt.

David Blaine, wearing cargo pants, a woolly hat and a blank stare, was chopped out of the six-tonne block of ice in which he had spent 58 hours preparing for the climax of his latest television special.

More than 25,000 people appeared to have made their way to Times Square, Manhattan, to see him stand stock-still with five inches of room to spare inside the block, placed in an ABC television studio.

"I'm trying to believe it's real but I'm tending to believe it's fake," said one of the onlookers, David Hammer. "Still, it's a cool spectacle."

In fact, it was not quite cool enough. An extra 1,360kg (3,000lb) of ice had to be added to the block around Mr Blaine as time went by and his frozen carapace melted away.

Other members of the magic trade were not over-impressed, either.

"Pumping hot air into a phone booth and putting ice around it, and standing around without a thought in your head, isn't a trick," said Penn Jillette of the Penn & Teller act.

"The hardest part of this trick is being in there and looking good without a shirt on."

A spokesman for the illusionist David Copperfield said: "If you look at the physics of it, it's warmer than a down-filled sleeping bag in there."

Drinking-water and air were pumped into Mr Blaine's space and he was fitted with a catheter to remove body waste.

"He's in a lot of pain, mostly from his back and his legs," said Dr Ronald Ruden, his medical adviser.

"If he comes out with 10 fingers and 10 toes, I'll be a very happy doctor."

In the event, the closest the disciple of Houdini came to disaster was when paramedics observed that his heart-rate had taken a leap and he appeared to be swearing. The reason, it transpired, was an inadvertent tug on the tube from the catheter.

The ordeal earned Mr Blaine, who buried himself in a transparent coffin last year, $1m for the television show.

webTitle: Europe-wide cattle cull as panic over BSE spreads

fields.headline: Europe-wide cattle cull as panic over BSE spreads
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Drastic new safety measures were announced yesterday as the European commission sought to contain rising consumer panic about BSE. They include the effective banning of up to 7m older cattle from all food products from January 1.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn in Brussels and James Meikle
fields.body:
Drastic new safety measures were announced yesterday as the European commission sought to contain rising consumer panic about BSE. They include the effective banning of up to 7m older cattle from all food products from January 1.

In a move designed to save Europe's livestock industry from ruin it also called for a temporary ban on the feeding of any meat and bonemeal to other farmyard animals, bringing the rest of the EU more into line with anti-BSE measures already taken in Britain.

The package may cost as much as £3.4bn to implement and cut nearly 10% of the EU's cattle herds out of food. But commissioners said the measures had to be taken to halt the collapse of the beef market on the continent. Sales have crashed in France, Spain and Germany as the disease has spread in recent weeks.

The new measures will be put to farming and health ministers at a crisis meeting on Monday, at which some countries, especially those still without BSE - Finland, Sweden, Italy and Austria - might bridle at the extra costs.

But commissioners believe that earlier blocking tactics, especially by Germany and Spain, which delayed for years the banning of risky parts of cattle from food, must never be repeated.

They said cattle carcasses more than 30 months old which tested negative for BSE could enter food products, but officials openly admit that member states are nowhere near to being ready for such measures. Laboratories, testing facilities and storage rooms will be needed."I don't think they will be prepared to carry out a full-scale testing programme anytime soon," said one source last night.

David Byrne, the food safety commissioner, said: "BSE does not know any borders ... The consumer deserves to be told that we're taking the highest possible measures for their protection.''

The agriculture commissioner, Franz Fischler, said: "These measures are going to be quite an expensive affair but I do believe the investment makes sense. We have seen that the collapse of the beef market is quite a lot bigger than in 1996 and therefore robust measures are necessary unless we wan t to lose it altogether.''

The BSE crisis has already cost Britain nearly £6bn in destruction of cattle, compensation to farmers and lost exports. Britain has excluded virtually all animals aged over 30 months from food since 1996.

Random testing is being stepped up across Europe but not on a scale that would clear substantial numbers of older animals to enter food products.

Taking animals out of the food chain under a "purchase for destruction scheme" would cost at least £660m in a full year (70% of which would be met from EU funds), with new animal feed controls costing £1.8bn and other losses to the farming industries £900m. Sir John Krebs, the chairman of the food standards agency, welcomed the measures, saying: "If adopted, they would provide effective protection for consumers against the spread of BSE across Europe."

webTitle: Florida Republicans hint at electoral college coup

fields.headline: Florida Republicans hint at electoral college coup
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Their tempers becoming increasingly frayed, Republican politicians in Florida meet today to embark on a process which could ensure that George W Bush becomes president, regardless of what happens to the court challenges to his declared election.
fields.body:
Their tempers becoming increasingly frayed, Republican politicians in Florida meet today to embark on a process which could ensure that George W Bush becomes president, regardless of what happens to the court challenges to his declared election.

They propose to authorise the state legislature to fill the state's 25 seats in the electoral college with people who will vote the Republican candidate into the White House. The Democrat leader in the state senate warned last night that this would provoke a constitutional crisis.

With the December 12 deadline for the electoral college vote fast approaching, Democrat lawyers are pinning their hopes on Florida's judges and the US supreme court.

Tomorrow all the ballots from Miami-Dade and Palm Beach counties will be delivered in security vans to a judge in Tallahassee. Last night the court asked for all the ballots, not just the disputed 14,000 which the Gore camp wants recounted, to be produced.

But state Republicans are beginning to flex their political muscle. A committee under their control spent a second day yesterday discussing whether to call a special session of the state legislature to appoint electors who will vote for Mr Bush. The state senate and the congress are both controlled by Republicans.

Tearful voters from Palm Beach county, giving evidence to the committee, told of their horror on realising that they had voted for the rightwing Reform party candidate, Pat Buchanan, instead of Al Gore, because of the confusing "butterfly ballot" used in the county.

One by one they urged the committee to consider that many voters had been disenfranchised, and not to act hastily by, in effect, appointing Mr Bush.

It was further evidence that the Florida election has by any standards been inefficient and chaotic, or possibly worse. Spectators cheered as angry voters berated the committee's 14 members for considering giving the state electors the authority to vote for Mr Bush.

"I certainly hope we are not here simply because the Bush campaign needs a backup plan in the event our courts indeed require every vote in Florida to be counted," the senate Democrat leader Tom Rossin said, voicing the Gore camp's fear that Mr Bush is being bounced into the presidency.

One of the Republicans on the committee, Johnnie Byrd, said: "I think there's a proverb that says 'he who hesitates is lost'." He and others of the eight Republicans on the committee said that if they did not act there was a danger that Florida's voters would not be heard at all.

A member of the public, the Rev Richard Harris, told the committee: "Listen to the voice of the people." If they appointed electors to give Mr Bush the presidency they would be behaving "no better than thieves".

War veterans expressed anger that recounts might not take place. "Bush is trying to steal the election," Harry Abramovitch said to cheers.

The Republicans looked increasingly uncomfortable as more evidence emerged that thousands of Gore voters had not had their votes counted. Voters warned that they would remember when it came to the state elections whether the committee's members had acted "hastily" and taken the political, rather than the legal, way of choosing the president. The dilemma facing the Florida politicians is that it is usual for the governor to authenticate the state electors, and the governor is George W Bush's brother, Jeb.

Mr Rossin said when yesterday's session closed: "This was a done deal three weeks ago. They are going to create a constitutional crisis."

fields.trailText: Guardian cartoonists again came to the fore at the British Cartoon Awards last night. Martin Rowson won the political section in which three-time winner Steve Bell had been barred to "give someone else a chance". David Austin was runner-up in the "pocket" competition, which was won by Pugh of the Times.

Guardian cartoonists again came to the fore at the British Cartoon Awards last night. Martin Rowson won the political section in which three-time winner Steve Bell had been barred to "give someone else a chance". The judges included the former education secretary Kenneth Baker, the historian David Starkey, the comic Arthur Brown and the newsreader Julia Somerville. The awards were presented at the Royal Institution in central London.

webTitle: George II prepares to restore the court of his father

fields.headline: George II prepares to restore the court of his father
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush, the man on the threshold of the White House, may belong to a new generation of Republicans, and may promise a fresh start for America, but the men and women at his side are overwhelmingly veterans of his father's presidency.
fields.body:
George W Bush, the man on the threshold of the White House, may belong to a new generation of Republicans, and may promise a fresh start for America, but the men and women at his side are overwhelmingly veterans of his father's presidency.

It was not supposed to be like that. When Mr Bush began his campaign for the presidency more than 18 months ago, he consciously dissociated himself from former president George Bush.

"He's not the candidate, I am," the Texas governor insisted when he announced the formation of his exploratory committee in March last year. "America will know that it's George W Bush that's going to be the president."

Now, as he inches towards the Oval Office his father occupied between 1989 and 1993, he is relying more than ever on daddy's team. In the increasingly dynastic culture of American politics, a new Bush administration is beginning to look uncommonly like a restoration presidency.

Mr Bush's parents try resolutely to stay out of the spotlight but, as the former president said yesterday in a television interview in Florida: "We're sitting on the sidelines, but we're in the game."

The influence of Mr Bush Sr is strong enough for the New York Times columnist Maureen Dowd to dub the son "President-elect Mini-Me", after the cloned villain of the Austin Powers movies.

One of the most striking examples of the continuity from the old regime is the central role being played by the putative vice-president, Dick Cheney.

Mr Cheney is not the traditional seen-but-not-heard running mate: on the contrary, he is the running mate who is actually running things.Mr Cheney, who was defence secretary in the earlier Bush administration, is chairing the transition team: its offices are temporarily housed just down the road from his Virginia home. It is Mr Cheney, who was in hospital with a heart attack only last week, who has been given the job of gathering the key players together.

While Mr Cheney closes in on Washington, George W has disappeared once again to his west Texas ranch near Waco for the rest of the week.

"The grown-ups keep sending him off to play," Dowd wrote yesterday. But Mr Cheney is among old and familiar friends. At his side is Andrew Card, designated White House chief of staff earlier this week.

Mr Card was deputy chief of staff to John Sununu in former president Bush's administration, and then transportation secretary. Heading the campaign effort in Florida was, and is, James Baker, campaign manager for Mr Bush Sr's unsuccessful White House candidacy in 1980 and then secretary of state from 1989 to 1992, before being put in charge of the doomed effort to prevent Bill Clinton capturing the White House in 1992.

According to Bush campaign sources, the next two significant appointments are likely to be every bit as familiar. As his secretary of state, Mr Bush is likely to appoint General Colin Powell, who was chairman of the joint chiefs of staff under his father. And his national security adviser is expected to be Condoleezza Rice, the Mr Bush Sr's chief Russia specialist. A top economic job is likely to go to Larry Lindsey, a special presidential assistant for policy development in the previous Bush administration.Mr Cheney denies that the team is too reliant on the past. "The fact is, we're looking for experienced people," he said yesterday. "We welcome folks regardless of what prior administration they might have been affiliated with."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Paris bids good night to sexism
fields.body:
Paris bids good night to sexism

France voted yesterday to scrap a 19th-century ban on women working at night, to comply with today's European Court of Justice deadline to end discriminatory work practices.

The ban excluded women from night work in certain places, such as factories and mines, to help family values.
Reuters, Paris

Seven executed in Xinjiang

Seven Chinese citizens in the Xinjiang autonomous region were executed by bullet last week for crimes including robbery, arson, murder and rape. The executions follow an increasingly violent crimewave right across China, which Beijing hopes to counter with a new police unit focusing on violent and organised crime.
Reuters, Beijing

Police catch 124 illegals in Sicily

Sicilian police yesterday detained 124 Sri Lankan illegal immigrants - all men - who arrived on an old fishing boat. Most were caught trying to slip inland from a beach after dark. Reports claimed the immigrants had paid up to £6,300 each to sail from Turkey.
Reuters, Catania

Street clashes in Albania

Supporters of Sali Berisha clashed with police yesterday, hours after the former Albanian president was freed from jail. Mr Berisha was held after followers set fire to a court in Tropoje, northern Albania. Riot police shot at least two people dead. Tensions in the country have been rising since disputed local polls last month.
AP, Tirana

webTitle: Clinton to visit forgotten US state

fields.headline: Forgotten US state to get Clinton visit
fields.trailText: Irish eyes may be smiling at the prospect of Bill Clinton's planned visit to Northern Ireland in mid-December, but news of the trip has not exactly gone down well in Nebraska.
fields.body:
Irish eyes may be smiling at the prospect of Bill Clinton's planned visit to Northern Ireland in mid-December, but news of the trip has not exactly gone down well in Nebraska.

The facts are cruel and indisputable.The Irish visit will be the 55th foreign trip of Mr Clinton's presidency, during which he has visited 72 countries, including, most recently, Vietnam. In nearly eight years as president, he has visited 49 of the 50 US states, most of them many times. California has had 56 visits.

But in all that time, he has failed to touch down in Nebraska. The closest Air Force One has come to the state is flying over it at 40,000 feet on the way to somewhere else.

Just what Nebraska has done to be left off Mr Clinton's itineraries for so long is not clear. Although the birthplace of Fred Astaire, Marlon Brando, Warren Buffett and Malcolm X tends to vote solidly Republican, it elected a Democratic senator, Ben Nelson, on November 7.

But the president has not spurned other predominantly Republican states, such as Kansas, Oklahoma or Utah.

So obvious is the snub - at least to the sensitivities of Nebraskans - that some in the state wear it as a badge of honour. The Nebraska governor, Mike Johanns, made a point of celebrating his state's Clinton-free years when he spoke at this year's Republican party convention.

But now the White House has been forced to commit itself to getting Mr Clinton to Nebraska before he hands over the keys to the White House to his successor in less than eight weeks' time.

In Monday's White House press briefing, Mr Clinton's spokesman, Jake Siewert, was suddenly asked the question he must have dreaded all these years: "What about Nebraska? Is he ever going to visit Nebraska?"

"We are going to visit Nebraska," Mr Siewert stuttered. "I promise you." It was an "iron-clad commitment", he added. "I will not let us not go to Nebraska."

Although the birthplace of Fred Astaire, Marlon Brando, Warren Buffett and Malcolm X tends to vote solidly Republican, it elected a Democratic senator, Ben Nelson, on November 7. But the president has not spurned other predominantly Republican states, such as Kansas, Oklahoma or Utah. So obvious is the snub - at least to the sensitivities of Nebraskans - that some in the state wear it as a badge of honour. The Nebraska governor, Mike Johanns, made a point of celebrating his state's Clinton-free years when he spoke at this year's Republican party convention. But now the White House has been forced to commit itself to getting Mr Clinton to Nebraska before he hands over the keys to the White House to his successor in less than eight weeks' time. In Monday's White House press briefing, Mr Clinton's spokesman, Jake Siewert, was suddenly asked the question he must have dreaded all these years: "What about Nebraska? Is he ever going to visit Nebraska?" "We are going to visit Nebraska," Mr Siewert stuttered. "I promise you." It was an "iron-clad commitment", he added. "I will not let us not go to Nebraska."

webTitle: Harry Potter and the Radio Marathon

fields.headline: Harry Potter and the Radio Marathon
fields.trailText: Radio 4 is to test the forbearance of its famously loyal band of listeners by clearing the schedules for an uninterrupted, eight-hour reading of JK Rowling's first Harry Potter novel on Boxing Day.
fields.body:
Radio 4 is to test the forbearance of its famously loyal band of listeners by clearing the schedules for an uninterrupted, eight-hour reading of JK Rowling's first Harry Potter novel on Boxing Day.

The marathon recording of Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, read by Stephen Fry, will start at noon. The somewhat eccentric scheduling tactic came about because of Ms Rowling's insistence that the book be read unabridged and in one go.

Helen Boaden, the controller of Radio 4, said the broadcast could become an event that listeners would recall for years to come: "What we're doing is a radio experience. I would like there to be a generation of children in their 20s who will look back and remember listening to the radio on Boxing Day, because Harry Potter is part of their imaginative landscape."

Ms Boaden confessed yesterday to having been "taken aback" when Ms Rowling's agent, Christopher Little, revealed that the only way of broadcasting a Harry Potter reading on the radio was to play the full Fry recording, which is available commercially and is the only one authorised by the author. She "gulped" when she realised the terms were non-negotiable, and told Mr Little that she would have to think about it. "But when I was coming back on the 94 bus I thought: 'I know how we'll do it.' "

So, Radio 4's normal Boxing Day schedule - which includes Desert Island Discs, a play and the shipping forecast - will be broadcast on longwave, while listeners to FM will be treated to Harry Potter.

Only Radio 4 would have the "bottle" to take such an unusual step, Ms Boaden said. "Radio 4 has the confidence, the tradition, the backbone if you like, to throw the normal rules in the air just once in a while and surprise everyone. I think that's part of our job."

Ms Boaden, who has been in her post for eight months, said she was convinced of the wisdom of the move when she recalled giving her nephew an audio version of the book last Christmas: he disappeared to his room for hours. "I just thought the power of story-telling should never be under-estimated," she said.

Few listeners would concentrate on the recording for the full eight hours, she predicted, but many families might keep it on in the background, or in children's bedrooms, all day. "I'd be amazed if people listened intently for eight hours. I think there will be people who keep it on all day and dip, mentally, in and out."

Fry, who is filming in Spain, said yesterday that he was delighted. "Reading Harry Potter books out loud is more fun than I feel a single human being could ever deserve. It's like swimming in chocolate."

Ms Boaden, who is keen to attract younger listeners and has already announced plans to revive a dedicated children's programme, said Fry was the ideal choice to read the book. "I felt that him reading Harry Potter on Radio 4 might be a way of bringing a new generation of children ... to the magical experience of listening to speech radio and seeing the pictures in their heads."

webTitle: Labour warned off by rail boss

fields.headline: Labour warned off by rail boss
fields.standfirst:
Chairman will be our choice, Railtrack insists

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The embattled Railtrack board is on the offensive against the government, saying it will not tolerate interference from ministers or regulators in the selection of its new chairman, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
The embattled Railtrack board is on the offensive against the government, saying it will not tolerate interference from ministers or regulators in the selection of its new chairman, it emerged last night.

In an unprecedented letter to ministers and in a clear snub to John Prescott, Sir Philip Beck, who is to step down as chairman next year, spelled out the appointment procedure. It states: "The appointment is not subject to any external approval."

Never before has a listed company felt compelled to complain to ministers about the pressure to which it has been subjected from Whitehall.

This pressure started after the Paddington rail crash last year when both Tony Blair and his deputy, Mr Prescott, made it clear they wanted the scalp of Gerald Corbett, then Railtrack's chief executive.

In the wake of the Hatfield crash and Mr Corbett's subsequent resignation, there had been mounting speculation that the government would seek to influence the selection of the new chairman.

There is understood to be particular concern in Whitehall that the Railtrack board immediately appointed the group's finance chief, accountant Steven Marshall, to take over from Mr Corbett.

Gwyneth Dunwoody, the Labour chairwoman of the transport select committee, has been highly critical of Mr Marshall's appointment, pointing out a dearth of experienced railmen in the Railtrack boardroom.

Sir Philip has also been widely criticised for his low profile as the crisis of confidence in the rail network has mounted.

Industry sources also revealed last night that the government has been waging a subtle campaign to remove Mr Marshall.

Potential candidates for a successor are being drawn up with the government's knowledge, although ministers have no right to interfere in the activities of a private company -even though it is being supported by the taxpayer.

Last week Sir Alastair Morton, the chairman of the shadow strategic rail authority, met Sir Philip and Mr Marshall.

The SSRA has quietly made it clear that it was not happy with the Corbett and Beck regime and sources close to the authority say Sir Alastair has been asked by Mr Prescott to ensure that Railtrack recruits the right person as its next chairman.

Several high-profile names have already been linked with the job, including David James, a troubleshooter drafted in to oversee the final months of the Millennium Dome project, and the Conservative's London mayoral candidate, Steve Norris.

David Varney, the former boss of British Gas and now head of the New Deal London taskforce, has also been named as a potential chairman. Mr Varney has close links with the Labour party. Another named candidate is Christopher Garnett, brother of Virginia Bottomley and chief executive of Great North Eastern Railway.

Mr Norris, a former Tory transport minister and a member of Transport for London, the body set up to oversee plans for the capital's transport system, has already confirmed that he would be interested in the job. Mr James has only pointed out that he is unavailable until next year (when the Railtrack job becomes vacant).

But the letter being circulated by Sir Philip insists that Railtrack is determined to select its own chairman in the same way as any other public company.

It says headhunters have been appointed to find candidates and that a shortlist will be passed to the Railtrack board's nominations committee. This is a three-strong panel of non-executive directors chaired by Jonathan Bloomer, the chief executive of the Prudential insurance group.

They will assess the candidates and their recommendation will then be put to the whole board for approval.

The letter adds that this procedure is in line with standard corporate practice and that the company's stakeholders will be kept informed "at the appropriate time".

A spokesman for Railtrack admitted last night that Sir Philip's letter was an unusual move, but he said: "These are unusual times."

He added that the selection procedure had already started and that the company had decided it was time for an "injection of clarity" to point out that it was down to Railtrack to decide who would become its next chairman.

Sir Philip has not been regarded as a successful chairman, leaving Mr Corbett alone to face the music too frequently.

webTitle: Physics bids to halt gravy drain

fields.headline: Physics bids to halt gravy drain
fields.trailText: Modern physics has at last come up with an answer to the great gravy drain. According to new research, 150,000 gallons of this mixture of meat juices, vegetable water, fat and starch disappear down kitchen sinks every week.
fields.body:
Modern physics has at last come up with an answer to the great gravy drain. According to new research, 150,000 gallons of this mixture of meat juices, vegetable water, fat and starch disappear down kitchen sinks every week.

The solution is simple, according to Len Fisher, a physicist who has just calculated a gravy absorption index for Bisto, the firm that produces gravy browning, and issued a set of rules for mopping up the stuff. They are:

Put your roast potatoes soggy side down on the plate. The bottom part of the potato is 30% more porous

Use hot gravy (if you do, absorption times can be accelerated 20%)

Eat the meat first (it does not absorb any gravy at all)

Then eat the sprouts, peas or beans (they absorb 15% of their dry weight in 30 seconds)

Yorkshire puddings (90%) and roast potatoes (30%) should be eaten last. They take five and 10 minutes respectively to absorb gravy.

And if there is anything left, says Dr Fisher, reach for the ciabatta. It has bigger holes that ordinary white sliced, so it can soak up more.

His calculations boil down to a simple equation: %gravy uptake = (W- (D/S)) /D x 100 where W is uncooked weight, D is dry or cooked weight, and S is the shrinkage factor. The average roast dinner is served with 60ml of gravy. About 20ml remains on the plate at the end of the meal.

Dr Fisher achieved fame two years ago by providing biscuit manufacturers McVitie's with the mathematics for the perfectly dunked digestive.

Mashed potatoes, he said, soak up no gravy. "The gravy carries the meat flavour through the meal, so it links the meal's components together rather interestingly."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Bombs inquiry man released
fields.body:
Bombs inquiry man released

Detectives last night released without charge a 35-year-old man from Banbury, Oxfordshire, who was being questioned in connection with two caches of bombs found in the county and in Gloucestershire in August.

Lord Irvine waits on appeal

An employment appeals tribunal reserved judgment on allegations of sex discrimination by the lord chancellor. An earlier hearing found Lord Irvine had discriminated indirectly against a London solicitor, Jane Coker, last year when he appointed a friend to an advisory post without advertising it.

Council drops tax demands

Peterborough city council has halted legal action against nearly 400 people who owe a total £130,000 in council tax, poll tax, domestic rates and business rates. "There are cases where it's impossible to pursue payments," a spokesman said.

Sir Elton's sale tops £100,000

A London sale of Sir Elton John's clothes for his Aids foundation raised over £100,000 in four hours, organisers said last night. The pop star is disposing of 15,000 items of clothing and accessories.

Lottery winner

One ticket won the £3.26m jackpot in last night's national lottery draw with 7, 19, 28, 30, 33 and 37. The bonus was 29. Lottery extra numbers were 7, 9, 21, 22, 26 and 49, the jackpot £3.5m.

fields.headline: Derailed trains add to misery
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack was last night carrying out emergency repair work at Northampton and Bristol after the derailment of two freight trains, causing widespread inconvenience to thousands of passengers.
fields.body:
Railtrack was last night carrying out emergency repair work at Northampton and Bristol after the derailment of two freight trains, causing widespread inconvenience to thousands of passengers.

The most serious incident happened at Northampton in the early hours of yesterday morning and involved two wagons leaving the tracks. Railtrack last night estimated the cost of repairs could top £750,000, before compensation for passengers. In extensive repair work, four miles of sleepers will have to be relaid, and services for the town may be disrupted for a fortnight.

Environment agency staff were called to the scene of the 2.30am Bristol derailment after diesel from the coal train's engine spilled into a stream. More than 1,000 litres of fuel polluted a brook and lake.

Railtrack announced that limited services for peak time trains could begin tomorrow at Northampton.

Work on the task of moving the two damaged wagons from the goods train of 27 wagons which, after the incident, was blocking the south entrance to Northampton station, began soon after 1.30am yesterday. Hydraulic lifts were used to carry out the work, which was complicated by the position of the trucks on a viaduct.

Railtrack said that one of the wagons came off the rails four miles south of Northampton. The train had been travelling at 20 mph, but the driver was initially unaware of the problem due to the size of the train, which was more than a quarter of a mile long.

The train had freight containers and flasks, some of which were marked "hazardous substances''.

Mr Dawson said initial investigations ruled out gauge corner cracking, the problem at the centre of the Hatfield crash last month; the likely cause was a broken sleeper.

Northampton is on a branch line of the west coast main line, and is served by 71 trains each day, now working on an emergency timetable.

Steve Brook, of the environment agency, said that it was too early to assess the impact the diesel spilled at the Filton junction in Bristol would have on the environment but that already some birds had been affected. The priority, he said, was to remove as much diesel as possible and keep damage to a minimum.

The rail freight company, English, Welsh and Scottish Railways, yesterday said that the Bristol derailment probably had been caused by safety mechanisms activated after the train passed a red signal. Initial inquiries showed that the "catch-point" system automatically derailed the train to prevent it carrying on into further danger.
