webTitle: War games on the net: but this time it's for real

fields.headline: War games on the net: but this time it's for real
fields.standfirst: It's a war where nobody gets killed and almost anyone can join in. Brian Whitaker         reports on the Middle East    cyber-war
fields.trailText: It's a war where nobody gets killed and almost anyone can join in. Brian Whitaker reports on the Middle East cyber-war
fields.body:
While Israelis and Palestinians have been slugging it out on the ground with guns and stones, others have gone into battle with mouse and modem. Although cyber-attacks are not in themselves new, this is the first political conflict in which two sides have fought each other in such an organised way over the internet.

The war began early in October when Israel supporters crashed Albawaba.com, a Jordanian-based portal site, by deluging its chat room with emails containing large and offensive image files.

Hackers also broke into several Hizbullah-related websites, planting Israeli flags and other material on their pages.

Palestinian supporters retaliated with an attack on Netvision, the Israeli internet service provider (ISP) which hosts websites for the Knesset, the foreign ministry and the defence forces. Service became extremely slow for a couple of weeks and ordinary subscribers to the Netvision service had difficulty logging on.

The American giant, AT&T, came to Netvision's rescue - and was promptly listed by various Arab/Islamic groups as a company to boycott.

So far, about 90 Israeli sites have been attacked, and around 20 on the other side, according to iDefense, an electronic security firm. The balance of casualties in cyberspace is the reverse of what has actually happened on the ground, and this may be explained by the scarcity of Palestinian websites.

The most common attacks are of two types, both fairly primitive.

The first is the equivalent of scrawling graffiti on a street poster: someone breaks into an "enemy" website and defaces it. The damage is usually so obvious that it is quickly spotted and repaired.

Last week Unity, one of the Arab-Islamic groups involved in the cyber-war, circulated an email announcing that the Israel Institute of Technology's website had been defaced with a message saying: "Leave Jerusalem... or better, drop dead!"

By the time the email arrived, the website was back to normal, and as proof of the exploit, Unity had to rely on pointing to a mirror copy of the offending page.

The other type of attack, known as "denial of service", overloads a server - usually by bombarding it with emails or pings. There are several bits of software that can do this, with such colourful names as EvilPing, FakeMail, WinSmurf, PutDown and QuickFire. There are also ways of defending against them once a website is aware that it may be attacked.

To bring down a website by this method usually requires a concerted effort by a group of surfers - which can be difficult to organise. It may be fun at first, but people quickly get bored.

Several "attack sites" have been set up where surfers can join in the battle. But the more they are publicised, the more likely it is that the host ISP will find out and remove them.

This happened to one attack site hosted by Tripod. Last week it had been replaced by a message saying it was unavailable because the subscriber "may have posted content in violation of the Tripod Terms of Service".

Unity's attack page still survives - possibly because it is difficult to find and can only be reached by redirection from another site. Visitors are invited to "defend the Resistance" by attacking groups of "Zionist websites" which include the Israeli defence forces, the prime minister's office, the Bank of Israel and the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange.

"One small windows will be opened for each link you click, and all what you have to do is not to close them as long you are on net, the program will be automatically work," it says, with scant regard for grammar.

Trying this for a few seconds - purely in the interests of research - I found that my hard drive whirred madly, and I was struck by the frightening thought that anyone who joins in this kind of attack is taking a lot on trust. How could I be sure that Israeli hackers had not broken into the Unity site and replaced its attack software with some horrible bug that could, at this very moment, be scrambling my own hard drive?

In reality, there is no evidence that these crude attacks have so far caused lasting damage. Israeli internet services may well be made more resilient as a result, and the companies that advise on defensive systems will get richer.

But a more sophisticated attack hit the American-Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC), a pro-Israel lobbying group.

The attacker, "Doctor Nuker, founder of the Pakistan Hackerz Club", not only defaced the site, but also downloaded the credit card details of 700 people - including a Republican senator - who had subscribed to AIPAC via the internet. The FBI advised them all to cancel their cards and monitor transactions.

The Pakistan Hackerz Club had previously concentrated its efforts on defacing Indian websites, in support of Kashmir separatism.

Opinions on the ethics of cyber-war range from "cool" to "criminal". Some see it as a legitimate form of political protest - "hacktivism" - while others regard it as vandalism, or worse.

At one level, shutting down an "enemy" website can be considered a suppression of free speech - the electronic equivalent of book burning. It conflicts with the spirit of the internet, which is to let everyone have their say.

In the crude form that it takes in the Middle East conflict, there is no sign that it is doing much to advance the cause of either side, though it does give some people a sense of participation and conceivably diverts them from more violent activity.

We have yet to see the full weight of a government's resources deployed in a cyber-attack. Earlier this month there were reports that the Pentagon had considered bringing down Serbia's financial systems during the Kosovo conflict.

It is said to have backed off, partly because of doubts about international law, and partly because of fears that such weapons, if used, could easily be adopted by America's enemies.

On the other hand, an effective cyber-attack might have ended the war more quickly, with fewer lives lost.

Last week Unity, one of the Arab-Islamic groups involved in the cyber-war, circulated an email announcing that the Israel Institute of Technology's website had been defaced with a message saying: "Leave Jerusalem... or better, drop dead!" By the time the email arrived, the website was back to normal, and as proof of the exploit, Unity had to rely on pointing to a mirror copy of the offending page. The other type of attack, known as "denial of service", overloads a server - usually by bombarding it with emails or pings. There are several bits of software that can do this, with such colourful names as EvilPing, FakeMail, WinSmurf, PutDown and QuickFire. There are also ways of defending against them once a website is aware that it may be attacked. To bring down a website by this method usually requires a concerted effort by a group of surfers - which can be difficult to organise. It may be fun at first, but people quickly get bored. Several "attack sites" have been set up where surfers can join in the battle. But the more they are publicised, the more likely it is that the host ISP will find out and remove them. This happened to one attack site hosted by Tripod. Last week it had been replaced by a message saying it was unavailable because the subscriber "may have posted content in violation of the Tripod Terms of Service". Unity's attack page still survives - possibly because it is difficult to find and can only be reached by redirection from another site. Visitors are invited to "defend the Resistance" by attacking groups of "Zionist websites" which include the Israeli defence forces, the prime minister's office, the Bank of Israel and the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange. "One small windows will be opened for each link you click, and all what you have to do is not to close them as long you are on net, the program will be automatically work," it says, with scant regard for grammar. Trying this for a few seconds - purely in the interests of research - I found that my hard drive whirred madly, and I was struck by the frightening thought that anyone who joins in this kind of attack is taking a lot on trust. How could I be sure that Israeli hackers had not broken into the Unity site and replaced its attack software with some horrible bug that could, at this very moment, be scrambling my own hard drive? In reality, there is no evidence that these crude attacks have so far caused lasting damage. Israeli internet services may well be made more resilient as a result, and the companies that advise on defensive systems will get richer. But a more sophisticated attack hit the American-Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC), a pro-Israel lobbying group. The attacker, "Doctor Nuker, founder of the Pakistan Hackerz Club", not only defaced the site, but also downloaded the credit card details of 700 people - including a Republican senator - who had subscribed to AIPAC via the internet. The FBI advised them all to cancel their cards and monitor transactions. The Pakistan Hackerz Club had previously concentrated its efforts on defacing Indian websites, in support of Kashmir separatism. Opinions on the ethics of cyber-war range from "cool" to "criminal". Some see it as a legitimate form of political protest - "hacktivism" - while others regard it as vandalism, or worse. At one level, shutting down an "enemy" website can be considered a suppression of free speech - the electronic equivalent of book burning. It conflicts with the spirit of the internet, which is to let everyone have their say. In the crude form that it takes in the Middle East conflict, there is no sign that it is doing much to advance the cause of either side, though it does give some people a sense of participation and conceivably diverts them from more violent activity. We have yet to see the full weight of a government's resources deployed in a cyber-attack. Earlier this month there were reports that the Pentagon had considered bringing down Serbia's financial systems during the Kosovo conflict. It is said to have backed off, partly because of doubts about international law, and partly because of fears that such weapons, if used, could easily be adopted by America's enemies. On the other hand, an effective cyber-attack might have ended the war more quickly, with fewer lives lost.

webTitle: Army whistleblower will not be prosecuted

fields.headline: Army whistleblower will not be prosecuted
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: An army whistleblower who has become the key witness in a police inquiry into collusion between the military and loyalist terrorists in Northern Ireland will not be prosecuted for breaking the Official Secrets Act, the Guardian can reveal.
fields.body:
An army whistleblower who has become the key witness in a police inquiry into collusion between the military and loyalist terrorists in Northern Ireland will not be prosecuted for breaking the Official Secrets Act, the Guardian can reveal.

The soldier, known by the pseudonym Martin Ingram, was charged under the act following a series of articles in a national newspaper which revealed the activities of a covert army intelligence cell, the force research unit (FRU), during the late 1980s and early 1990s.

Ingram's allegations made him an invaluable witness for an investigation led by Sir John Stevens, the commissioner of the Metropolitan police, who began an inquiry into collusion last year, focusing on the murder of the solicitor Pat Finucane.

But Ingram's allegations also infuriated the Ministry of Defence, which sought and won gagging orders on the Sunday Times newspaper.

While Sir John's team investigated Ingram's claims, Scotland Yard's special branch began its own inquiry into a man it believed to be Ingram.

Security sources told the Guardian yesterday that the investigation had been halted and the charges against the former FRU soldier had been dropped. The police are also believed to have dropped their investigation into Liam Clarke, Northern Ireland editor of the Sunday Times.

Ingram has said a military intelligence breaking and entry team tried to destroy evidence of FRU collusion by burning a Northern Ireland office used by Sir John's team.

Fire broke out hours before the team planned to arrest Brian Nelson, paid by the army while also acting as intelligence officer for the Ulster Defence Association, and implicated in the unresolved murder of Mr Finucane.

Ingram also claims that at least one soldier was killed because army handlers of an IRA quartermaster in Derry refused to sabotage weapons, fearing it would compromise him. The IRA later discovered his double life, and murdered him.

The soldier accused of being Ingram has had his house burgled. A manuscript of a book he was writing went missing. The manuscript turned up a few days later in the hands of the prosecution at a court hearing when government lawyers obtained an injunction preventing him from publishing his book.

Last night, the crown prosecution service said the police had conducted a "thorough investigation" into disclosures in the Sunday Times last year.

It said that after carefully considering the matter it had decided there was insufficient evidence to provide a "realistic prospect of prosecution of either of the individuals" concerned.

webTitle: IRA man sought gun 'to defend crowd'

fields.headline: IRA man sought gun 'to defend crowd'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: The first self-confessed member of the Provisional IRA to give evidence to the Bloody Sunday inquiry yesterday told how he tried unsuccessfully to find a rifle "to shoot back at the soldiers and to defend the people in the crowd".
fields.body:
The first self-confessed member of the Provisional IRA to give evidence to the Bloody Sunday inquiry yesterday told how he tried unsuccessfully to find a rifle "to shoot back at the soldiers and to defend the people in the crowd".

Leaning on the shoulder of his wife, Patricia, Thomas McGlinchey, 66, hobbled into the inquiry room at Derry's Guildhall on artificial legs.

His legs were blown off in October 1975 as he turned on the ignition of his car, in one of four assassination attempts on him by the loyalist paramilitary Ulster Volunteer Force.

Mr McGlinchey told the tribunal about his family's republican history. His grandfather was the commander of the IRA in Derry and his father was operations commander in the 1930s and 40s. He himself joined in 1956. After the Troubles started, and the Official IRA split, he joined the Provisionals in 1970.

At the time of Bloody Sunday, in January 1972, he was chairman of the prisoners' dependants fund in Derry, raising money for their welfare and driving families to Long Kesh internment camp, where his oldest brother was held.

Mr McGlinchey was repeatedly asked by counsel to the inquiry, Christopher Clarke QC, if he would give in private the names of other Provisionals in the city at the time who could then be approached and possibly offered anonymity like the soldiers. The chairman, Lord Saville, made a personal appeal.

"If you are not prepared to help us," Lord Saville said, "then it is going to be said - whether true or not - that the reluctance of people to come forward and help us speaks for itself and shows that those people have something to hide."

Mr McGlinchey replied: "I am here to help the Bloody Sunday thing, that is what I am sitting here doing. I could have said no, I'm not coming. I came here to help the people involved. I am not here to tell names of who was a member of the republican movement. I do not think it would be right of me to do it. If the people, that is members of the republican movement, want to do what I have done, that is up to them."

He also claimed not to know the identity of the Provisional officer commanding in Derry at the time, despite being shown a contemporary cutting from the Derry Journal openly describing the OC of the Derry battalion as Martin McGuinness, now Sinn Fein's education minister.

On the day of the civil rights protest, which ended in the death of 13 unarmed civilians, Mr McGlinchey had been asked by the organisers to drive his coal lorry at the head of the march with the loudspeaker equipment for the rally.

Arriving at Free Derry Corner, he realised from the panic and shouts from the crowd that shooting had started. "I do not recall where the shooting came from. I was more interested in getting hold of a rifle to shoot back at the soldiers and to defend the people in the crowd. I wasn't the only one looking for a gun. I went to a place near Cable Street, where I thought I would have been able to get a gun, but there were none around. "That day I would have went anywhere to get a gun."

Asked how many people were looking for guns, he replied: "Thousands. I think the majority of people on that march, if they had got a gun, they would have been using it."

But he claimed not to know whether anyone had got a weapon or had fired one.

Other witnesses, Mr Clarke pointed out, would tell the inquiry about gunmen in the Rossville flats where a number of people were shot by the army, as well as at other vantage points in the no go areas of the Bogside and the Creggan.

Later a retired post office worker, Wilfred White, described how his statement at the time about an army sniper firing from the GPO had been suppressed after he was threatened with the Official Secrets Act. Mr White agreed to tear the document up in front of the assistant postmaster.

"There was the implied threat that my job was at stake. But there was a very good explanation," he said. "We were working in a republican area and we had allowed troops into government property. We would have been an open target."

Last year Mr White was given assurances by the Saville inquiry lawyers that he would not be in breach of the act.

An Englishman who had served in the Royal Navy, Mr White said that on the morning of the march, soldiers in an armoured personnel carrier, known as a pig, were let into the compound. One soldier, with Royal Artillery flashes, climbed up a ladder to the first floor window of a derelict house in the compound. He was handed up a 303 Lee Enfield rifle.

Just before the rioting started shortly after 4pm, Mr White said, "I heard a loud crack. I looked up to the window at the old house and saw the soldier in the window. His rifle was at his shoulder in the firing position and there was a wee bit of smoke coming from it." A few minutes later he said he heard another shot. Looking up he saw a soldier behind a parapet on the Presbyterian church, with his rifle in the firing position.

webTitle: Beef farmers face uncertain future as market falls

fields.headline: Beef farmers face uncertain future as market falls
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Farmers are watching the supermarket shelves once more, trying to gauge how the consumer will jump as the BSE crisis worsens across Europe.
fields.body:
Farmers are watching the supermarket shelves once more, trying to gauge how the consumer will jump as the BSE crisis worsens across Europe.

There was concern that shoppers were already turning away from beef to lamb before the latest edict from Brussels heralded more sweeping emergency measures to combat the threat to the EU's cattle industry.

Prices paid to farmers are falling, by up to 5% in the past week, and around 15% on this time last year. It may be a seasonal blip. Some in the industry doubt it.

There is a glut on the European market as consumer interest dives in France, Germany and Spain, and while taking millions of cattle off the market might stabilise prices in the medium term, it is anyone's guess what happens in the next few weeks.

The National Farmers' Union and government authorities will naturally be welcoming tight controls across Europe - nearly five years after they were imposed in Britain. But they also remember how beef production dived in 1996, when the link between BSE and new variant CJD in humans was established.

The market dropped by a fifth in the year, and though consumption is back to pre-1996 levels, prices have never really recovered. Britons consume 917,000 tonnes of beef a year, a sixth of it imported. Exports are a trickle, 500 tonnes worth £5m in the year since the EU embargo was lifted.

Market research for the meat and livestock commission has suggested that consumers want a ban on French imports (about 5,000 tonnes a year), even if the authorities are waiting for scientific evidence to justify a decision. There is also a perception that "our beef is all right", and renewed encouragement to look at the label for country of production.

But providing country of origin information to consumers in hotels and restaurants is often difficult.

Britain knows all about destroying cattle more than 30 months old. It has been doing it since March 1996. No animal in recent years has shown signs of BSE unless well over that age.

About 4.7m of them have been slaughtered and burned into a near 500,000 tonne pile of remains in 13 stores around the country. Last week, 29,100 cattle, mainly old dairy cows past their milking best, headed for this mountain.

A handful of special incinerators is used to destroy this grisly reminder that will be with Britain for years. Only 60% of the pile is likely to have been removed by 2002, and any hopes that the 30 month rule might be abandoned in a couple of years, providing the British epidemic continues to fall and other safeguards remain, seems forlorn if the European problem worsens.

This alone is costing the EU taxpayer £400m a year. Brussels picks up 70% of the costs, and there are severe doubts in Britain whether provisional estimates of the extra £785m of EU-wide measures is anywhere near accurate.

Then there is the question of the tests. They are meant to be used as an indicator of the size of the BSE epidemic, not a health guarantee. They have not been validated to test for sub-clinical BSE, where cattle may be infected but not showing obvious signs. The controls on offals, thought more likely to carry the disease, and proper enforcement are more important. Privately the government was already getting nervous that the testing regime was appearing to act as a health guarantee when it is not.

But if it insists on a 30 month blanket ban when no other country has more than 600 cases - compared with Britain's 177,500, and 1,100 this year alone - even in a declining epidemic, hopes of the ban being lifted in Britain in the near future seem doomed.

fields.headline: Cigars the reward for really bad sex
fields.trailText: It is every novelist's dream: to steal one of the most hotly contested awards in the publishing world from under the nose of a literary giant. Yesterday Sean Thomas was understandably ebullient as he beat off a challenge from John Updike for the Bad Sex in Fiction prize.
fields.body:
It is every novelist's dream: to steal one of the most hotly contested awards in the publishing world from under the nose of a literary giant. Yesterday Sean Thomas was understandably ebullient as he beat off a challenge from John Updike for the Bad Sex in Fiction prize.

"It's an enormous honour and I'm gratified," said the author, after judges from the Literary Review decided that the remarkable coital descriptions in his second novel, Kissing England, were not only bad but astoundingly silly.

"I knew I had a very good chance of winning it. I think mine was by far the most outrageous passage."

As Alex, one of the three narrators of Kissing England, beds his "schoolgirl chick", Mr Thomas writes: "It is time, time ... Now. Yes. She is so small and compact and yet she has all the necessary features ... Shall I compare thee to a Sony Walkman, thou art more compact and more - She is his own Toshiba, his dinky little JVC, his sweet Aiwa ... Aiwa, aiwa aiwa aiwa aiwa aiwa aiwa aiwa aiwa aiwa aiwaaaaaaaaahhhhhhhhh ..."

Thomas said defensively: "It was meant to be funny and I think the judges took it that way. But it's also meant to be an insight into the lunacy that goes through men's minds when it comes to sex. I'm not sure women quite understand that lunacy. Apart from the sex passages it's quite a serious book - it looks at nationalism and race and sex."

Despite the meagre prize of cigars, the annual awards are becoming increasingly well known. And the judges are becoming more exacting.

"It's always easy to find foolish descriptions of the sexual act, but they have to be funny as well," explained Auberon Waugh, editor-in-chief of the Literary Review.

Even rising star Brian O'Doherty, shortlisted for the Booker Prize, failed to rally the judges with his description of sex with a sheep.

The other nominees, in addition to Updike for Gertrude & Claudius, were Wendy Perriam, for Lying; Candida Clark, for The Constant Eye; Edward St Aubyn, for A Clue to the Exit; and Wendy Holden, for Bad Heir Day.

fields.headline: Hope for Huntington's sufferers
fields.trailText: Surgeons yesterday offered new hope to sufferers of Huntington's disease saying they   appeared to have succeeded in regenerating damaged parts of the brain through grafts   of human foetal tissue.
fields.body:
Surgeons yesterday offered new hope to sufferers of Huntington's disease saying they appeared to have succeeded in regenerating damaged parts of the brain through grafts of human foetal tissue.

Only five people so far have had the surgery, but the French team responsible says three of the five experienced marked improvements in their lives.

Marc Peschanski and his colleagues in Paris published their results on the website of the Lancet medical journal, following release of some of their material by the French government . They do not claim the surgery means a cure, but believe it offers "a glimmer of hope" and justifies a bigger trial.

Huntington's is inherited and symptoms usually appear between the age of 35 and 50. A distressing, degenerative brain condition, it leads to jerky, involuntary movements and dementia.

The French team transplanted healthy brain cells from seven to nine-week-old foetuses into the brains of the five patients, all of whom had mild to moderate Huntington's. A year after the surgery, scans showed increased brain activity at the location of the grafts in three patients, who also displayed improved limb function and thinking ability.

fields.headline: Webwatch
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: On call | Film fun
fields.body:
On call
You too can have one of the first personal PhonePages, though it won't be much use until third generation (3G) phone systems arrive. The idea is that when someone calls you, your PhonePage will be sent to their mobile. PhonePages can also be viewed on the web at www.my.no, but you have to know someone's mobile phone number to look them up. The company's site is at www.thephonepages.com.

Film fun
The end of the year always brings lots of new movies and websites. Two of the best are for 102 Dalmatians and The 6th Day with Arnold Schwarzenegger. Anyday soon
Palm Inc has bought Anyday.com, my favourite web-based personal information manager, and plans to move us to www.palm.net. You don't need a Palm to use the service: it synchronises with Palm OS systems, Palm Desktop for Windows, Windows CE (but not PocketPC), Outlook 97, 98 and 2000, Lotus Notes, Lotus Organizer and others.

On live
The three tenors (Jose Carreras, Placido Domingo and Luciano Pavarotti) make their webcast debut on Sunday with a Christmas concert from Vienna (see www.onlineclassics.com). The programme includes White Christmas, Jingle Bells and Amazing Grace. Black music site Darkerthanblue.com will be webcasting film of Craig David's current tour from December 5. See darkerthanblue.

On radio
The XY Network, which is still in pre-launch mode, is hosting the whole syndicated two-hour Gilles Peterson Worldwide show. Go to www.xy.fm and select XY Music (Wap phone owners can also try www.xy.fm). The former Kiss FM DJ is more tuneful than the anti-liberal Rush Limbaugh, whose site at www.rushlimbaugh.com is already the most highly ranked broadcast site on the web. Well, he has 15 hours a week on 600 American radio stations to plug it.

Look down
Multimap.com has added a compelling new feature: aerial photographs. The images cover Greater London and major UK cities and counties. Some foreign cities - such as Amsterdam, Paris, Brussels and Tokyo - will be available soon. The photos at multimap.com are provided by Cities Revealed.

Upstarting?
The UpStarts Awards have been launched to offer £50,000 to help three "social entrepreneurs" start their projects. Entries may be posted on the website at www.upstarts.org.uk until May. The judges include Labour MPs Paul Boateng and David Willetts.

TopTenBuys, a site that lists the top 10 products in a wide range of categories, has just gone live: www.toptenbuys.co.uk delivers very brief but "up-to-date, unbiased, rated reviews of the most popular consumer products and services available both on and offline in the UK". fields.headline: Commuter Diary
fields.standfirst:
Waiting for a signal of life on the network

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Yorkshire commuter Richard Culf continues to chart his experiences with the troubled rail system
fields.body:
Yorkshire commuter Richard Culf continues to chart his experiences with the troubled rail system

In the 1970s I remember watching Leonard Rossiter as Reginald Perrin explaining his daily catalogue of rail incidents - "11 minutes late - stolen lines at Surbiton", "seven minutes late - badger ate a junction box at Effingham Junction". More than 20 years on I catch myself doing the same thing; the real excuses being no more plausible.

As a rule I find it's always a bad sign when there appear to be more buses at a train station than there are trains. I should have expected the worst as I picked my way past ranks of coaches at the front of Leeds city station. Not for the first time I stood and watched the stream of cancellations and delays tumbling down the screen; cascading like some kind of crazed fruit machine. All the favourites were there (delays to Edinburgh, London, Liverpool, Manchester) while the times of some were too embarrassing to display - I later discovered the service from Poole was a mere 225 minutes late.

As my service pulled into the platform I dared hope it might escape unscathed. Foolish thoughts obviously, as the Out of Service notice was being readied even as it drew to a halt. The public address system helpfully added: "We are sorry to announce that the 18:43 service to Ilkley has been cancelled due to signalling difficulties - please listen for further announcements." It's mildly entertaining to listen to the reflections of passengers. A man turned to me: "Call this running a railway? This lot couldn't run a bath." With a shrug he went to make the "alternative arrangements" we are so often advised to make.

The next service home, the 19:13, pulled out sedately at 19:25 - "signalling difficulties" apparently resolved. They say it's polite to be 10 minutes late.

fields.headline: Derailed trains add to misery
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack was last night carrying out emergency repair work at Northampton and Bristol after the derailment of two freight trains, causing widespread inconvenience to thousands of passengers.
fields.body:
Railtrack was last night carrying out emergency repair work at Northampton and Bristol after the derailment of two freight trains, causing widespread inconvenience to thousands of passengers.

The most serious incident happened at Northampton in the early hours of yesterday morning and involved two wagons leaving the tracks. Railtrack last night estimated the cost of repairs could top £750,000, before compensation for passengers. In extensive repair work, four miles of sleepers will have to be relaid, and services for the town may be disrupted for a fortnight.

Environment agency staff were called to the scene of the 2.30am Bristol derailment after diesel from the coal train's engine spilled into a stream. More than 1,000 litres of fuel polluted a brook and lake.

Railtrack announced that limited services for peak time trains could begin tomorrow at Northampton.

Work on the task of moving the two damaged wagons from the goods train of 27 wagons which, after the incident, was blocking the south entrance to Northampton station, began soon after 1.30am yesterday. Hydraulic lifts were used to carry out the work, which was complicated by the position of the trucks on a viaduct.

Railtrack said that one of the wagons came off the rails four miles south of Northampton. The train had been travelling at 20 mph, but the driver was initially unaware of the problem due to the size of the train, which was more than a quarter of a mile long.

The train had freight containers and flasks, some of which were marked "hazardous substances''.

Mr Dawson said initial investigations ruled out gauge corner cracking, the problem at the centre of the Hatfield crash last month; the likely cause was a broken sleeper.

Northampton is on a branch line of the west coast main line, and is served by 71 trains each day, now working on an emergency timetable.

Steve Brook, of the environment agency, said that it was too early to assess the impact the diesel spilled at the Filton junction in Bristol would have on the environment but that already some birds had been affected. The priority, he said, was to remove as much diesel as possible and keep damage to a minimum.

The rail freight company, English, Welsh and Scottish Railways, yesterday said that the Bristol derailment probably had been caused by safety mechanisms activated after the train passed a red signal. Initial inquiries showed that the "catch-point" system automatically derailed the train to prevent it carrying on into further danger.

webTitle: Election forces Ashdown to turn down Kosovo job

fields.headline: Election forces Ashdown to turn down Kosovo job
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Paddy Ashdown has told Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, that he is no longer available to succeed Bernard Kouchner as head of the troubled UN mission in Kosovo, because he cannot leave Westminster so close to the general election.
fields.body:
Paddy Ashdown has told Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, that he is no longer available to succeed Bernard Kouchner as head of the troubled UN mission in Kosovo, because he cannot leave Westminster so close to the general election.

"I am the MP for Yeovil, I owe it to my party and my constituency to stay on,'' the 59-year-old MP has told Lib Dem colleagues at the Commons. After months of speculation that Tony Blair might be able to win international backing for his ally, the former Liberal Democrat leader, Mr Annan rang Mr Ashdown in London on Tuesday night to ask if he was still available to take over now that the Frenchman has signalled a desire to leave Pristina before Christmas. But Mr Ashdown told him he was no longer able to consider the post because it had come at the wrong time - too close to the expected spring election to disrupt his party by triggering a byelection in Yeovil. "I would have done it like a shot if I had been asked last year,'' he told one Westminster colleague. Yesterday he said: "There are times in politics when time works in your favour and there are times when it doesn't.'' There is no question that the US has blocked his candidacy, he has assured fellow Liberal Democrats. His ex-research chief, David Laws, has been picked to fight Yeovil where Mr Ashdown had an 11,403 majority in 1997.

webTitle: Labour hits its youth jobs target pledge on jobs

fields.headline: Labour hits its youth jobs target pledge on jobs
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will today signal plans to overhaul and extend the new deal when he confirms the government has fulfilled Labour's manifesto to take 250,000 unemployed young people off the dole.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will today signal plans to overhaul and extend the new deal when he confirms the government has fulfilled Labour's manifesto to take 250,000 unemployed young people off the dole.

The prime minister is to make clear that a revamped scheme will be adopted if Labour wins a second term to help jobless single parents and the disabled find work. "We're not just going to give ourselves a big tick," said a No 10 official. "This is about looking forward and how it's important to meet the challenge of the most difficult cases."

The scheme has already been widened to cover long term unemployed adults and "job focused" interviews are under consideration for 800,000 on incapacity benefit.

At a Downing Street press conference Mr Blair will point out that the core of long-term unemployed young claimants is at an all-time low of 37,000.

Funded out of the £5.2bn windfall tax on privatised utlities, the government claims an average £2,000 per head was spent on young people, and £4,000 was the cost of those moving into unsubsidised jobs. The Tories, however, yesterday branded the new deal an "expensive flop" and put the cost of every job at nearer £20,000, arguing about a fifth of the jobs have proved temporary and many of those who found work would probably have done so anyway.

Independent experts, however, appear broadly supportive and judge the scheme a success. A National Institute for Economic and Social Research report last year concluded sthe new deal was effectively paying for itself by saving benefits while the Industrial Society yesterday said it had a "broader value" by shaking up the employment service.

Getting 250,000 unemployed young people aged between 18 and 24 into work was one of the five Labour promises listed on the credit card-sized pledge cards distributed at the last election and the third the party claimed yesterday had been fulfilled. The two others were a 100,000 cut in waiting lists, and a stable economy with no rise in income tax rates.

webTitle: Lockerbie defence has case to answer

fields.headline: Lockerbie defence has case to answer
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lockerbie
fields.trailText: Judges at the Lockerbie trial yesterday dismissed a defence motion to have the case against one of the Libyans accused of the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 thrown out.
fields.body:
Judges at the Lockerbie trial yesterday dismissed a defence motion to have the case against one of the Libyans accused of the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 thrown out.

Richard Keen QC, counsel for Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, had argued for the case against his client to be dropped on the basis that there was not enough evidence to sustain the charges.

But the presiding judge, Lord Sutherland, said: "We are not satisfied there is no case to answer."

The judges' decision was welcomed by the families of those who died in the 1988 bombing. Jim Swire, whose daughter Flora was on board, said the ruling meant there would be a more thorough examination of the circumstances which led to the bombing.

"We didn't come here looking for convictions or acquittals. We came expecting the court to decide ... and to get to the truth," he said.

Lawyers for Fhimah and the co-accused, Abdel Baset al-Megrahi, will begin the defence case when the £2m-a-month trial at the Scottish court in the Netherlands reconvenes on Tuesday.

Both men deny charges of murder, conspiracy to murder and a breach of the Aviation Security Act. They have lodged a special defence of incrimination, blaming various Palestinian terrorist groups - including the Damascus-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine - General Command - for the bombing.

Mr Keen had moved to have the case against his client thrown out on the basis that there was no forensic evidence, and all other evidence presented by the prosecution was purely circumstantial.

Prosecution lawyers agreed there was no direct evidence, but argued that, when the circumstantial evidence was looked at as a whole, it was enough to infer Fhimah's guilt.

Although many of the prosecution's star witnesses have appeared to crumble under cross examination, yesterday's decision by the judges was not based on the credibility of the evidence produced in court.

A key part of the prosecution's case against Fhimah is a diary entry, dated six days before the bombing, which refers to obtaining luggage security tags from Air Malta.

The prosecution alleges that the bomb which blew up flight 103 was planted on an Air Malta plane at Luqa airport, before it was transferred to the New York bound jumbo at Frankfurt. Fhimah worked as station manager for Libyan Arab Airlines at Luqa airport and the prosecution claims this was a front for his work with the Libyan intelligence agency, the JSO.

Although Fhimah had given up his job at the airport before the bombing, he kept his security pass. The prosecution says this was to allow Fhimah access to the Air Malta luggage tags.

A Libyan double agent, Majid Giaka, who defected to the US in 1991, also claimed he had watched Fhimah take a case, similar to the one prosecutors say housed the Lockerbie bomb, unchecked through customs at Luqa airport.

Mr Keen argued that these claims alone were not enough to warrant the continuation of the case against his client. The judges, however, disagreed.

"We have regard in particular to certain entries in the second accused's [Fhimah's] diary, his association with the first accused with whom he is charged with acting in concert and crucially the evidence of Giaka," he said.

The judges' rejection of the defence submission will have no effect on the trial outcome. Yesterday they considered only the quantity of the evidence; when they come to their verdict they will also consider its quality.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: A computer design engineer phoned emergency services to report his own suicide, an inquest at Basingstoke, Hampshire, heard yesterday. Eugene Kapustynski, 40, of Surbiton, Surrey, dialled 999 on September 27, and pulled the trigger of a shotgun after speaking to the operator.
fields.body:
999 caller's suicide

A computer design engineer phoned emergency services to report his own suicide, an inquest at Basingstoke, Hampshire, heard yesterday. Eugene Kapustynski, 40, of Surbiton, Surrey, dialled 999 on September 27, and pulled the trigger of a shotgun after speaking to the operator.

Ford race case settlement

Ford has reached an "amicable" settlement with an Asian worker who suffered racial abuse and threats of violence. Sukhjit Parmar had Ku Klux Klan graffiti scrawled on his pay packet and was sent to an area known as the "punishment cell" at the Dagenham plant in Essex. Ford accepted liability at an employment tribunal last year.

British tourist prices soar

Tourist prices in Britain have risen "alarmingly", says the Good Britain Guide 2001, out today. The sharpest price hikes have been in places to eat, such as restaurants and pubs, and accommodation rates were up "across the board".

Shoplifters warned off

Convicted shoplifters are being sent letters by Avon and Somerset police warning them "stay out of trouble over the festive season". The force hopes that targeting known offenders will cut stealing in Bristol's shopping centres.

Red letter day for dogs' litter

Council chiefs are changing the colour of 150 new dog litter bins in Basildon, Essex, from red to grey, after confused locals thought they were post boxes and put letters in them.

fields.body:
John Prescott's controversial plans to part-privatise the air traffic control system (Nats) were rescued at the 11th hour yesterday after Tory peers drew back from defeating the government.

The future of the entire btransport bill, with its crucial measures for reviving the railways, was secured after the transport minister, Lord Macdonald, promised a further safety report. The Tory leader in the Lords, Lord Strathclyde, described the concession as a "major climbdown''.

Lord Macdonald said the government was undertaking to "take time to conduct the process properly. We will work on the detail and make sure we get it right''. Lib Dem peers who pushed for a vote which the government won by 157-57, were irate, privately accusing the Tories of being"feeble and divided''.

The government's victory means it can go ahead, after three months' consultation, with putting 46% of Nats into private hands. Five per cent will go to employees while the government will retain 49%, enabling it to dictate how the company is disposed of in the future.

Ministers believe the deeply unpopular sale is crucial to raise £1bn of investment needed for Nats to compete overseas. But after yesterday's concession the government must conduct a further review of safety implications and report back to Parliament.

While the sale will go through the contentious issue will re-emerge in the run-up to an expected spring election. Last night the shadow transport minister, Bernard Jenkin, was jubilant at the prospect."Mr Prescott made it clear last night that he did not want any further discussion in public on this issue but his unelected deputy has stitched him up," he said.Lord Macdonald's compromise solution avoided a constitutional showdown. Members of both houses have repeatedly defied the government, with Labour backbenchers inflicting three of their largest rebellions - by 47, 37 and, on Tuesday, 43 votes - and peers inflicting two defeats, the last on Monday. Last night peers insisted they had "done their duty" by pressing for further concessions. "The house... refused to be pushed off by threats and as a result, the government have had to back down," said Lord Strathclyde. The government's success was described as a "pyrrhic victory" by the air traffic controllers' union, the IPMS. "We may have lost the vote against privatisation of air traffic control but we have won overwhelming support throughout the country, the aviation industry and from MPs and peers of all parties," said Paul Noon, general secretary.

fields.body:
We have already apologised for the misspelling of the artist Chris Ofili's name in an article, Within these walls, page 59 onwards, Weekend, November 25. We now offer a further apology to the architect of Chris Ofili's house/studio, which was featured in the piece, for neglecting to credit him, even though other architects whose work was referred to in the piece were credited. The architect is, in fact, David Adjaye of Adjaye & Russell.

In an article headed The blame game, page 6, G2, November 28, we accidentally had Saddam Hussein in 1990 planning the invasion of Iraq, rather than Kuwait.

In our report on Britain's paedophiles, page 14, November 27, we referred to Bratislava in the Czech Republic. Bratislava is the capital of Slovakia. Prague is the capital of the Czech Republic.

Laurence Olivier, contrary to what we said in an article about Eastbourne, Travel, page 2, November 25, was not born in Yorkshire. He was born in Dorking in Surrey (May 22 1907; he died in 1989). Three of the villages mentioned in the piece, Climping, Fulking and Hurstpierpoint are in West Sussex, not East Sussex.

In our obituary of Conrad Voss Bark, whom we described as a journalist and fly-fishing enthusiast, page 24, yesterday, we said his pastimes included typing files. He much preferred tying flies, of course. The obituarist is exonerated.

In our Pass Notes on Nancy Sinatra, page 3, G2, yesterday, we said that Phil Spector co-wrote Spanish Harlem for BB King. In fact, it was written for Ben E King.

Homophone corner, from, In my father's footsteps, page 8, G2, yesterday, the writer of which we allowed to say, "I bought a cloth badge emblazoned with the hammer and sickle, and was crudely sowing it on my greatcoat ..."

fields.headline: Reading remembers an involuntary guest
fields.trailText: In May 1897 the prisoner in cell number C33 was released from Reading jail: "Oh beautiful world!" he exclaimed, in words probably carefully rehearsed,  writes Maev Kennedy.
fields.body:
In May 1897 the prisoner in cell number C33 was released from Reading jail: "Oh beautiful world!" he exclaimed, in words probably carefully rehearsed, writes Maev Kennedy.

The words are incorporated in a spectacular riverbank memorial, beside the high prison wall, unveiled yesterday in a tribute to the Berkshire town's involuntary guest, Oscar Wilde.

The poem Wilde wrote after his release from two years' hard labour for gross indecency, the Ballad of Reading Gaol - originally published as "by C.3.3." - has made the town world famous, but until the council commissioned the memorial from the sculptor Bruce Williams and the Irish poet Paul Muldoon there was little for the legion of literary pilgrims to see.

The town council had thought of a modest statue. It has ended up with a tonne of steel, the gates, 30 metres of elaborate railings, four scarlet "love seats", and a memorial bench. "The idea just evolved," Williams said. "I must say they've been brilliant about it."

The unveiling was timed to coincide with today's centenary of Wilde's death in a hotel room in Paris.

His cry of delight at the sight of the world beyond the prison gates is woven into the laser-cut steel.

Instead of using more familiar Wildean aphorisms, the arts officer, Tammy Bedford, explained the work incorporates two new poems, in the gates and on a hard wooden bench, made to the size of the plank bed in the prison cell. One uses the ballad's opening line "As I roved out" to recall both Wilde's ballad and the pain of the man who spent two years "beneath that little tent of blue we prisoners call the sky" unable to rove anywhere.

 Researchers at the British Library have analysed the only known recording of Oscar Wilde reading the Ballad of Reading Gaol, and pronounced it likely to be a fake.

fields.headline: A good idea at the time
fields.trailText: Surely the man who influenced David Bowie, namely Anthony Newley whom Bowie imitated on several recordings, should have had more votes than he. As for Eminem at number eight! Perhaps the "stars" interviewed by NME should have been questioned after the drugs wore off.
fields.body:
 Surely the man who influenced David Bowie, namely Anthony Newley whom Bowie imitated on several recordings, should have had more votes than he (Pop stars hail Bowie's influence, November 28). As for Eminem at number eight! Perhaps the "stars" interviewed by NME should have been questioned after the drugs wore off.

Mitch Mitchell
Bromley, Kent

 We could play to national strengths and use Scottish players in the British team (Red card for Straw's 'British team' idea, November 29) during torrential rainstorms, and English ones when the weather is nice or when there's a big win bonus.

Moray Barclay
Windsor, Berks
MBarclay@colt-telecom.com

 Is it a metaphor for the state of Britain's railways that, travelling alongside a country lane in Kent, our 300kmh Eurostar train was overtaken by a Fiesta?

Paul Dodd
Gloucester
P.dodd@tesco.net

 Nice to see people putting something back "EU Bank to bail out tube with £1bn loan" (November 29). Very generous chap, that boxer.

Jane Welsh
Lincoln
welsh@postmaster.co.uk

 Your correction (November 29) of your correction of David Beckham's tattoo reminds me of a spell-checker I once owned, which misspelt "misspelt" as "mispelt". Mispelt: fling rotten fruit at wrong politician. See Prescott v Voynet.

Alan Tyson
Chester

 How very crafty to bring the "big five" complementary therapies under the umbrella of the NHS (Hit and miss medicine, November 29), so that they too can be effectively knackered by immense waiting lists for the eventual privilege of a glimpse of the Great Man.

Peter Willis
Retired NHS GP

fields.headline: Portillo's pledge
fields.standfirst:
Maybe he really doesn't want to be leader

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Maybe he really doesn't want to be leader.
fields.body:
Strange goings-on. Michael Portillo gives an interview to El Pais in which he says his past homosexuality should not harm his career in his party: yet then it is reported that friends of the shadow chancellor think he may no longer plan to run for the leadership. Soon rumours are sweeping Westminster that he is thinking of leaving politics. Not true, he tells the Daily Telegraph - but now he repeats on the record what his "friends" had been saying: he no longer sees himself as a possible successor to William Hague.

Coming from such an ambitious man, in a party so thin on talent, this is unsettling. What could have brought him to such a conclusion? If it reflects a feeling that colleagues are out to get him, that is scarcely surprising. Some of them clearly are. For true Thatcherites, Mr Portillo is a blasphemer. He has turned against the true faith. Once seen as the lady's very best hope for keeping the flame alive, he seems almost to have changed since he lost his seat in May 1997 into someone else.

At conference last year he seemed more concerned with himself than with the evils of socialism as practised by Gordon Brown. He uses dirty words like care and compassion. He has even broken his links with the backbench Thatcherite priesthood, the No Turning Back group. At best, he's become a heretic; at worst, a traitor. In last week's Spectator, Norman Tebbit derided the "touchy-feely, pink pound policies of Michael Portillo". Note that "pink", especially, with its simultaneous implications of "left" and "gay".

He may have lost his constituency in the party without yet building a new one. He may also, looking at last week's byelection results, have begun to think in terms of five more grinding, squabbling years in continuing opposition. It is traditional in politics for talented people to deny any aspirations to lead their parties. This time, though, the disavowal could turn out to be real.

fields.headline: Global trade talks hit buffers
fields.standfirst:
Hope of a new round in 2001

Special report: World Trade Organisation
fields.trailText: It is a year ago today since the tear gas cannisters began rattling down the streets of Seattle. The smoke has yet to clear in the aftermath of the disastrous collapse of what was designed to be the crowning diplomatic achievement of the Clinton presidency - the launch of a new round of global trade talks.
fields.body:
It is a year ago today since the tear gas cannisters began rattling down the streets of Seattle. The smoke has yet to clear in the aftermath of the disastrous collapse of what was designed to be the crowning diplomatic achievement of the Clinton presidency - the launch of a new round of global trade talks.

Twelve months on, the world's biggest trading powers - the European Union, the United States and Japan - appear to be further apart than ever, and developing countries still feel excluded from the inner sanctums of the World Trade Organisation. There are vague hopes in the capitals of western Europe and north America that a new trade round might be launched next autumn when trade ministers meet for the first time since Seattle.

But given that no city anywhere in the world is prepared to risk a week of violent protest and the bad publicity which would almost certainly accompany the WTO's arrival in town, even finding a venue for their meeting is proving problematic. Abu Dhabi was supposed to host the next gathering but has bowed out.

Optimists believe the changing of the guard at the White House in January will remove one of the big stumbling blocks to progress, the lack of any impetus from Washington during the election campaign.

But with George W Bush looking likely to inherit the presidency, the optimists may be whistling in the wind. Mr Bush is an isolationist by temperament with no great regard for any of the pillars of the multilateral system, and his critics say he is in hock to the US corporate interests. Big business in the US wants a new trade round, but only on America's terms - greater access for their goods to foreign markets without competition from cheap goods from developing countries at home.

The Americans are under less pressure than the Europeans to restart talks because at the end of the Uruguay round in 1993 it was decided that unfinished business in agriculture and services - Washington's main concerns - would be dealt with early this century, even if a comprehensive round of talks had not begun.

Brussels, which has most to lose in agriculture particularly, wants a broad ranging round so it can trade off the painful concessions it must make in its heavily subsidised farm sector with gains elsewhere. As a sweetner Pascal Lamy, Europe's top trade negotiator has proposed duty and tariff-free access to the world's 48 poorest countries.

Development lobby groups dismiss the EU offer as a sop. "The north appears to be intent on ramming its agenda down the throats of the developing world," says Duncan Green, policy analyst for Cafod. "The atmosphere is one of suspicion and cynicism, and few signs of a new deal for the world's poor."

Privately, the politicians are aware of the problems facing the WTO. Seattle taught them that they can no longer afford to ride rough shod over the views of developing countries which now make up a majority of the WTO's 139 members.

But ministers say privately that little been done since Seattle despite promises from Mike Moore, the WTO's director general, to institute reforms. The body spent much of the past year dealing with a series of acrimonious disputes between the EU and the US - one of side effect of the failure to restart talks. He has become a scapegoat for all that has not been fixed since Seattle, and many negotiators have written off his chances of launching a new round in 2002 when his term ends.

He admits the WTO has taken over the mantle of the world's most unpopular organisation from the International Monetary Fund. Changing that image will require root and branch reform of the institution itself - making it more open and transparent. But it will also require a political push from the west and a willingness to look beyond their own electorates' interests, to offer a better deal for developing countries. Neither looks likely.

webTitle: Letters: Shore's little England is washed up

fields.headline: Shore's little England is washed up
fields.trailText: Peter Shore's interesting, if unpersuasive comment lacked one element of clarity - the nation referred to in the title. The terms "England", "British" and "UK" appeared without distinction.
fields.body:
 Peter Shore's interesting, if unpersuasive comment (Traitors to their nation, November 28) lacked one element of clarity - the nation referred to in the title. The terms "England", "British" and "UK" appeared without distinction.

Is Peter Shore's patriotism directed towards the United Kingdom, the superstate of which England is one of the four nations; to Britain, with neither geographical nor political definition, rather a cultural and historical icon; or just to England? I suspect that it is the last: warm beer and cricket and all. Little England.
Alastair Walker
Bangor, Northern Ireland

 I sit here in a shirt made in Spain, jeans from the US and shoes made in Italy. My watch is Swiss, my car French, my TV Japanese and my wife German. The skipper of the England cricket team, Nasser Hussain, was born in Madras, and the English soccer team is soon to be managed by a Swede. One of the great English marques, Rolls- Royce, is now German-owned and a vast number of companies and Highland estates in my native Scotland are owned or controlled by English, American, Dutch, Danish, German and Middle East concerns.

So what is Peter Shore on about when he complains about the cultural elite or the "intellectual left" doing down good old Britain and selling out to Europeanism? He quotes Orwell, but he could go back farther to the great statesmen who fought bitterly on both sides to scupper the Act of Union that brought Britain into being in 1707. But sovereignty was pooled then and it has worked pretty well for 300 years.

At least while we're at the European table we have a say in the future of UK plc and a chance to influence the corporate interests which ought to worry him more than any left-leaning cultural elite.
FM Gillespie
Cambridge

 Peter Shore does not seem to believe that you can be both a nationalist and pro- European (or pro-world). Being British should not mean isolation, pompous self-belief and triumphalism in past and present deeds. While there is much to admire in this country, some structures and practices need improvement.

Nation states must work together for freedom, justice, and social inclusion, otherwise there is war and destruction. We need to communicate, to teach and to learn from each other. Working together does not mean losing identity. Appreciation of differing cultures can be enhanced. No one wants a uniform, grey world, just a peaceful and viable one.
J O'Brien
Farnham, Surrey

 It seems that Peter Shore still thinks that our democracy and independence are being dismantled by Euro-philes and Eurotravellers I suppose it's understandable that someone who was a trade secretary for just two years (and 24 years ago at that) should never have heard of the World Trade Organisation. If and when he does learn of it, he may begin to wonder whether it is this body, with its small groups of secretive and unelected people, working away at "a constitution for a single global economy" who pose the real threat to local decision- making. He could even go on from there to wonder whether remaining a committed member of the European community might be our best defence against an organisation which exists largely to further the interests of multinational corporations, regardless of the consequences for the economic wellbeing of individual states.
Michael Hutton
London

 Thank you Peter Shore. It's nice to see that someone recognises that my pride in being British doesn't represent rampant xenophobia. I was just surprised to see it written in the pages of the Guardian.
Jarod Weaver
Southwell, Notts

But sovereignty was pooled then and it has worked pretty well for 300 years. At least while we're at the European table we have a say in the future of UK plc and a chance to influence the corporate interests which ought to worry him more than any left-leaning cultural elite. FM Gillespie Cambridge  Peter Shore does not seem to believe that you can be both a nationalist and pro- European (or pro-world). Being British should not mean isolation, pompous self-belief and triumphalism in past and present deeds. While there is much to admire in this country, some structures and practices need improvement. Nation states must work together for freedom, justice, and social inclusion, otherwise there is war and destruction. We need to communicate, to teach and to learn from each other. Working together does not mean losing identity. Appreciation of differing cultures can be enhanced. No one wants a uniform, grey world, just a peaceful and viable one. J O'Brien Farnham, Surrey  It seems that Peter Shore still thinks that our democracy and independence are being dismantled by Euro-philes and Eurotravellers I suppose it's understandable that someone who was a trade secretary for just two years (and 24 years ago at that) should never have heard of the World Trade Organisation. If and when he does learn of it, he may begin to wonder whether it is this body, with its small groups of secretive and unelected people, working away at "a constitution for a single global economy" who pose the real threat to local decision- making. He could even go on from there to wonder whether remaining a committed member of the European community might be our best defence against an organisation which exists largely to further the interests of multinational corporations, regardless of the consequences for the economic wellbeing of individual states. Michael Hutton London  Thank you Peter Shore. It's nice to see that someone recognises that my pride in being British doesn't represent rampant xenophobia. I was just surprised to see it written in the pages of the Guardian. Jarod Weaver Southwell, Notts

fields.headline: Cartoonist of the People
fields.trailText: John Dugdale's, slur on the Sunday People's cartoonist Tom Johnston (The art of the political hit job, Media, November 27) was outrageous.
fields.body:
 John Dugdale's, slur on the Sunday People's cartoonist Tom Johnston (The art of the political hit job, Media, November 27) was outrageous. Mr Dugdale is perfectly entitled to dislike Tom's work, but he can't be allowed to casually wrong a man who was last year shortlisted for the Press Gazette's cartoonist of the year in the British Press Awards.

Mr Dugdale alleges that Tom is so stretched for material we have to print all his roughs. Untrue nonsense. Tom in fact produces so many ideas (at least eight, of ten 10) that the difficulty I face every Saturday afternoon is selecting just four to publish.

Your writer also says this newspaper has no cartoonist "of its own". Well, yes, Tom works at the Mirror, but lots of cartoonists work for lots of publications. Tom's contract with this newspaper is completely unconnected with his other employment.

I admired his work so much I approached him to become our cartoonist and thankfully he agreed.

Neil Wallis
Editor, Sunday People

fields.headline: Barak fishes for support
fields.standfirst:
Will the Palestinians take the bait?

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Will the Palestinians take the bait?
fields.body:
Ehud Barak has taken the biggest gamble of his political career. By caving in to opposition pressure for an early general election he has won himself six months, given the traditionally slow-moving process for dissolving the Knesset and scheduling the poll. In that time he hopes to embarrass Likud as it goes into in-fighting between Ariel Sharon and Binyamin Netanyahu over who is to be the party's candidate. More significantly, he hopes to persuade the Palestinians to end their intifada and do a deal so that he can present himself to the Israeli public as the peace-maker he promised to be when he was first elected prime minister last year.

To achieve that he may offer Yasser Arafat a few extra concessions beyond what was available in the last set of talks. Or he may suggest dropping the issue of Jerusalem and offering a partial deal rather than the comprehensive package which was under discussion before. At the back of his mind is the calculation that the Palestinians will see him as the lesser of the two Israeli evils. They will be readier to make peace with him than face almost certain stalemate from a potential Likud successor.

The assumption is questionable, and it is one which the outside world must seriously ponder. From any standpoint, whether it be that of the Arabs or the west, Barak has been a major disappointment. He has failed to implement many of the provisions of the Oslo accords, which were negotiated by his Labour party predecessors, such as releasing the agreed number of Palestinian prisoners. He has allowed settlements to go on being expanded and new ones to be built, often by people who are new arrivals in Israel and come there with rabid and racist views. In the crisis of the last few months he has ordered the Israeli army to use massively excessive and indiscriminate force against stone-throwing protesters.

It is not surprising if the view is growing in the Arab world, as well as in the occupied territories, that there is nothing to choose between Israeli leaders or that Likud may be better because any deal they make is more likely to get through the Knesset and stick. Others are wondering whether the kind of peace which is on the table is worth any price. The Palestinian state they are being offered is nothing more than a series of Bantu-stans, divided by heavily armed Israeli settlements and defence posts. Freedom of movement on the West Bank was easier in the pre-Oslo days of outright occupation than it is now, when constant roadblocks and permits make it very difficult to go from one town to another. There is also a mounting Arab sense that George W Bush may be more even-handed and less attached to the Israeli cause than a Democratic administration. The deadlock in the so-called peace process already stands as a miserable legacy of Bill Clinton's failure to put real pressure on Israel, even at the start of his second term when he did not have to worry about re-election and Monica Lewinsky was still living in California.

Barak's election gamble may therefore produce nothing more than a pause while everyone reconsiders, the Americans work out who their next president is, and the Palestinians decide whether they need to develop a new strategy. This could mean an effort to mobilise more players into the field, including European governments and Russia. The more people who can explain to the Israelis that long-term security lies in genuine compromise with the millions with whom they share the land, the better. If the Americans won't, others must.

fields.body:
The Guardian surely runs a risk of causing offence by placing a silly advertisement across the bottom of the front page (November 29) of the paper picturing condoms with labels such as "sensitive", "show off" and "liar". When the story above it turns out to be the tragic death of the 10-year-old schoolboy Damilola Taylor, then the Guardian is guilty of bad taste in advert placement.
Barbara Keeley-Huggett

webTitle: Letter: It's not a man's world

fields.headline: It's not a man's world
fields.trailText: As a male of the species, I shouldn't really be allowed to take issue with Hella Pick (The blame game, G2, November 28). Scapegoating occurs all the time, irrespective of gender. My own career has suffered badly from that inflicted by females. The examples that Ms Pick quotes of allegedly ill-treated women do not bear examination.
fields.body:
As a male of the species, I shouldn't really be allowed to take issue with Hella Pick (The blame game, G2, November 28). Scapegoating occurs all the time, irrespective of gender. My own career has suffered badly from that inflicted by females. The examples that Ms Pick quotes of allegedly ill-treated women do not bear examination.

Golda Meir's sheer nastiness and racism can be judged from her own autobiography as well as her actions in office. The British diplomat Pauline Neville-Jones has already been judged a disaster by your own columnists after her performance in the Bosnian conflict. Paris is a prime posting for diplomats and men were passed over for this position as well.

April Glaspie rightfully had to take the blame for her ineptitude in giving a green light to Saddam Hussein to invade Kuwait. After trying to wriggle out of blame, it took Saddam's memos to put the record straight. Hillary Clinton has been elected to the US senate despite several political scandals and despite her sole political project under her husband, the healthcare reforms, ending in a complete mess that severely damaged the presidency, her party and her own reputation.

People get blamed, Hella, not just women.

David Rennie
Cardiff

fields.headline: Consumers remain in bullish mood
fields.trailText: British consumers remain willing to borrow and spend - despite saying they are less confident about the economic outlook - sending contradictory signals about the next move in interest rates.
fields.body:
British consumers remain willing to borrow and spend - despite saying they are less confident about the economic outlook - sending contradictory signals about the next move in interest rates.

Consumer confidence rose sharply last month following the resolution of the fuel crisis. But it fell two points in November to minus two, according to the monthly survey by market research company GfK for the European commission published today.

However, monthly consumer credit figures published yesterday by the Bank of England gave no sign of a slowdown in high street spending.

Net consumer credit jumped £1.5bn in October, the highest figure since May and well above City forecasts.

Two thirds of the increase came from non-credit card lending, suggesting that shoppers are taking advantage of cheap in-house finance deals for large purchases.

"The robust rise in credit suggests UK consumers remain in bullish mood and warnings of any significant weakening in consumer demand look premature," said Ross Walker, an economist at Royal Bank of Scotland.

The figures also hinted at a rebound in the housing market, with new mortgage approvals - seen as a good forward-looking guide to sales and prices - rising by 1,000 to 98,000, compared with an average of 95,000 in the three months to September. Michael Saunders, an economist at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, said: "This is the first time since May that commitments have risen from a year ago, which suggests that mortgage lending will probably also pick up a bit in coming months. This fits in with other signs which suggest that housing activity also is picking up a bit."

GfK said all five components of its headline consumer confidence index - based on interviews between October 31 and November 9 - fell back, including perceptions of the general economic situation and household finances.

Growing insecurity was reflected in a sharp increase in the perceived benefits of saving, which rose to the highest level since September 1998.

GfK said it was possible the threat of a second fuel crisis - since diffused by Gordon Brown's pre-Budget report - had depressed sentiment, suggesting that it may recover next month.

Low inflation and slowing global economic activity has persuaded the City that the next move in British interest rates will be downwards.

But Jonathan Loynes, of Capital Economics, said the Bank of England would be reluctant to cut the cost of borrowing from its present rate of 6% without firm evidence that consumer spending is coming off the boil.

"Although we still expect such a slowdown to materialise in response to slower gains in income and wealth, these numbers suggest that it has not yet arrived," said Mr Loynes.

webTitle: Letters: The good old bad old union days

fields.headline: Remembering the good old bad old union days
fields.trailText: Has Jimmy Reid checked with his trade union friends on the continent before saying (Enemies of the workers, November 27) life is awful for trade unionists here and pure nirvana across the Channel?
fields.body:
Has Jimmy Reid checked with his trade union friends on the continent before saying (Enemies of the workers, November 27) life is awful for trade unionists here and pure nirvana across the Channel?

Britain is the only nation in the European Union where trade union membership is going up, where new laws (26 according to the TUC, not government spin doctors) have been enacted to help workers, and where real wages are increasing. In France there are about 800,000 dues-paying union members, while in Germany union membership has sunk by one third since 1990 and 4m German public sector workers still have no right to strike. Chancellor Schröder has made it clear he isn't going to give it to them.

The idea that consultation rights or lay-off rules protect jobs in the EU will come as news to the Renault workers in Vilvoorde in Belgium which was shut down over-night by management diktat. It will also come as news to the millions of workers on the dole in France and Germany, who lost their jobs despite nominal consultation rights and who look with envy at the job creation record of the Labour government.

Certainly, British unions are entitled to demand more rights, more pay, and more time for themselves and their families. But the key base for union power is full employment, not an endless list of rights which are irrelevant if no one joins a union and a reserve army of unemployed reduces working- class rights to zero. We haven't got everything right in Britain and employer hostility to partnership is a major problem but trade unions and workers have done a lot better under Tony Blair (though please don't tell him) than many of their continental counterparts.
Denis MacShane MP

 Jimmy Reid has a short memory. Doesn't he remember what happened to workers' rights under the Conservative government? Has he already forgotten the new rights for trade unions and for trade union representatives in last year's Employment Relations Act?

This Labour government has delivered many new rights for working people. These include the national minimum wage, new child care arrangements, and family friendly policies such as better maternity and parental leave. Not to mention increased employment and increased investment in public services.

The trade unions know what the alternative to a Labour government is and what it would mean. The trade unions want more from a Labour government, and we know that a second term for this government will bring even greater benefits. That's why we support Labour and that's why we will be working for that second term.

It is sad that someone with Jimmy Reid's history is so out of touch with the reality of the year 2000, but regrettably he certainly is.
Roger Lyons
General secretary, MSF
