webTitle: 'John Prescott, you are the weakest link'

fields.headline: 'John Prescott, you are the weakest link'
fields.trailText: Sometimes the bad news doesn't hit you all at once. Nobody rings up and says curtly, "Your sister's dead," or, "Your house has burned down." For the most part, people try to tell you gently, to soften the coming blow, or to prepare you psychologically to face the very worst.
fields.body:
Sometimes the bad news doesn't hit you all at once. Nobody rings up and says curtly, "Your sister's dead," or, "Your house has burned down." For the most part, people try to tell you gently, to soften the coming blow, or to prepare you psychologically to face the very worst.

But that can make it even more painful. If your boss calls you into his office and begins, "I do want to say how grateful we are for all your work in the, um, 12 years since you joined us," you immediately get a sinking feeling because you know what's coming next, and it isn't a promotion.

When the woman you love says, "I've been doing some thinking about our future," you are aware within five seconds that she's found someone else. Of course, any conversation that starts, "I think you should sit down," is going to be hell. You want to scream, "Tell me, tell me, for God's sake get on with it!"

John Prescott must have felt that way yesterday afternoon. For once he wasn't in the house - there were no fresh disasters to report - but he's a politician, and he knows the weight every word carries when it is uttered at prime minister's question time.

So when he learned that Charles Kennedy had asked about him, he must have studied Mr Blair's reply with meticulous care. The Lib Dem leader asked scornfully whether, in view of the "chaos on the railways, the gridlock on the roads, the party revolt on air traffic control, if you win a second term, will the deputy prime minister still be in charge of all these things?"

This is the point where, as Mr Prescott reads the transcript this morning, he would hope to find a prolonged vote of confidence, a recital of his innumerable qualities, and to hear the welkin ring with the celebration of his virtues.

Instead he will read this: "The prime minister: As a result of the deputy prime minister and the 10-year transport plan, more money has been put into our infrastructure than at any time since the 19th century.

"May I just remind him that that plan, an £18bn-worth, is more than he promised at the last election, and as ever  he still tells us it's not enough."

Not one word about his deputy's merits. Not a line of congratulation, not a single assurance that the prime minister has every possible confidence in his understrapper. At the time it sounded like a bold assertion of government policy, and to most onlookers, unversed in the arcane ciphers of Westminster, it might have seemed exactly that. But to John Prescott it must sound as deathly and silent as the seconds before the hangman pulls the trap. It was the invitation to sit down. As Miss Anne Robinson would say with that sadistic cheeriness, "Goodbye!"

There was a nicer moment when Hilary Benn pointed out that the Goldfish credit company was arranging to put kidney donor symbols on their cards, so we would get lots more kidneys for transplant. What an excellent idea. I will adjust my organ donor card so as to give my goldfish to those who need them after I'm dead. And, perfectly, the next MP up was David "Ooh, you are offal, but I like you" Kidney.

At the end of the session, Hilary's father Tony Benn made a dignified statement marking the 50 years since he was first elected and thanking colleagues in all parties for their sympathy at the death of his wife, Caroline.

At this, the former raging leftie, scourge of the Tories, hammer of the moderates, was warmly applauded by the whole house, the Tories louder than anyone. They are a sentimental lot. It's quite sweet; they'll cheer John Prescott as soon as he has no power.

webTitle: DNA vaccine offers first hope against Ebola fever

fields.headline: DNA vaccine offers first hope against Ebola fever
fields.trailText: Scientists are on the track of a vaccine against Africa's nightmare killer - Ebola fever. Researchers at the US National Institutes of Health in Maryland report in Nature today that they successfully vaccinated four monkeys against a lethal dose of the virus.
fields.body:
Scientists are on the track of a vaccine against Africa's nightmare killer - Ebola fever. Researchers at the US National Institutes of Health in Maryland report in Nature today that they successfully vaccinated four monkeys against a lethal dose of the virus.

Ebola is a mysterious microbe that lives in Zaire, Sudan and Ivory Coast, although most outbreaks have been in Zaire. The virus kills nine victims in 10. It strikes quickly, and individuals suffer severe pain, high fever and dramatic internal bleeding before they die. There is no cure and, until today, no hope of a vaccine. Nobody knows where it lives in the wild, or how infection gets into human populations. But once it does, it spreads swiftly.

The US researchers started with lengths of Ebola DNA - rather than proteins from the virus - in their tests on animals. DNA vaccines are a new class of treatments and the thinking is that, like viruses, the vaccines enter the cell and use the cell's machinery to replicate - tricking the host's immune system into thinking a real virus infection has occurred.

They tested it on rats and guinea pigs, and then boosted the immune responses by using a different and safer virus to make Ebola-like proteins which would set the immune system roaring into action.

They vaccinated four macaque monkeys, and then exposed them to huge doses of Ebola. Three showed no sign of any infection, and one showed Ebola in the bloodstream but this disappeared after a week. Six months later, all four were free of any symptoms of the disease.

Gary Nabel, of the vaccine research centre at the institute, said: "Doctors have essentially been helpless against Ebola virus. We have not known if immunity to the virus exists or what parts of the immune response are important. Our studies show that animals can launch an effective immune response against Ebola virus.

"Although much more work needs to be done, we hope this moves us closer to new vaccines and treatments for Ebola and other viruses."

webTitle: One year on, no further forward

fields.headline: One year on, no further forward
fields.standfirst:
Cities balk at hosting new talks

Special report: World Trade Organisation
fields.trailText: It is a year ago today since the tear gas cannisters began rattling down the streets of Seattle. The smoke has yet to clear in the aftermath of the disastrous collapse of what was designed to be the crowning diplomatic achievement of the Clinton presidency - the launch of a new round of global trade talks.
fields.body:
It is a year ago today since the tear gas cannisters began rattling down the streets of Seattle. The smoke has yet to clear in the aftermath of the disastrous collapse of what was designed to be the crowning diplomatic achievement of the Clinton presidency - the launch of a new round of global trade talks.

Twelve months on, the world's biggest trading powers - the European Union, the United States and Japan - appear to be further apart than ever, and developing countries still feel excluded from the inner sanctums of the World Trade Organisation. There are vague hopes in the capitals of western Europe and north America that a new trade round might be launched next autumn when trade ministers meet for the first time since Seattle.

But given that no city anywhere in the world is prepared to risk a week of violent protest and the bad publicity which would almost certainly accompany the WTO's arrival in town, even finding a venue for their meeting is proving problematic. Abu Dhabi was supposed to host the next gathering but has bowed out.

Optimists believe the changing of the guard at the White House in January will remove one of the big stumbling blocks to progress, the lack of any impetus from Washington during the election campaign.

But with George W Bush looking likely to inherit the presidency, the optimists may be whistling in the wind. Mr Bush is an isolationist by temperament with no great regard for any of the pillars of the multilateral system, and his critics say he is in hock to the US corporate interests. Big business in the US wants a new trade round, but only on America's terms - greater access for their goods to foreign markets without competition from cheap goods from developing countries at home.

The Americans are under less pressure than the Europeans to restart talks because at the end of the Uruguay round in 1993 it was decided that unfinished business in agriculture and services - Washington's main concerns - would be dealt with early this century, even if a comprehensive round of talks had not begun.

Brussels, which has most to lose in agriculture particularly, wants a broad ranging round so it can trade off the painful concessions it must make in its heavily subsidised farm sector with gains elsewhere. As a sweetner Pascal Lamy, Europe's top trade negotiator has proposed duty and tariff-free access to the world's 48 poorest countries.

Development lobby groups dismiss the EU offer as a sop. "The north appears to be intent on ramming its agenda down the throats of the developing world," says Duncan Green, policy analyst for Cafod. "The atmosphere is one of suspicion and cynicism, and few signs of a new deal for the world's poor."

Privately, the politicians are aware of the problems facing the WTO. Seattle taught them that they can no longer afford to ride roughshod over the views of developing countries which now make up a majority of the WTO's 139 members.

But ministers say privately that little been done since Seattle despite promises from Mike Moore, the WTO's director general, to institute reforms. The body spent much of the past year dealing with a series of acrimonious disputes between the EU and the US - one of side-effect of the failure to restart talks. He has become a scapegoat for all that has not been fixed since Seattle, and many negotiators have written off his chances of launching a new round in 2002 when his term ends.

He admits the WTO has taken over the mantle of the world's most unpopular organisation from the International Monetary Fund. Changing that image will require root and branch reform of the institution itself - making it more open and transparent. But it will also require a political push from the west and a willingness to look beyond their own electorates' interests, to offer a better deal for developing countries. Neither seems likely.

fields.headline: BA keeps jumbo options open
fields.trailText: British Airways has joined the queue to purchase the A3XX, the world's largest super jumbo, through the back door by supporting an order for 12 of the aircraft by the Australian carrier, Qantas.
fields.body:
British Airways has joined the queue to purchase the A3XX, the world's largest super jumbo, through the back door by supporting an order for 12 of the aircraft by the Australian carrier, Qantas.

This is the first time that Qantas, which has flown Boeing planes almost exclusively, has ordered aircraft built by the European consortium, Airbus. BA - which has a 25% stake in Qantas - has been closely involved in the consultations surrounding the £3bn order, which also includes 13 Airbus 330s.

BA has been among 20 of the world's leading airlines which led talks with Airbus on the development of the jumbo.It will carry at least 555 passengers. The British carrier says that it will not be among the first list of launch customers for the A3XX, but the Qantas order will allow it to keep its options open.

The biggest aircraft yet built will operate on Qantas routes across the Pacific direct to the west coast of the United States, but BA may be able to use some of the aircraft since it is in effect involved in the purchase.

Qantas chairman Margaret Jackson said: "With their wide cabins, the A3XX and the A330 will bring enhanced comfort to our passengers, enabling us to meet growth while increasing efficiency.''

Deliveries of the A3XXs will begin in 2006. The plane will also provide extra capacity between Australia and the UK.

The order gives another boost to the UK aerospace industry. The UK company, BAE Systems, makes the wings for Airbus and has a 20% stake in the Toulouse-based company, in which France, Germany and Spain are also partners.

Qantas now joins Emirates, the middle east carrier, Air France, Singapore Airlines and Virgin Atlantic as launch customers. Airbus expects a formal go-ahead for the new plane in the next few weeks and the first flight in 2004.

fields.headline: Ikea costs more in Britain
fields.trailText: Chucking out your chintz, as instructed by an Ikea advertising campaign, costs more in Britain than other European countries.
fields.body:
Chucking out your chintz, as instructed by an Ikea advertising campaign, costs more in Britain than other European countries.

According to the new research by Barclays Capital, the investment banking arm of Barclays bank, a basket of goods from the clutter-free Swedish retailer costs between 20% and 30% less in Europe than Britain.

Economists from Barclays Capital compared prices of 18 typical Ikea products, ranging from coat hangers to wall "uplighters", and concluded that the same items were 26% cheaper in Germany than in the UK. The economists established that the price of the basket was similar across the E6 - Belgium, Germany, Italy, Netherlands and Spain, which they conclude might be the impact of the introduction of the single currency.

On this basis, joining the euro might be good news for Britons desperate to rid themselves of chintz, the economists said. But they pointed out that they do not believe Britain's economy will be ready to join the single currency for another 20 years.

In the interim they suggest the currency differential offers great opportunities for entrepreneurs to make "a large amount of cash".

They urge anyone with a large warehouse and a few lorries to set up an Ikea resale operation.

fields.headline: ONdigital postpones float
fields.trailText: The £1.5bn stock market flotation of ONdigital has been postponed to take account of both poor market conditions and the background of a restructured ITV.
fields.body:
The £1.5bn stock market flotation of ONdigital has been postponed to take account of both poor market conditions and the background of a restructured ITV.

Charles Allen, Granada Media's chairman, said yesterday "it would be daft to give away value" by floating the business at a time when media stocks have been taking a bruising.

Granada also sought to calm investors' nerves over the robustness of the ITV advertising market. The company said a strong autumn schedule on ITV had translated into better revenues for November than expected, while advance December bookings were already 7% ahead of the same month's revenues last year.

ONdigital had been earmarked for flotation at the 1m subscriber mark - a figure the pay-television group should reach by the end of this month.

Mr Allen said the sharp reversal in sentiment against the media and technology sectors meant there was little sense in progressing now.

He said: "You have to ask, is this the right time to optimise value? The only reason for doing it is to crystallise value, and if it doesn't reflect the upside of the business then it's not worth doing it."

Analysts, however, have also raised concerns over the rate at which ONdigital is losing customers as it moves into its second year in business.

Mr Allen said the focus in the coming months would be on developing a closer relationship between ONdigital and ITV.

The consolidation in ITV over the summer has left just Granada and fellow ONdigital shareholder Carlton Communications holding the lion's share of the franchises, providing better opportunities for a coordinated strategy between the free to air and pay-TV services. "We think there is a lot of opportunity for getting ONdigital working together with ITV and we will revisit the issue of flotation when appropriate," Mr Allen said.

He said the market had placed too heavy an emphasis on individual monthly ITV advertising figures instead of broader trends - a reference to brokers' notes in the autumn that devastated Granada's share price by focusing on the prospect of a poor October.

ITV growth for 2000 is expected to reach 4.6%. Analysts' forecasts for 2001 are advertising growth of 3.5%, but Mr Allen said the longer term trends for ITV were around 5%.

The share price, which had been at 694p in August, made a modest recovery, closing 1p higher at 383p.

Granada chief executive Steve Morrison said he was confident in the 2001 schedule, which included the return of Premiership football, the British version of Survivor - the biggest ratings winner in the US this year - and Popstars, a new 14-week fly on the wall series. He said the BBC's decision to move its nightly news bulletin to 10pm had backfired.

"The BBC took the pin out of a grenade and the fragments fell in surprising places," he said. "ITV's audience share has been resilient."

For the year to the end of September, Granada reported a 9% increase in revenues to £1.1bn, while operating profits were 8% better at £253m. Programme sales overseas increased 10%.

Mr Allen also confirmed that discussions have been held with a wide variety of potential investors in ONdigital, including Microsoft.

A Carlton insider echoed the comments from Mr Allen, and said flotation had only ever been one of a series of options for the business.

He said the market had placed too heavy an emphasis on individual monthly ITV advertising figures instead of broader trends - a reference to brokers' notes in the autumn that devastated Granada's share price by focusing on the prospect of a poor October. ITV growth for 2000 is expected to reach 4.6%. Analysts' forecasts for 2001 are advertising growth of 3.5%, but Mr Allen said the longer term trends for ITV were around 5%. The share price, which had been at 694p in August, made a modest recovery, closing 1p higher at 383p. Granada chief executive Steve Morrison said he was confident in the 2001 schedule, which included the return of Premiership football, the British version of Survivor - the biggest ratings winner in the US this year - and Popstars, a new 14-week fly on the wall series. He said the BBC's decision to move its nightly news bulletin to 10pm had backfired. "The BBC took the pin out of a grenade and the fragments fell in surprising places," he said. "ITV's audience share has been resilient." For the year to the end of September, Granada reported a 9% increase in revenues to £1.1bn, while operating profits were 8% better at £253m. Programme sales overseas increased 10%. Mr Allen also confirmed that discussions have been held with a wide variety of potential investors in ONdigital, including Microsoft. A Carlton insider echoed the comments from Mr Allen, and said flotation had only ever been one of a series of options for the business.

webTitle: Pressure on Portillo adds to Tory woes

fields.headline: Pressure on Portillo adds to Tory woes
fields.standfirst:
With an election looming Conservatives are in turmoil, concentrating on infighting and the Hague succession rather than fighting Labour.

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: With an election looming Conservatives are in turmoil, concentrating on infighting and the Hague succession rather than fighting Labour.
fields.body:
These are strange times for the Conservative party, even by the increasingly strange standards they have so often adopted during the three-and-a-half year Hague era. Only William Hague himself gives off an aura of unflappable calm at the eye of the storm.

At this stage in the electoral cycle, governments expect to be in trouble, losing byelections and being humiliated at the dispatch box while trailing in the polls by 20%. None of which currently applies to New Labour.

This week even John Prescott twice saw off his tormenters in the Commons. "I sometimes look at them and wish I could set up as a political consultant so I could offer them advice,'' one Labour cabinet minister said pityingly of the Opposition after they had let him off the hook yet again.

Instead yesterday's Daily Telegraph, bible of the once-mighty army of Conservative activists, devoted an eight column page one headline to "Portillo: I Don't Want To Be Leader.''

It was an apparent repudiation of the widely held assumption that if Mr Hague does as badly as the polls suggest on May 3 many Tories will want to replace him with his shadow chancellor.

There may have been wheels turning within Tory wheels over the report. The Telegraph is close to Hague, whereas the Times which had earlier reported a "stop Widdecombe'' cabal boasts a strong pro-Portillo lobby among its officer class.

Yesterday Portillo aides insisted that it was all very straightforward. Responding to the leadership question Mr Portillo had said he had "no ambition to be leader of the Conservative party'' (what else could he say?). As for his alleged lost appetite for politics, he denied it.

Yet many MPs believe that Mr Portillo is not the man he was, not the ambitious thruster who electrified his party conference as defence secretary with his "who dares wins'' speech which aped the SAS. To some the wellspring of ambition seems broken. Opposition is not the Tory forte. Gordon Brown is a hard nut to crack when the economy is doing so well.

Others express distaste and bewilderment about the shadow chancellor's "compassionate conservatism'' speech at the Bournemouth conference last month. In terms of addressing the ''inclusive'' centre ground of politics it made sense.

So have other Portillo changes like the attempt to scale down Hague's inflexible tax-and-spending pledge which is such an easy target for Labour - the "£16bn black hole'' which translates handily into £24m worth of public spending cuts per constituency.

But destructive forces like Norman Tebbit, who has not forgiven Portillo's admission of a gay sexual past, as well as Margaret Thatcher reinforce their party's atavistic impulse towards the social authoritarianism of the Daily Mail. They will not leave him to find his own path. He seems to lack Hague's bouncy resillience.

Though old hands like Stephen Dorrell MP yesterday expressed the hope that their talented colleague will not drop out of politics it was also noticeable that none of Mr Hague's aides appeared to be wearing black armbands at the prospect. Quite the reverse.

If that was not enough Monday's Daily Mail had carried an interview with Mr Hague. The Tory leader was relentlessly cheerful about his prospects, though in fairness the interview was conducted before the voters of West Bromwich West destroyed Tory hopes of winning at least one of Thursday's three Labour-held byelections.

The disappointed Mail marked its interview by adding a hatchet job analysis of Mr Hague's performance: a nice guy presiding over an incoherent political message and a bunch of shadow ministers who are nowhere near as energetic as the one he sacked, John Redwood.

The Mail's editorial complained that Fleet Street does a better job opposing Tony Blair. Next day the Sun also took a poke at Mr Hague. Tory MPs with small majorities are getting jittery.

"The Lib Dems were second in my constituency last time. Their candidate is busy and Labour won't select one until close to polling day, just to help them,'' predicted one gloomy southern MP whose majority is below the 3,000 vote level.

"There is a sense of shadow ministers distancing themselves from William Hague, an air of detatchment,'' reports one academic who often talks in private to politicians. The Tory leader's habit of surrounding himself with unthreatening acolytes - notably Olympic ex-champion, Lord Seb Coe - enhances that feeling. He rarely discusses policy with shadow colleagues one-on-one.

The brutal fact is that Labour spin doctors' confident assessments of where the Tory strategy has landed Mr Hague are often vindicated by the opinion polls. When the Telegraph's Gallup poll quizzed voters about the EU's new rapid reaction force (RRF) - against which the paper railed noisily last week - it found that more thought it a good idea (48%) than a bad one (34%).

Not unreasonably, some Tory officials argue that polls can be unreliable and the mood of voters is volatile, as the September fuel protest briefly showed. "Labour has increased taxes, yet failed to deliver on its promises or meet the public expectations it aroused,'' one said yesterday.

But Her Majesty's official opposition is not well placed to cash in. Ann Widdecombe's efforts to reflect genuine public alarm about crime, drug policy or asylum have recoiled against her. This week she backtracked on her costly plans to lock up all asylum seekers pending their assessement.

So it would be reasonable to assume that Hague would be the jittery introspective one and Widdecombe a busted flush whose hopes of winning a second round play-off ( MPs shortlist, but activists pick the winner under Hague-created rules) have crumbled.

Instead the "stop Widdecombe'' shadow ministers are said to be urging John Redwood and Iain Duncan Smith (a dark horse in any leadership stakes) to stand if William stumbles so as to soak up some of her votes.

They rarely think of Ken Clarke, though he is still waiting for the call, cigar in hand at Nottingham-les-deux-Eglises. Hague, whose idyllic family childhood in Rotherham was recently filmed for TV (14 pints and all), appears to be unphased by it all. However misplaced, he does has self-belief. And it may be misplaced. Some MPs recall how the then Welsh secretary predicted the Tories could win 13 Welsh seats in 1997. They got none.

fields.headline: M&S sales continue to slip
fields.standfirst: Executives put brave face on damaging leaks
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer is continuing to lose sales in the run-up to Christmas, according to renewed speculation in the City.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer is continuing to lose sales in the run-up to Christmas, according to renewed speculation in the City.

Yesterday there were suggestions that, in the week to November 19, the struggling retailer had seen its food sales climb 3% on last year's levels.

But that advance had been more than wiped out by a 9% decline in other trading. As home sales have been performing well, it is estimated that clothing sales slumped by up to 12% in that week.

Senior executives are known to be concerned about the frequency and accuracy of leaks regarding sales figures and have slashed the internal circulation list of staff allowed to receive up to date trading figures in an effort to halt damaging information leaks.

Yesterday the store chain refused to comment on the figures."We are just all focused on making this a bumper Christmas. It is really misleading to take one week's figures. In the six to eight weeks before Christmas trading patterns are volatile. And spending is also volatile depending on which day Christmas Day falls," said a spokeswoman.

Analysts described the figures as awful, but pointed out customers may be delaying festive shopping because there is an additional weekend for shopping immediately before Christmas. They also believe that retailers have been affected by the weather and the rail crisis, which is curtailing weekend shopping.

Nevertheless they are concerned about the scale of the reported decline - on top of two previous years of poor performance from the firm.

At the time of M&S's half- year results, which were announced ths month, the group revealed a sharp deterioration in sales over the five weeks to November 4. Total sales were down 6.4 % or 8.4 % on like for like basis.

Clothing, footwear and gifts sales were down 14.6%, but home sales and food sales were up 7.6 % and 5.8% respectively.

At that time analysts cut their full-year profit expectations to between £440m and £500m - half the levels of two years ago.

Nevertheless M&S executive chairman Luc Vandevelde was upbeat on the retailers' Christmas prospects.

"We're looking forward to a wonderful Christmas, and I'm confident that we are going to achieve positive results during that period.

"I would be satisfied if we can finally turn negatives [like for like sales] into positives ... I'm confident that we can do that." Last night M&S shares closed down 2p at 194p.

fields.headline: Gucci takes LVMH to court
fields.trailText: The continuing battle between luxury goods group LVMH and Gucci intensified yesterday when Gucci said it was launching proceedings against LVMH in the French courts for alleged defamation.
fields.body:
The continuing battle between luxury goods group LVMH and Gucci intensified yesterday when Gucci said it was launching proceedings against LVMH in the French courts for alleged defamation.

Dutch-registered Gucci said it was taking action "in view of the unsubstantiated and baseless accusations made by LVMH earlier this week attacking the integrity of key Gucci executives".

The move came after LVMH asked a Dutch court on Monday to investigate the possibility of a connection between share options granted to Gucci chief executive Domenico De Sole and chief designer Tom Ford, and Gucci's backing for the acquisition of some 42% of the company's shares by Pinault-Printemps-Redoute.

LVMH is asking the court to annul the agreement between Gucci and PPR which diluted LVMH's own stake in Gucci from 34% to 21%.

Yesterday LVMH said the options granted to Mr Ford and Mr De Sole were kept secret and "the failure to disclose such material is a violation of the most fundamental rules of transparency applicable to publicly listed companies. Were it not for LVMH's intervention this information would have remained secret".

The size of the package was "unprecedented" for a company of Gucci's size and "seriously damaging to interests of Gucci's minority shareholders", LVMH claimed yesterday.

Gucci yesterday released details of the option packages under which Mr Ford was granted options over 4m shares and Mr de Sole 1m shares.

In a statement the chairman of the supervisory board Adrian Bellamy said the options packages had been set "with the guidance of a leading compensation expert and unanimously approved by the board which has a majority of independent members".

"Both executives have performed extremely well in the past and, as part of new employment contracts with extended terms and renewed commitments to the company, we offered them a package of options that incentivised them for the future.

"The strike price of the options is above the market price in June 1999 and a significant amount of these options remains above the current share price."

Mr Bellamy's statement said: "There should be no misunderstanding as to the fundamental point: there has never been any agreement, oral or written, between PPR and Gucci or its key executives that linked the future compensation of our key executives to the March 19, 1999 Gucci-PPR strategic investment agreement."

A Gucci spokesman added that under Dutch law there had been no obligation to disclose details of the options package.

LVMH, however, refused to back down. "In the light of Gucci's failure to disclose this extraordinary compensation to its executives, LVMH has decided to file a complaint with the US securities authorities, and in particular the SEC."

Relations between LVMH and Gucci have been strained since the French group built up a stake in Gucci. They took a turn for the worse when Gucci brought in PPR. That brought two of France's richest businessmen - Bernard Arnault at LVMH and Francois Pinault at PPR - into direct conflict.

webTitle: Rover purchase of Longbridge plant put on hold

fields.headline: Rover purchase of Longbridge plant put on hold
fields.trailText: MG Rover's hopes of buying the BMW-owned engine and transmission plant on its Longbridge site are beginning to fade. Industry sources said talks about the deal to buy the plant, known as Powertrain, have been pushed back to March next year.
fields.body:
MG Rover's hopes of buying the BMW-owned engine and transmission plant on its Longbridge site are beginning to fade. Industry sources said talks about the deal to buy the plant, known as Powertrain, have been pushed back to March next year.

Earlier this year executives at the British car maker believed they were about to close a deal to buy the plant from BMW.

Powertrain makes K-series engines for MG Rover, which account for about 80% of its output. It also supplies Land Rover, which BMW sold to Ford earlier this year.

Ford is believed to have opposed the plant's sale to MG Rover, not wishing to see the plant fall into the hands of a firm which had yet to prove its financial viability.

A BMW spokesman said that the group was talking to several parties who were interested in buying the engine plant.

But he stressed that the talks had not progressed to negotiations. Then discussions would take place with just one preferred buyer, he said.

"We do not see the plant as a long-term part of our core business but we are under no time pressure to sell," he said.

However an MG Rover spokesman insisted that the issue of the engine plant was still being discussed with BMW "at all levels".

"We talk to BMW on a day to day basis, and the engine plant is just one of the things we discuss," he said.

"We are the plant's biggest customer. The talks are progressing and we remain positive about the outcome."

MG Rover wants control of one of its main engine suppliers, especially as it is developing a new range of vehicles to be sold under the MG and Rover marques. The group released photographs of the first of these, the MG X10 sports saloon, earlier this month.

But BMW has discovered that there are other would-be buyers - among whom are said to be Proton, the Malaysian car maker, and Tata, the Indian conglomerate.

BMW is thought to be nearer a decision on the sale of its body pressing plant in Swindon. Industry sources expect an announcement in January.

The consortium lead by former Rover chief executive John Towers is still discussing the final accounting of the deal earlier this year in which they bought the Rover and MG brands, together with the Longbridge car plant in Birmingham, for a nominal £10.

Executives have been trying to persuade BMW to increase the £500m dowry - which was part of the deal - to reflect the lower value of stock caused by the government-inspired reduction in new car prices in the UK. BMW has refused to do so.

webTitle: Detectives arrest 11 in bank computer theft inquiry

fields.headline: Detectives arrest 11 in bank computer theft inquiry
fields.trailText: City detectives yesterday raided a gang of computer thieves who are believed to be responsible for a string of multi-million pound attacks on major banks.
fields.body:
City detectives yesterday raided a gang of computer thieves who are believed to be responsible for a string of multi-million pound attacks on major banks.

Eleven men were arrested during dawn raids carried out at 20 addresses across the capital by more than 150 officers from City of London police and Scotland Yard.

The operation, which used the codenames Wheelwright and Regis, recovered a haul of stolen computer equipment, two replica hand guns and a quantity of drugs.

The investigation was launched after a spate of burglaries at universities, institutions and IT firms across the country - some £15m worth of equipment has been stolen since March.

These valuable components, mainly processing units which act as a computer's brain, cost up to £50,000 each and are said to be "powerful enough to run the Iraqi defence system".

Most of the sought-after parts are made by Sun Microsystems but a black market has evolved as the company appears to be unable to keep up with demand. It is estimated the equipment can easily fetch up to 80% of its full retail price in this way and provide handsome profits for the thieves. Products made by Dell, Compaq and Cisco are also highly prized. Police believe those behind the thefts are part of a "pool of burglars" who started out by attacking universities which often have highly technical equipment but rarely the security to match.

Detective Inspector Richard Jack, from Islington CID, said some of the attacks had been violent, with the victims tied up while the robbery was carried out.

"They have gone from universities to having the confidence to start hitting City banks," he said.

"This stuff is being stolen to order, but we don't know where it's going. It could be recycled in this country or it could be going abroad."

City institutions are now so worried by the attacks that they have put up a £100,000 reward for information leading to the conviction of those responsible.

The latest theft, believed to have taken place at Deutsche Bank last week, resulted in the loss of 49 pieces of equipment valued at £1.6m, although the bank is rumoured to have suffered £25m trading losses. Four other banks are also understood to have fallen victim.

"These computer parts are the tools of the trade for City banks," said a City of London police spokesman. "Potentially, if a bank or institution loses its computers, until they are replaced it is not able to trade."

According to figures released by the Association of British Insurers, computer theft now costs British firms £1bn a year, and can be enough to close them down.

Yesterday's operation, which followed weeks of covert surveillance and information gathering, was launched from the police station in Wood Street - right at the very heart of the City.

A convoy of vehicles, mainly plain saloons and vans, then left for the destinations - 18 of which were in Islington, with the other two in East Ham and Fulham.

At the stroke of 7am, as daylight broke in drizzling rain, officers began breaking down the doors of houses with red battering rams, known as enforcers, arresting suspects and searching properties.

At one flat on the Bemerton Estate in Islington a suspect tried to climb out of an upstairs window wearing just his underwear before finally giving himself up to officers. He was then wearing a dark blue Nike sports top and jeans, bundled into the back of an unmarked police car.

Insp Jack said: "It will certainly disrupt this gang for some time to come, but it's a matter of who takes their place because the rewards for this type of crime are substantial.

"That is why we are trying to find out who is handling the property."

Those arrested were still being questioned by detectives last night. They can be held for up to 36 hours without any charge being made. The maximum jail sentence for aggravated burglary is 14 years.

The investigation was launched after a spate of burglaries at universities, institutions and IT firms across the country - some £15m worth of equipment has been stolen since March. These valuable components, mainly processing units which act as a computer's brain, cost up to £50,000 each and are said to be "powerful enough to run the Iraqi defence system". Most of the sought-after parts are made by Sun Microsystems but a black market has evolved as the company appears to be unable to keep up with demand. It is estimated the equipment can easily fetch up to 80% of its full retail price in this way and provide handsome profits for the thieves. Products made by Dell, Compaq and Cisco are also highly prized. Police believe those behind the thefts are part of a "pool of burglars" who started out by attacking universities which often have highly technical equipment but rarely the security to match. Detective Inspector Richard Jack, from Islington CID, said some of the attacks had been violent, with the victims tied up while the robbery was carried out. "They have gone from universities to having the confidence to start hitting City banks," he said. "This stuff is being stolen to order, but we don't know where it's going. It could be recycled in this country or it could be going abroad." City institutions are now so worried by the attacks that they have put up a £100,000 reward for information leading to the conviction of those responsible. The latest theft, believed to have taken place at Deutsche Bank last week, resulted in the loss of 49 pieces of equipment valued at £1.6m, although the bank is rumoured to have suffered £25m trading losses. Four other banks are also understood to have fallen victim. "These computer parts are the tools of the trade for City banks," said a City of London police spokesman. "Potentially, if a bank or institution loses its computers, until they are replaced it is not able to trade." According to figures released by the Association of British Insurers, computer theft now costs British firms £1bn a year, and can be enough to close them down. Yesterday's operation, which followed weeks of covert surveillance and information gathering, was launched from the police station in Wood Street - right at the very heart of the City. A convoy of vehicles, mainly plain saloons and vans, then left for the destinations - 18 of which were in Islington, with the other two in East Ham and Fulham. At the stroke of 7am, as daylight broke in drizzling rain, officers began breaking down the doors of houses with red battering rams, known as enforcers, arresting suspects and searching properties. At one flat on the Bemerton Estate in Islington a suspect tried to climb out of an upstairs window wearing just his underwear before finally giving himself up to officers. He was then wearing a dark blue Nike sports top and jeans, bundled into the back of an unmarked police car. Insp Jack said: "It will certainly disrupt this gang for some time to come, but it's a matter of who takes their place because the rewards for this type of crime are substantial. "That is why we are trying to find out who is handling the property." Those arrested were still being questioned by detectives last night. They can be held for up to 36 hours without any charge being made. The maximum jail sentence for aggravated burglary is 14 years.

fields.headline: K-For split on policing border
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: France broke ranks with its Nato allies yesterday on how the peacekeeping forces in Kosovo should handle the fighting between ethnic Albanian guerrillas and Serbian troops in the Preshevo valley area of Serbia, on the Kosovan border.
fields.body:
France broke ranks with its Nato allies yesterday on how the peacekeeping forces in Kosovo should handle the fighting between ethnic Albanian guerrillas and Serbian troops in the Preshevo valley area of Serbia, on the Kosovan border.

The foreign ministry in Paris said that an agreement which prevents Yugoslav troops from entering the three-mile buffer zone might have to be "adapted". A Nato spokesman said that was not possible.

The suggestion came after further Yugoslav troop movements in the valley. Senior Serbian politicians have warned that they will use "any means necessary" to regain border territory lost to the Albanian separatists in recent fighting.

A Serbian police unit retook the strategic village of Lucane, just inside Serbia, yesterday. Backed by two armoured vehicles, it entered the village unopposed by Albanian militants who watched from afar.

Vojslav Kostunica, the Yugoslav president, said on Monday that K-For had failed to prevent the rebels using the border zone to attack Serbian forces. "It's crystal clear that K-For and Unmik [the UN administration in Kosovo] have failed to do their part of the job properly," he said.

Flight-Lieutenant Mark Whitty, the K-For spokesman, said that renegotiating the accord on the buffer zone agreed by Nato and the Yugoslav government at the end of the war in Kosovo was not a possibility.

"No one is looking at changing the military technical agreement. We have every confidence in it," he said.

An indefinite ceasefire has been agreed by both sides while attempts are made to find a solution to the clashes.

But yesterday Norwegian K-For soldiers stopped a truck in central Kosovo containing landmines, more than 1,000 rounds of ammunition, mortars, and uniforms bearing the initials UCMPB, the badge of the rebels who want three mainly Albanian populated towns in Serbia returned to an independent Kosovo.

The Nato secretary general, Lord George Robertson, raised the prospect of K-For and Serbia deploying joint inspection teams on the border in an attempt to contain the rebels.

Speaking in Brussels, he denied reports that Nato intended to patrol the region with Yugoslav army troops. He also appeared to rule out Nato intervening by itself in the border zone.

But the prospect of Serbian police and Nato troops working together in the area is unlikely to be well received by ethnic Albanians. The Serbian interior ministry police are accused of committing widespread human rights abuses in Kosovo during the past 10 years.

Lord Robertson announced a series of measures to quell further outbreaks of violence in the region.

They include a public information campaign to counter what he described as "the politically damaging effect of extremist activity in the Preshevo valley".

fields.headline: Ailing Sema sacks director
fields.trailText: Sema, the troubled software group, sacked director Hartmut Lademacher yesterday but failed to dispel the concern surrounding the company.
fields.body:
Sema, the troubled software group, sacked director Hartmut Lademacher yesterday but failed to dispel the concern surrounding the company.

Mr Lademacher, a non-executive director, was dismissed for breaking stock exchange rules by selling £30m worth of shares in a closed period ahead of Sema's September's financial results.

He had arrived at the Anglo-French company in the summer when Sema bought LHS, a US software company of which Mr Lademacher was the founder and chairman.

Sema saw its shares plunge 8% yesterday and end the day down 21p at 308p as an investigation into the unauthorised share dealing continued by the financial services authority.

Sema issued a profits warning last week which led to a 44% fall in the share price and investors said last night that the growing debacle undermined the position of chief executive Pierre Bonelli.

Sema said Mr Lademacher had explained his decision to sell shares had been made through ignorance of stock exchange rules. But a spokeswoman for the group denied it should have made him aware of his responsibilities.

The Sema official also rejected criticism made privately by some investors that it had failed to act quickly enough over the Lademacher affair and its trading difficulties. She said the company had told the stock market about the share sale as soon as it learned about it. Sema plans to try to quell investor unrest about Mr Lademacher and its profits performance with a series of meetings next week.

Analysts said questions remained about the financial situation inside LHS ahead of its purchase by Sema.

The position of the company was undermined further yesterday when house broker HSBC downgraded Sema from "buy" to "reduce" and gave a target price of 335p.

fields.headline: Investors left holding the baby
fields.trailText: Further doubts dog Sema
fields.body:
Further doubts dog Sema

The departure of Sema director Hartmut Lademacher yesterday seemed dramatic, but the share selling scandal at the heart of the Anglo-French software company is almost a sideshow. The fuses are being blown in the minds of investors not so much by what Mr Lademacher did with his personal equity holdings but by what he and chief executive Pierre Bonelli did or did not know about LHS, Mr Lademacher's company, bought by Sema in the summer for £3.35bn.

That deal has been a disaster. There were suggestions early on that Sema had overpaid, and that the technology used by LHS was not as cutting-edge as had been made out.

Regulatory delays compounded the difficulties and the profit warning issued by Sema last Friday - stemming directly from LHS, whose performance had "significantly deteriorated" - seemed inevitable.

In fact irate investors are now questioning how much was known about the precarious position of LHS in the run-up to the Sema deal and whether all this information was disclosed publicly.

At the very least, Mr Bonelli is going to have his work cut out for him explaining to investors at hurriedly organised meetings next week that he acted as quickly as he could to make public these problems.

The relevance of this to the breaking of stock exchange regulations in the share sale fiasco is that Mr Lademacher is either casual in his reading of rules or dismissive of them.

So could Mr Lademacher be lined up as a scapegoat for wider blame if Mr Bonelli needs to save his own bacon?

At least on Mr Bonelli's side is the fact there are few big shareholders to rock the boat - aside from France Telecom and BNP Paribas, which may be more supportive than some American and British institutions.

Mr Bonelli next week will stick to his belief that once the teething troubles are over, LHS will offer significant opportunities for synergies plus growth in the fast growing telecommunications software. The French chief executive has trumpeted the advantages of this communication sector for building his business. Now he needs to learn the art of better communications with his investors.

Gatecrashers

Trust the Americans to spoil the party. Just as the euro was beginning to tick up a touch on the foreign exchanges, along comes the dollar to take a bite out of the recovery on the back of better than expected US growth numbers.

But pause for a moment. In recent days the foreign exchange options market has begun to suggest there is more risk of the dollar going down against the euro than up - albeit it only just.

It may be, as some would suggest, that the euro is simply the least worst buy in the currency market at present. Opinion is still divided as to whether the US economy is on course for a hard or a soft landing.

There is still an element of political uncertainty. In Japan the administration has a dead duck look, while the issue is not which type of landing is on the cards but whether the Japanese economy will ever get off the ground.

As for the euro - well, things could hardly get worse, could they? Actually what is interesting about the euro's move briefly back above 86 cents yesterday is that it came despite rather gloomy news from Europe, including Tuesday's GDP figures from Germany, the single currency zone's biggest economy.

What may be happening is that rather than looking for excuses to sell the single currency, big players in the foreign exchange markets are looking instead for reasons to offload the dollar.

That is still a long way from saying anyone actually wants to buy the euro for its own sake. And it is a very long way indeed from the theoretical models to which the European commission drew attention yesterday and which suggest the single currency is 20%-25% below its medium term equilibrium levels, whatever they are. Still, it could be a start.

Minced words

The highly paid bankers and lawyers who draw up bid documents should look to their dictionaries to end the growing practice of referring to "irrevocable undertakings", which are nothing of the kind. Yesterday's £322m bid for the Hewden Stuart plant hire business is a typical example of the practice.

The advisers refer to large irrevocable undertakings to accept the bid but add they will cease to be binding if something else happens. The dictionary defines irrevocable as "not able to be revoked, changed or undone, unalterable". The word these City brains should use is "conditional". It might not have the same ring of unswerving support as irrevocable, but is at least correct.

fields.headline: Venture capitalists 'failing' new business
fields.trailText: The British venture capital sector yesterday was accused of failing start-up businesses and growing rich on the back of established companies.
fields.body:
The British venture capital sector yesterday was accused of failing start-up businesses and growing rich on the back of established companies.

The charge came in a new report from the Institute for Public Policy Research, which sought to explain why only 8% of venture capital was used for seedcorn investment compared to 24% in Germany and 31% in the US.

Rebecca Harding, author of the centre-left think-tank's review, said the figures pointed to the part-failure of government policies to encourage venture capitalists to support new businesses.

Britain was unique among those countries studied in having an "equity gap" between what businesses needed and what venture capitalists were prepared to provide.

"Despite the fact that the British venture capital market is the largest and most developed in Europe, our venture capital funds are disproportionately reluctant in comparison with their overseas counterparts to invest in high-risk business at a very early stage," said Ms Harding.

But the British Venture Capital Association believed the IPPR figures were misleading, and pointed out that start-ups were by nature small scale affairs taking up relatively small amounts of money compared with that placed elsewhere.

David Thorp, chairman of the Association and managing director of Friends Ivory & Sime Private Equity, said the IPPR figures represented reasonable historic data but that the situation had changed.

"The last six months show a shift from late to early stage funding of businesses in Britain," Mr Thorp explained.

Ms Harding said government policies in Germany and elsewhere helped by putting up public money alongside private investment. They also gave financial guarantees to reduce the risk for venture capital.

webTitle: UN should leave Haiti, says Annan

fields.headline: UN should leave Haiti, says Annan
fields.trailText: The United Nations secretary-general has recommended withdrawing its mission to Haiti after more than five years, warning that attempts to strengthen democracy are failing in the face of mounting violence aimed at the international community.
fields.body:
The United Nations secretary-general has recommended withdrawing its mission to Haiti after more than five years, warning that attempts to strengthen democracy are failing in the face of mounting violence aimed at the international community.

In a highly critical report, Kofi Annan effectively accused the country's dominant political party, Fanmi Lavalas, and its founder, the former priest and one-time president Jean-Bertrand Aristide, of drifting towards international isolation and violating democracy by refusing to recount the results from May's disputed parliamentary elections.

Mr Annan's written comments, though dated November 9, were released this week following Sunday's presidential election - boycotted by the opposition - which is expected to return Mr Aristide to office. The decision to withdraw is a fresh setback for the UN, coming hard on the heels of continuing problems in Sierra Leone.

"A combination of rampant crime, violent street protests and incidents of violence targeted at the international community could severely limit the ability of [the international civilian support mission in Haiti] to fulfill its mandate," Mr Annan wrote. He recommended "with regret" that the mission be terminated when its current mandate expires on February 6.

The UN mission has been substantially scaled down in recent years - almost all the US troops who arrived in 1994 left 18 months ago.

This month, UN vehicles were fired upon and some international aid donors have suspended projects in protest at the political crisis, although Britain's Department of International Development still channels £45,000 a year towards aid schemes in Haiti, the poorest country in the western hemisphere.

With results from six out of nine districts declared yesterday, the electoral council said Mr Aristide, or "Titid" as he is known in Creole, had received 91% of the vote in the presidential ballot. On Monday, the reclusive politician broke his silence and reached out to the opposition, promising: "There will be a place for everyone in my government."

His efforts fell on deaf ears. Sauveur Pierre Etienne, of the 17-party Convergence alliance, told a local private radio: "What we have in mind is to sit down with other opposition parties and civil organisations and work out a national democratic alternative." He added: "The Haitian people have sung the funeral mass of Lavalas."

The Organisation of American States, which oversaw the disputed May elections, declined to send observers to last weekend's poll. But a statement from a voluntary coalition of predominantly US observers in the capital, Port-au-Prince, yesterday said that there had been few problems with the election.

"We witnessed minor irregularities at the Bureau de Votes but no widespread evidence that registered voters encountered major problems," the International Coalition of Independent Observers stated.

webTitle: Dot.com staff to set up union

fields.headline: Dot.com staff to set up union
fields.trailText: Hi-tech workers in the United States who once shunned trade unions are now turning to collective bargaining efforts to prevent job cuts and mandatory overtime.
fields.body:
Hi-tech workers in the United States who once shunned trade unions are now turning to collective bargaining efforts to prevent job cuts and mandatory overtime.

Employees at Etown.com, a consumer electronics website, yesterday took a step towards organising what could be the first trade union at a dot.com when they filed a petition with the National Labor Relations Board in Washington.

Their efforts follow the organisation of a similar campaign among customer service staff at Amazon.com, the online retailer.

In both cases employees who previously accepted a lack of job security and extended working hours in return for the promise of stock option millions are seeking greater employment protection.

Scott Alan Buss, a customer service representative at Amazon who is involved in Day2, the unionisation effort, said he was opposed to the creation of a union 18 months ago.

"I am very much on the right of the political spectrum," he said. "When unionisation was first proposed, the company had to do very little to squelch it. Now that's not the case."

His views changed, he said, when the company's much vaunted flexibility became mandatory overtime and job losses. At the same time, stock options which once promised untold wealth became worthless as the company's share price plummeted.

The organisers at Amazon named their campaign Day2 because of the favourite mantra of company founder Jeff Bezos.

"Bezos is always telling us, 'It's day one, we can't stop or rest,' and we think five years of day one is generating lots of problems for us."

The effort has not yet garnered sufficient signatures for an officially sanctioned union, about 30% of the workforce.

Meanwhile, call centre staff at Etown have accused the company of forcing employees to work long hours without extra pay amid constantly changing schedules. Robert Heiblim, the chief executive, said he knew nothing about the specific complaints alleged by the employees.

The company received notice that a union was being organised on Monday. All Etown staff are given share options, including hourly paid workers. "We are a start-up company and that can be exhilarating at times and stressful at others. That's just the way it is."

A strike at Verizon, the telecommunications company, over working conditions at a new wireless unit this summer, was regarded as the first successful attempt at transferring old economy organisations to new offshoots.

However, this week's efforts at two dot.coms are believed to be the first at net companies. Gretchen Wilson, an organiser at Washington Alliance of Technology Workers in Seattle, said: "These two companies are in many ways leading the pack. We expect more and more dot.coms to call for collective bargaining."

At the same time, stock options which once promised untold wealth became worthless as the company's share price plummeted. The organisers at Amazon named their campaign Day2 because of the favourite mantra of company founder Jeff Bezos. "Bezos is always telling us, 'It's day one, we can't stop or rest,' and we think five years of day one is generating lots of problems for us." The effort has not yet garnered sufficient signatures for an officially sanctioned union, about 30% of the workforce. Meanwhile, call centre staff at Etown have accused the company of forcing employees to work long hours without extra pay amid constantly changing schedules. Robert Heiblim, the chief executive, said he knew nothing about the specific complaints alleged by the employees. The company received notice that a union was being organised on Monday. All Etown staff are given share options, including hourly paid workers. "We are a start-up company and that can be exhilarating at times and stressful at others. That's just the way it is." A strike at Verizon, the telecommunications company, over working conditions at a new wireless unit this summer, was regarded as the first successful attempt at transferring old economy organisations to new offshoots. However, this week's efforts at two dot.coms are believed to be the first at net companies. Gretchen Wilson, an organiser at Washington Alliance of Technology Workers in Seattle, said: "These two companies are in many ways leading the pack. We expect more and more dot.coms to call for collective bargaining."

fields.headline: Marconi enters US telecoms
fields.trailText: Marconi, the telecoms equipment maker, yesterday set out ambitious plans to break into the US market for optical networking and compete with big north American groups such as Lucent and Nortel.
fields.body:
Marconi, the telecoms equipment maker, yesterday set out ambitious plans to break into the US market for optical networking and compete with big north American groups such as Lucent and Nortel.

The group's plans to satisfy what it sees as an exponential demand for broadband networks could also see it finally abandon the industrial legacy it took over from GEC.

Reporting a 26% rise in sales to £3.2bn and a similar increase in operating profits, Lord (George) Simpson, the chief executive, set the group a target of 30% or more growth and rejected doom-laden City forecasts that it would suffer the same hit to profits as American technology firms. Marconi, he said, had won £6bn in new orders in the first half.

"We are taking that capability into the US, where we are launching our photonics [dense wave division multiplexing] range," he said.

webTitle: Iraqi plan threatens winter oil supplies

fields.headline: Iraqi plan threatens winter oil supplies
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: A new confrontation between Iraq and the UN has raised the spectre of oil supplies being disrupted this winter.
fields.byline: Brian Whitaker, and Luke Harding in New Delhi
fields.body:
A new confrontation between Iraq and the UN has raised the spectre of oil supplies being disrupted this winter.

Baghdad's aim is to divert about $420m (£300m) a year from the oil-for-food programme controlled by the UN and put the money directly into the regime's coffers.

To that end it is ostensibly cutting its oil price but asking customers to pay a premium of 50 cents for each barrel into a special bank account in Jordan, with the implied threat that contracts will not be renewed if they fail to do so.

The UN sanctions committee has rejected this plan, but talks on an alternative mechanism are continuing.

In the absence of an agreement this month, legitimate oil supplies from Iraq - which currently exports more than 2m barrels a day - could begin to dry up.

Some western diplomats believe Iraq is bluffing and would not, if it came to the crunch, be willing to halt oil exports for the sake of gaining more control over the money. But because prices in the petroleum market are currently high, Iraq has accumulated a cash cushion of around $11bn that would allow it to withstand a period without exports. Last night, Iraq and India announced a deal which Iraq's vice-president, Taha Yassin Ramadhan, hailed as a sign that the UN embargo against Baghdad had lost its meaning.

"We will sell oil to any country which wants to buy it," he said on a visit to New Delhi.

Under the agreement Iraq will increase its oil supplies to India and India will export surplus wheat to Iraq and help Iraq to upgrade its oil refineries and explore its oilfield at Tubah in the south.

It is believed that the deal is a fixed-price commitment for at least 20 years.

webTitle: Vote gives Putin chance of life-long criminal immunity

fields.headline: Vote gives Putin chance of life-long criminal immunity
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: President Vladimir Putin acted to put himself and future Russian presidents above the  law yesterday, gaining parliamentary backing for a bill securing lifelong personal immunity   from prosecution for anything he does while in office.
fields.body:
President Vladimir Putin acted to put himself and future Russian presidents above the law yesterday, gaining parliamentary backing for a bill securing lifelong personal immunity from prosecution for anything he does while in office.

Despite a raucous debate in the duma (lower house), the bill was given a first reading by a majority of 282 to 130. It has to be given two more readings to become law.

Mr Putin and his supporters were keen to push it through. It had many critics, raising the possibility that Mr Putin might suffer his first defeat in parliament since assuming the presidency last year. Last night's vote was a measure of his support in the duma.

The first thing Mr Putin did when he became acting president on New Year's Eve was to sign a decree guaranteeing former president Boris Yeltsin immunity, just as prosecutors began to examine allegations of corruption in his family and entourage.

The haste with which he acted raised suspicion, but the bill debated yesterday goes further, adding guarantees against prosecution to all Russian presidents.

It also guarantees a former head of state and his or her family a pension, a government residence, medical cover, bodyguards, a private office and staff, and "special communications". The cost to the taxpayer of looking after the Yeltsin family is estimated at more than £1m a year.

Mr Putin's critics called the bill unconstitutional, because the Russian constitution makes all citizens equal before the law.

They also said it contradicted Russia's signed undertaking to the international criminal court in September that no government officials would be immune from criminal liability.

The criticism came from across the political spectrum. The liberal Yabloko caucus called for the debate to be postponed and said it would abstain on the first reading.

The Communists were the loudest in their opposition, claiming the bill gave carte blanche to a sitting president to act above the law.

"I've been in the duma for seven years and never witnessed such cynical frankness and immorality in draft legislation," a Communist MP, Viktor Ilyukhin, said.

Mr Putin's decree giving Mr Yeltsin immunity is still in force, but opposition MPs have asked the constitutional court to rule on whether it is legal. Many MPs said the Kremlin bill should wait until the court had ruled on the Putin decree, although that may not happen until next summer.

fields.headline: Serbian court to interrogate Milosevic
fields.standfirst: Critics see Serbian plot to save ex-leader from Hague trial
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic will face some form of court proceedings in Serbia for fraud soon after the republic holds elections on December 23, according to an interview given to a Belgrade newspaper by Zoran Djindjic, the man likely to be Serbia's next prime minister.
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic will face some form of court proceedings in Serbia for fraud soon after the republic holds elections on December 23, according to an interview given to a Belgrade newspaper by Zoran Djindjic, the man likely to be Serbia's next prime minister.

The scheme reflects the new authorities' determination not to give up the former Yugoslav president for prosecution at the international war crimes tribunal at the Hague. Those who believe Mr Milosevic should face the Hague tribunal view Mr Djindjic's scheme as a fudging device.

The court, Mr Djindjic said, "will examine three issues: election fraud, the issue of his wealth and the way he acquired it, and the question of who ordered the several murders and assassinations [in Yugoslavia]."

Cedomir Jovanovic, a spokesman for Mr Djindjic's party, said he expected this to take place in January. There was a need to assign responsibility for what happened in Serbia in recent years: "We need some answers from Milosevic."

Mr Djindjic gave the first details of his plan in an interview with the Belgrade-based daily Glas Javnosti. Specifically, he referred to the attempted killing of Vuk Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, and the assassination of a leading Belgrade editor and journalist, Slavko Curuvija.

"He [Milosevic] will have to appear during an investigation process, maybe as a witness, but he can't avoid coming to court. And that will be immediately after elections," he said.If, as expected, the party of President Vojislav Kostunica wins the December elections in Serbia, Mr Djindjic will very likely become the republic's prime minister.

Under Serbia's system, preliminary inquiries are carried out by an investigating judge, who decides whether charges and a trial are justified.

Whether the new government will actually go beyond an initial court interrogation and allow a full prosecution of Mr Milosevic, is open to question. He has just been triumphantly reelected as head of the republic's largest party, the Socialists, and has been allowed to live freely in his Belgrade villa with military protection.

Sonja Biserko, president of the Helsinki commission for human rights in Belgrade, reacted with dismay to the news of the Serbian proceedings. Despite threats against her, she has long advocated cooperation with the Hague.

"Milosevic is responsible for many more things than election fraud," she said. "He is responsible for perpetrating the wars in former Yugoslavia, for war crimes in Croatia, Serbia and Kosovo - and for isolating Serbia."

Zarko Korac, leader of the small Social Democratic Union which belongs to the anti-Milosevic coalition and supports the Hague tribunal, said: "The indictment of Milosevic is much more serious [than the issues Mr Djindjic listed] ... My firm opinion is that this has to be done in cooperation with the Hague."

Aleksandar Popovic of Mr Kostunica's Democratic party of Serbia - which is anti-Hague - said Mr Djindjic had failed to talk to members of the anti-Milosevic coalition before speaking. "Politicians should not interfere with the judicial system. We need an independent judiciary," he said.

fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Speculation of day
fields.body:
Speculation of day

Forget May 3 next year as a possible general election date. The latest rumours have the Millbank planners circling April 5. Apparently, Labour is so confident of victory it wants to get the election out of the way to enjoy the Easter holidays.

Remainder of day

Tony Blair's signature, not worth the paper it's written on in Grimsby. At a charity auction featuring a book bearing his signature a mere £2 was raised from the floor. Mind you, sensible bargain hunters offered nothing for Countdown's Richard Whiteley's tie.

Today

Trade and industry questions. Disqualifications bill, Lords amendments.
MPs will consider any further Lords amendments and once all acts have received royal assent, the house will prorogue until December 6.

Lords: Protection of animals (amendment) bill, third reading. House will prorogue if there is no further business.

webTitle: Tide turns after years of ecological decline

fields.headline: Tide turns after years of ecological decline
fields.standfirst:
Decade-long survey shows improving quality of rivers, ponds, fens and moors, in wake of incentives to look after wildlife habitats

Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Decade-long survey shows improving quality of rivers, ponds, fens and moors, in wake of incentives to look after wildlife habitats.
fields.body:
Britain may have finally turned the tide against more than 30 years of environmental decline. A comprehensive audit, over almost 10 years, covering all land and rivers, suggests we are planting more trees, increasing the number of ponds, maintaining or reviving hedgerows, bogs and moors, and improving the biological quality of rivers.

But the good news, which reflects on conservation policies taken both by Conservative and Labour governments in the past decade, is tempered by marked declines in the quality of grassland, downland, and heaths, and the decline of bogs in Northern Ireland and Scotland. The build-up of nitrogen from car exhausts and intensive factory farming is thought to be destroying many favourite plant species and reducing botanical diversity.

The nadir of British conservation was in the early 1990s, said John Lawton, head of the government's natural environment research council whose Countryside Survey 2000, covering the 90s up to 1998, was published yesterday.

"I believe we are now at a turning point," said Professor Lawton yesterday. "There was appalling loss until 1990 but things are improving now from a very low point. Following intense pressure from conservation groups, politicians are putting into place policies that are making a difference."

The report, which took scientists two years to compile using satellite mapping and detailed field studies, says there has been a 27% expansion of fen, marsh and swamp, a halt to hedgerow destruction, and an increase of 38% in plant diversity around fields.

Broadleaved woodlands have expanded by 4% in England and Wales and 9% in Scotland and Northern Ireland. More than a quarter of all small rivers and streams in Britain are in better condition than was the case in 1990; just 2% have deteriorated.

Tens of thousands of miles of ecologically important hedges and stone walls were lost in the 1980s, said the report, but since 1990 a combination of grants to restore them, and laws to protect others, have effectively stopped the destruction countrywide.

The report noted that the downturn in farm incomes had helped conservation, including hedgerow maintenance, by reducing the pressure from farmers to make larger fields.

Most of the improvements, said Professor Lawton, were due to farmers taking positive, paid action to improve conservation after years of being paid to rip out hedges, enlarge fields and intensify agriculture. "Farmers are not vandals, but economic animals. It shows that agri-environment schemes and special schemes for sensitive areas work. If there are incentives to manage habitats, farmers will respond."

He expected the face of the British countryside to change radically because the common agricultural policy, which paid European farmers, would have to alter if more countries joined the EU. "We do not know exactly how it will change, but the major driver of landscape is economics."

Professor Lawton expected society to want to pay more in future for conservation and recreation, and the maintenance of the environment. The environment minister, Michael Meacher, said: "We need to keep a close eye on the impact that climate change and other human activities might have on our natural habitats. The countryside must not be frozen in time, but the decline in wildlife and habitats must be reversed."

webTitle: Money for spire hire is heaven sent for churches

fields.headline: Money for spire hire is heaven sent for churches
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The Church of England has written to all 13,000 parishes in the country asking whether they would like to have mobile telephone aerials concealed in their steeples.
fields.body:
The Church of England has written to all 13,000 parishes in the country asking whether they would like to have mobile telephone aerials concealed in their steeples.

The move is seen as a potential money-spinner for churches weighed down by restoration costs, but they are being assured that the bats in their belfries will not be disturbed. Parishes are being asked to respond by the end of January to agree to allowing the church to negotiate on their behalf with potential operating companies.

They are being lured with suggestions of annual rentals for aerials of £5,000 - more in some urban areas - and a share of operating profits, which they can put towards church repairs.

The mobile phone network is expanding rapidly with operators planning to have 87% of their coverage in place by 2007. It is estimated that 11,000 new aerial sites and 50,000 cell sites will be needed by 2004 to reach operators' targets.

Richard Hopgood, the Archbishops' Council's director of policy, said: "Doing nothing is not an option. Churches are already being approached by operators and it is a fairly unusual opportunity for us."

Several dozen churches have already accepted radio aerials, including Guildford Cathedral and St Mary Redcliffe, Bristol, described by Elizabeth I as the "fairest and comeliest parish church in all England" which has an aerial hidden in its spire. Norwich's Roman Catholic cathedral is also getting an aerial.

Church officials believe some parishes may already have been ripped off by companies persuading them to lease the use of towers too cheaply. Vicars and parish councils are being told that the aerials will be safe and that regulations will prevent churches inadvertently transmitting sex chat lines.
