fields.headline: Ousted law chief  'felt frightened'
fields.trailText: Kamlesh Bahl, ousted as vice president of the Law Society for bullying staff, told an employment tribunal yesterday that she was made to feel frightened and vulnerable by the president on the day she was asked to leave.
fields.body:
Kamlesh Bahl, ousted as vice president of the Law Society for bullying staff, told an employment tribunal yesterday that she was made to feel frightened and vulnerable by the president on the day she was asked to leave.

Ms Bahl told the tribunal in Watford, Hertfordshire, how Robert Sayer walked into her office on December 13, 1999, and closed the door without greeting her.

She said: "He looked angry. He towered over my desk and started to talk. He is over 6ft tall and a large man. I am 5ft 2in tall and of small build. I found this frightening and asked him to sit down. He did so."

Ms Bahl, 44, a former chairwoman of the equal opportunities commission, is seeking damages from the society for race and sex discrimination, victimisation and constructive dismissal.

She had been in line to succeed Mr Sayer as the first Asian and first woman solicitor to become president of the Law Society, the professional body for the 85,000 solicitors in England and Wales. But she was suspended from her high-powered post and forced to resign after an inquiry chaired by a former law lord, Lord Griffiths, upheld allegations of bullying made by five staff.

Ms Bahl, who received a CBE for services to equal opportunities, described how during their confrontation, Mr Sayer wanted to know only one thing - if she was going to stay away from the office.

She explained that a reply to his letters, about complaints over her behaviour, was being typed, but he was not interested in any reply. She said: "He just wanted to know whether I would be staying away. He told me he had been authorised to escort me from the building if I did not leave.

"I was by then very frightened and felt extremely vulnerable. I genuinely did not know what he would do next. I said I did not want to continue the conversation without a witness present.

"I was shaking and could not believe what had happened. In the whole of my career I had never been treated in this manner."

Ms Bahl told the hearing earlier that she had been expected to become president last summer. She said Mr Sayer asked her to stand because he had a good professional opinion of her.

Ingrid Simler, counsel for Mr Sayer, former head of human resources Jean Johnson and former secretary general Jane Betts, denied discrimination. She said in her opening statement that Ms Bahl's career had run aground, adding: "She now reaches for the self-protection mechanism and it is she who seeks to make gender and ethnicity relevant again."

The hearing continues.

Ms Bahl, who received a CBE for services to equal opportunities, described how during their confrontation, Mr Sayer wanted to know only one thing - if she was going to stay away from the office. She explained that a reply to his letters, about complaints over her behaviour, was being typed, but he was not interested in any reply. She said: "He just wanted to know whether I would be staying away. He told me he had been authorised to escort me from the building if I did not leave. "I was by then very frightened and felt extremely vulnerable. I genuinely did not know what he would do next. I said I did not want to continue the conversation without a witness present. "I was shaking and could not believe what had happened. In the whole of my career I had never been treated in this manner." Ms Bahl told the hearing earlier that she had been expected to become president last summer. She said Mr Sayer asked her to stand because he had a good professional opinion of her. Ingrid Simler, counsel for Mr Sayer, former head of human resources Jean Johnson and former secretary general Jane Betts, denied discrimination. She said in her opening statement that Ms Bahl's career had run aground, adding: "She now reaches for the self-protection mechanism and it is she who seeks to make gender and ethnicity relevant again." The hearing continues.

fields.headline: It's your round
fields.standfirst: The number of licensed premises has increased, as have the industry's profits, but little is being done to tackle the rise of alcohol-related crime
fields.trailText: Business leaders have been complaining again this week about the burden of red tape and regulation they carry - prompting assurances from Tony Blair that the UK offers firms a friendlier environment than anywhere else in Europe. Self-regulation, says the CBI, is preferable. But where market forces have a negative social impact they should be blunted by regulation and business should bear some of the cost of remedying the ills for which it is responsible.
fields.body:
Business leaders have been complaining again this week about the burden of red tape and regulation they carry - prompting assurances from Tony Blair that the UK offers firms a friendlier environment than anywhere else in Europe. Self-regulation, says the CBI, is preferable. But where market forces have a negative social impact they should be blunted by regulation and business should bear some of the cost of remedying the ills for which it is responsible.

The profits of some companies are fuelled by alcohol. The growth of the night-time economy in our cities and town centres is based on alcohol; it has been encouraged by local authorities anxious to foster regeneration and create new forms of employment. Over the past 20 years, the number of licensed premises has increased by 23% - but this average conceals disproportionate growth in city centres and decline in rural areas. Applications for new licences are running at 5,000 a year. With an annual turnover of £22bn, pubs and clubs now employ 500,000 people and are responsible for no less than one in five new jobs.

But success has come at a price. While crime overall has fallen by 10% since Labour came to power, violent crime persists at over 3m offences a year, 40% of which are alcohol-related. If Labour is to be judged successful on crime, it must be seen to address the loutish behaviour to which excess alcohol consumption gives rise - so said Jack Straw yesterday in a big speech on rights and responsibilities. In Manchester, numbers of licensed premises have gone up by 242% over the last three years, while the number of assaults reported to police is up by 225%.

Identifying ways to promote responsible behaviour by individuals is important - not least to protect women who are twice as likely as men to be victims of alcohol-related domestic violence. But what of the companies whose growing profits depend on drink?

Successful marketing of pubs and clubs associates drink with a relaxation of constraints on behaviour. Cheap drinks boost market share. The greater the "happy hour" discount and the shorter its duration, the greater the incentive to drink irresponsibly, according to the drink industry's own watchdog, the Portman Group.

Extrovert, drunken behaviour is the subject of peer humour, not disapproval. But the fine line between high spirits and violence is frequently crossed. A recent Economic and Social Research Council study concluded that "aggressive hedonism is now the norm and unruly violent behaviour is a central feature of this new economy". It found that two-thirds of violent crimes in city centres occur at weekends, one-third happening in the vicinity of licensed premises.

Half of the facial injuries suffered by 15 to 25-year-olds are sustained in assaults, usually in bars or nearby streets. Some 30% of pubs report having at least two fights a year. A quarter of adults have been a victim of alcohol-related violence, whether in a pub, on the street or in their own home.

While pubs and clubs make a profit, the social problem they generate spills out onto the street. Bouncers and doormen, employed to eject unruly customers, literally transfer the problem from their private space into the public domain. There, the inebriated customer may find no open premises at which to buy food, no public toilets nor public transport home. Police officers on the late shift, funded by the taxpayer, are expected to deal with the aftermath.

There is an inherent contradiction between the deliberate promotion of alcohol by the private sector and a public policy objective of reducing alcohol-driven offending. Some pubs and clubs try to curb consumption among those under age and to limit abuse. Licensees have formed local watch schemes to provide early warning of trouble to each other and to the police, and to share information on known offenders. Some schemes ban troublemakers from all watch premises.

The Brewers and Licensed Retailers Association urges its members to use toughened glass to reduce injuries. Some 60% of brewers offer training to licensees on handling violence, 37% offer it to bar staff.

The government intends to regulate the private security industry and bouncers. Not before time: local registration schemes have failed to exclude bouncers with fresh convictions for violent offences or to require more than the average 12 hours training they currently receive.

Regulation of door control is not, however, the answer to violence within pubs, nor on the street. Licensed premises must share responsibility for, and the cost of, the social problem to which they are contributing. If voluntary self-regulation is not effective the issuing and renewal of licences should be tightened. Savings in police time and the cost of accident and emergency services would surely outweigh the cost of monitoring compliance. Licensees who flout legislation banning the sale of alcohol to someone who is already intoxicated, should feel the sanction of the law. Proposed legislation to allow flexible closing times and, in extremis, to enable the police to shut down premises that repeatedly give rise to disorder, should not be delayed.

Who should pay? When football clubs stage events that tax police resources, they are required to pay for the additional policing that the event requires so that the cost does not fall on the taxpayer. The staggering growth in city centre alcohol-based leisure taxes police resources in the late hours of Friday and Saturday, yet the industry is not required to contribute any funds to enable the police to meet demand. Isn't it time that they did?

Sarah Spencer is director of the citizenship and governance programme at the Institute for Public Policy Research

webTitle: Hugo Young: Blair's relations with Africa

fields.headline: Blair's quiet mission to Africa is a personal crusade
fields.standfirst:
Rather covertly, it seems the premier wants to convert the heathen

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Blair's quiet mission to Africa is a personal crusade.
fields.body:
Six months ago, Britain deployed a rapid reaction force in Sierra Leone. The operation took only 48 hours, which even the Americans said they could never have done. At some point, though, the British troops were meant to come home. After rescuing European civilians, and helping restore a measure of stability while the UN got its act together, the intervention was thought likely to be at an end. The implied limit was about three months. Yet there are now 750 British military personnel in Sierra Leone, more not fewer than six months ago, and, the MoD quietly announced last week, they will be there for six more months.

Behind this lies an unwritten story, which is not just military and not just about Sierra Leone. A new wind of change is blowing from London through Africa. This is not a publicly debated strategy. It is something more personal. By far the strongest pulse behind it is the prime minister's own sense of mission. The exercise may not be about territorial imperialism, but has a lot to do with converting the heathen to good government. Tony Blair is on a quiet crusade to help Africa, and do the British duty. Benign though this may be, it is strange that almost nobody knows about it.

Before Christmas it is due to acquire more definition, with the report of a cabinet committee, which Blair set up under Clare Short. Ms Short is one of Blair's favourite ministers, and had something to do with his awakening. With two-thirds of her budget spent there, she is in effect the cabinet minister for Africa, though placing Peter Hain at the Foreign Office last year was part of the conscious choice to give Africa a higher profile. Hain, South African by origin and campaigner by formation, set about putting his continent on the map. A by-product of the signals from Downing St has been the elevation of Africa from its third division status among FCO careerists. Postings there are now sought after by younger diplomats.

This is no doubt because of Blair's ambitious plans. The Short committee will come up with recommendations for a bigger British role in peace-keeping, and in military and police training. The two most potent African countries, South Africa and Nigeria, troubled though they are, will always be the linchpins on which outsiders must rely. But the Blair initiatives are meant to find new roles for Britain, after the Jubilee 2000 campaigns, beyond the familiar territory of aid and debt relief.

Alongside that is an embryonic concept of partnership between OECD developed countries and the "good" African countries that are thought to be making headway towards uncorrupt government and liberal economics. This is still being worked up, but if it makes persuasive sense Uganda, Botswana, Senegal, Mali and Mozambique could be assigned to partner-godfathers in the developed world, to help them sustain their comparative economic success. This is what Blair would like to start putting to selected OECD members early in 2001.

Though Ms Short had a role, nobody seems sure where Blair discovered his enthusiasm for Africa. Unlike John Major, he had no youthful experience there. Unlike Harold Macmillan, he's devoid of the inherited historical awareness that bestowed on leaders of the postwar period a taste for strategic grandeur. If anything, the Blair Africanism is part of the self-instruction that has enlightened him to the scale of the worlds that now touch him. He is an urgent and fascinated learner. No other prime minister has devoted time, as he has, to reading the Koran. Likewise, none has surely asked for special briefings on the Congo, the part of Africa that apparently most fascinates him, for its size, mineral wealth and massive potential for good or ill at the heart of darkness.

Within this oddly covert plan, the decision to keep an indefinite British presence in Sierra Leone is less surprising than it would have seemed if announced last May. Of the 750, about 400 are soldiers, the rest sailors and airmen. On the face of it, they are there to train the Sierra Leone army, but the commitment is obviously deeper than that. A new headquarters group of 100 was announced last week, together with a reaffirmed promise that this group, as well as supporting the trainers and thereby helping the UN mission, would be there to support, if required, another rapid reaction capability of up to 5,000 British personnel. This seems more in line with one of the objectives defined by Robin Cook last June, when the original force was digging in. Among its purposes, he startlingly stated then, was "to rebuild Sierra Leone".

Sierra Leone thus appears in the frontline of a more expansive British dream, of becoming a player in Africa once again. There are practical gains that might follow. It can be made to fit into a strategy of British interest. Wanting to export, we need growing markets in the developing world. Without political stability, these markets have little chance of creating the prosperity British business could help to feed. So there is self-interest in mission. Avoidable disaster beckons. Unless, with outside help, Aids is somehow held in check, whole countries will be decimated, perhaps, like Malawi, losing a quarter of the cabinet and a sixth of the teachers to the disease. But self-interest is not the driving-force behind the new British commitment. That has more to do with Blair's own sense of moral duty, combined with his belief that this prosperous and multi-soldiered country has the capacity to do the work. When defending the intervention in Kosovo, he formulated a doctrine of which Sierra Leone turns out to be the next beneficiary, and is unlikely to be the last. The finest army in the world, he thinks, can train a bad one. A stable government can teach a weak one how to build the institutions that might make it stronger. A rich country should be available to keep the peace in poor ones. And so forth.

This is a distinct and novel foreign policy. Yet it has never been spelled out this way by Tony Blair or Robin Cook. Nor, of course, has it been debated in parliament. Indignation on that point last week, over the creation of the European rapid reaction force, was patently synthetic. The European defence initiative, which originated in Tory times, has been fully signalled and much discussed. The pretence that the EDI is another exercise in Euro-stealth smacks of the familiar phobic routines of Euro-mendacity. This African policy, by contrast, is new. In principle there's much to be said for it. Service chiefs are said to be pleased to have 750 men on active duty in a theatre where they might see some action. But for how long? To what wider end? With which allies? In what uncontrollable circumstances? Pursuing what relationship with the UN? On what assessment of Britain's strategic and "moral" interest? In other times, it would have been inconceivable that this kind of new priority was established without consulting the wisdom of parliament and notifying the country. Even when doing good, the Blair instinct is to keep things quiet rather than open up for an uncontrolled debate.

webTitle: George Monbiot: Indonesia and West Papua

fields.headline: Another massacre is on the way
fields.standfirst:
There is hardly a news editor who has heard of the land concerned

Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: There is hardly a news editor who has heard of the land concerned.
fields.body:
There's an odd component of globalisation, which I find myself at a loss to explain. We are, we're assured, living in a global village, whose people are daily brought closer together. Yet we hear ever less about what is happening in distant parts of the world. There is less foreign news in the papers than there has been for 60 years. Foreign documentaries are almost extinct. Parliamentary debate about overseas issues has all but dried up. In the midst of the communications revolution, we are becoming strangers to each other.

So the massacres due to begin tomorrow will take almost everyone by surprise. Indeed, there is hardly a news editor who has even heard of the land in which they are scheduled to take place.

West Papua is the western half of the island of New Guinea, which has been occupied since 1963 by Indonesia. Tomorrow, local people expect the Indonesian army to launch a one-sided war, bloodier even than the carnage in East Timor last year. The troops and militias have been armed and trained and are awaiting orders. Only the international community can stop them. But, though western nations such as Britain are up to their necks in it, they haven't the faintest intention of seeking to prevent the Indonesian plan from going ahead.

In 1961, the 800,000 Melanesian people of West Papua were promised independence. Holland, the colonial power, began to transfer the administration to local people. In 1962, Indonesia invaded. The attack failed, but John Kennedy, with Britain's backing, coerced the Dutch into surrendering West Papua to the United Nations, on the grounds that if the Indonesian government were not appeased it might succumb to communism. The UN, as planned, promptly gave West Papua to Indonesia, but on condition that within five years its people would be granted "the right of self-determination". In the event, 1,000 Papuan men were rounded up and forced to vote, on pain of death, for Indonesian sovereignty.

Since then, tens, possibly hundreds of thousands of Papuans have been tortured, mutilated and killed by Indonesian soldiers. The government launched a eugenics programme whose purpose, according to the former governor, was to give "birth to a new generation of people without curly hair, sowing the seeds for greater beauty". The Papuans have been pushed out of their lands and replaced by people from the central islands of Indonesia, brought in by the government to pacify the province. Its forests have been sold to logging companies, its mountains to western mining firms. When villagers have sought to defend their lands, they have been bombed and strafed. Now the whole place is about to explode.

Tomorrow, the indigenous people will make a formal declaration of independence. The Indonesian army has been waiting for months for just such a moment. Since August, thousands of commandos and paratroops have been flown into West Papua. British-made Hawk jets have been overflying the province's central highlands. Their deployment there was, according to the Financial Times, sanctioned by Britain's Foreign Office. Militias are currently being trained by the army outside the town of Wamena, one of the centres of Papuan resistance. Some 12,000 firearms have been flown in, presumably for distribution to Indonesian volunteers. Local people, by contrast, are armed with spears and bows and arrows.

The Indonesian army has been encouraging the Papuans to rise, planting agents provocateurs and issuing public statements suggesting that independence ceremonies will be tolerated (all previous rituals have been ruthlessly crushed). Here, as in East Timor, the army will seek to unleash sufficient force to persuade the indigenous people to abandon their hopes of self-determination.

Papuan leaders have repeatedly sought to reach a peaceful independence settlement with the Indonesian government. But while President Wahid seems vaguely sympathetic to their cause, Vice President Megawati, who has, in effect, ultimate control over the province, appears interested only in delivering lucrative logging and development concessions to the army in order to secure its support. The Papuans have approached the British government for help. It has ignored them. And still it continues to sell arms to Indonesia.

When the massacre begins, our officials will doubtless wring their hands and lament the failure of Indonesia's people to resolve their differences by peaceful means. Having seen what happened in East Timor and having failed to do anything to prevent its repetition, the blood this time will be on our hands. We helped to start all this. Now we must stop it.

The Papuans have approached the British government for help. It has ignored them. And still it continues to sell arms to Indonesia. When the massacre begins, our officials will doubtless wring their hands and lament the failure of Indonesia's people to resolve their differences by peaceful means. Having seen what happened in East Timor and having failed to do anything to prevent its repetition, the blood this time will be on our hands. We helped to start all this. Now we must stop it. g.monbiot@zetnet.co.uk

fields.headline: Artists who paint by digits
fields.standfirst: The mouse and keyboard are taking their place alongside the brush and chisel for a new generation of artists, reports  Sean Dodson
fields.trailText: The mouse and keyboard are taking their place alongside the brush and chisel for a new generation of artists, reports Sean Dodson
fields.body:
The internet might have thrown up its very own forms of art but it is not just designated digital artists who are now taking advantage of computer technology.

A number of professional painters, sculptors, illustrators and print makers are making art that includes computer technology in some part of their creative process. The work does not always look digital, so the paintbrush and chisel are not doomed yet. But there is little doubt that computers are now a valuable assistant for even the most traditional of disciplines.

Yesterday saw the launch of Artfutures, an exhibition, held at the Barbican Centre in central London. The show is the work of Contemporary Art Society (CAS) and Hewlett-Packard. It features more than 1,000 new works from a variety of different artists. The event raises money for donations to museums and galleries. ARTfutures features the e-magination exhibition, showing how British artists and designers have been creative with new technology

One of the artists is David Austen, a professional painter who has had solo shows in London, Los Angeles and Amsterdam. Hewlett Packard loaned Austen an HP Colour LaserJet 8550 a week before the show. Austen was asked to produce work that could be printed on it. He handpainted five separate prints in editions of 200.

In return for the loan, HP gets an extra avenue to publicise its wares (the Barbican is a brief walk from the City of London) and some extensive product testing from the artists. As Austen says: "When artists are given stuff like this they think 'how can I break it? How can I do things wrong?' " But the HP in the corner of his studio is still working.

Austen says that the main attraction to working digitally is speed. He says that he has to stop himself from becoming too fussy, but he can manipulate the prints much quicker than he can using traditional methods.

"On the one hand you can print out as many as you like and they are cheap," says Austen. "But that's offset by the fact that they are almost unsaleable."

The other main problem is that they are not as stable as other methods of printing. They don't last as long. But "I think a lot of artists are interested in making longer editions that can be spread around and owned by the many". In the case of ArtFutures, Austen's prints will be given away. His fee comes from Hewlett-Packard.

Although digital technology allows digital works to be produced in vast quantities, not all digital artists are using computers to produce unlimited editions of their work.

Penelope Wakeham (penelopewakeham.com), a Winchester-based painter, has been using computer technology for years. However, her prints are unique and cannot be reproduced exactly.

Wakeham paints not with a brush and canvas but with a mouse and a computer screen - usually using a package such as PhotoShop. She prints out her paintings in the usual way, but that is where any similarity with David Austen ceases.

Because next she fixes the ink with a transparent medium (eg varnish), allows the medium to dry, and peels off the paper leaving a thin, brittle sheet of ink and medium. Wakeham then pastes the sheet on to a canvas or board. Each painting usually takes three or four layers of ink. This she says gives her paintings the kind of depth we see on a computer screen but never on a printed copy.

"Using digital technology to produce images that look like photographs, drawings or paintings is just reinventing the wheel," says Wakeham. "The computer must have its own means of expression.

"In my work, I endeavour to take something of the screen - be that computer monitor, cinema screen or television and paint with it. I want to take the image, saturated with light and give it physicality and texture.

"My work is digital and unique. Each piece is a one off unrepeatable work created using a computer as the tool by which pigment is distributed."

Other artists are embracing digital technology in novel ways. Former Turner Prize nominee Mark Wallinger has used digital technology to produce a 3-D text-based work. Credo is currently on show at Tate Liverpool. It includes two passages from the New Testament and requires the use of special glasses. After the show it will then be reproduced in a limited edition set and distributed on CD. While Tomoko Takahashi, more recently shortlisted for the Turner, has already produced Word Perhect , a web-based work that examines the effect that word processors have on language.

But although a number of professional artists are taking to the computer, it is in the colleges where it they are most common. Trudy Stephenson is a promoter of artists still at college.

She represents artists like Anthony Gross, who is currently studying for an MA at Goldsmiths and who makes wall sized computer generated prints that evoke games technology.

"Artist are always interested in new technology," says Stephenson. "And you don't have to be a whizz at computers. I think that you can sometimes produce better work if you don't have any experience in that field because you see thing in a totally new light."

In March, Tate Britain will host its first exhibition of internet art. The exhibition will follow high-profile shows in the US at the Whitney Museum in New York and Walker Centre in Minneapolis. Each work will celebrate the use of new technology. But the work of Austen, Wakeham and Gross proves that digital works are not that easy to tell from the non-digital.

Next time you see a work of contemporary painting or sculpture or photography, ask yourself this question: Just what role has a computer played in producing that particular work of art?

 ArtFutures is at the Barbican until December 3. Admission free.

 Credo is at the Tate Liverpool until December 23.

 Painting with Numbers is at Changes Studio, Sheridan House, Jewry Street, Winchester from December 4 until Christmas.

fields.headline: Gerald Soffen
fields.standfirst: Viking mission biologist who was a guiding force behind the search for life on Mars
fields.trailText: Gerald Soffen, the biologist who directed the Viking science team that performed the first experiments on the surface of Mars in 1976, has died aged 74. He was a pioneer of astrobiology and a guiding force behind efforts of the US space agency, Nasa, to search for life on Mars and elsewhere in the Universe.
fields.body:
Gerald Soffen, the biologist who directed the Viking science team that performed the first experiments on the surface of Mars in 1976, has died aged 74. He was a pioneer of astrobiology and a guiding force behind efforts of the US space agency, Nasa, to search for life on Mars and elsewhere in the Universe.

The Mars landing was one of the most spectacular achievements in interplanetary exploration. The mission involved the Viking 1 and 2 space probes. These twin spacecraft consisted of an orbiter and lander; the latter carried unmanned laboratories to perform the first experiments on the surface of the planet. The vehicles were equipped with a battery of cameras, seismometers, soil-sampling scoops, and three distinct biology experiments to test for the existence of microbial or simple plant life.

Soffen directed the work of 70 researchers from a dozen American universities and institutes as they gathered the data beamed back to Earth. The results were tantalising. Analysis of the planet's atmosphere and soil found the elements essential for life: carbon, nitrogen, hydrogen, oxygen and phosphorous. But tests for the chemical compounds that would provide tell-tale signs of the metabolic processes which keep bacteria, green plants and animals on Earth alive were inconclusive.

The results were a disappointment for Soffen, but he speculated that Martian life should not be ruled out until the polar regions and other places where there was evidence of water, now or in the past, had been explored. Viking 2's orbiter indicated that the permanent ice cap over the north pole was mostly frozen water.

He said he had always believed that the search for life must take place where there were signs of water. Gilbert Levin, principal investigator for one of the three biology experiments on Viking, maintained over the years that results he and a colleague obtained were consistent with the presence of microbial life on Mars. Recently, those results were dusted down for an independent review by a new generation of scientists keen to use advances in technology to devise more sensitive instruments to look for life on the Red Planet.

Daniel Goldin, the head of Nasa, said Soffen's pioneering work paved the way for new studies of the origin, evolution and distribution of life in the Universe.

Gerald Soffen was born in Cleveland, Ohio. He received a bachelor's degree from the University of California at Los Angeles, and a PhD in biology from Princeton in 1961. He worked for Nasa for more than 30 years, starting at the agency's jet propulsion laboratories in Pasadena, California, developing various types of biological instruments for space flight.

He was recruited to Nasa's Langley research centre, in Virginia, to work as project scientist on the team planning the Viking Mars landing mission.

Although Viking's search for life was inconclusive, the disappointment felt by the biologists was tempered to a degree by the wealth of other findings about the geological features on the planet; the composition of the surface, atmosphere and polar caps; and about many aspects of Martian meteorology, including temperatures, pressures, tides, dust storms and the abundance and transport of water vapour.

In 1978 Soffen became director of life sciences at Nasa's headquarters. He was responsible for all the medical and biological issues connected with America's astronaut corps when the launches of the space shuttle began; and he directed the agency's biomedical, space biology and exobiology research programmes.

As concern grew about the global effects of environmental pollution, Soffen helped to formulate the Mission to Planet Earth programme. In 1983 he moved to the agency's Goddard space flight centre to direct research using the spacecraft that form the Earth Observation System to monitor the globe. In 1990 he formed and directed the university programmes office at Goddard, to strengthen the links between Nasa's research groups and the academic community.

In the months before his death, he was planning the 25th anniversary celebration of the Viking landings. His wife, Kazuko, survives him. His first wife, Hoshi, died in 1978.

Gerald Alan Soffen, biologist and space scientist, born February 7 1926; died November 22 2000

fields.headline: Jack Lowy
fields.standfirst: Unravelling the mysteries of how muscles work
fields.trailText: The biophysicist Jack Lowy, who has died aged 78, was one of the pioneers of the study of the molecular structure of muscle. Using the electron microscope, he made a major contribution to what we know about how muscle works by analysing the structure of various unstriated invertebrate and vertebrate muscles, and of the fibrous protein actin.
fields.body:
The biophysicist Jack Lowy, who has died aged 78, was one of the pioneers of the study of the molecular structure of muscle. Using the electron microscope, he made a major contribution to what we know about how muscle works by analysing the structure of various unstriated invertebrate and vertebrate muscles, and of the fibrous protein actin.

Lowy came to England in 1938 as a refugee from Bratislava, Czechoslovakia. Following a year at Exeter University College, where he lived with a Quaker family and learned English while also attending science courses, he joined his parents in the US in 1940. There he read chemistry at Temple University, Philadelphia, supporting himself partly by playing gypsy violin in New York cafes.

He also worked for the OSS (Office of Strategic Services), a forerunner of the CIA, recruiting men to support the Czech resistance and collecting early intelligence on concentration camps. He volunteered for the RAF in Canada in October 1942, and served for two years with Coastal Command's 311 RAF (Czech) Squadron in England, doubling as a radar technician and rear gunner on Lancaster bombers. Like fellow members of the Czech Resistance, he dropped anti-Nazi leaflets wherever he could on raids, particularly over Poland. After the war he went back to Czechoslovakia as a debriefing officer for the OSS. It was there that he learned at first hand of the fate of his extensive family - most them had perished in Auschwitz - an event that scarred him for life.

Back at university, this time Trinity College, Cambridge, he studied zoology, and for his PhD in 1951 investigated the mechanical behaviour of an unstriated bivalve molluscan muscle. He continued this line of research as a physiologist at the Plymouth marine biological laboratory, as a lecturer at Queen's University, Belfast, and as a member of the Medical Research Council's biophysics unit at King's College, London.

Lowy was totally dedicated to the pursuit of science, and was reluctant to play politics in the academic arena. Prof Jean Hanson, an early colleague, said that she found Lowy stimulating and charismatic, albeit somewhat abrasive. That was a profound insight into his personality, and remained true until his death. Others noted that his wry humour was among his most endearing characteristics.

In 1968, Lowy took up a professorship at the University of Aarhus in Denmark, where he had been invited to found the institute of biophysics. He took with him a powerful group of young English scientists, and set up a structural programme studying smooth and striated muscle from many different species. The group was able to show the presence of filaments of the protein myosin in mammalian smooth muscle, using X-ray diffraction.

Following a heart attack, he was forced to take early retirement from Aarhus, but no one expected him to give up science and, following a brief period of recuperation, he became visiting professor at the Open University's Oxford research unit.

Jack Lowy's period with the Open University turned out to be the longest and the most fruitful of his scientific life. This research (first with Finn Poulsen and then Joan Bordas) revealed many important features of the behaviour of the actin and myosin filaments that make up the contractile apparatus of all muscles. There were many exciting and unexpected new results, though the interpretation was exceptionally difficult and could often be controversial. At such times, Lowy's incisive and logical mind proved invaluable.

He took advantage of his membership of the Open University to study medieval and renaissance art. Even after he was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukaemia in June 1999, he continued an OU course in comparative religion. Apart from science, his great passions were music, reading, walking holidays in the Alps, and studying art and architecture.

Jack Lowy married Ruth Curwen in 1952, following divorce from his first wife. Ruth came from a London family of Jewish intellectuals. She served in the Royal Navy during the war, listening in to German radios and translating military documents. Afterwards, she trained as an architect - after the death of her first husband in 1948 - and worked with the architectural team at the University of London.

She and Jack were inseparable, and she nursed him throughout his final illness. When they eventually decided that they could no longer tolerate Jack's pain, they went gently together into the dark night, appropriately perhaps, on Yom Kippur.

They leave three sons (one from her first marriage) and a daughter.

 Jack Lowy, biophysicist, born March 5 1922; died October 9 2000

fields.headline: Théodore Monod
fields.standfirst: French activist whose life linked the lonely desert and urban protest
fields.trailText: French activist whose life linked the lonely desert and urban protest.
fields.body:
With the death of Théodore Monod at the age of 98, France has lost one of the greatest natural scientists of the last century, and the living proof that adventure and humanitarian protest can last a lifetime.

Two recent images of Monod illustrate the passions of a man who described himself as "an anarchist Christian". Almost blind and deaf, he was filmed, at the age of 93, stumbling through the Sahara with a Touareg assistant, searching for another example of monodellia flexuosa, a desert flower he had discovered in 1940.

This physical and scientific obstinacy is complemented by memories of a bent, old man with a white cane during recent demonstrations in support of decent housing for poor immigrant families in Paris. The link between the desert and the urban protester was clear; Monod wore a camel brooch on the lapel of his threadbare, three-piece suit.

After more than 70 years of exploration in the Sahara, a region that was "beautiful, clean and never lied", Monod said the vast emptiness had only two conquerors - "the camel and the goat". Modesty at his own achievements in changing scientific perception of the western desert contrasted with his admiration for the nomads, soldiers and administrators who had tried to keep up with him during exhausting, near-mystical journeys through what he called his "diocese".

Born in Rouen to a Protestant family, and with five generations of pastors behind him, Monod appeared destined for missionary work from birth. But on moving to the left bank in Paris with his family at the age of five, his real vocation was formed by a visit to the Jardin des Plantes - "an enchanted world which I never quit", as he wrote in his autobiography, Le Chercheur Absolu.

By the time he was 14, he had developed the rigorous scientific methods of a born naturalist, with a report on the zoological and botanical features of Provence. A year later, he created his own natural science society, with a bulletin called Le Martin-Pêcheur (The Kingfisher). He had already installed a telescope in the family bathroom, prefiguring a fascination for other disciplines, including biology, geology and anthropology.

The scholarship Monod displayed during his degree course in natural sciences at the Sorbonne was rewarded by his first period of practical exploration, aboard a French naval vessel studying sea-life off Brittany in 1920, a logical step towards his admission to the Paris natural history museum, whose most influential researcher of the century he was to become.

But it was an expedition to study fish off the coast of Mauritania a year later that led to his passion for the Sahara, where his name gained the same ascetic renown as that of the reclusive French missionary, Père Charles de Foucauld, who died in 1916.

According to his own account, Monod set out on foot to reach Dakar to overcome an unhappy love affair. In the 70 years that followed, he undertook several epic journeys on foot, covering thousands of kilometres, accompanying camel caravans and collecting hundreds of insects, plants and fossils.

One of his best-known discoveries was the skeleton of the Asselar Man, dating back to the neolithic era in Mauritania. Until the end of his life, he searched in vain for a giant meteor that fell on the desert during the first world war. Nor did he find another example of monodellia flex-uosa, the plant which became the subject of controversy after its discovery was contested by British botanists.

In 1997, 24 years after he retired, the Muséum national d'histoire naturelle held an international symposium in the hope of producing a definitive catalogue of Monod's journeys and finds. It concluded that more than a hundred species of previously unknown plant and animal life merited the Latin tag monodi. The work has yet to be finished, while an assessment of all his other scientific interests and political activities could fill several volumes.

After founding the French Institut d'Afrique Noire in Dakar in 1938, Monod was sent to northern Chad during the war to spy on the Italians in Libya, but profited from the remoteness to continue exploration. Recalled and disciplined, he became an active resistance worker, issuing pamphlets condemning the Vichy regime and broadcasting his opposition to its anti-semitic policies from Dakar, where he welcomed De Gaulle in 1944.

Three years after the war, Monod joined the Swiss underwater pioneer, Auguste Piccard, during the first experiments with the bathyscaphe, and, in 1954, descended to 1,450 metres off the African coast. His most intensive Saharan journeys took place between 1956 and 1964 when, among other scientific work, he described prehistoric cave paintings in the Hoggar mountains, part of what he saw as his work as an "encyclopaedist looking at the departure point of human adventure".

His immense prestige proved a constant problem for successive governments when he joined humanitarian protests, leading a socialist minister, Charles Hernu, to describe him as "a zozo" - a crank. The variety and persistence of Monod's campaigns was unequalled by any postwar figure in France. fields.bodyText: With the death of Théodore Monod at the age of 98, France has lost one of the greatest natural scientists of the last century, and the living proof that adventure and humanitarian protest can last a lifetime. Two recent images of Monod illustrate the passions of a man who described himself as "an anarchist Christian". Almost blind and deaf, he was filmed, at the age of 93, stumbling through the Sahara with a Touareg assistant, searching for another example of monodellia flexuosa, a desert flower he had discovered in 1940. This physical and scientific obstinacy is complemented by memories of a bent, old man with a white cane during recent demonstrations in support of decent housing for poor immigrant families in Paris. The link between the desert and the urban protester was clear; Monod wore a camel brooch on the lapel of his threadbare, three-piece suit. After more than 70 years of exploration in the Sahara, a region that was "beautiful, clean and never lied", Monod said the vast emptiness had only two conquerors - "the camel and the goat". Modesty at his own achievements in changing scientific perception of the western desert contrasted with his admiration for the nomads, soldiers and administrators who had tried to keep up with him during exhausting, near-mystical journeys through what he called his "diocese". Born in Rouen to a Protestant family, and with five generations of pastors behind him, Monod appeared destined for missionary work from birth. But on moving to the left bank in Paris with his family at the age of five, his real vocation was formed by a visit to the Jardin des Plantes - "an enchanted world which I never quit", as he wrote in his autobiography, Le Chercheur Absolu. By the time he was 14, he had developed the rigorous scientific methods of a born naturalist, with a report on the zoological and botanical features of Provence. A year later, he created his own natural science society, with a bulletin called Le Martin-Pêcheur (The Kingfisher). He had already installed a telescope in the family bathroom, prefiguring a fascination for other disciplines, including biology, geology and anthropology. The scholarship Monod displayed during his degree course in natural sciences at the Sorbonne was rewarded by his first period of practical exploration, aboard a French naval vessel studying sea-life off Brittany in 1920, a logical step towards his admission to the Paris natural history museum, whose most influential researcher of the century he was to become. But it was an expedition to study fish off the coast of Mauritania a year later that led to his passion for the Sahara, where his name gained the same ascetic renown as that of the reclusive French missionary, Père Charles de Foucauld, who died in 1916. According to his own account, Monod set out on foot to reach Dakar to overcome an unhappy love affair. In the 70 years that followed, he undertook several epic journeys on foot, covering thousands of kilometres, accompanying camel caravans and collecting hundreds of insects, plants and fossils. One of his best-known discoveries was the skeleton of the Asselar Man, dating back to the neolithic era in Mauritania. Until the end of his life, he searched in vain for a giant meteor that fell on the desert during the first world war. Nor did he find another example of monodellia flex-uosa, the plant which became the subject of controversy after its discovery was contested by British botanists. In 1997, 24 years after he retired, the Muséum national d'histoire naturelle held an international symposium in the hope of producing a definitive catalogue of Monod's journeys and finds. It concluded that more than a hundred species of previously unknown plant and animal life merited the Latin tag monodi. The work has yet to be finished, while an assessment of all his other scientific interests and political activities could fill several volumes. After founding the French Institut d'Afrique Noire in Dakar in 1938, Monod was sent to northern Chad during the war to spy on the Italians in Libya, but profited from the remoteness to continue exploration. Recalled and disciplined, he became an active resistance worker, issuing pamphlets condemning the Vichy regime and broadcasting his opposition to its anti-semitic policies from Dakar, where he welcomed De Gaulle in 1944. Three years after the war, Monod joined the Swiss underwater pioneer, Auguste Piccard, during the first experiments with the bathyscaphe, and, in 1954, descended to 1,450 metres off the African coast. His most intensive Saharan journeys took place between 1956 and 1964 when, among other scientific work, he described prehistoric cave paintings in the Hoggar mountains, part of what he saw as his work as an "encyclopaedist looking at the departure point of human adventure". fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Who will play Shaggy in the Scooby-Doo movie, due to be filmed next year?
fields.trailText: Who will play Shaggy in the Scooby-Doo movie, due to be filmed next year?
fields.body:
Matthew Lillard ..............1-3

Jason Biggs ...................4-1

James Van Der Beek ......6-1

Christian Bale ................8-1

Mike Myers ..................16-1

The remake of the much-loved Hanna-Barbera cartoon detective series (now showing on Cartoon Network) is heading for production in Australia during April 2001. And with his wimpish cries and silly ways, Shaggy is the perfect part for a teen actor - a little bit shambolic, but don't we just want to mother him?

Matthew Lillard has gone from bit-parts in films (Ghoulies 3: Ghoulies Go To College) to carving out a niche career in the goofy role department. He was Cereal Killer in Hackers, funny psycho Stu in Scream, and Brock Hudson in She's All That. "If you mentioned Lillard's name, you would probably draw a blank," says Andy Clifton, entertainment odds compiler at Ladbrokes, "but these roles are so high-profile that his photograph would be immediately recognised. The more I researched him, the more I was sure that he was right for the role. Plus he's worked alongside Freddie Prinze Jr three times, and his last two films were for Warner Bros."

While James (Dawson's Creek) Van Der Beek is "almost too sexy", according to Andy, that's not something you could accuse Mike Myers of. "It looks as if it's going to be a teen movie, and Myers is popular in the later years crowd," says Andy. And despite being "unlikely", Myers has spawned a set of internet rumours worthy of their own Scooby mystery.

Another chalk and cheese pair of Shaggies is Jason Biggs (pictured) and Christian Bale. Their big debuts couldn't have been more different. Biggs turned on his teen sex charms in American Pie, while Bale played a war orphan in Steven Spielberg's Empire Of The Sun. "After Henry V, Portrait Of A Lady and American Psycho, I don't see Scooby-Doo following for Bale," says Andy, "but Biggs would have an outstanding chance, especially if Lillard turned it down."

fields.headline: Pass notes
fields.standfirst: No: 1772 Stephen King
fields.trailText: No: 1772 Stephen King
fields.body:
Age: 53.

Job: Blood 'n' guts horror writer. Blame him for Carrie, Salem's Lot, The Shining, Misery, Pet Sematary and a curdle of other 70s and 80s screamfests.

Appearance: "Stephen stands 6ft 4in and weighs about 200 pounds. He is blue-eyed, fair-skinned, and has thick, black hair, with a frost of white most noticeable in his beard, which he sometimes wears between the end of the World Series and the opening of baseball practice in Florida."

What is this, the personal ads column? No, I thought for a change we could let Stephen speak for himself, or rather, just lift chunks from his website.

I don't pay good money to read what Stephen King has to say on his website! Oh dear. Not you as well.

What are you talking about? Well, King rather hoped you would want to pay to read his site, along with millions of others. The author thought he could revolutionise book publishing by releasing his latest novel, The Plant, chapter by chapter, on the net. He launched the first instalment in the summer, but announced earlier this month that part six, to be published in a few weeks, will be his last for a while.

The axes must be out at the fan club. Devoted readers, needless to say, are not best pleased. They will now have to wait to discover whether the man-eating vine, sent by an author to devour his publishers (geddit?), actually gets its man.

So what happened, nobody wanted to download it? Not quite. Plenty of people downloaded it; it's just that King had left it up to them whether they paid for it or not. Oddly, given a choice of having something for nothing or paying for it, more than half his readers overlooked paying the $2 fee for the later chapters. So King's putting it out to seed, and is off to pastures new.

Do say: " It's not dead, it's hibernating."

Don't say: " Always protect plants from parasites."

webTitle: Counting the beat Queensland's whales take up new tunes

fields.headline: Counting the beat Queensland's whales take up new tunes
fields.trailText: Humans are not the only ones bowled over by a catchy new tune. Australian scientists report today that humpback whales, too, discard old songs when they hear a new beat.
fields.body:
Humans are not the only ones bowled over by a catchy new tune. Australian scientists report today that humpback whales, too, discard old songs when they hear a new beat.

Megaptera novaeagliae is a barrel-chested baritone that grows up to 50ft long and peaceably sucks shrimps and plankton through its baleen. It also sings ballads. It assembles its snores, groans, moans and squeaks into a recognisable pattern of song that can last from five to 55 minutes.

And, like humans, taste varies. Each regional group has its distinctive patterns, which change gradually from year to year. Until now, biologists believed that whale songs evolved.

But a team of eavesdroppers - from the University of Sydney's veterinary department, the Centre for Whale Research at Fremantle, and the Australian Defence Science and Technology Organisation - reports in Nature today that humpback taste is fickle.

The researchers recorded 1,057 hours of humpbacks' songs as they migrated in the Pacific, off Queensland, between 1996 and 1998. At first, the songs changed subtly. But two singers out of the 82 males were singing a completely different song. In 1997, there were 112 singers, and some sang the old song, some the new - and some went in for arias containing themes from both. By 1998, only the new song was audible.

This was almost identical to a shanty recorded off the west coast of Australia. There was only one explanation: Indian ocean whales had mixed with those from the Pacific, and their sound swept all before it.

"Complete replacement of a complex song over a period of less than two years is revolutionary rather than evolutionary, and suggests that novelty drives changes in whale song," the scientists say.

webTitle: Michael Craig-Martin, the godfather of Britart

fields.headline: There goes art's last hope
fields.standfirst: Michael Craig-Martin, the godfather of Britart, is moving on. Bad news for the next generation of students, says Jonathan Jones
fields.trailText: Michael Craig-Martin, the godfather of Britart, is moving on. Bad news for the next generation of students, says Jonathan Jones.
fields.body:
When the time comes for the story of British art in the 1990s to be written, there will have to be a whole chapter on Michael Craig-Martin. Today he is a painter of household objects in acid colours. But it is his influence on younger artists that is extraordinary. As a tutor at Goldsmiths College in the late 1980s, he was acknowledged as an inspirational figure by Damien Hirst and other hardcore young British artists. He was also an influential Tate trustee throughout the 1990s and a key force in the creation of Tate Modern, for which he co-designed the purple light on top of the chimney. You could play a great art-world game called Six Degrees of Michael Craig-Martin.

So it's a surprise to discover, talking to him on the eve of his retirement as Millard professor at Goldsmiths, that far from expressing quiet contentment, he has serious anxieties about the state of the visual arts in Britain, or at least about the state of art education.

"The whole nature of education has changed dramatically in the past 15 to 20 years; this is true at every level of education and it certainly has had an impact on art education," he says.

What Craig-Martin worries about is an insidious growth in academicism. Artists have been drawn more than ever before into the university ethos, into certain patterns of activity and assessment that are associated with university education. All the models that are being used come from the academic world. People take PhDs in fine art; this is something that either didn't happen in the past or was at least very rare.

This academicism is the opposite of the approach that Craig-Martin is famous for. The Goldsmiths class of the late 1980s, which included Damien Hirst, Sarah Lucas, Mat Collishaw, Gary Hume, Simon Patterson - all of whom appeared in the show Freeze, curated by Hirst when he was still a student - were about as far from academically oriented perpetual students as it is possible to be. They were openly ambitious. They wanted, and got, careers as artists. This was a result of the way they were taught. At Goldsmiths, teachers including Craig-Martin and Jon Thompson had developed since the 1970s a style of teaching geared to producing artists rather than art teachers.

"Our model was, what is the nature of the world into which they leave? What's expected of an artist? Is there an equivalent of a painting department out in the world, and the equivalent of a sculpture department out in the world? The answer is no." Now Goldsmiths is changing. The academics are taking over.

The next Millard professor will be Victor Burgin, an art theorist as well as an artist. Burgin makes photo-based artworks that are essentially illustrations of his academic writings. Despite coming from the same conceptual art generation of the 1970s - Craig-Martin acknowledges that it was Burgin who helped him get his first job at an art school - Burgin couldn't be further removed in his attitude to art. His artworks deconstruct Hitchcock, or stage cinematic scenarios with Lacanian subtexts.

Of academic practices generally, Craig-Martin says, "I feel uneasy about whether these formats are the ones that best enable people to have the kind of creative courage that's needed to be artists." Contemporary art, he says in a rather more relaxed way than Sir Nicholas Serota did in last week's Dimbleby Lecture, is in Britain to stay: the London art scene has an energy that is not going to go away. Nevertheless, he admits, "That energy there was at the beginning with that particular group of people, that's not easily repeatable."

This is something that is already affecting the art in galleries. More and more art, it seems, is being made with one eye on theory. Photo-based artists in particular, with the exception of Turner winner Wolfgang Tillmans, seem to be trying to conform to the writings of American academics such as Rosalind Krauss, Hal Foster and others associated with the journal October. Some academics, complains Craig-Martin, "exercise an authority that would be considered shocking if they were artists". The October group see themselves as overturning the high modernist word of Clement Greenberg, champion of the abstract expressionists, in favour of a feminist and queer postmodernism. But they seem to have more of a stranglehold over art in America today than any high modernist critic ever had, as is obvious from the new displays at the Museum of Modern Art in New York.

The American critic David Hickey has blamed the rise of the museum and the academically minded curator for the crisis in American art. One thing never pointed out in gushing accounts of the success of British art in the 1990s is that it was made a lot easier by the suicide of the opposition. This was the decade in which American art's amazingly fertile, turbulent history spluttered and croaked. There has not been a single exciting new star in American art for more than a decade now.

So what Craig-Martin is saying is chilling, because what is happening here sounds like what has already happened there. American art was suffocated by the elevation of postmodern theory to an orthodox museum language, as notoriously manifested in the heavily politicised 1991 Whitney Biennial. Their loss was our opportunity: while American artists were squabbling about politics, Damien Hirst was sawing cows in half. Now it looks as if the miasma of theory is coming over here. It takes a distinctively British form, with the post-Hirst generation claiming to be more serious and politically aware than its predecessor. The magazine Art Monthly is full of piss-poor Marxist theory. Even the venerable journal New Left Review has got in on what is becoming a retro-1970s art scene. The rise of the curator is part of the same phenomenon.

No one describes better than Craig-Martin just what it was that was special about British art in the early 1990s, just how distinctive the art of Damien Hirst really is. Perhaps that is because of the depth of history he brings to it. Craig-Martin is anything but anti-intellectual. He just wears his knowledge lightly. Born in Dublin and brought up in Washington DC, he could not have had a more refined education. He studied art at Yale University, in a radical department shaped by the émigré Bauhaus teacher and artist Josef Albers. So he can claim a direct link to the art and design principles of the Bauhaus, the constructivist academy that flourished in Weimar Germany.

The Bauhaus preached a simple acceptance of modern forms, and Craig-Martin has been fascinated by objects since the 1960s. It was the moment of minimalist and conceptual art, when, as he remembers, "the question of what is art was one that artists thought about a lot. I suppose part of my interest in objects was why one object should be a work of art and another object not. How can you tell the difference?"

Craig-Martin came to Britain in 1966 to teach art in Bath, stayed on, and was invited to tutor at Goldsmiths in 1974. This was a time when artists did not expect to make money from their work, so being an artist almost inevitably meant being a teacher too. He continued his inquiry into what makes one object a work of art and another just a thing. His most famous joke on the mystery of objects was 1973's An Oak Tree, which consisted of a glass of water on a shelf and a text insisting that he had changed it into an oak tree without altering its appearance in any way.

"One of the things I wanted to do with the oak tree was to make something where the proof that it did happen was the same as the proof that it didn't happen, so that you couldn't conclusively say one way or the other. I suppose one of the things that intrigued me most - and it remains true in the drawings I do now - is that you can represent something with something that it doesn't look like."

Today he is best known for his paintings and wall drawings; he was invited to do a large wall painting at the Museum of Modern Art in New York this year to celebrate the museum's rehang of its collection. His paintings, which grew out of drawings very much in the clear-eyed spirit of Bauhaus design, are of mass- produced objects that he paints in a deliberately uninflected way, in non-representational colours, everything marked out in bold lines and perfect linear perspective, floating freely in space. They are paintings that make you wonder how things are connected, why this bunch of keys has come together with that umbrella.

It's probably the directness of his own art that enabled him to recognise the worth of Hirst and his contemporaries. "Right from the beginning they made work in the language of their time that made it possible for people to engage with it," says Craig-Martin. "People could understand what it was about. It was accessible work. It didn't have certain kinds of distancing things that were associated with high modernism."

There was something special about British art 10 years ago, but it is disappearing fast. Today the very success of Hirst and co in creating a London art world, a system of talk and activity around art, seems to be making the simplicity of their art less and less likely to be repeated. Michael Craig-Martin is only talking about art education, but you can already see the debilitating effects of academicism on art in London. Where we once had artists but no art world, we are in danger of getting an art world on the scale of Manhattan's without any real artists. Someone needs to come along with a cocky attitude and a chainsaw - with someone like Michael Craig-Martin to teach them.

He studied art at Yale University, in a radical department shaped by the émigré Bauhaus teacher and artist Josef Albers. So he can claim a direct link to the art and design principles of the Bauhaus, the constructivist academy that flourished in Weimar Germany. The Bauhaus preached a simple acceptance of modern forms, and Craig-Martin has been fascinated by objects since the 1960s. It was the moment of minimalist and conceptual art, when, as he remembers, "the question of what is art was one that artists thought about a lot. I suppose part of my interest in objects was why one object should be a work of art and another object not. How can you tell the difference?" Craig-Martin came to Britain in 1966 to teach art in Bath, stayed on, and was invited to tutor at Goldsmiths in 1974. This was a time when artists did not expect to make money from their work, so being an artist almost inevitably meant being a teacher too. He continued his inquiry into what makes one object a work of art and another just a thing. His most famous joke on the mystery of objects was 1973's An Oak Tree, which consisted of a glass of water on a shelf and a text insisting that he had changed it into an oak tree without altering its appearance in any way. "One of the things I wanted to do with the oak tree was to make something where the proof that it did happen was the same as the proof that it didn't happen, so that you couldn't conclusively say one way or the other. I suppose one of the things that intrigued me most - and it remains true in the drawings I do now - is that you can represent something with something that it doesn't look like." Today he is best known for his paintings and wall drawings; he was invited to do a large wall painting at the Museum of Modern Art in New York this year to celebrate the museum's rehang of its collection. His paintings, which grew out of drawings very much in the clear-eyed spirit of Bauhaus design, are of mass- produced objects that he paints in a deliberately uninflected way, in non-representational colours, everything marked out in bold lines and perfect linear perspective, floating freely in space. They are paintings that make you wonder how things are connected, why this bunch of keys has come together with that umbrella. It's probably the directness of his own art that enabled him to recognise the worth of Hirst and his contemporaries. "Right from the beginning they made work in the language of their time that made it possible for people to engage with it," says Craig-Martin. "People could understand what it was about. It was accessible work. It didn't have certain kinds of distancing things that were associated with high modernism." There was something special about British art 10 years ago, but it is disappearing fast. Today the very success of Hirst and co in creating a London art world, a system of talk and activity around art, seems to be making the simplicity of their art less and less likely to be repeated. Michael Craig-Martin is only talking about art education, but you can already see the debilitating effects of academicism on art in London. Where we once had artists but no art world, we are in danger of getting an art world on the scale of Manhattan's without any real artists. Someone needs to come along with a cocky attitude and a chainsaw - with someone like Michael Craig-Martin to teach them.  Michael Craig-Martin's latest show opens at fig-1, 2-3 Fareham Street, London W1 (020-7734 9269), on December 12.

fields.headline: Day of the dead
fields.trailText: Brookside / Back To The Floor / The David Beckham Story
fields.body:
On the whole, people are far too forgiving, especially where dead friends and family are concerned. Nasty grandparents somehow attain sainthood once they have shuffled out of their carpet slippers and into their coffins. Irritating next-door-neighbours "weren't really that bad" once they've passed away thanks to an ingenious plan to creosote the inside of their shed. And tiresome old pals are missed much more when they're six feet under as opposed to down under. While some may attribute such exculpation of the departed as evidence of a tremendous capacity for forgiveness, it's really about abandoning one's convictions in an attempt to avoid feeling guilty about the downfall of one's foes. Instead of celebrating that the ex-partner who deliberately dropped all your bath bombs down the toilet has keeled over dead in the changing rooms at Dorothy Perkins, for example, some people would mourn their passing. Pah! Such revisionism is a get-out clause for the cowardly, an emergency exit for the weak.

Witness the to-do down Brookside (Channel 4) now that Susannah's body has at last been found. After spending so much of her life on her back staring at the stars (and the cracks on ceilings), Susannah spent her last moments of life - and the following three weeks - lying on her front gazing down at the kitchen lino. Oh, cruel fate.

As is the way with these things, everyone who had previously wished her dead is now backtracking faster than Ann Widdecombe on drugs. She may have been horrible, said Nikki Shadwick, Dr Darren, Jacqui Dixon and Mick Johnson, but death doesn't become her. Even Emily "Now With Free Foot Pump" Shadwick said she had forgiven Susannah for getting her dad and brother killed. What is the world coming to when you can't rely on Mad Em for a bit of sulphuric bitterness and homicidal rancour?

It was a relief then that Jessie, remotely operated by Brian Henson, unveiled her hatred of La Morrissey. "While my son was lying in the ground," she wailed, "Susannah was unloading the shopping, having her hair done, flitting around in a pretty dress." Obviously the trauma was playing with Muppety Jessie's mind - Susannah never owned a pretty dress.

If it isn't post mortem regret and reappraisal, it was rampant stupidity which took effect. Take the toxic teenager Adele Murray, who, if there's any justice in SoapLand, will die a virgin. Coming over all Amanda Burton, she wanted to know the gory details of Susannah's death. In a moment of stunning imbecility, Adele asked "Did she look beautiful?" as if falling down a flight of stairs was akin to a makeover from Bobbi Brown. Yes, Adele, she looked lovely what with her fractured skull, decomposing body and slackened orifices.

The big question now isn't, will Jacqui get Harry back? Or, will Max ever shave again? Or even, what vegetable has Lance lodged in his person to maintain so pained a look (my money's on a big red onion)? Rather, it is how will Susannah be dispatched to Soap Heaven? In the great BBC tradition of getting the public to call premium-rate phone lines to do the job of schedulers, there should be a phone vote. I vote for a farewell similar to that given to Matthew and Emily, the children whom Susannah catapulted through the windscreen of her car. Their ashes were scattered on a Liverpudlian beach by Max and Susannah, who then groaned "Let the tide take them." Along with old sanitary towels, used condoms and dead seagulls. A fitting end, to be sure.

Back To The Floor (BBC2) yet again proved a delight as Jacqueline Gold, head of Ann Summers, left her glamorama offices to head back to the coalface. In Gold's case, this meant sewing saucy bras at the company's factory in Portsmouth and selling the finished items (which wouldn't keep you warm on a winter's night), as well as all manner of eye-watering love contraptions - perhaps well known to the vibrator ladies from last week's Hidden Love - to a bunch of Lambrini-powered women at one of the company's legendary parties. Though her sewing skills were redoubtable, her blowing-up-condom abilities left a lot to be desired, as did her attempts at the filthy talk. It was as much a revelation for Gold as it was for us, with more epiphanies than all her Christmases come at once. Class.

The David Beckham Story (ITV). Lots of nice pictures and no long words.

fields.headline: Standard deviation
fields.standfirst: John Fordham on the jazz classics album Django Bates swore he would never make
fields.trailText: John Fordham on the jazz classics album Django Bates swore he would never make.
fields.body:
Django Bates says he wanted to work with the Smith String Quartet because the name appealed to him. He liked its laconic literalness in a world of Amadeuses and Kronoses. He also liked the tape the ensemble sent him as an invitation to a cross-genre collaboration - "quite mechanical modern classical pieces they made to sound very unmechanical and groovy". The result of the collaboration - Quiet Nights, the jazz standards project that Bates swore he'd never make - goes on the road next week.

Bates is joking about the Smiths' name, but only just. To him, the formalities and ceremonies of the classical world have always seemed inappropriate for something as fluid, intuitive and emotionally expressive as music. He once said that being a musician was incompatible with self-importance because it was surreal in itself - "Selling vibrations in the air. What's more surreal than that?"

Bates's parents, he says, grew cabbages in the front garden of "a street full of bank managers" in Beckenham, and filled the house with vagrant artist friends and their families. Equally crucial to his early career path was his father's motley record collection of Romanian folk, African music and jazz. Bates lasted two weeks studying composition at the Royal College of Music in London, and has been composing ever since.

Since his 1980s days as an undeclared key figure in the revolutionary orchestral collective Loose Tubes, he has moved freely between writing for jazz and classical bands. Bates began this year with the Britten Sinfonia and Joanna McGregor, and ends it with the Smiths, with a break for composing for the West End production of Tennessee Williams's Baby Doll along the way. It's a long stride from the classy Keith Jarrett-inclined straightahead jazz pianist that Bates might have been.

Bates says the strongest impression making Quiet Nights left with him was the beauty of tunes such as Solitude and Over the Rainbow, whatever contemporary treatment he might give them. But his two years on the project have shown him how passionately some music lovers fight to protect a meaning of "standards" that is something more than a cherished source of raw material. One jazz commentator who had declared admiration for his earlier work went out of his way to tell him that Quiet Nights was "fucking awful". It was a stronger reaction than Bates had received for far quirkier examples of his work.

"In the jazz world it's been OK, since bebop, to make standards more and more complicated. People have written books on how to put five chords in where there used to be two. You don't get criticism for that. But though it might have seemed to be taking the music out harmonically, making it more adventurous, it was really the opposite - like saying, 'We're playing this game of stretching the possibilities, but really we're just making more rules for ourselves.' Removing bits from standards is what I got interested in, making them simpler. And turning around some of the regular ways they've been played."

Bates has certainly done the latter with Quiet Nights. While Teach Me Tonight gets the cool, poised vocal treatment you might expect from his Swedish discovery Josefine Cronholm, the supporting ensemble chatters in the background at twice the speed, as if Cronholm were singing by the kitchen of a busy restaurant. Hi Lili Hi Lo, generally a boisterous outing for a singer, is given a solemn, perversely slow-moving delivery, while the band plays oompah music. Only Solitude is taken pretty straight, but Bates took care to replace the decent studio piano with an abandoned out-of-tune upright that he found.

Bates has just celebrated his 40th birthday, which makes it harder for the enfant terrible tag from his Loose Tubes days to endure. When he won the 1996 Jazzpar prize, the Danish Jazz Centre's £20,000 award that once went to Miles Davis, the judges complemented his music for being "grotesk og folsom" - "grotesque and fulsome". He thought it was one of the nicest compliments he'd ever had, and still does. And "enfant terrible"? "Well, I suppose I have to face up to dropping the 'enfant' now," Bates admits. "Just as long as I don't have to lose the 'terrible'."

 Django Bates and the Smith Quartet play the Djanogly Recital Hall, Nottingham (0115-951 4764) on Sunday, then tour.
