webTitle: EU may ban aid to states that allow female circumcision

fields.headline: EU may ban aid to states that allow female circumcision
fields.trailText: Third world countries that refuse to ban the controversial practice of female genital mutilation could be stripped of their right to receive European Union development aid, an EU commissioner warned yesterday as campaigners from Africa lobbied in Brussels.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn in Brussels and Sarah Boseley, health correspondent
fields.body:
Third world countries that refuse to ban the controversial practice of female genital mutilation could be stripped of their right to receive European Union development aid, an EU commissioner warned yesterday as campaigners from Africa lobbied in Brussels.

In an impassioned speech before the European parliament, Anna Diamantopoulou, the EU's Greek commissioner for employment and social affairs, condemned the procedure as an appalling violation of fundamental human rights.

As many as 2m girls are considered to be at risk of genital mutilation every year. The painful operation sees all or part of the clitoris and other genitalia removed, without anaesthetic and in conditions that are usually unsanitary. Death, disability and sterility can be the result.

Female circumcision is practised in 28 African countries. In Somalia, it is done to 98% of women. Sudan, Djibouti, parts of the Arabian peninsula, and Democratic Republic of Congo, are among the places named in UN studies as practising ritual mutilation. The EU and the United Nations estimate that some 135m women have been circumcised.

UN experts believe that the practice is gradually being rolled back through legal action. Last year Senegal outlawed it, and the year before, Tanzania, Ivory Coast and Togo. Among other recent reformers are Ghana, Burkina Faso and Egypt.

"It is high time that member states, and indeed the EU as a whole, addressed the issue," Ms Diamantopoulou told the parliamentary hearing in Brussels. Some MEPs want EU states to recognises the threat of female circumcision as a reason for granting refugee status.

In a speech that will enrage proponents who argue that their cultural traditions require control of female sexuality and keeping girls virginal until marriage, the commissioner also called on EU member states to outlaw the procedure among African immigrant communities.

In Europe, laws banning female genital mutilation exist only in Britain, Norway and Sweden, Ms Diamantopoulou said. Britain, she noted, is the EU country with the highest number of female immigrants from cultures that practise circumcision - 300,000.

But it is her suggestion that EU development aid be linked to stamping out female circumcision in Africa which is likely to cause controversy. "We may consider making aid to recipient countries contingent on their commitment to fight the practice of female genital mutilation via legislation and education," she said.

Sensitive to accusations of western interference, she went out of her way to justify her position.

"Europe is not in the business of preaching and imposing its culture on other countries and nations. However, Europe must be very clear in defending its values which are built around justice, equality of the sexes and human rights," she said.

fields.headline: £3m for war slave labourers
fields.trailText: Japan's biggest construction company agreed to pay wartime slave labourers 500m yen (£3.2m) yesterday in a deal that could boost compensation claims by British prisoners of war.
fields.body:
Japan's biggest construction company agreed to pay wartime slave labourers 500m yen (£3.2m) yesterday in a deal that could boost compensation claims by British prisoners of war.

The company, Kajima, operated an infamous construction site in Odate, northern Japan, where 418 Chinese workers died of beatings, torture or illness between 1944 and 1945.

Eleven survivors sued the company in 1995, seeking 60m yen in compensation for their suffering and unpaid labour.

In a surprise out-of-court deal yesterday, the company agreed to establish a fund worth 500m yen, not only for the plaintiffs but for the families of all 986 Chinese workers at the site.

It is the largest sum ever paid out in a slave labour suit by a Japanese company.

Kajima said that the payment was not intended as compensation. "As it was wartime, the conditions of the workers were extremely harsh, and though we gave our greatest consideration, unfortunately many died from illnesses and we are deeply grieved by this," it said.

Three British former PoWs have filed a suit in the US seeking compensation from Japan Energy for their unpaid labour and suffering at the Kinkaseki mine in Taiwan. Their lawyer, Martin Day, said: "This judgment is indicative of the fact that taking on Japanese firms has real potential."

The British government agreed earlier this month to pay 16,700 former PoWs or their families £10,000 each in recognition of their suffering. But the PoWs plan to continue to fight for an apology and compensation from Japan.

webTitle: Finns to double paid paternity leave

fields.headline: Finns to double paid paternity leave
fields.standfirst: Family-friendly prime minister tells Guardian why
fields.trailText: Praised by Cherie Blair earlier this year for the "fine example" he set Tony when it came to taking time out for the birth of their baby, the family-friendly prime minister of Finland, Paavo Lipponen, is now proposing a big increase in the number of days of paid paternity leave for Finns.
fields.body:
Praised by Cherie Blair earlier this year for the "fine example" he set Tony when it came to taking time out for the birth of their baby, the family-friendly prime minister of Finland, Paavo Lipponen, is now proposing a big increase in the number of days of paid paternity leave for Finns.

Under the Lipponen proposal, which the parliament in Helsinki is expected to approve, fathers of newborn babies would have more than double the time they currently get - a further 24 days of paid paternity leave added to the present 18 paid days, for a grand total of six weeks.

Britain, by contrast, has no statutory paid paternity leave, so the Finnish initiative will widen what is already a big gap in this social provision for families.

"If I can help advance this cause that I believe in - that men and women should share responsibility for children, so that the mother can have the opportunity to work or study and have free time - then that's good," Mr Lipponen told the Guardian.

"This is a step forward in adjusting working life to family life."

Mr Lipponen, serious-minded and at times slow to articulate his thoughts, may look every bit as macho as John Prescott, but in a country whose female voters are famously tough in their insistence on equal rights, he is an enthusiastic proponent of women's rights.

He was the first Finnish government minister to take time off when he and his wife, Paivi, had their first child, Emilia. In March this year he again took a week-long break when their second daughter, Sofia, was born.

Sitting at a utilitarian desk in the parliament building in Helsinki, he also professes to do his bit around the house in the interests of equality.

"I take care of the children in the early morning so that my wife can rest a little. I prepare breakfast for the family, and, if I can, I take the seven-year-old [his daughter by his first wife] to school on my way to work.

"In the evening I participate in the ritual of the children going to bed - getting changed into their night clothes and eating porridge." Asked how it feels to be held up as a model for Britain's prime minister, Mr Lipponen - who is called Moses by the press for his dry manner and sermon-like speeches - argues that he is only doing what comes naturally. "I don't think of myself as a model, because I'm doing what I should do to help my wife."

His Social Democratic party has good relations with the British Labour party and he has a friendly working relationship with Mr Blair.

"We've exchanged experiences and we've both been woken up in the middle of the night. I said to him that it serves him right, because I have to get up, too," he laughs.

He may joke, but Finns, and by extension their state, take families seriously. Last year some 40,000 fathers took two weeks off to be with their new babies, at an estimated cost to the state of some £13m.

Under Finnish law women are entitled to 105 paid days of maternity leave, while fathers currently get 18 days. In addition, 158 paid days are available for the parents to share, though in practice it is usually the mother who uses these.

Mr Lipponen's new proposals mean that fathers would get 24 more paid days which could not be used by mothers.

Finns have had paid paternity leave since the early 1980s. This contrasts with Britain, where it was only last year that the right to take paternity leave was introduced - and this was due to an EU directive.

As a result, British fathers can take up to 13 weeks off in the first five years of their child's life, but this time is unpaid and can be taken only by men who have been with the same employer for a year.

Fathers' days

As a matter of national law - distinct from policies in individual companies - provisions for paternity leave vary hugely in the west

US No paid leave on offer, but fathers can take up to 12 weeks' unpaid time off in the year after the birth

Norway Fathers are obliged to take a four-week block of paid leave or lose the right to take any paid paternity time

Finland Fathers are eligible for 18 days of paid leave but a further 24 paid days are likely to be added soon

Britain No statutory paid paternity leave, but fathers can take up to 13 weeks of unpaid leave in the first five years after the birth, if they have been in their job a year

fields.bodyText: Praised by Cherie Blair earlier this year for the "fine example" he set Tony when it came to taking time out for the birth of their baby, the family-friendly prime minister of Finland, Paavo Lipponen, is now proposing a big increase in the number of days of paid paternity leave for Finns. Under the Lipponen proposal, which the parliament in Helsinki is expected to approve, fathers of newborn babies would have more than double the time they currently get - a further 24 days of paid paternity leave added to the present 18 paid days, for a grand total of six weeks. Britain, by contrast, has no statutory paid paternity leave, so the Finnish initiative will widen what is already a big gap in this social provision for families. "If I can help advance this cause that I believe in - that men and women should share responsibility for children, so that the mother can have the opportunity to work or study and have free time - then that's good," Mr Lipponen told the Guardian. "This is a step forward in adjusting working life to family life." Mr Lipponen, serious-minded and at times slow to articulate his thoughts, may look every bit as macho as John Prescott, but in a country whose female voters are famously tough in their insistence on equal rights, he is an enthusiastic proponent of women's rights. He was the first Finnish government minister to take time off when he and his wife, Paivi, had their first child, Emilia. In March this year he again took a week-long break when their second daughter, Sofia, was born. Sitting at a utilitarian desk in the parliament building in Helsinki, he also professes to do his bit around the house in the interests of equality. "I take care of the children in the early morning so that my wife can rest a little. I prepare breakfast for the family, and, if I can, I take the seven-year-old [his daughter by his first wife] to school on my way to work. "In the evening I participate in the ritual of the children going to bed - getting changed into their night clothes and eating porridge." Asked how it feels to be held up as a model for Britain's prime minister, Mr Lipponen - who is called Moses by the press for his dry manner and sermon-like speeches - argues that he is only doing what comes naturally. "I don't think of myself as a model, because I'm doing what I should do to help my wife." His Social Democratic party has good relations with the British Labour party and he has a friendly working relationship with Mr Blair. "We've exchanged experiences and we've both been woken up in the middle of the night. I said to him that it serves him right, because I have to get up, too," he laughs. He may joke, but Finns, and by extension their state, take families seriously. Last year some 40,000 fathers took two weeks off to be with their new babies, at an estimated cost to the state of some £13m. Under Finnish law women are entitled to 105 paid days of maternity leave, while fathers currently get 18 days. In addition, 158 paid days are available for the parents to share, though in practice it is usually the mother who uses these. Mr Lipponen's new proposals mean that fathers would get 24 more paid days which could not be used by mothers. Finns have had paid paternity leave since the early 1980s. This contrasts with Britain, where it was only last year that the right to take paternity leave was introduced - and this was due to an EU directive. As a result, British fathers can take up to 13 weeks off in the first five years of their child's life, but this time is unpaid and can be taken only by men who have been with the same employer for a year. webTitle: Anna Davis pays tribute to the grandes dames in all our past

fields.headline: My aunt and other heroines
fields.standfirst: Anna Davis pays tribute to the grandes dames in all our pasts
fields.trailText: Anna Davis  pays tribute to the grandes dames in all our pasts
fields.body:
Visits to Margaret's were always the best. Margaret is my mum's older cousin, living in Cardiff with husband Brian. We'd go over for the evening; me, my mum and my brother. There'd be a mess of people coming and going - their three sons and one daughter, with partners and kids. Margaret would be elegantly perched on the edge of her sofa, cigarette in hand (she's since given up), pretending to complain about them ("Dear God, look at this rabble. The state of this place . . . Fifteen for Sunday roast yesterday") in her wonderfully dry, witchy Welsh voice. I used to wonder what it would be like to grow up in that crowded, wild household where Margaret was queen. My brother and I have always been welcomed - "You know there's a room here if ever you need it."
Margaret grew up during the war years in Ystrad, Rhondda, where her Gran South also presided over a large working-class family: eight children, plus assorted waifs and strays. "That house must have been made of bloody elastic," Margaret tells me. "The back door was always open. Everyone felt welcome in Gran's house."
It's important to Margaret, now in her late 60s, that her Gran would be proud of the way she runs her household. But Margaret is more than a domestic matriarch. She's a woman who's made it in a man's world: she became the first ever woman credit controller in a steelworks company and ran her own debt recovery business. When you talk to Margaret, you can tell she's someone who's really struggled and survived. You can hear it in her ultra-dry humour. It sounds corny but you can see it in her eyes - she has stature, she has drama. She's as much grande dame as Bette Davis or Lauren Bacall. An envious woman in my family was once heard to mutter: "She's like Joan Collins with that hat and that briefcase" when Margaret walked into the room.
And Margaret is a stoic - a real one, which is very rare in my generation (the twenty and thirtysomethings). It's partly about having lived through a world war, but it's more than that. Margaret may have fulfilled her youthful ambition to marry a man with ginger hair and have four children, but the biggest tragedy of her life is that once upon a time there was a fifth child. Janet was born with a congenital heart disease. She died at the age of six. "You can never get over something like that," Margaret tells me. "But you can't be weeping and wailing and falling apart. There's the other children to think of. You have to be a brick wall . . . It's made me hard. It's made me what I am."
Stoic is a word that keeps cropping up when women talk about the grandes dames in their families. My friend Francesca, in her early 30s, used it when she told me about her Italian aunt, crippled by polio, who grew up illiterate in an orphanage, but who became a successful mother and teacher in the UK. "It's incredible to think about what she's been through and what she's achieved," Francesca says. "But she's never complained. She's just carried on. I don't think I could ever be like that."
I don't suppose many women of my age could be like that. These days, we communicate our feelings, unburden ourselves, believing this makes us healthier and less stoppered.
My paternal grandmother, Florrie (also known as The Duchess) subscribed entirely to the stiff-upper-lip philosophy of life. You kept your feelings under control. There was no use in moaning; you stuck together and you got through somehow. "Family" was Florrie's priority, her reason for being. When I was 11 and my parents' marriage was splintering and snapping, Florrie created an oasis of grandparently, chocolate-cakey, Monopoly-playing happiness for my brother and me. Crying was banned at Grandma's. You had to leave it outside with the shoes. The theory was that if you didn't indulge your unhappiness, maybe you could make it go away. If you let the tears come out, everything would get worse. This was how Florrie had always dealt with personal tragedy - this was how she survived.
When Florrie was a teenager, her sister Lil had an illegitimate baby. Florrie helped look after the little boy and grew to love him, but one day when the child was already two years old, she came home to find he was gone. She was told he'd been taken off to be adopted in Australia. Florrie was heartbroken and determined that when she had children, they would always come first.
Talking to friends about the charismatic, opinionated older women in their lives, the conversation returns time and again to family. Family was at the heart of everything. All your aspirations were for your children. Grandma Florrie married Grandad Len because she thought he could give her the harmonious family life she'd never known. She wasn't in love with him - and that's all wrong, isn't it? Isn't it?
Well, now, maybe. But Grandma chose to focus her dreams on the next generation. Somehow shop assistant Florrie and lorry driver Len saved enough money to send their son to a private primary school so he'd have a chance at an education. Education was the key to a better life. Florrie was bright: if she were young today, she would certainly go to university instead of leaving school at 14 to get a job and help support the family, but it wasn't possible then. She wanted for her son what she couldn't have for herself and this was the way forward: you strove, you struggled and you didn't complain. If you succeeded, you might live to see your kids posing for photos in their mortarboards.
In recent years, I've become critical of Grandma Florrie and her strategy of bottling things up and putting on a brave face. I've often thought it was wrong of her to tell me and my brother not to cry when our parents were breaking up. But if I'd been born 50 years ago, I could have been her.
My life is full of anxiety over my career; dilemmas over whether to get married and whether marriage really means anything. Should I have kids? When? Where? It could be said my generation is a petulant one, forever dawdling on the therapist's couch. We will never be like those queens of stoicism who brought us up. We indulge our emotional traumas, analyse our neuroses; we weep and wail and fall apart. We do it because we can. But it's worth remembering that ours is not the only way.

fields.headline: It's not over till the fat lady zaps
fields.standfirst: If you like high culture, you ought to love the new TV channel Artsworld. But  Stuart Jeffries  has his doubts
fields.trailText: If you like high culture, you ought to love the new TV channel Artsworld. But Stuart Jeffries has his doubts
fields.body:
A long time ago, television was thought of as something that would be good for us, that would open the couch potato to new experiences. A monocled toff watching telly over his brandy and soda might be exposed to the hitherto unperceived realities of Ken Loach's Cathy Come Home. A slob in a stained string vest might turn over after the pools and suddenly find himself entranced by a ballet. "Educate, inform, entertain" was the great Reithian mantra of public-service television. But now, for good or ill, and despite the fact that two terrestrial channels are still funded by the licence fee, it is over.
The days are gone when TV producers took risks. Who would have known that David Attenborough would thrill the masses by means of crouching in the bushes and whispering about wildlife? Or that Panorama might encourage a nation to reflect on the political issues of the day? Or that something with the unpromising name of Monty Python's Flying Circus might have a profound impact on what we thought of as funny?
Now our whole culture - not just television, but nearly every cultural outlet - is saturated with consumers being given more of what they want. Typical is If You Liked That, You'll Like This, the Sunday morning programme on Classic FM hosted by David Mellor. In Q magazine, CD reviews end with a list of similar records. In such a culture it is difficult to encounter new, challenging experiences, much easier to insulate yourself from anything threatening. The media - television especially - prefer to expose us to the familiar, to fit everything (arguably even the news) into existing patterns of thought. Nothing can disturb us. Nothing can, in a sense, enrich or entrance us.
This is the digital philosophy that has replaced the Reithian vision. We are treated as desiring machines who can be satisfied only by more of the same. If you're a film fan, then you'll want as many movie channels as possible. If you're a football fan, you'll want Sky Sports 1 to 7. True, you'll be shelling out a fortune and still wind up watching Lethal Nonsense VII on widescreen on Wednesday night, or Burnley reserves versus Bury reserves with Player Cam, but this is, we are to suppose, progress.
It is in this climate that Artsworld, a subscription cable channel devoted to the arts, starts broadcasting on Saturday. Airing for 10 hours a day with news, previews, concerts and documentaries, it is the brainchild of Jeremy Isaacs, former Royal Opera House general director and founding chief executive of Channel 4. "We know how great the hunger is for the arts in this country," he wrote earlier this week. "Attendance at the Tate Modern alone attests to that. But public-service broadcasting appears to have chosen just this time to shrink the spaces they inhabit."
Isaacs writes about going with fellow sixth-formers to Saturday night symphony concerts in Glasgow: "I still remember the way their spines jolted them upright at the beginning of the last movement of Beethoven's Fifth." This is the epitome of the Reithian vision of entertainment: Isaacs's schoolmates may not have known that they would have loved Beethoven before they went to the concert, but they found that they did.
Isaacs's idea for Artsworld came from the notion that Something Had To Be Done. But we no longer live in an era where Those Who Know programme TV for Those Who Really Ought To Find Out. Such patrician programming today would be commercial suicide, and wisely, despite Isaacs' rhetoric, his new channel is doing all it can not to fall on its own sword. In other words, Isaacs may talk like a Reithian, but his channel delivers something utterly digital.
If one looks at Artsworld's schedules, one finds not patrician programming of difficult art, but extremely safe, middlebrow programmes that make one wonder if Isaacs isn't at the helm of a Classic FM for telly. Thus, there will be opera, but it will be Maria Callas and Tito Gobbi at Covent Garden, tenor Andrea Bocelli singing sacred arias. There will be classical music, but it will feature the likes of Lesley Garrett, Roger Norrington and Michael Nyman. There will be dance, but it will include ex-Riverdance stars in a fly-on-the-wall rehearsals documentary and a ballet with music by Queen, costumes by Versace, choreography by Maurice Béjart. There will be world music, too, but by the likes of the MOR and already overexposed Ladysmith Black Mambazo.
There will be arts and architecture - but mostly featuring already famous practitioners such as Norman Foster and David Hockney. There will be a George Melly panto at Christmas and Bryan Ferry singing from his album of 1930s favourites, As Time Goes By. There is too little to challenge the viewer, too little at the cutting edge.
This is not to damn Isaacs's project before it has started. Rather, it is to suggest that to set up a channel like this, in times like these, is extremely perilous. A couple of years ago, a study of the least popular programmes in the previous decade found that opera occupied the three lowest places, and that arts programmes in general were a turn-off. This may show that people think opera is not best seen or heard on the small screen, which is something that may preoccupy Isaacs and his colleagues in the sleepless nights ahead.
In principle, it need not matter that Artsworld is devoted to the most unpopular forms of broadcasting, since the great dream of digital TV was that it would give everybody what they wanted, no matter how abstruse their demands. The corset of terrestrial TV had burst open and everybody could now express themselves freely. But that dream was fanciful, and Artsworld will not be run on such lines.
Artsworld occupies a similar position to FilmFour in this respect. Both are reserved for viewers who have already paid their monthly subscription to their digital TV provider and are prepared to pay an extra £6 each month to receive the new channel. But the nature of this subscription dictates in a large measure the nature of the programming. Just as FilmFour has had to resort to programming mainstream movies and marginalises the more outré stuff until the early hours, so Artsworld cannot afford to position itself at the cutting edge of culture.
If it is to succeed commercially, Artsworld must court the viewers who have subscribed to Sky to see more movies or football. Isaacs must hope that these people might be persuaded to shell out a few extra quid to see some art. But this seems unlikely: such viewers are not exercised about the dearth of ballet on the box. It seems even less likely that aesthetes who already go to the operas, read the novels, hear the recitals, etc, will shell out £50 for a Sky subscription as well as the few quid charged for Artsworld.
But the bigger question is this: where is the creative, challenging television these days? It comes from people who take risks, who are trying to jolt the spines of their viewers in the way Beethoven jolted those of Jeremy Isaacs's schoolmates. One of the few recent examples is Chris Morris's Jam. Morris was allowed to take a risk and he exploited that opportunity, thus putting himself at the cutting edge of television culture. But Artsworld risks only commercial failure, which, if you care primarily about art, isn't very interesting at all.

fields.headline: Swearing like a trooper
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The new owner of the Daily Express, all the profiles agree, is a great one for swearing. As one Sunday newspaper evocatively put it, Richard Desmond "swears like a trooper".
fields.body:
The new owner of the Daily Express, all the profiles agree, is a great one for swearing. As one Sunday newspaper evocatively put it, Richard Desmond "swears like a trooper". Like a trooper, eh? That helps establish the scale of it. Yet how many people reading those words had ever been treated to the sound of a trooper swearing? There are probably fewer troopers in action now than there have been in centuries, and in any case the nature of trooping has changed since the days when they used to ride, swearing, on horseback to battle. Now they are much more likely to be safely contained in tanks where the outside world hears none of their filthy prattle.

The habit of adding "like a trooper" to one's reference to a swearer probably derives from an age when children were deliberately schooled in cliche. That is not what the classes were called. They thought they were learning metaphor and simile. "As smooth as..?" the teacher would prompt, and the class would answer "as silk". "As flat as..?" A pancake, of course.

No doubt this sort of thing still continues in literacy hour. Any child who, fed with "as smooth as..." replied: "Peter Mandelson", or when offered "as flat as...", suggested "an intervention by Archie Norman" would go to the bottom of the class. I suggest we dispense with "swear like a trooper" and replace it with something more modern and tangy. In my part of south London "swear like six schoolgirls on top of a bus" would do pretty well. Alternatively, you could try: "swears like that chap who has just bought the Daily Express."

Few of these ancient clanking devices is more popular than a coach and horses, used as an emblem of wrecking. The natural home of the coach and horses is the Telegraph's leaders and letters columns. November 22: the Telegraph is railing editorially against a government bill designed to let Irish nationals sit both in the Dail in Dublin and at Westminster and Stormont, "thus driving," it rages, "a coach and horses though the time-honoured principle that 'no man can serve two masters.'" November 24: a reader from Holbury, Hants, writes to suggest that the recent defection of the Tory MEP Bill Newton Dunn to the Liberal Democrats gives that party a higher representation in Strasbourg than it deserves. "It would appear to drive a coach and horses," he writes, "through the Liberal Democrat argument that proportional representation is the fairest method of election."

Yet the picture of coach and horses in most people's minds today has little to do with destruction. It's the Queen on her way to open parliament, accompanied by heralds and various kinds of pursuivant while the tractable populace cheers from the pavement. Or the coach and horses as portrayed on mock-Victorian Christmas cards, trotting sweetly into a coaching inn with its cargo of cheery, rubicund gentlefolk. What we need today is something far more brutal and 21st century. Given recent events at the Dome, "drive a JCB" (or mechanical digger, if you wish to avoid giving free publicity) would be nearer the mark.

The same applies to the saying: "a voice like a foghorn." On last Saturday's Private Passions on BBC Radio 3, Rick Stein, the seafood king, chose a work by Malcolm Arnold which features a sound like a foghorn off-key. Stein then went on to reveal what was certainly news to me, that electronic equipment has effectively ended the days of the foghorn. So to say that someone or other has a voice like a foghorn conveys little to anyone under 40. The hooter at the end of a rugby league match might be a more appropriate reference now, though given the size of the crowds for the recent world cup that too is outside most people's experience.

I do not wish to suggest that every ancient allusion should be sent to the scrapheap, the knacker's yard or the shredder. There is still no better image than Sisyphus, endlessly pushing his rock up the hill only to have it roll back on him, to evoke a man like William Hague whose every effort looks doomed. On the other hand, that most famous of tragedy duos, Scylla and Charybdis, has at last gone into retirement, replaced by the 20th-century US saying "between a rock and a hard place".

We cannot quite junk the lot. But the time has certainly come for someone with a voice like a foghorn to drive a coach and horses through our national museum of cliche. Meanwhile, the best advice for those tempted to fall back on such usages is that which was once enshrined in the Guardian style book. "Avoid cliches," it said, "like the plague."

fields.headline: Death in Peckham
fields.standfirst:
It would be wrong to jump to conclusions
More about the Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: It would be wrong to jump to conclusions.
fields.body:
The painful poignancy of the death of Damilola Taylor lie in the details. He was a keen pupil and such was his eagerness to learn that he stayed on at school on the evening he died for an extra computer course. But this young ambition was cut tragically short by his murder. He dragged himself 100 yards towards home before dying alone. We also hear that he and his family came to London four months ago after saving up money for treatment for his sister's epilepsy. It is hard to imagine the suffering now of the Taylor family having to deal with the health of their daughter gained at the price of her brother's death.

The common impulse when faced with such a tragedy is to look for people to blame. Yesterday, David Blunkett and Jack Straw and commentators rushed in to do just that. It's a temptation to be resisted. At this stage, it is far from clear who killed Damilola and why. Attempts to pin the blame on the school for not acting on the mother's complaints of bullying seem inappropriate. There is no evidence that Damilola's murderers attended his school. Oliver Goldsmith is the kind of over-stretched inner-city school struggling to weld a hugely disparate and fluctuating set of children into a community. The school has made a point of stamping out bullying, and its hard to see how it could have extended its authority to protect Damilola beyond its gates. The north Peckham estate is being blamed, yet Damilola's death has come when regeneration is starting to dent high crime figures. Sadly, the £260m being ploughed into demolishing parts of the estate - such as the stairwells where Damilola died - will come too late for this 10-year-old boy.

There are crimes that transfix the nation's attention: Sarah Payne's death was one, as was the attack on the Russells. Damilola Taylor has become another, and yesterday, his face with its shy, rueful grin was on every front page. All these children have become icons: we are haunted by the loss of their innocent lives and by our collective failure to protect them from random violence. In Damilola's case, this is heightened by his recent arrival in Britain from Nigeria, and the fact that he may have been killed by children only slightly older than he. It underlines the reality that the welcome which awaits immigrants to the developing world is no such thing; they arrive to a culture riven with racism with pockets of social disintegration as dangerous as anything they might have left behind.

webTitle: We must take a stand against thugs, says Straw

fields.headline: We must take a stand against thugs, says Straw
fields.trailText: Jack Straw yesterday stepped up his attack on the immoral "walk-on-by society'' and said   it was time everyone took a stand against against crime and yobbish behaviour.
fields.body:
Jack Straw yesterday stepped up his attack on the immoral "walk-on-by society'' and said it was time everyone took a stand against against crime and yobbish behaviour.

The growing culture of thuggery, bullying and violence had to be confronted, the home secretary said. "I am not talking about 'having a go' or getting involved in a potentially dangerous situation. But people do have a responsibility to report crimes and help the police in their work to tackle crime."

He hoped the murder of Damilola Taylor would serve as a wake-up call to remind Britons they could not afford to let lawlessness go unchallenged.

Later Tony Blair expressed his shock and outrage in the Commons. Describing the attack as "appalling and brutal", he told a sombre chamber: "We must do everything we possibly can to bring the killers to justice."

The Downing Street-ordered attempt by Mr Straw to put flesh on the Mr Blair's concept of "responsible society" was underpinned by a speech by the education secretary, David Blunkett. Both ministers were speaking at an Institute for Public Policy Research conference.

Mr Blunkett criticised some of the passersby who failed to help Damilola as lay bleeding to death in the south London street.

"I understand that some of those who did stop to help the youngster were horrified by those who ran away in sheer horror of what they saw," he said. "We have got to create a society where people do not run away from anything, but face up to it and are prepared to be engaged and involved, no matter how horrendous it may be."

The home secretary's attack on those who failed to do anything about crimes committed by their relatives and neighbours, or crimes they witnessed in the street, foreshadows his new bill designed to tackle street drunkenness and yobbery. At the same time the Downing Street social exclusion unit published a report putting the annual cost of anti-social behaviour such as vandalism and graffiti at £1.3bn a year.

Mr Straw said a family who protected a burglar or a thief, or a parent who did nothing about a child bully, or a group of friends in a pub who did not step in to stop a fight were guilty of acquiescence. The "circle of irresponsibility'' stretched to include the town planners and housing authorities who designed and built estates with multiple back alleys which could be used for drug dealing.

He hoped that social attitudes would change as they had towards drink-driving, so that people no longer tolerated violent crime and disorder.

The Liberal Democrat Simon Hughes agreed tackling crime was the responsibility of everyone, but said: "The truth is that the public frequently receives a less than satisfactory response to non-emergency calls from our overstretched police."

fields.headline: Happy as Larry
fields.standfirst: You know him as Hank 'Hey now!' Kingsley from The Larry Sanders Show. But actor Jeffrey Tambor has been responsible for some of America's finest character comedy of the last 20 years. He talked to  Danny Leigh
fields.trailText: You know him as Hank 'Hey now!' Kingsley from The Larry Sanders Show. But actor Jeffrey Tambor has been responsible for some of America's finest character comedy of the last 20 years. He talked to Danny Leigh
fields.body:
Two words are stuck in my head the whole time I'm with Jeffrey Tambor. Two insistent, unshakeable words. Oddly - although it's the title of the film he's here to promote - those words are not "The Grinch". Neither, despite it being the character that made his name, are they "Hank Kingsley". They're not even "When's lunch?" The words are these: penis, and vagina.

Bear with me. There is a reason. In an early episode of The Larry Sanders Show, already the most inspired show on American television, Tambor's monstrous, preening alter-ego Hank discovers an error in the latest issue of his (self-published) fanzine Hanks For The Memories. On every page, someone, somehow has replaced every queasy showbiz bon mot with those two common nouns. Certain of the culprit's identity, an enraged Hank confronts them, bellowing like a mantra: "Penis! Vagina! Penis! Vagina!" The victim - entirely innocent - stands baffled, then gestures towards the terrified elderly couple beside him: "Uh, Hank... meet my parents."

As an example of what Tambor - perhaps the finest comic actor currently active - is routinely called upon to essay, it's perfect: grotesque hubris leading, inexorably, to abject humiliation. Which, appearing opposite Jim Carrey as the bumptious Mayor of Who-ville, is precisely his role in Ron Howard's imminent, baroquely sentimental Grinch. For every cockle-warming group hug, there's Tambor, spewing bile and condescension; for every small child bursting winsomely into song, there he is again, a snout-nosed vision of pompous self-delusion. "Wonderful", is how he describes his six months making the film, with the same open-faced sincerity he uses when calling Howard "a true human being" or Carrey "generous, giving and, ah... gentlemanly".

He gets the same crack in his voice ("it's been such a marvellous life") whenever he mentions his chosen profession: the epiphany of stumbling into a tiny San Francisco theatre as a child, the decade spent as a twentysomething hopeful touring in Brecht and Shakespeare. "The thing is, I lost my hair when I was very young. It was all gone by 18. But rather than seeing that as a tragedy, it was really a boon, because I could play these older guys, which were always the best roles."

Then, at the end of the 70s, came a small part on Taxi as a budding Romeo with a sweat problem, swiftly followed by the ceaseless flow of TV and movie gigs (in everything from Hill Street Blues to Muppets From Space) that cemented his reputation as the man to call whenever you needed insane vanity, seismic arrogance, and male pattern baldness. Which, gently glinting scalp apart, hardly suggests the cerebral, actorly individual in front of me.

"I was never going to be the hero. The guy in Titanic yelling 'I'm King Of The World'? That's not going to be me. And I think people are basically foolish. I do. I know we make these attempts at being noble, but really we're all kind of... ridiculous. And I like playing those guys. They're part of a great tradition. Molière knew about those guys. Dickens knew about those guys."

As, indeed, did Garry Shandling ("a mensch - a real stand-up guy") when, back in 1992, he offered Tambor Hank, fawning sidekick to his own neurotic talk-show host Larry. By turns craven and manic, given to abusing his minions and filming himself with escort girls, it was a peach of a role, a chance to hone his staple traits over seven gloriously acerbic seasons. By the time the show finally ended last year, Hank wasn't so much a sitcom character as a universal byword for self-pitying venality.

"Right. And when people called him a buffoon, I never understood it. To me he was anything but. He was smart." The way he talks about him, he sounds like a friend. Not a friend you'd care to be seen with in public, but a friend all the same. "You know, I have a feeling that Hank was basically very lonely. That he really didn't have any real human connection. I mean, I think in this world, the more communication we have, the more people tend to be glib, and arch, and Hank could never do that. He's a child, and we all recognise that, and we're all scared of it. We're all afraid of the gushing, overweening child inside us. Which is Hank."

Yet, while he admits to missing him ("Hanks don't come along too often"), he says he doesn't regret the show itself folding. "We went at the right time, you know? And it's done wonderful things for me. I mean, I don't want to sound like the grand poobah, but I'm so happy with the way things are going professionally."

As we leave, he takes my photograph - "isn't that what tourists do?" - and trades favourite Hank moments (his being Kingsley's ill-fated, careerist flirtation with Judaism). I'll never have a better chance. Without admitting I've been thinking of genitals throughout our conversation, I tell him mine was the fanzine episode. His face lights up.

"Oh, that's great. That's so great. See that's what I loved about the show, and about Hank. That someone like you, a young guy, can take such joy in something like that." For a second, he clasps his hands together, as if in prayer. "Penis! Vagina! Ah... that's great ."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Tonights best films
fields.body:
Paint Your Wagon

(Joshua Logan, 1969)

10.45am, 4pm Sky Cinema

A charming musical Western about the rise and fall of a mining town, No Name City, where hard-hitting buddies Clint Eastwood and Lee Marvin agree to share their woman (Jean Seberg). Some violence is done to Lerner and Loewe's songs, but there's marvellous Marvin, bristly and honourable in long johns, following his Wandrin' Star.

Tokyo Story

(Yasujiro Ozu, 1953)

6pm, FilmFour

FilmFour's splendid Ozu season wouldn't be complete without this masterpiece, his best-known and probably finest work. Full of the drama of family life, it follows an elderly couple who leave their quiet provincial home to visit their children in chaotic Tokyo, only to find son and daughter too busily self-centred to look after them. Their disappointment, then joy when their widowed daughter-in-law welcomes them, is beautifully portrayed: simplicity bordering on the magical.

The Wind

(Victor Sjostrom, 1928)

3.15am, TCM

One of the last great silent movies, and the peak of the career of Lillian Gish, one of the era's brightest stars. Filmed under gruelling conditions in the Mojave desert, the story of a young woman's suffering is given elemental force by the shrieking wind that expresses her inner turmoil - married to a man she doesn't love, and assaulted by another.

The Big Lebowski

(Joel Coen, 1998)

3.25am, Sky Premier

Wonderful, wacky comedy filtering a noir plot - complete with kidnap, mistaken identity, a severed toe - through the confused consciousness of hippy throwback The Dude (Jeff Bridges), aka Lebowski. Helping him navigate the dangerous world of his rich, objectionable namesake (he'd rather be smoking weed and going bowling), is the hilarious double act of John Goodman's cracked Viet vet and Steve Buscemi's dopey Donny. John Tutturro's cameo as lilac-clad bowler Jesus steals the show.

Tokyo Story (Yasujiro Ozu, 1953) 6pm, FilmFour FilmFour's splendid Ozu season wouldn't be complete without this masterpiece, his best-known and probably finest work. Full of the drama of family life, it follows an elderly couple who leave their quiet provincial home to visit their children in chaotic Tokyo, only to find son and daughter too busily self-centred to look after them. Their disappointment, then joy when their widowed daughter-in-law welcomes them, is beautifully portrayed: simplicity bordering on the magical. The Wind (Victor Sjostrom, 1928) 3.15am, TCM One of the last great silent movies, and the peak of the career of Lillian Gish, one of the era's brightest stars. Filmed under gruelling conditions in the Mojave desert, the story of a young woman's suffering is given elemental force by the shrieking wind that expresses her inner turmoil - married to a man she doesn't love, and assaulted by another. The Big Lebowski (Joel Coen, 1998) 3.25am, Sky Premier Wonderful, wacky comedy filtering a noir plot - complete with kidnap, mistaken identity, a severed toe - through the confused consciousness of hippy throwback The Dude (Jeff Bridges), aka Lebowski. Helping him navigate the dangerous world of his rich, objectionable namesake (he'd rather be smoking weed and going bowling), is the hilarious double act of John Goodman's cracked Viet vet and Steve Buscemi's dopey Donny. John Tutturro's cameo as lilac-clad bowler Jesus steals the show.

webTitle: Fritz Lang: Beyond a Reasonable Doubt

fields.headline: Fritz Lang: Beyond a Reasonable Doubt
fields.trailText: It is a film of great economy and precision, with the terrifying inevitability of Greek tragedy and a pervading sense that man is his own worst enemy... The story is so tautly directed and skilful in its manipulation of our sympathies that, several times during the film, one changes sides
fields.body:
I went to a Hollywood party in the early 1970s, held in honour of François Truffaut, one of the few French directors that Hollywood had heard of at the time. There were a lot of high-rollers there congratulating each other on their careers but I was curious about the old man with an eyepatch sitting alone in a corner.

When I asked who he was, someone said: "Oh, that's some old Hollywood director." It was, in fact, Fritz Lang who, apart from his German classics, made a number of the very best American films of the 1940s and 1950s. He had been invited largely because of Truffaut's long-held admiration for him.

He seemed surprised that I knew most of his films and asked me which I liked best. I cited M (1931) as the German example and Beyond a Reasonable Doubt (1956) as the American, although it could have been half a dozen others.

Born in Vienna in 1890, Lang had an extraordinary mastery of European expressionism that allowed him to illustrate the state of a continent that gave rise to fascism, and to make an implicit critique of the "freedom" of American capitalism. Perhaps he was a pessimist for whom life itself appeared to be some kind of trap. But he was indisputably a great director.

Beyond a Reasonable Doubt, in which Dana Andrews gives one of his most effective performances, illustrates that greatness perfectly. It is a film of great economy and precision (it lasts only 80 minutes), with the terrifying inevitability of Greek tragedy and a pervading sense that man is his own worst enemy.

Andrews plays a reporter who agrees to incriminate himself in a murder case because his editor (Sidney Blackmer) is pursuing a campaign against capital punishment. They plant a lighter that was given to the reporter by his fiancee (Joan Fontaine) and the reporter then poses for the photographs that will prove his innocence. Almost immediately Lang's long shot of the scene seems to suggest that things may go badly wrong.

They do. He seduces a stripper who was the murdered girl's friend, infuriating his own girlfriend although he is sure that she'll understand when all is explained. But when the only man who can exonerate him is killed in a car accident, she fights to establish his innocence - only to find that he is, in fact, guilty.

This story is so tautly directed and skilful in its manipulation of our sympathies that, several times during the film, one changes sides, for and against the man who tempted fate and the woman whose righteousness may be impeccable but is also rather irritating.

The reason the film deserves its accolades is partly that Lang makes a simple format beautifully complicated. The form is one thing, the content another in most movies. Here they are indivisible.

Lang's career is ample evidence that while most European directors who went to America were hampered by the system, not all of them were destroyed by it. Europe itself did its share of destruction.

Lang's The Testament of Dr Mabuse (1933) was banned by the Nazis, after which Lang was summoned to the office of Joseph Goebbels, the propaganda minister, and apologetically asked to supervise Nazi film production.

Fearing his Jewish background would be discovered, he fled Germany. But it is only fair to add that he also fled Hollywood in 1956, citing disputes with producers.

Nevertheless Lang made great films in two continents - in three if you agree that The Tiger of Eschnapur (1959), made in India, is a successful mixture of his German and American styles. That's an extraordinary record.

webTitle: Work in progress: Gavin Robertson, actor

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Gavin Robertson, actor
fields.trailText: Gavin Robertson, actor
fields.body:
About two weeks to the press night of Thunderbirds FAB at The Playhouse and things were rather manic, but slightly less chaotic than in recent days. For this version of the show my stage partner Andrew Dawson and I have decided to have a set - something we've never attempted before in our heady touring days - and so there has been a feeling of adventure and apprehension about the whole idea. But - glory be! - it arrived at the theatre three days ahead of schedule, and the marking out of the floor, which apparently gave us no stage space at all, turned out to be because it was marked out upside down - the problem was resolved and we both relaxed!

The costumes were all remade too. The ones we originally - and last - performed with, in New Zealand in 1993, were discovered stuck together in a gluey plastofibrous mass in an aluminium trunk, so it was either remake or ring Blue Peter for help.

We have no director for the show, and that means the buck stops with us. In this case it meant writing a potted history of the show for the programme, and so we had to spend time remembering the show in Japan when Andy signed a girl's glasses in liquid paper, or cringing when we recalled the first ever performance in a community centre outside Edinburgh. The first 20 minutes were rubbish, so we rewrote them! Andy also made copious notes about the music, which we've had the opportunity to remaster.

We both feel slightly wobbly given the fact that we have both had sons since we last performed the show... what will they think of us? What a comfort it is, though, that the whole team knows each other from before. We have the same producer, production manager, dresser, and we all get on. So much so, in fact, that the latter two, who met on the show, are now married...

Thunderbirds FAB is now showing at the Playhouse Theatre, London, WC2 (tel: 020-7316 4747)

webTitle: The member's tearoom - where the plot thickens

fields.headline: You plot, I'll pour
fields.standfirst: Forget the Commons chamber and the MPs' bar. The place where the big Westminster deals are done - and where the gossip is white hot - is the members' tearoom.  Michael White  explores an institution
fields.trailText: Forget the Commons chamber and the MPs' bar. The place where the big Westminster deals are done - and where the gossip is white hot - is the members' tearoom.  Michael White  explores an institution
fields.body:
There are plenty of smells I associate with politics, including fear, pride and ambition, stale beer and sweaty suits. But one of the most persistent is altogether more wholesome. It is the smell of toast. Burned toast, toast with sardines, beans on toast: you can catch a whiff of them any working morning at Westminster by turning left in the ways and means corridor - a brief hop from the Commons chamber - and passing outside the members' tearoom.

It is long and thin, and decorated in dark rich colours, but I cannot tell you exactly what the tearoom is like because I am not allowed in. It is one of the parliamentary inner sanctums and when I researched it for a Radio 4 programme, MPs of all persuasions were full of affection for it - awe even. The tearoom is where reputations rise and fall, where plots are hatched and discovered, while nosy reporters can only press their noses against the window pane.

"The tearooms are a unique place," says the rascally Tory ex-minister Steven Norris. "First of all, it is actually divided into three areas. You might think that meant Tory, Liberal and Labour. It doesn't. It means Labour round the counter, where you're served literally as though you were in some kind of 60s railway canteen. The next room you go into is the Conservative room, detached from Labour very definitely. And then the third room is not for the Lib Dems, strangely enough, but for the officers of the house, where discreet figures whose name one never knows after 30 years in the place go and take their cup of tea and sit down."

Actually, I also discovered a Welsh table. The Ulster Unionists have a table too. And Labour's Margaret Hodge, now a minister, owns up to a dodge of her own: if you want a quiet cuppa, go and sit at the Tory end, where no one will talk to you.

The members' tearoom is a period caff - tea urns, toast, waitresses in uniforms, armchairs and newspapers. The Tory, Sir George Young, confirms it does a very good breakfast: "Much better than years ago. One of our colleagues, who shall remain nameless, has breakfast at home and then he has a second breakfast in the tearoom." Labour's Fraser Kemp pops in for "a sausage sandwich and a cuppa".

In an era when MPs, like everyone else, don't have time to stop for a proper lunch, a tearoom snack can be a compromise between three courses and a sandwich at the desk. But food and non-alcoholic beverages are only part of it: the real purpose is gossip, chatter, ideas, or bad news from a recent byelection; the kind of informal focus grouping that ministers do when they turn up to take the political temperature. Which usually means they are in trouble.

"It's the favourite place for prime ministers to drop into," says Norris. "If the PM wants to take a quick five or 10 minutes just to be known and be seen, then rather than go to the bar where you can get tied down for rather a long time with a bunch of old bores, most of whom have had far too much to drink, you go to the tearoom, spend 10 minutes schmoozing around. It pays great dividends."

There is some dispute about which grandees used the tearoom. Austin Mitchell, a veteran of the Labour minority government of 1977-79, remembers prime minister Jim Callaghan turning up and pouring out his woes. "You felt an instinctive sympathy and support for Jim because the troubles of the world were on his shoulders and he was such a nice man."

Margaret Thatcher preferred to descend on - and terrify - colleagues in the dining room, often bearing a plate of Welsh rarebit. "When she didn't have an official dinner she did make a point of going over to rub shoulders with MPs," says her spokesman, Sir Bernard Ingham.

As a former whip, always on the prowl, Young recalls how John Major "was a regular tearoom visitor. He enjoyed it - and actually he had been in the tearoom regularly before he was PM." William Hague pops in after PM's question time, but few of his colleagues dare to tell him when he has done badly, I was assured by one Tory troublemaker. Tony Blair put in an appearance once, during the fuel crisis, and thoroughly alarmed Labour MPs.

Who's up, who's down: plenty of high-grade gossip is hatched in the tearoom, though Mitchell recalls how the whips got wind of a tearoom plot against Michael Foot's leadership in 1983 and quickly scotched it.

"Only foolish people conspire in the tearoom because it's so public," says Michael Mates, chief lieutenant to Michael Heseltine (not the tearoom type). "Like-minded people sit together, but it's the same as the dining room - you go and sit where there's a seat, regardless of who else is sitting there. If you want a particular chat with someone then you'd take them off to a quiet corner and of course this would be observed - do it again and again and again, then people will draw their own conclusions - that's why it's a bad place to have a plot."

That's not how it worked for Michael Martin. Older MPs such as Labour's Joe Ashton attribute his election to the speakership last month entirely to "the power of the tearoom", where the teetotal MP sat for years, simply being nice to colleagues, especially nervous new ones.

It all sounds a bit clubby, as much in the working men's club sense as the Atheneum. New MPs, especially women, feel a bit uneasy. They would prefer somewhere where they can leave their mum or teenage sons. But old sweats are nostalgic for the days when MPs didn't have a fancy office, full of computers and keen young staff, often 200 yards away in a plush new building such as the £200m Portcullis House. The word they seem to use is "community".

MPs are better, more professional nowadays, according to old hands such as Ashton and the Tory Eric Forth - a man who prefers the tearoom to a pager to keep in touch. But there's not the fun or the camaraderie of the old days when Labour MPs - sharing Callaghan's misfortunes - used to gather in the tearoom and sing songs from the trenches of 1914-18 to cheer themselves up.

Ashton recalls how old MPs used to outdo each other with grim tearoom tales which vied to see which of them had the most deprived childhood, just like the Monty Python sketch. The winner was a Gorbals MP whose slum neighbour not only murdered his wife, but chopped her into pieces and threw them into a canal (until a dog retrieved an arm and he was caught).

Not the sort of story which would appeal to Roy Hattersley, even though he and Ashton were once rising stars on Sheffield council. He takes a dismissive view of the tearoom. "The idea that it was vivacious never passed through my head," he concedes, before describing its denizens as "worthy" seekers after pie and tea. But it also occurs to him that this attitude towards the tearoom ("in my day, a bit of a joke") may have cost him the Labour leadership. He may be right.

fields.headline: Fowler leads eight-goal romp
fields.trailText:
Stoke 0 - 8 Liverpool
A bad night for Stoke - and Iceland - as Robbie Fowler scored a hat-trick and Liverpool ran riot.
fields.body:
No more holidays in their homeland for the men from the land of fire and ice, surely. The entire population of Iceland was apparently glued to their sets for live transmission of what amounted to a home international, according to the commentator.

What they witnessed was a Second Division team owned, managed and in no small part staffed by their countrymen being humiliated by eight goals, three from Robbie Fowler, as Liverpool ran riot.

After being knocked out of the FA Cup recently by Nuneaton Borough these are not good times for for Stoke.

Barely four minutes had elapsed when Peter Thorne made himself the simplest chance. Chasing down a short back-pass he came out of a 50-50 tackle with Pegguy Arphexad with the ball at his feet and the goal empty. Somehow he hit the post.

Within 90 seconds Liverpool were ahead. Breaking quickly, Robbie Fowler made space on the left and drove in a low cross. Christian Ziege, closing unmarked on the six-yard line, sidefooted high into the net.

Determined to make a game of it but unable to rely on Thorne, Liverpool's defence handed Kyle Lightbourne an immediate chance to square it up, Stphane Henchoz slicing the ball to the big striker with no one but Arphexad to beat.

Unfortunately for Stoke Lightbourne's first touch was criminally wooden, allowing the goalkeeper enough time to block at his feet. Suddenly you began to see how it was they had failed to score in two games against Nuneaton.

Having laid siege to Liverpool's goal for 10 minutes, Stoke immediately conceded twice. First they failed to clear a Gary McAllister hoof clear, allowing Markus Babbel, slightly fortuitously, to find Vladimir Smicer, who duly scored.

Within a couple of minutes the tie was completely over. Fowler was allowed to return a half-cleared corner into the area with a scissors-kick and, with Stoke's defence admiring that, Babbel smacked home.

Liverpool made it four before half-time. McAllister sent over a corner, Sammi Hyypia flicked on and Fowler nodded in.

Hyppia delivered the fifth goal on the hour, prodding home Danny Murphy's cross after Brynjar Gunnarsson slipped; Murphy himself hit the sixth, courtesy of Fowler, both striking in less than splendid isolation.

Fowler completed his hat-trick, first seizing on a Ziege through ball and then burying a penalty. Then as the highest football crowd the Brittannia Stadium has ever drawn began to empty, the diehards sang the club anthem Delilah, laying emphasis on the line: "I just couldn't take any more."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: A British football team? No chance
fields.standfirst: James Naughtie  on why Jack Straw can think again about Scotland playing with England
fields.trailText: James Naughtie on why Jack Straw can think again about Scotland playing with England
fields.body:
Perhaps there is someone living on a distant planet near Saturn, or someone lost in the Amazonian rainforest for half a lifetime whose reason has deserted him, who thinks that he might like to see a British football team. You never know. But the chances of him making contact with Jack Straw are remote.


Most politicians, and all governments, come up with a daft idea from time to time. It hangs in the air for a moment and then falls to earth with a loud plop. Everyone knows that sound and the sickly grin the perpetrator has to wear until it is all forgotten and the world has passed on to other things. For Jack Straw's sake, may it pass on to other things rather quickly.


Think of it. Lions rampant and couchant, side by side. Red dragons trying to snuggle up with St George. Flower of Scotland sung by Arsenal fans; Scots trying to understand what all the three-lions business is about anyway. It would be an absurdity as profound as playing football at Murrayfield or cricket at Upton Park. The clocks would start to run backwards and the skies would go dark.


Does the horror need explanation? Generations of Scots have been reared in the knowledge that, more often than not, England will beat us ... but that when victory does come it is all the sweeter for being plucked from that abyss of pessimistic bravado that is our lot. It was much better to beat England at Wembley in 1967 and to take the shine off the World Cup (Law and Baxter ... oh, the bliss of it) than to have qualified for the World Cup in the first place and then been beaten in the finals, no doubt by the South Koreans. No one manages these things better.


These delights are hard won, and spring from our history. We need the thought of the occasional victory against England to set against the sorry story that we have all learned from the cradle, starting in 1314 with the party that followed Bannockburn and has been going on ever since.


Now this isn't petty nationalism. It is much more important than that. Just as a Welshman would pale at the thought of cheering on a team half in red and half in white running from the Twickenham tunnel, a Scot could hardly imagine what it might be like to have to traipse half way round the world to gaze from under one of those hairy red wigs at a team consisting of the likes of Beckham and Sheringham, Adams and the late David Seaman. Defeat under those circumstances would lose its delicious sting.


Many years ago I sat in a stadium in Cordoba in Argentina when we drew one-all with Iran and paved the way for World Cup defeat at the feet of Holland. England, of course, had not qualified. I merely mention it in passing. The team left after three dreadful performances, leaving the rest of us to watch some football. But we bathed in happiness.


We couldn't have done it for what Jack Straw would no doubt call Team Britain. And I venture this mild thought. Would any self-respecting English fan enjoy the experience the other way round? I can assure them that the special agonies associated with Scottish football are the result of instinct, breeding and years of practice.

I have on my desk a recent letter from a listener who rails about the prevalence of Scots across the landscape. As far as he can see they are everywhere, even, he writes, "in every nook and cranny of the government". Well, I can assure him of one thing with no fear of being proved wrong. There will be none in the English football team. Nor should there be. And no proud Englishman or woman, with those three rather limp- looking lions, those inferior anthems and that stadium that hasn't been rebuilt yet, should be required to submit to a similar humiliation the other way round. Anyway, it would take them years to get the hang of it.


I suppose, though, we should try to understand Jack Straw's predicament. England have had to winkle a Scandinavian manager out of Rome; the World Cup campaign is in familiar stuttering mode. Under pressure, the home secretary may just have lost it for a moment.


Or perhaps he is thinking of getting a real manager ... Fergie? Graham? Birley? Now we're talking. But the ghosts of Busby and Shankly and Stein and the rest are lining up on the celestial touchline and the song they are singing has one word. No!

 James Naughtie presents Today on Radio 4 and supports Aberdeen.

fields.headline: Pensioners win extra £4bn in compensation
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
SocietyGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Millions of widows who were misled about their pensions won a multi-billion pound   compensation package yesterday when the government bowed to pressure and abandoned an   earlier scheme which had been branded as mean-spirited.
fields.body:
Millions of widows who were misled about their pensions won a multi-billion pound compensation package yesterday when the government bowed to pressure and abandoned an earlier scheme which had been branded as mean-spirited.

In a spectacular u-turn, the social security secretary Alistair Darling pledged an extra £4bn to exempt millions from a plan to cut pension payments to widows and widowers.

His announcement was welcomed last night by pensioner groups which had campaigned against the initial compensation package for widows who were misled about plans to cut the state earnings related pension scheme.

Mr Darling introduced his first compensation package last March after it emerged that pensioners had been misinformed about a Tory scheme to halve the amount of Serps that widows or widowers inherited on the death of their spouse.

Up to 20 million people were not told about the Tory scheme which was announced in 1986 and was due to come into force this year. Widows without an occupational or personal pension, who relied on Serps to top up their state pension, could have lost up to £62.50 a week.

In his announcement yesterday, Mr Darling pledged an extra £4bn to make three fundamental changes to his initial compensation package. The new scheme will mean that:

 Pensioners will no longer have to prove that they were misled in order to receive compensation. The government's initial scheme, in which pensioners had to demonstrate in an interview that they had been misled, was condemned by a Commons committee last week as an unworkable fiasco which was open to fraud.

 Anyone of pensionable age on October 5 2002 - the day the new scheme comes into force - will be exempt from the changes. Under the governmment's first scheme, existing pensioners would have been affected by the changes from that date;

 A transitional scheme will soften the blow for people who become pensioners after the scheme is introduced. Anyone who becomes a pensioner between 2002-04 will be entitled to 90% of their spouse's Serps. This will decrease to 80% for people who become pensioners between 2004-06 and so on. The transitional scheme is designed to avoid a "cliff edge" in which pensioners suddenly find themselves hit by the new rules; Mr Darling declared yesterday that his announcement would remove any worries pensioners have about providing for their spouses. "This problem should have been sorted out 14 years ago," he told MPs. "What happened in the years after 1986 was a series of colossal blunders which was inexcusable and caused untold distress to millions of people."

Mr Darling admitted that his initial compensation package, known as the protected rights scheme, would have been unfair. "Over the past few months I have become convinced that [it] would not work in the way intended," he said. "It wouldn't be fair because we cannot be sure that it would reach all those affected and it would be difficult to safeguard against fraud and abuse."

The news was welcomed by Age Concern. Gordon Lishman, its director general in England, said: "Alistair Darling's announcement is a victory for Age Concern's two year campaign. It will come as a huge relief to pensioners... who can now enjoy retirement knowing their spouse will be properly provided for if they die before them."

Tony Wright, the Labour chairman of the Commons public administration commitee which had condemned the initial package, welcomed "an act of justice that all the Serps pensioners will be thankful for".

Mr Darling's announcement represents a significant victory over the Treasury which had been resisting the extra costs of the new scheme. However, the government has decided that it must do more for pensioners after a successful campaign against last year's 75p rise in the basic state pension.

fields.headline: Madonna's saucy gig in Brixton
fields.standfirst:
Madonna
Brixton Academy, London
****
fields.trailText:
Madonna
Brixton Academy, London
****
fields.body:
Through all the image changes, the one constant in Madonna's two-decade career has been that she is the canniest of media manipulators. There is, after all, no better way of guaranteeing that you are the talk of the town than organising a gig that accommodates a mere fraction of your fans (Brixton Academy has a 4,200 capacity), and then refusing to sell tickets.

The Academy's phone lines practically combusted; the Sun has been offered bribes, including a wife for the evening, in return for one of their competition tickets; people have paid over £1,000 for a ticket in auction. Outside the Academy, forlorn-looking fans huddle behind barricades and police, gazing jealously at the jammie sods queuing to get inside.

Yes, queuing. Get past the hype and what you are left with is nothing more than a gig, as mundane and, at times, dull as any other. The people waiting for an hour to get inside look miserable, and count themselves lucky that it's not raining, let alone that they have tickets. Apart from an Ali G lookalike, accessorised with a scantily clad babe, and the odd cowboy hat, these are ordinary people displaying very little sense of occasion.

Inside, Dolce and Gabbana's supremely tacky decorations boil down to the kind of gold tinsel stuff you'd hesitate about hanging on your Christmas tree, several lightbulbs and - actually a wonderful touch, this - some rhinestone cacti. There are glittering Ms, glittering horseshoes and a higher than usual quotient of stars, but otherwise it's business as usual: the supports acts (Richard Ashcroft and Texas) are ignored, no one dances to Prodigy frontman Liam Howlett's DJ set, everyone's just getting drunk to pass the time.

And then Howlett plays the opening bars of Music, the crowd cheers so loudly that no one notices the weird moment of silence that follows it, the band break into Impressive Instant - and the show is instantly impressive. Madonna emerges from beneath a giant union flag - nothing like appealing to the jingoist in people to get a party started - gyrating on a huge white truck, looking for all the world as though the 1990s haven't happened. She's practically been stitched into her black T-shirt bearing the names Rocco and Lula and doesn't look like any 42-year-old mother of two any normal person knows.

And, importantly, as long as she's on stage, she doesn't act anything like a 42-year-old mother of two either. She is the saucy Madonna we know and love, swivelling her hips, lasciviously whispering "kiss me" while muscly blokes in fashion-error trousers lick her. It's seven years since Madonna has played in this country, and as annoying as her past few singles have been, as irritating as you find her current earth-mother aura, you immediately remember why she is talked about and why she is so loved: she is a natural performer, bursting with energy and enthusiasm, enthralling to watch on stage.

She is in fantastic voice, too: stripped of the ridiculous, excessive vocoder that marred her recent album, Music, each note rings out clean and pure. Impressive Instant is followed by Runaway Lover and Don't Tell Me, and each sounds significantly better than it does on record: her voice is no longer grafted on to generic club beats, but melds with them beautifully. Her fourth number, What it Feels Like for a Girl, is exquisite - this, you feel, is the Madonna of old, talking about being a pop bitch and making you tingle even at hackneyed lyrics.

And then suddenly, we do get the Madonna of old: she breaks into Holiday, and every person in the room is transformed into an over-excited teenager. So how disappointing was it that the next song, the single Music, was her last? Profoundly. As thrilling as those six numbers were, as pleasing as it was not to have to sit through American Pie, it was hard not to feel just a little cheated, just a little manipulated. But then, that is Madonna's forte.

fields.headline: Halifax finally launches IF
fields.trailText: Intelligent Finance, Halifax's new bank, finally launched its internet operation today, five months behind schedule.
fields.body:
Intelligent Finance, Halifax's new bank, finally launched its internet operation today, five months behind schedule.

An aggressive new advertising campaign, set to the Fatboy Slim tune of Right Here, Right Now, is being prepared to air on primetime national television to coincide with IF's delayed debut in cyberspace.

The bank has already spent £7m on a television campaign that began in October - just after the operation went live via telephone after a series of technical glitches.

The telephone launch at the end of September was already two months behind schedule, and the internet opening was further delayed while the system underwent further checks.

Those tests are now thought to have given the Scottish-based operation the confidence to press ahead with the launch, which is expected to be accompanied by an update on the progress of the business.

It is expected that IF, which claims to be starting a revolution in financial services, will reveal that business has continued to come in at the pace set during the first 10 days of the original launch. In the middle of October, the bank revealed that it had sold £90m of mortgages, opened 3,500 current accounts and given out 2,000 personal loans or credit cards.

Halifax hired Jim Spowart, the banker who launched Standard Life bank two years ago, to set up IF and set a target of 500,000 customers in the first year. Halifax is also demanding that IF breaks even by its third year and makes profits by its fifth year of operation.

The internet launch of IF, which the Halifax expects to generate around 30% of its business, comes after Lloyds TSB admitted that its internet bank, Evolvebank.com, would undergo a "phased" launch in the UK.
