webTitle: Theatre review:  The Year of the Monkey

fields.headline: The Year of the Monkey
fields.standfirst:
Drill Hall,
London
***
fields.trailText:
Drill Hall,
London
***
fields.body:
You would, as our own dear Nancy Banks-Smith might put it, be looking at Claire Dowie for a long time before you were reminded of an allotment-mad pensioner or a middle-class matron. Yet these are just two of the characters the energetic Dowie conjures up without the benefit of props or costume changes. It's a convincing endorsement of what she describes as "stand-up theatre".

This one-woman show is a quartet of monologues, separated by Dowie's chatty but slightly breathless and-this-is-me patter. A woman whose mother has been killed by a drunk driver describes how she shot her way through the criminal's nearest and nearest; a little girl whose grandad had Alzheimer's recalls the events leading up to his death; a pensioner who claims not to care about politics lets slip how she and her neighbours opted out of the capitalist economy; and a well-to-do mother watches her daughter's marriage while railing at her own inability to connect with anyone.

There's nothing as harrowing as Easy Access, Dowie's 1998 show about child abuse; instead she flicks back and forth between wry humour and underplayed tragedy. The bereaved daughter recalls how the car that killed her mum sent her spinning in the air - "quite gymnastic really"; the girl confuses Alzheimer with "arse-hammer" and believes it is grandad's magic bottom that lands him in a succession of life-threatening situations.

Like Alan Bennett, with whom she shares an intermittent archness of tone, Dowie is fascinated by repression: of acts, of emotions, of speech. The serial killer has been let down by life, the courts and the fiance who deserted her but can only express her fury adequately through violence; the bride's eager-to-please mother admits, "I'm well practised in getting things right"; the pensioner describes her street-level revolution as "just being neighbourly". Only the child seems to speak everything that passes through her mind, and this is the only segment that palls.

The show raises a lot of interesting questions: about women's place in society, our fascination with firearms, our stereotyped view of old people and the political impact of the tiniest acts. I doubt it raised a single consciousnesses in the terribly right-on Drill Hall. Still fun, though.

 Until Saturday. Box office: 020-7637 8270.

This one-woman show is a quartet of monologues, separated by Dowie's chatty but slightly breathless and-this-is-me patter. A woman whose mother has been killed by a drunk driver describes how she shot her way through the criminal's nearest and nearest; a little girl whose grandad had Alzheimer's recalls the events leading up to his death; a pensioner who claims not to care about politics lets slip how she and her neighbours opted out of the capitalist economy; and a well-to-do mother watches her daughter's marriage while railing at her own inability to connect with anyone. There's nothing as harrowing as Easy Access, Dowie's 1998 show about child abuse; instead she flicks back and forth between wry humour and underplayed tragedy. The bereaved daughter recalls how the car that killed her mum sent her spinning in the air - "quite gymnastic really"; the girl confuses Alzheimer with "arse-hammer" and believes it is grandad's magic bottom that lands him in a succession of life-threatening situations. Like Alan Bennett, with whom she shares an intermittent archness of tone, Dowie is fascinated by repression: of acts, of emotions, of speech. The serial killer has been let down by life, the courts and the fiance who deserted her but can only express her fury adequately through violence; the bride's eager-to-please mother admits, "I'm well practised in getting things right"; the pensioner describes her street-level revolution as "just being neighbourly". Only the child seems to speak everything that passes through her mind, and this is the only segment that palls. The show raises a lot of interesting questions: about women's place in society, our fascination with firearms, our stereotyped view of old people and the political impact of the tiniest acts. I doubt it raised a single consciousnesses in the terribly right-on Drill Hall. Still fun, though.  Until Saturday. Box office: 020-7637 8270.

fields.headline: Pensions lobby attacks changes
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: A three-year delay in the introduction of new accounting rules for company pensions has failed to placate investors who believe the new Accounting Standards Board rules will inject too much volatility into company's profits and disadvantage pensioners.
fields.body:
A three-year delay in the introduction of new accounting rules for company pensions has failed to placate investors who believe the new Accounting Standards Board rules will inject too much volatility into company's profits and disadvantage pensioners.

The ASB is today publishing rules which require companies to disclose more information about their pension schemes and the effect changes in world market will have on the value of the assets.

The ASB is not requiring the rules to be fully introduced until 2003, but asks that companies start to insert notes on the impact of the change into their annual reports from next June onwards.

Alan Pickering, chairman of the National Association of Pension Funds, said: "The longer it is delayed the better."

He is concerned that pension fund managers will try to avoid injecting volatility into accounts by taking more conservative investment decisions which might be less lucrative for pensioners. He also believes that companies may be discouraged from increasing benefits to their pensioners.

Yet while the NAPF remained opposed to the new rules - which have also attracted the attention of Guardian Media Group chairman Paul Myners, who is heading the government review into pension fund investment - other bodies welcomed the delay. Actuaries Bacon & Woodrow said the delay could turn "disaster into success".

Anne McGeachin, a project director at the ASB, said the aim of the rules to make shareholder understand the impact of defined benefit pension schemes on a company's balance sheet.

She said the decision to delay the new rules was a consequence of the controversy they had evoked, but for three other reasons. First, to prevent pension funds having to under take new evaluations of their schemes; second to give the ASB time to lobby for changes to international standards; and third, to give companies the opportunity to start preparing accounts in line with the new rules.

fields.headline: Feuersnot
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall,
London
****
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall,
London
****
fields.body:
Feuersnot (Fire Famine), Richard Strauss's second opera, was first performed in 1901 and in its day was considered obscene. While its raunch factor admittedly is high, it is the work's sexual politics that are most likely to be a source of comment nowadays.

The opera takes place on Midsummer Night in medieval Munich, where solstice bonfires burn and lovers pledge fidelity by leaping through the flames. The city's bourgeoisie are troubled by a stranger, a sorcerer called Kunrad. He has the hots for Diemut, the burgomaster's daughter, and, carried away by the sensuality of the revels, he flouts convention with his overtly erotic approaches. Offended, she takes revenge by publicly humiliating him, whereupon he causes all the fires in the city to die. They can only be relit, he tells the horrified populace, from "the body of a virgin in heat".

Goaded by the citizens, Diemut gives in to his demands - and predictably enjoys the experience. With her first orgasm, the fires explode back into life. "Master, I love you," she drawls, when the bonking is over.

The other charge flung at Feuersnot is that of excessive topicality. Strauss intended the work to be a satire on the conservatism of his native city, which had rejected his music while he was assistant conductor at the Court Opera. Kunrad, whose sorcery is music itself, is the pupil of another magician, similarly trounced in Munich, called Reichart der Wagner (no guesses as to who is meant). In both text and score, puns and quotes flow fast and thick, though the resulting amalgam, far from being over-topical, now comes over as embodying postmodernism.

Time and history buckle and bend, as the music becomes giddy with anachronism and allusion in ways that prefigure Der Rosenkavalier and Ariadne auf Naxos. Tremendous waltzes sweep the characters onwards. Not only Wagner, but also the entirety of the Austro-German musical tradition is caught up in its flow as Mozart, Beethoven, Mendelssohn and Schumann are examined in their turn. It's a magical score.

The task of keeping the opera alive in the UK has fallen to the Chelsea Opera Group, which, over the years, has presented it in concert. This is very much a labour of love, occasionally rough round the edges, though unfailingly compelling and thrilling. It's conducted with supreme elan and an almost pornographic vividness by Adrian Brown, and played and sung with uncommon gusto by a committed cast and orchestra.

fields.headline: Consumers remain in bullish mood
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: British consumers remain willing to borrow and spend - despite saying they are less confident about the economic outlook - sending contradictory signals about the next move in interest rates.
fields.body:
British consumers remain willing to borrow and spend - despite saying they are less confident about the economic outlook - sending contradictory signals about the next move in interest rates.

Consumer confidence rose sharply last month following the resolution of the fuel crisis. But it fell two points in November to minus two, according to the monthly survey by market research company GfK for the European commission published today.

However, monthly consumer credit figures published yesterday by the Bank of England gave no sign of a slowdown in high street spending.

Net consumer credit jumped £1.5bn in October, the highest figure since May and well above City forecasts.

Two thirds of the increase came from non-credit card lending, suggesting that shoppers are taking advantage of cheap in-house finance deals for large purchases.

"The robust rise in credit suggests UK consumers remain in bullish mood and warnings of any significant weakening in consumer demand look premature," said Ross Walker, an economist at Royal Bank of Scotland.

The figures also hinted at a rebound in the housing market, with new mortgage approvals - seen as a good forward-looking guide to sales and prices - rising by 1,000 to 98,000, compared with an average of 95,000 in the three months to September. Michael Saunders, an economist at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, said: "This is the first time since May that commitments have risen from a year ago, which suggests that mortgage lending will probably also pick up a bit in coming months. This fits in with other signs which suggest that housing activity also is picking up a bit."

GfK said all five components of its headline consumer confidence index - based on interviews between October 31 and November 9 - fell back, including perceptions of the general economic situation and household finances.

Growing insecurity was reflected in a sharp increase in the perceived benefits of saving, which rose to the highest level since September 1998.

GfK said it was possible the threat of a second fuel crisis - since diffused by Gordon Brown's pre-Budget report - had depressed sentiment, suggesting that it may recover next month.

Low inflation and slowing global economic activity has persuaded the City that the next move in British interest rates will be downwards.

But Jonathan Loynes, of Capital Economics, said the Bank of England would be reluctant to cut the cost of borrowing from its present rate of 6% without firm evidence that consumer spending is coming off the boil.

"Although we still expect such a slowdown to materialise in response to slower gains in income and wealth, these numbers suggest that it has not yet arrived," said Mr Loynes.

fields.headline: Grand Drive
fields.standfirst:
Borderline,
London
**
fields.trailText:
Borderline,
London
**
fields.body:
Something about Grand Drive's lilting tunes and hayseed harmony vocals has sent some reviewers spinning hysterically into hyperdrive. But while their latest album, True Love and High Adventure, has its moments of melodic blissfulness and makes a brave attempt to nail down that elusive thing called "soul", this live show frequently teetered on the brink of chaos.

Singer and guitarist Danny Wilson reminded an uncomfortably packed house more than once that the band hadn't played live in a while, but we really didn't need telling. The vocal harmonies were often so ragged you could barely tell what key the songs were supposed to be in. While the band negotiated the more up-tempo material fairly successfully, perhaps carried towards the finishing tape by sheer momentum, the longer, slower pieces (A Little Numb, for instance) broke down into disconnected chunks.

Being cut from vaguely country-tinted cloth, with a dollop of Spooner Oldham-style Memphis soul whisked into the brew courtesy of Julian Wilson's simmering Hammond organ, Grand Drive inevitably get lined up with the usual suspects - the Jayhawks, the Flying Burrito Brothers and the woefully misunderstood Gram Parsons. Parsons was unique, not some journeyman hack who can be routinely cloned by every new band who happens to own a dog-eared copy of Grievous Angel, and the Drive have several major obstacles to clear before they can consider themselves fit to polish the great man's rhinestone-encrusted boots.

What they desperately need most is a powerful, distinctive singer - because Danny Wilson isn't it.

fields.headline: AC/DC
fields.standfirst:
NEC Arena,
Birmingham
****
fields.trailText:
NEC Arena,
Birmingham
****
fields.body:
More than 25 years after they started it, AC/DC are still playing it - the riff. The same sticklebacked three-chord trick has been their passport from adolescent Australian pub roistering to the venerable global institution they are now, not so much transcending prevailing musical trends as standing to one side, bemused at why people would want to try doing anything else. On witnessing this latest restatement of principles, that little conundrum at least is easily explained: people simply have to try doing something else, because nobody else plays deafeningly loud nuts-and-bolts basic rhythm and blues like AC/DC.

"Wheeee!" gasps the molten tar-larynxed Brian Johnson. "We got a shitload o' great rock songs for you tonight. Hard to pick 'em, innit?" Statements do not come more rhetorical. AC/DC are so constrained by their own legend that half of this two-hour set picks itself. Smarter men than they would struggle to assimilate such a vast complement of noise. During the band's fallow period, stretching from the mid-1980s until 1996's Rick Rubin-produced renaissance LP, Ballbreaker, this was hardly a problem. But this year's Stiff Upper Lip is their best since the epochal Back in Black, so for its spring-heeled boogie nirvana to merit similarly scant treatment is little short of scandalous.

Fortunately, just as Van Gogh painted the same vase of flowers a hundred times without diminishing the wonder of his art, so AC/DC make a virtue out of endlessly reploughing the same gnarly furrow, each time unearthing hitherto unimagined nuggets of base wisdom.

Rhythm guitarist Malcolm Young is the group's core. Willingly overshadowed by younger brother Angus's barmy showmanship, Malcolm does very much the same thing in every song, because that's what every song demands. Only he knows for sure how many times he has played Highway to Hell, but it always sounds like the first. No wonder he's one of the few guitar-players to whom Keith Richards pays respect. Indeed, AC/DC are probably the only band today who could credibly claim to rock like the Rolling Stones in their satanic majestic pomp.

Not that they themselves would claim such a thing. Egos aren't allowed in this most self-effacing outfit. Brian Johnson has been lead singer for nearly three times as long as his deceased predecessor Bon Scott, yet he still happily screeches his way through chunks of Scott's canon without a murmur. How long his 52-year-old lungs can stand the strain must be a moot point. But so long as there are riffs to be played, AC/DC are the only ones fit to play them.

 At Sheffield Arena (0114-256 5656) tonight, then touring.
